DOC.HEAD: Stockbroker Sentenced to Prison for Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A former stockbroker who bilked his golf buddies and other associates of more than $2 million was sentenced Monday to five years in prison after pleading guilty to federal mail fraud and other charges. U.S. District Court Judge Edward Harrington sentenced Walter F. Curran, a former stockbroker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., to two concurrent five-year terms followed by five years probation for mail and bank fraud. A condition of his probation is that Curran reimburse his victims. Harrington called the crime ``deliberate and calculated fraud.'' ``It was fraud of enormous proportions,'' he said. ``One of the predominant motivations was excess greed.'' Curran, 47, who pleaded guilty to 13 counts of mail fraud and bank fraud, told the court he understood the serious nature of his crime. ``It's been a very trying period for everyone concerned with this,'' he said. Curran also pleaded guilty to one count of violating currency transaction reporting laws, for which he received a 13-month sentence to be served concurrently with the other sentences. That charge was filed in New York after Curran was found to be carrying $132,000 in cash when he was arrested at the Canadian border last February. As part of his sentence, Curran was ordered to pay more than $260,000 to the Bank of Boston Corp. for overdrawing money in a series of checking transactions. Curran was suspended from Dean Witter Reynolds in February 1989, when he was arrested in connection with the disappearance of $2.39 million he had convinced friends and associates to invest in his personal account instead of with Dean Witter. Defense attorney Robert Cordy described the broker from Wellesley as a decent and engaging man, ``probably the most generous person I have ever met,'' who became desperate when he could not fulfill promises he had made to his investors. Starting in April 1981, Curran solicited money from eight people, including two golfing companions, as well as his accountant and his lawyer at the time, Cordy said. Cordy said Curran promised them interest payments of 20 percent if they invested in a deferred compensation account in his name. Instead, however, over the eight years Curran invested $3.6 million in the stock market and other ventures. During that time, the funds suffered ups and downs, but when the market collapsed on Black Monday in October 1987, Curran lost his investors' money, as well as much of his own, Cordy said. ``He had tried everything, from gambling to long shots,'' Cordy said. ``Eventually when everything came crashing down, there was no way he could continue to juggle the balls and get the money back.'' Faced with huge losses, Curran fled to Canada and when he disappeared, his scheme came to light. He surrendered to authorities in Massena, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Subdued Reaction Among South African Blacks To Reforms
An AP Extra
By BARRY RENFREW
DOC.TEXT: The reinstatement of the African National Congress has brought little joy or hope to South Africa's black townships and activists say it won't change the harsh lives of millions of poor blacks. President F.W. de Klerk's announcement Friday that the ANC and other anti-government groups no longer will be banned, along with other reforms, prompted few celebrations in the sprawling townships. While many foreign leaders hailed de Klerk's pronouncements, just a few thousand of the country's 28 million blacks marched or celebrated in most cities. While applauding de Klerk's call for talks to resolve South Africa's racial problems, anti-apartheid leaders said the concessions would change little in the short term. They said black, Asian and mixed-race South Africans want total equality and full democracy immediately, with no special privileges for whites. De Klerk hopes to preserve at least some white power and little will change for most blacks, the activists say. ``Most of us realized that the speech did not change a single bit of the political realities and the living realities of our people,'' the Rev. Allan Boesak said in an interview. Boesak, a mixed-race clergyman and prominent anti-apartheid leader, said the changes would not ease the plight of millions of blacks who live in shantytowns, struggling to feed and clothe their families. There is no reason to celebrate while most non-whites still face chronic unemployment, malnutrition and poor education and health facilities, he said. ``The realities of apartheid will take away what joy or gratitude the people may have,'' he said. De Klerk's speech prompted no major celebrations in Soweto, the main black township outside Johannesburg, with a population of 2.5 million. In Cape Town, a few hundred people, many of them children, attended a township ``victory'' celebration. Boesak said non-whites do not trust the government after years of repression and would have little faith in its statements until they see real change in their lives. Many apartheid laws, enforcing the separation of the races, remain in effect and power and privilege are still vested in the hands of the white minority. ``It's going to take 10 to 15 years to make South Africa nice,'' said a young ANC activist taking part in a protest in Cape Town. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Activists said the modest black turnout to celebrate de Klerk's speech also reflected a lack of political organization and widespread apathy among many blacks that must be changed. Celebrations last year to mark the release from prison of Walter Sisulu and other senior ANC leaders failed to fill a 70,000-seat stadium in Soweto. ``Too many of the people are afraid or do not care,'' said a labor union official, who also insisted on not being identified. While de Klerk promised to end apartheid legislation allowing segregation of public facilities, government ministers ruled out scrapping other apartheid laws at this time. Laws segregating residential areas and requiring South Africans to register by race will be retained for now, the ministers say. They say the government still strongly supports the right of ethnic groups to live separately. De Klerk has spoken out against the concept of black majority rule and said repeal of apartheid laws would have to be negotiated as part of an overall settlement. ``When you see through this maze of excitement (over the speech), apartheid is still very much intact,'' said Eugene Nyati, a political analyst at the Center of African Studies. Anti-apartheid leaders say de Klerk and his National Party remain committed to preserving a special status for whites that would give them an indefinite hold on power. ``It is unlikely that the promised land of a non-racial democracy will be reached before, at best, the second half of this decade,'' said Sampie Terreblanche, an opposition Democratic Party analyst. Black labor leaders are playing down de Klerk's reforms, noting that the government has not ended the 3{-year-old state of emergency, which gives police wide powers to curb dissent. ``The people are not satisfied,'' said one union leader, who refused to be identified. De Klerk said he wanted to end the state of emergency as soon as possible, but gave no date. The government must prove its sincerity with rapid and massive change to end white-minority rule and ease the plight of millions of poor blacks, Boesak said. Said the clergyman: ``If Mr. de Klerk really wants to give meaning to what he has said ... to give some meaning and direction to the grand vision he has painted ... he has to move very, very quickly.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Indicates Domestic Homicide Unpredictable
DOC.TEXT: A study of domestic violence in Milwaukee concluded that police cannot rely on past abuse incidents to predict and prevent homicides in which a husband or wife kills a spouse. The study conducted by the Washington-based Crime Control Institute found that previous domestic violence was reported in only one of 33 adult domestic homicides in Milwaukee during a 22-month period from 1987 to 1989. The study challenges previous research suggesting that most domestic homicides are foretold by domestic violence calls, said Lawrence W. Sherman, director of the study for the Crime Control Institute. Police Chief Phillip Areola said the findings were ``unexpected and disappointing,'' and would set back police efforts to improve the prevention of spouse killings. ``Police have long hoped for a reliable basis for predicting and preventing domestic homicide,'' Areola said. ``Unfortunately, the Crime Control Institute research suggests we have not developed the tools to do that particular job.'' The study released Sunday found a group of 1,112 couples had an average of more than three incidents of violence per couple during the 22-month study period but none resulted in homicide. In contrast, only one of the 33 domestic homicide cases involved a couple with a previous report of violence. ``Millions of dollars have been paid out by taxpayers and insurers in lawsuits, all based on the theory that police can predict and prevent domestic homicide,'' Sherman said. ``According to the Milwaukee evidence, that theory is wrong. ``It's almost a suggestion that homicide and assault are two different phenomenons,'' Sherman added. Joseph Weis, a sociology professor and director of the Center for Law and Justice at the University of Washington, said he isn't surprised by the study's findings. ``We aren't really very good at predicting any kind of crime on a regular basis,'' Weis said. ``We can't tell you whether John or Joe or Jane will kill their spouse ... even if there is a history of violence.'' But Carey Tradewell, executive director of the Milwaukee Women's Center, said people who work with domestic violence cases do see a pattern. ``What we see is that the longer women and men stay in a relationship where there's violence without any intervention, there is repeated violence and the violence is more severe.'' Sherman said his data shows no evidence to support Tradewell's observation. The findings contradict an earlier study conducted by the Kansas City Police Department, which found that 90 percent of domestic homicides had been preceded by a disturbance call at the address of either the victim or the offender in a two-year period before the homicide. The study will be published later this year by the Academy of Criminal Justice Sciences and the Anderson Publishing Co. of Cincinnati in a book titled ``Redefining Crime: Responses to Woman Battering.''

DOC.HEAD: Third-Grader Suspended for Bringing `Billy Beer' to Show-and-Tell
DOC.TEXT: A woman is fuming because school officials suspended her 8-year-old daughter for three days for bringing an unopened can of beer to show-and-tell. ``I am furious,'' Melissa Woodfin said Monday. ``I have no problem with them having a policy, but you can't treat a third-grader the way you would a teen-ager.'' Mrs. Woodfin's daughter Haley also must undergo counseling for bringing the can of Billy Beer to school last week. The beer, named for President Carter's late brother, is no longer made, and unopened cans are considered collector's items. Officials at Skipwith Elementary School in suburban Henrico County said the suspension is consistent with their strict drug and substance abuse policy. Superintendent William C. Bosher Jr. acknowledged that the suspension of an elementary school pupil is highly unusual, but he said the issue is serious. ``Suspending young people is not what we are about,'' Bosher said. ``But we want to help young people understand that alcohol and drugs are not appropriate.'' But Mrs. Woodfin said the punishment did not fit the crime. ``My daughter has been treated unfairly,'' she said. ``She has lost three days of school with no right to make up the work, according to the policy.'' Mrs. Woodfin said her daughter removed the can of beer from a display case at home and took it to school. ``She took it for show-and-tell,'' Mrs. Woodfin said. ``She didn't run into a closet and pop it open.'' In addition to the suspension, police were notified that the girl was in illegal possession of an alcoholic beverage. Sgt. James Price said the girl would be referred to juvenile proceedings, ``which is nothing more than a counseling session.'' Mrs. Woodfin said the can of Billy Beer was returned to her by police and is back in the display case, where it will remain. Haley was back in school Monday after serving her suspension.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth-Graders Become Kiddie Cooks for a Day
DOC.TEXT: After an hour of slaving over a hot grill, John Sullivan's fourth-grade class was ready to dig into the sumptuous meal of steak frites, emince de volaille friture and floating island they had just prepared. Impressed? Well, don't be. Translated that's a simple fare of steak and fries, fried chicken strips and caramel-topped meringue. And, OK, they didn't exactly slave over anything. But they did giggle. ``Oh, yuck. I think I squeezed it too hard,'' said Eric Mattes, 9, who had a goopy glob of egg dripping down his hand. The youngster admitted he's never separated eggs before, but then, that's what this trip was all about. ``It's a real world lesson, I think,'' said Sullivan, who brought 18 pupils from the Dalton School, a private school on Manhattan's Upper East Side, to the la Cite restaurant in Rockefeller Center for Monday morning's outing. ``They get to find out how things work in a restaurant in a major city,'' said Sullivan, adding, ``It's the most exciting field trip I've ever been on.'' The trip was courtesy of la Cite's owner, Alan Stillman, who is known to the Dalton school kids simply as Michael's dad. Michael appeared delighted to share his kitchen expertise with his schoolmates. He joined them in taking turns learning how to bread, fry and grill foods, and, more important to this crowd, whip up a little dessert. The egg separating proved a tad tricky for the kids, most of whom ended up crushing the egg entirely or dumping the yolk in with what was supposed to be pristine egg whites. ``Now you've got to go fish,'' pastry chef Julie Marx, told one after another, showing them how to dip a demolished egg shell into the blender to scoop up the unwanted yellow yolk. ``Is this high in cholesterol?'' ``How come it's OK to eat this when it's cooked and not now,'' the kids fired at Marx as she whipped the egg white and sugar mixture into a fluffy white mound. No one asked about calories. Actually, Jonathan Block, 9, considers himself a fair-to-middling dessert maker. ``I make stuff a lot,'' he said licking meringue from his fingers. ``My favorite dessert is ice cream, bananas, chocolate sauce, cake, cookies and brownies'' _ together. Meanwhile, at the other end of the kitchen, others were busy dipping, dredging and grilling. The meal the kids prepared costs $28.50, including a salad and soft drink. The best part of the trip? Eating, of course. ``We never get anything like this at school,'' said Betsy Mallow, 9. She rated the chicken better than the fast food kind and ``a lot better'' than her mom's. ``My mother's chicken is just awful.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Timber Case Begins Before Federal Judge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of attorney's name to `Siegler,' sted `Steigler,' throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Chippewa Indians seeking unlimited access to about 1.8 million acres of forest should be free to harvest timber without government regulation under 19th-century treaties, a Chippewa lawyer told a federal judge Monday. Lawyers for several northern Wisconsin counties asked U.S. District Judge Barbara Crabb to allow government regulation of the Indians' activities to preserve timber resources. David Siegler, who represents the Chippewa's Bad River band, said on the opening day of a trial to decide the matter that the Chippewa do not believe all timber regulations issued by counties are necessary to avoid deterioration of the forest land at stake in the case. Siegler also told the judge the Chippewa believe the land belongs to them. The forests involved in the case are managed by counties, which make about $3 million annually from timber sales. ``It doesn't make sense to make the Indians pay for something that is theirs,'' Siegler said. Wisconsin's six Chippewa bands retain the right to hunt, fish, gather food and cut timber under court-affirmed treaties that ceded northern Wisconsin to the federal government. Federal courts have upheld the treaties in rulings dating to 1983 in the case initiated by the Chippewa. The previous court rulings left it up to Ms. Crabb to decide how the land should be managed. Several other issues relating to the treaties, including deer and bear hunting, are still pending. Others, such as tribal fishing and wild rice gathering, have been settled. ``We will prove that our regulations are necessary'' for preserving the timber resources of northern Wisconsin counties, attorney Thomas McNulty, who represents the counties, told the judge. The trial is expected to last several weeks. About eight counties are involved in the timber case, though 28 counties will be affected by the outcome. Assistant Attorney General Lisa Levin said the state does not plan to charge the Indians a user fee, but seeks a ruling on whether the Indians could hire non-Indians to work for their timber harvest operations. She said the Indians ``want to expand the scope of the treaty rights to non-Indians.'' Crabb must decide to what degree county, state and federal governments can regulate the Chippewa's timber cutting in forests also used by the paper industry in Wisconsin. Tribal lawyers have argued the treaties allow the Chippewa unlimited access to cut timber without the regulations or user fees imposed on non-Indian loggers, and that they should have first access to all the timber they can cut in county- and state-managed forests. County officials claim the forests might be destroyed if user fees are waived for the Indians since the money is used to replant trees and care for the land. ``We're just saying that the Indians should abide by the same regulations as everyone else,'' said Loren Sloan of the Wisconsin Counties Forest Association. ``If they don't pay to protect our forests, the taxpayers are going to have to pay for the Indians to come in and harvest timber for free,'' Sloan said. Forest products manufacturers employ about 77,000 people and produce about $8 billion worth of products annually in Wisconsin overall, the state Department of Development reported. Unemployment rates on most of the six Chippewa reservations in Wisconsin exceed 50 percent and Indians are looking to logging as a way to boost their economies, Siegler said.

DOC.HEAD: New Prosecutor Named in McMartin Preschool Case
DOC.TEXT: A new prosecutor was named Monday to retry Raymond Buckey on molestation and conspiracy charges in the McMartin preschool case, and District Attorney Ira Reiner said many of the charges could be dropped. Deputy District Attorney Joe Martinez replaced Lael Rubin and Roger Gunson, according to a statement issued by Reiner's office. Rubin and Gunson prosecuted Buckey, 31, and his 63-year-old mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, on molestation and conspiracy charges. A Superior Court jury acquitted the pair last month of 52 counts but deadlocked on 13 additional counts against Raymond Buckey. Superior Court Judge William Pounders scheduled a new trial for March 9. Reiner said Monday the number of charges against Buckey probably would be reduced because at least two potential witnesses, both children, have balked at the prospect of taking the stand. The prosecution may ask that up to eight of the 13 counts be dismissed, he said. His office listed 17 potential witnesses for the trial, including all five children named in the charges, relatives and doctors. Reiner said the list could change. Of the five children named in the remaining counts, two did not testify at the original trial. The youngsters now range in age from 11 to 14. If convicted on all 13 counts, the maximum sentence Buckey could receive would be 36 years in prison, Reiner said. If convicted of fewer charges, Buckey could go free because he already spent five years behind bars, the equivalent of a 10-year sentence, while awaiting trial. Buckey was released on his own recognizance pending the new trial. Pounders has said the facts involved in the remaining 13 counts ``mitigate in favor of a long second trial.'' But Reiner said Monday his office hoped to try the case in three months. Defense attorneys and parents of children who attended the Manhattan Beach preschool criticized Rubin and Gunson's handling of the original case, the longest, costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history. Both Rubin and Gunson requested reassignment before verdicts were announced last month. They will assist Martinez in the transition, Reiner said.

DOC.HEAD: Susan Dunn Makes Debut at Met
DOC.TEXT: The Search for the Next Great Verdi Soprano resumed at the Metropolitan Opera as Susan Dunn, a rising young American star, made her debut in ``Il Trovatore.'' She may not yet be the answer to an opera lover's prayers. But on the strength of her performance Monday night, the Arkansas native is a force to be reckoned with for some time to come. In the grueling role of Leonora, Dunn displayed a voice of considerable power, beauty and agility. And yet, she made a curiously muted impression, never quite throwing herself into the frenzy of the occasion when Verdi demanded it. Perhaps it was the difficulty she was having in her upper register, where some high notes seemed forced and one or two were omitted entirely. Even with that qualification, for sheer vocal luster she has the edge over Aprile Millo, another young American who has been laying claim to the heavy Verdi roles once owned by the likes of Leontyne Price and Zinka Milanov. Another aspirant, Alessandra Marc, made a debut earlier this season in ``Aida,'' showing phenomenal potential and a lot of unresolved vocal problems. Dunn's was not the only debut of note Monday night. As the villainous Count di Luna, Paolo Gavanelli, a young Italian baritone, made an unscheduled debut, replacing the Hungarian Lajos Miller, who had fallen ill. Gavanelli made a strong impression, his medium-size voice brimming with vigor. The conductor also was new to the Met. Rico Saccani _ from Arizona, not Italy as the name might suggest _ led a peppy and idiomatic performance. It may sound like a bonus, but it wasn't, that the Met presented not one but two tenors in the part of Manrico. Ermanno Mauro begged off halfway through, complaining of tracheitis. Franco Bonanome, who took over, sounded as if he might be headed for his sick bed as well by the time the night was out. The finest singer on stage was mezzo Dolora Zajick, a powerhouse who did full justice to the juicy role of the mad gypsy Azucena. Whether singing softly or soaring above the orchestra, she was thrilling. ``Trovatore'' is famous for having one of the silliest plots in all opera, and the Met's production, new a few years back, is almost as silly. The sets, by Ezio Frigerio, consist mainly of an interminable set of steps, decorated by now-notorious shiny black movable pillars that rearrange themselves during scene changes.

DOC.HEAD: `Driving Miss Daisy' Runs Up to $6 Million at Box Office
DOC.TEXT: ``Driving Miss Daisy'' was No. 1 movie ticket in U.S. theaters for the second consecutive weekend. ``Stella,'' the tear jerker starring Bette Midler, made its debut in second place. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' starring Jessica Tandy as a Southern widow and Morgan Freeman as her chauffeur in a story of manners and race relations, earned $6 million last weekend, up 5 percent from the previous weekend, said Entertainment Data Inc. ``Stella,'' a critically lambasted remake of 1937's ``Stella Dallas'' with the late Barbara Stanwyck, pulled in $4.3 million. In third was ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' the account of Vietnam veteran Ron Kovic, with $4 million. In fourth was the police drama ``Tango & Cash,'' which earned $3.1 million. The comedy-drama ``Flashback,'' a new film featuring Kiefer Sutherland as a rookie FBI agent and Dennis Hopper as a '60s fugitive, finished in fifth place with $2.9 million. The police drama ``Internal Affairs,'' starring Richard Gere and Andy Garcia, was sixth with $2.7 million. In seventh was the black divorce comedy ``The War of the Roses'' with $2.6 million. In eighth was the thriller ``Tremors'' on ticket sales of $2.4 million. Rounding out the top 10 was the new transplant-themed movie ``Heart Condition'' with $2.1 million and ``Steel Magnolias,'' $2 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Entertainment Data. 1. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Tri-Star, $6 million (weekend gross), 895 screens, $6,717 per screen, $24.4 million (total gross), eight weeks in release. 2. ``Stella,'' Disney, $4.3 million, 1,033 screens, $4,174 per screen, $4.3 million, one week. 3. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $4 million, 1,309 screens, $3,065 per screen, $44.5 million, seven weeks. 4. ``Tango & Cash,'' Warner Bros., $3.1 million, 1,526 screens, $2,007 per screen, $53.6 million, seven weeks. 5. ``Flashback,'' Paramount, $2.9 million, 875 screens, $3,326 per screen, $2.9 million, one week. 6. ``Internal Affairs,'' Paramount, $2.7 million, 986 screens, $2,740 per screen, $19.5 million, four weeks. 7. ``The War of the Roses,'' 20th Century Fox, $2.6 million, 1,432 screens, $1,816 per screen, $75 million, nine weeks. 8. ``Tremors,'' Universal, $2.4 million, 1,405 screens, $1,710 per screen, $11 million, three weeks. 9. ``Heart Condition,'' New Line, $2.1 million, 885 screens, $2,429 per screen, $2.1 million, one week. 10. ``Steel Magnolias,'' Tri-Star, $2 million, 1,369 screens, $1,475 per screen, $67 million, 12 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: New Allegations in Covenant House Case
DOC.TEXT: The Covenant House shelter for runaways conceded Monday that it provided a dead boy's identity to a former male prostitute, but refused to say how it obtained copies of the boy's vital records. In another development, The New York Times reported that Roman Catholic church officials were investigating allegations by a second man who says he had a sexual relationship with the Rev. Bruce Ritter, who founded Covenant House. Darryl J. Bassile, 31, of Ithaca, N.Y., told the Times in a report published Tuesday that he met Ritter in April 1973, when he entered a Covenant House intake center at age 14. Bassile said that during his third visit with Ritter, the priest began fondling him and they had sex. Bassile's accusations are being reviewed this week by a panel convened by the Franciscans, the order to which Ritter belongs, the Times said. Ritter said he remembered meeting Bassile only in passing, and called the allegations ``garbage.'' Only a minor's parents, their lawyer or someone with a proven legal interest can legally obtain birth certificate copies, state officials said, but an attorney for Ritter maintained no law was broken. The disclosure put a new twist in the allegations against Ritter by the former prostitute, Kevin Kite, who has alleged that Ritter gave him money, housing and gifts in exchange for sex. Ritter has denied the accusations, and Kite's father has described him as an emotionally troubled liar. Manhattan prosecutors have confirmed they are investigating the use of Covenant House finances. Covenant House, founded in New York in 1968, manages 17 shelters with more than 2,000 beds in the United States, Toronto and Latin America, directly serving about 25,000 young people annually. Its $85 million annual budget comes mainly from private donations. Ritter has said he tried to help Kite get off the streets, even giving him a new name to protect him from his former prostitution ring. Kite was told by a Covenant House official that Warner was a child from upstate Jamestown who died at age 10 from cancer, the New York Post reported Monday. Kite said he was also given Warner's baptismal certificate and blank Social Security and passport application forms, the Post reported. Betty Anne Warner expressed shock in a telephone interview at the use of her son's name, saying she and her husband had never been asked. ``When I first heard it, I thought it was a joke,'' she said. ``I thought, oh golly, what's happening in this cruel world?'' Mrs. Warner said she and her husband knew nothing of the matter until they learned of it from a reporter last week. She said they contacted the FBI and have been interviewed by a Manhattan prosecutor. Timothy Warner died of leukemia in 1980. It was unclear how Covenant House may have obtained copies of his birth record and his baptismal certificate; Mrs. Warner said she has the originals. Covenant House said in a brief statement that it was ``deeply sorry that the Warners have been hurt in this way. ... We never imagined the Warners would be hurt.'' The statement did not say how the identity was obtained. Bill McAndrew, a Covenant House spokesman, said it had no further comment. Stanley Arkin, Ritter's lawyer, said earlier Monday that he did not know if Timothy Warner's name and records were used, but maintained that it is legal to use such records so long as it is not for illegal purposes.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Company Named In L-tryptophan Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of disease to `myalgia,' sted `mylagia,' throughout.
DOC.TEXT: A woman filed a $20 million negligence lawsuit Monday against a Japanese manufacturer of L-tryptophan, a dietary supplement linked to a rare and potentially fatal blood disorder. Helen Jones, 52, of Portland claimed in the lawsuit filed in Multnomah County Circuit Court that the Showa Denko company was negligent in manufacturing L-tryptophan, leading her to suffer eosinophilia myalgia syndrome. The rare disease is characterized by abnormal levels of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell. Victims complain of severe muscle pain, weakness and fatigue, swelling in the arms, legs and face, fevers, rashes and, in some cases, breathing disorders. L-tryptophan is an amino acid that has been sold over the counter as a nutritional supplement and a sleep aid for decades without harmful effects. Imports of L-tryptophan were halted in December after the number of eosinophilia myalgia syndrome cases began mounting. By the end of January, nearly 1,200 cases of the disease had been reported nationally, with at least a dozen deaths attributed to it, according to officials with the National Centers for Disease Control. Jones said in her lawsuit that Showa Denko has refused to cooperate with U.S. health authorities, displaying ``callous disregard for the rights and health of plaintiff and all the other victims of L-tryptophan in Oregon and elsewhere in the United States.'' Jones, a forklift driver, claimed in her lawsuit that her health is worsening and that other victims of the syndrome also suffer deteriorating health. Dr. David Fleming, deputy state epidemiologist, said in December that the condition of many eosinophilia myalgia syndrome victims did not improve quickly after they stopped taking the dietary supplement containing L-tryptophan. CDC doctors in Atlanta say there is no effective treatment for eosinophilia myalgia syndrome, and they have nearly ruled out the possibility that some unknown ingredient contaminated capsules or pills containing L-tryptophan. Dr. Edwin M. Kilbourne, who is leading the CDC investigation, has said L-tryptophan itself might be causing the disease, although L-tryptophan manufactured by other companies apparently has not triggered it. Jones' attorney, Gayle Troutwine, said Showa Denko is the sixth-largest petrochemical manufacturer in Japan, with profits of nearly $1.2 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Guess Ownership Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began Monday in a trial pitting two families in a dispute over profits and ownership of Guess, the country's top-selling jeans maker. The 12-member Superior Court panel will decide whether to award damages to the Marciano family, which founded Guess in 1981 and sold a half interest of the company in 1983 to the Nakash family, which also own Jordache jeans. In the first part of the two-stage trial, a jury last year found the Nakashes intended to steal for Jordache trendy Guess clothing designs. The Marcianos now are seeking more than $500 million in damages plus a return of the Nakashes' half ownership of Guess. Judge Norman Epstein will decide whether the Nakashes must relinquish their interest. Also at issue is disposition of a frozen account containing the Nakashes' accrued share of Guess profits that contains more than $93 million. Opening statements were expected Feb. 13. The four French-born Marciano brothers _ Maurice, Armand, Paul and Georges _ also contend that the Israeli-born Nakashes _ Joe, Ralph and Avi _ were responsible for destroying a Guess fashion subsidiary, Gasoline. The Marcianos also named as defendants a Hong Kong couple, Lee Sec Mon and his wife, who manufactured Jordache products in the British crown colony. They allege the Lees were to have manufactured Gasoline designs but diverted materials to Jordache. The Lees are unlikely to appear at trial because of an outstanding warrant for their arrest on customs violations involving garment imports, according to a source close to the case who spoke on condition of anonymity. Founded on an investment of $170,000, Guess last year sold $500 million worth of blue jeans, men's and women's casual wear, swimsuits, shoes, watches, eyeglasses and children's clothing with the distinctive inverted triangle logo. Over the last four years, Guess profits have averaged $45 million a year.

DOC.HEAD: Youths In Largely Black District Attack Police, Firefighters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT typo in `blazes.'
DOC.TEXT: In an attack that appeared premeditated, about 200 youths in a troubled, largely black district of Liverpool rammed a police patrol car with a stolen car then hurled stones at police, authorities said. The youths also set fire to private cars in Monday night's rioting and threw stones at firefighters who arrived to battle the blazes, the police said. The district, Toxteth, was the scene of widespread rioting in 1981 and was among three largely black inner-city districts, including Handsworth in Birmingham in central England and Tottenham in London, hit by riots in the fall of 1985. Police refused to speculate on the cause of Monday night's violence in the northwestern port city. They said in a statement that trouble flared when white officers went to investigate reports of black youths in Toxteth arming themselves with bricks. Two officers who arrived in a patrol car had the car repeatedly rammed by a stolen car and faced a barrage of rocks, the statement said. It said police believed the attack was premeditated. The statement said two police vans were also damaged in the violence and three privately owned autos set on fire. It said the youths threw stones at firemen who arrived to put out the flames. Police reinforcements arrived and drove the attackers off while a police helicopter with a powerful spotlight flew overhead. One police officer was reported to have received a minor eye injury when hit by a stone. Police said nobody was arrested. Superintendent Bernard Keegan, sub-divisional police commander for Toxteth, said: ``I appeal to all parents, teachers and local community leaders to help me in preventing this outrageous behavior by misguided youths.'' In the violence in 1981 and 1985, black youths said the cause was police harassment. Drug dealing and other street crime is widespread in the area and there is often violence when police arrest suspects. Social workers say the underlying causes of the rioting in 1981 and 1985 were high unemployment among young blacks, poor housing and other social ills.

DOC.HEAD: Felled Trees From Hurricane Hugo Results in Too Much Mulch
DOC.TEXT: Since October, workers have been grinding 140 tons of mulch a day from limbs and trees felled by Hurricane Hugo. There's so much mulch, Mecklenburg County is giving it away. So much, one huge pile caught fire from spontaneous combustion 13 days ago and is still burning, officials said. ``Come and get it,'' said Bill Warren, county operations supervisor for recycling. ``We're grinding more than we can give away.'' For gardeners, the woody pulp is ideal for landscaping. It keeps moisture in and weeds out. As the mulch decays, it enriches the soil. The county once charged $15 a pickup load. But until all Hugo debris is ground up, the stuff is free for the taking. After four months, the county has ground up only one-fifth of Hugo's debris. The task probably will continue through autumn, said Fred Remington, division manager of recycling. Mulch will then go back on sale as part of the county's recycling program.

DOC.HEAD: Army Goes Hip _ Well, Sort Of
DOC.TEXT: Some might have thought the Army had gone hip when U.S. troops started blasting rock 'n' roll music toward the Vatican Embassy in Panama City to encourage Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's eviction in December. But the Army brass in Washington apparently wasn't too sure what the guys were doing down there _ at least according to a list the Pentagon provided later of the songs that deafened the Panama City neighborhood. In citing just a few of the songs played on loudspeakers outside the Vatican Embassy, Army Lt. Col. Fred L. Serene Jr. got either the name of the song or the musicians wrong. Serene, a congressional coordinator, provided the list in a letter to Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., who sought the information on behalf of a constituent. A copy of the letter was obtained by The Associated Press. In the letter, Serene wrote, ``Some of the numbers played included `The Smugglers' Blues' sung by Glen Fry, `Take the Money and Run' by Stevie Miller, `I Shot the Sheriff' by Eric Clampton, `Free Bird' sung by the Lynrd Skynyrd Band, and `Nowhere to Run To.' Twisted Sister was not one of the numbers played.'' It's really Glenn Frey, Steve Miller, Eric Clapton, Lynyrd Skynyrd, and the name of the Martha and the Vandellas song is ``Nowhere to Run.'' Twisted Sister is a rock group, not a song. Among the songs played but not mentioned by Serene were ``I Fought the Law'' by the Bobby Fuller Four, ``Voodoo Chile'' by Jimi Hendrix and ``You're No Good'' by Linda Ronstadt. Serene wrote that the 82nd Airborne Division Band based at Fort Bragg, N.C., was responsible for the music, and he directed further inquiries to the bandmaster there. But a sergeant with the 82nd Airborne said he didn't think the band had anything to do with the music played over the loudspeakers, and there was no immediate response from the bandmaster. There also was no answer at Serene's office Monday afternoon. Noriega fled to the Vatican Embassy Dec. 24, five days after President Bush ordered a U.S. invasion that toppled Noriega's government and sent him into hiding. Noriega gave himself up to U.S. troops on Jan. 3, and he awaits trial in Miami on drug trafficking charges. The Vatican Embassy officials complained at the time about the loud music. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said then that the music was not a pressure tactic on the Vatican but simply ``fairly standard practice'' to disrupt any attempt to eavesdrop on U.S. officials' conversations. He said the same thing was done during the 1988 Moscow summit. Of the choice of music, Fitzwater said, ``I'm certainly glad to see the American sense of whimsy comes forward in this situation.'' On Dec. 29, the troops turned the volume down so the music was no longer ear-splitting but still loud. The next day, the music was turned off. ``I am sympathetic to the papal nuncio's plea that the music was keeping him awake while Noriega slept,'' a senior U.S. embassy official in Panama City said on Dec. 30. Bush said the same day, ``I think it aggravated the people inside. It has stopped. It would have aggravated me, I'll tell you. I'm not into rock. Country music, maybe. That's different.''

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 9 a.m. EST; time set by source
Report Calls for More Than Bottom Line in Business Deals
DOC.TEXT: Individuals and corporations involved in mergers or takeovers should consider the effect on their employees, communities and society before signing on the dotted line, a report recommended today. The report, ``Ethical Considerations in Corporate Takeovers,'' released by the Woodstock Theological Center at Georgetown University, suggested executives consider ethical questions while making deals. The questions range from: ``Are the terms of the transaction consistent with the reasonable interests, obligations and expectations of participants?'' to ``will the transaction reward productive effort, innovation and leadership?'' The report, summing up two years of conferences with prominent members of the financial industry, government and academia, seeks to offer ``an evaluation and recommendations for ethical conduct in the financial industry,'' the Rev. James L. Connor, director of the Woodstock center, said in the foreword. The report notes ``corporations do not exist in isolation.'' ``They must be a constructive part of the larger society in which they operate, and even shareholders who seek solely to maximize their own profits will, as a practical matter, have to take into account the interests of workers, customers and communities, without whom the corporation would not exist,'' it says. The participants included Michael Blumenthal, chairman of Unisys Corp.; former Securities and Exchange Commission member Joseph A. Grundfest; former Federal Reserve Board Chairman Paul Volker; Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind.; and former Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara. The 19-page report will be distributed to business schools, financial institutions and other corporations, research centers, government organizations and other interest groups.

DOC.HEAD: Frank Denies Allegation by Former Employee Gobie
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., says he told a group of Marines to stop taunting homosexuals in a restaurant, but did not report them to their superiors as reported by male prostitute Stephen Gobie in a magazine article. Frank also denies Penthouse magazine's report that he offered Gobie $10,000 to $12,000 to help him get a new start in Florida after they quarreled about the man's activities in Frank's rented townhouse. Meanwhile, a campaign finance report released by Frank's office shows that he drew hefty contributions from individuals outside his district and political action committees while coping with a House ethics committee investigation of his relationship with Gobie. Frank, an acknowledged homosexual, said Monday, ``Yeah, I was in Mr. Henry's on Capitol Hill when some Marines were hassling some guys and I went over and identified myself and told them to stop. ``But I never gave their names to the Marine Corps, because it was right after the Lebanon bombing and I figured they were upset and I'd give them a pass on it,'' he said. A Marine Corps barracks in Lebanon was bombed on Oct. 23, 1983, and 241 servicemen were killed. Gobie is quoted in the latest issue of Penthouse as saying, ``One day, at a restaurant, Barney stood up to a bunch of Marines razzing a table of gays. They were sashaying around with limp wrists and laughing. So Barney says, `My name's Congressman Barney Frank. Do you guys have a problem? Were you harassing these men because they are gay?' He got their commanding officer's name and reported them.'' Outside of the account of his encounter at the restaurant, which he said was partially correct, Frank said virtually everything else about him that was attributed to Gobie in the article was untrue. Gobie is quoted as saying that he and Frank argued after the congressman's landlord learned Gobie was operating a sex-for-hire business in Frank's Capitol Hill townhouse. ``I told him I needed $2,000 or $3,000 to move to Florida,'' the authors quote Gobie as telling them. ``I thought Washington had tapped out for me. Barney offered me $10,000 to $12,000, but I said, `I don't need that much.''' The article does not say whether Gobie said he received any money. He has remained in Washington. Frank said the report was ``totally bizarre ... as is virtually all of the new information'' in the article. Of the planned Florida venture, he said, ``It's the first time I ever heard of it.'' The ethics committee is investigating an allegation that Frank knew Gobie was operating a prostitution business from his home. Frank has denied the allegation. The congressman, 49, has acknowledged paying $80 to Gobie, 33, for an initial sexual encounter. He says that after that they became friends and he gave Gobie a job as a personal aide, housekeeper and driver, firing him after learning Gobie was using his home as a business base. Frank's financial report showed he raised $103,476 in 1989, including $45,800 from PACs and about half of that coming after Gobie's allegations surfaced in August. Of 46 individual contributors, only nine live in Frank's district.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Taxi drivers short on cleanliness or courtesy will face long fines, thanks to a new ordinance. Mayor Tom Bradley on Monday signed the law calling for $500 fines to punish cabbies and the city's six taxi companies for behavior deemed uncouth. The ordinance takes effect March 28. ``I think we now will see a new day in Los Angeles in terms of cab service,'' Bradley said. He urged disgruntled riders to telephone the Department of Transportation with complaints. ``We'll get action for you,'' the mayor promised. Department general manager Ed Rowe said individual driver fines will be imposed based on customer complaints and observations of city taxi inspectors posing as riders. The L.A. law establishes standards for cab cleanliness and driver courtesy, and sets a dress code that prohibits drivers from wearing tank tops, shorts and dirty clothing.

Anguilla is not a real eel, insists state Sen. Richard Matsuura, who says it is simply the victim of bad publicity. ``It looks like an eel, but it is a true fish with scales, gills, fins, et cetera,'' he said. Matsuura is the current legislative champion of the nearly annual bill to allow the importation of anguilla rostrada and anguila japonica for research on raising them commercially as an aquaculture product. There is a huge market for anguilla, which sells for as much as $16 a pound in Europe and Asia, Matsuura told the Senate on Monday. The House Agriculture Committee last week killed the House version of the bill after siding with biologists and environmentalists who said there was too much risk that the slippery critters would escape into the wilds and munch away on Hawaii's native stream life. Live anguilla were allowed into Hawaii before 1974, primarily for the restaurant business, Matsuura said. ``No one seems to know why the ban was placed on the anguilla except that it looked like an eel, which it is not,'' he said.

New York should tax Penthouse instead of Plato and Playboy instead of Plutarch, according to a state legislator. State Sen. Anthony Masiello says it's unfair that college students pay tax on textbooks but that magazines bring no extra state levy. ``How can we collect sales tax on the works of the great masters while adult magazines and borderline pornography are trafficked openly and freely?'' the Democratic lawmaker asked Monday. Under Masiello's proposal, the state would stop charging sales tax on college textbooks. To compensate for the lost revenue, Masiello would charge sales tax on ``adult'' magazines, which he defined as any magazine that must appear in a brown wrapper at a newsstand. All magazines are exempt from New York state sales tax. Other states exempt textbooks from sales tax, Masiello said. Masiello said New York receives about $13 million a year from sales tax on textbooks. He says taxing the magazines would bring in about $9 million.

DOC.HEAD: Census Launches Publicity Campaign
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: ``It Counts for More Than You Think,'' is a slogan about to begin bombarding Americans as the 1990 Census approaches. A massive publicity campaign, designed to encourage participation in the national head count, was unveiled Monday. There will be both a national effort and specialized promotions for special groups. ``This is Our Chance,'' Hispanic-Americans will be told in Spanish-language advertising, while ``Stand Up For Who You Are'' is the theme targeted at blacks. Print advertising aimed at American Indians carries the slogan ``Listen to the Drums, Raise Your Voice.'' For Asians, advertising will feature an abacus and carry the theme ``Any Way We Add It _ It Makes Good Sense to Answer the Census.'' Five different advertising agencies have donated their work, the 50 state titleholders from the Miss America Pageant are serving as census ambassadors and businesses across the nation are helping out, officials said Monday in launching the publicity campaign for the 1990 Census. Census Day is April 1, that's the day the government wants to use as a snapshot of the American public. ``Participation is one of the most important activities each one of us can do as citizens,'' said Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher. More than 100 million census forms will be mailed out on March 23, with a request that people fill out the answers and send them back following April 1. Since getting an accurate count depends on public cooperation, the Ad Council, a public service arm of the advertising industry, was asked to help out. The result was the series of promotion campaigns unveiled Monday. People who don't mail back the forms have to be contacted in person, and every 1 percent increase in the mail response rate saves the government $10 million, explained Mosbacher. Reaching some Americans is no easy task, however, and special efforts are being made. Brenda August, Los Angeles census field coordinator, said a former gang member has been hired to work with enumerators in her community, seeking the cooperation of the gangs and easing their distrust of government officials. Census workers will wear special vests so they can be identified and receive safety training and travel in groups, she explained. But they will not be accompanied by police. With red and blue colors used to differentiate the Los Angeles gangs, Ms. August pointed out that both colors are being used on Census products. Well-known athletes are being used to help reach people in Chicago, said regional Census director Stan Moore. He said gangs also are being worked with, and enumerators are being hired from among the residents of public housing projects. Miss America Debbye Turner and Mosbacher filled out sample forms at Monday's news conference, handing them over to Census Director Barbara E. Bryant. Turner called for Americans to join together in answering the census, and said the 50 state Miss America titleholders will become encourage participation in their states. Census assistant director Peter Bounpane said many businesses are also assisting. Included are ads being shown on the Goodyear blimp, mailed ads being sent out by J.C. Penney and Sears, Roebuck and Co., and donated space for census workers to answer questions in many 7-Eleven stores. The national campaign, stressing the Census ``Counts For More Than You Think,'' stresses the importance of census numbers in locating public facilities, apportioning legislatures and distributing federal funds to localities. That census answers are kept secret is also a major theme in the Hispanic community, where distrust of government officials often runs deep. Mrs. Bryant pointed out census records are kept private for 72 years and information about individuals is not given to any other group, either government of private. Faced with FBI agents carrying a subpoena for census files in 1980, an agency official in Denver barricaded the office and called Washington. The FBI agents were called off, she said.

DOC.HEAD: No Stampede Among Tax Writers to Support Moynihan Tax Cut
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: A widely publicized proposal for cutting Social Security taxes apparently is not grabbing the attention of voters and has little support among Senate tax-writers. Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn S. King said the agency's toll-free number had received only about 60 calls on the tax cut since it was proposed in late December by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. ``I don't find a lot of support in my state for cutting payroll taxes,'' Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas said Monday as the Senate Finance Committee opened the first congressional hearing on the bill. He said the subject has not come up at his public meetings in Kansas and that his office has received only two letters on the subject. Members of the committee praised Moynihan for turning the spotlight on the way surplus Social Security taxes are being used ``for general government needs _ from aircraft carriers to paper clips.'' But no one offered a solid endorsement of the bill. ``Not a good idea,'' Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., said of the bill. ``A tax cut would be disastrous'' for future retirees, added Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., agreed with Moynihan that Social Security surpluses should not mask the true size of the deficit but said the tax cut ``would almost certainly bankrupt Social Security in short order.'' Democrats treated the proposal more gently. ``This may be the best answer we can find'' to stop the use of Social Security taxes to cut the budget deficit, said Sen. Don Riegle, D-Mich., who added he has not made a decision. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the committee, said use of Social Security surpluses for deficit reduction can no longer be ignored, but did not recommend how the problem can be corrected. Robert J. Myers, who helped create the system in 1934 and was its chief actuary for 23 years, endorsed the reduction. ``The time has arrived when the financing of the Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance program should be rationalized, stabilized and made crystal clear by going to a pay-as-you-go basis, as proposed by Senator Moynihan,'' Myers told the committee. Moynihan wants to eliminate the surpluses by rolling back the rate tax increase that took effect Jan. 1 and by cutting the rate again next year, to 6.55 percent. The rate now is 7.65 percent of the first $51,300 earned; employers match contributions from the 132 million employees. Congress and the Reagan administration planned for the Social Security surpluses to grow by $1 billion a week when they overhauled the system in 1983 to ensure benefits will be financed when the large generation born soon after World War II begins retiring in about 2012. Under the law, the surpluses must be invested in government securities, which will have to be redeemed in the future to finance benefits. But the surplus taxes are actually being used to finance general government spending and to hide the true size of the budget deficit. Robert M. Ball, Social Security commissioner from 1962 to 1973, said if Congress eliminates the surpluses, the money should be transferred into the Medicare hospitalization fund _ not used for tax cuts. The Bush administration vigorously opposes the cut as a threat to benefits and an opening for increases in other taxes. Nevertheless, Social Security Commissioner King told the hearing, ``the administration is open to every reasonable alternative'' so long as any change does not upset ``the sound financial footing ... of the last seven years.'' Bush said last month that Moynihan's bill is ``a disguise for increased taxes around the corner.'' The president wants to do nothing about the surpluses until the federal budget is balanced _ 1993 at the earliest _ and then to use surplus Social Security taxes only for debt reduction.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental, Safety Flaws Called Endemic to Nuclear Arms Plants
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department says virtually all its nuclear weapons plants appear to be violating safety, health and environmental rules and the department itself is to blame for failing to correct the problems. A report released by the department Monday said some of the health and safety violations posed ``relatively high risks of injury or death to small numbers of workers'' at the plants. Among the problems cited was improper use of toxic substances and electrical dangers. The report compiled previously disclosed problems at six weapons plants: the Rocky Flats plutonium processing plant in Colorado; the Fernald uranium processing plant and the Mound weapons laboratory in Ohio; the Y-12 uranium plant in Tennessee; the Pantex weapons assembly plant in Texas and the West Valley radioactive waste site in New York. The report was prepared by the department to analyze the findings of special investigations of the six plants by private contractors and consultants. The rest of the weapons plants are to be investigated during 1990. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins expressed dismay at the conclusions, including a finding that five of six weapons plants evaluated last fall were storing wastes in violation of federal environmental laws and three were inadequately controlling radiation. The report said other common problems include poor emergency planning, a failure by plant managers to take environmental regulations seriously and a shortage of skilled workers. The report blamed the problems partly on the Energy Department's failure to impose tougher management practices at the plants, which are owned by the government but run by private contractors. ``We must demonstrate that we are able to discipline ourselves and our contractors,'' Watkins wrote in an internal memorandum released with the report. ``Our inability to conform to our own requirements is particularly disturbing.'' One of the plants cited as illegally storing wastes was Rocky Flats, which is under FBI investigation for possible criminal violations of environmental laws. Watkins has acknowledged before that Rocky Flats and other atomic bomb plants are not complying with waste laws and has pledged to correct the problems as quickly as possible. In his memorandum to department employees, Watkins said that although he saw indications of improvements at the plants, he was not satisfied that all managers take the need for further improvements seriously. ``Steps to eliminate the `business as usual' approach to compliance are still required,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Accident Study Shows Tired, Drug-Impaired Truck Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials say they are ``surprised and disturbed'' by new evidence of fatigue and drug abuse as major causes of fatal truck accidents. The evidence came in a report adopted Monday by the National Transportation Safety Board, which found one-third of truck drivers killed in the crashes studied tested positive for alcohol, marijuana, cocaine, over-the-counter stimulants or other drugs. The study covered 182 fatal truck accidents in eight states _ about one-fourth of the national total _ between October 1987 and September 1988. ``We are surprised and disturbed by the findings,'' said board Chairman James Kolstad after the four-member board unanimously adopted the report. The study said impairment of the driver because of fatigue was a cause in 31.5 percent of the crashes, with just slightly fewer attributed to alcohol or drug abuse. The safety board drew up several recommendations but postponed a vote on their adoption. Kolstad said they include increased testing for alcohol and other drugs, with a proposed demonstration project to screen all drivers who pass a given weigh station rather than current random testing. The board also will recommend tamper-proof, on-board recording devices to identify drivers who exceed the maximum of 10 hours of driving with eight hours rest. The board has no rule-making power, but makes recommendations to federal and state agencies. Other proposals include state laws that would discourage any use of alcohol or other drugs that might impair driving, including a reduction of the tolerable blood alcohol concentration for commercial drivers to 0.01 percent. The current level is 0.04, with the legal limit for the general public at 0.1. ``The cab of a truck should be a drug-free zone,'' said Kolstad, citing evidence than any amount of alcohol can impair driving. Drivers who are at the wheel for long hours often use drugs in an effort to stay awake, said Kevin Quinlan, board staff member who led the study. He said investigators traced the activities of each driver in the study to determine how many hours were driven and, when possible, how much rest the driver had prior to the accident. ``It's clear fatigue was a constant companion of the drivers in this study,'' Quinlan said. Board member Jim Burnett said there also are indications of inadequate medical screening of drivers, with 19 of the accidents blamed on heart attacks or other driver medical problems. ``This study indicates to us we've got a lot of holes in the medical qualification process _ holes that you could run a truck through,'' said Burnett during board discussion of the report. Burnett said although drug use decreases as drivers get older, they are more susceptible to health risks. The report showed marijuana and alcohol were the most common substances found in tests of drivers who were killed, with 13 percent of the fatalities showing evidence of one or the other. Cocaine was found in 9 percent of the fatalities, over-the-counter stimulants in 8 percent, amphetamines in 7 percent and opiates or PCP in less than 1 percent. More than 80 percent of the drivers who tested positive for drugs had a record of prior abuse, and abusers were more likely to have a suspended or revoked license and to have violated federal regulations against long driving times, the report said. The study covered all fatal accidents involving trucks of over 10,000 pounds gross weight, ranging from straight trucks to tractors with two trailers. It included cases in California, Colorado, Georgia, Missouri, Maryland, New Jersey, North Carolina, Tennessee and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Bailout Agency Sets Tough Ethics Rules for Contractors
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan bailout officials are trying to strike a balance between preventing fraud and efficiently selling the mountain of sour loans and repossessed real estate inherited from failed thrift institutions. The Resolution Trust Corp., created last August to conduct President Bush's S&L cleanup, adopted ethics rules Monday governing its employees and the thousands of private consultants and managers it expects to hire. The rules for contractors were also approved by an administration oversight board headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. They are designed to screen out contractors with conflicts of interest, a past record of fraud, a pattern of defaults or previous involvement with a savings and loan collapse. They apply to anyone receiving contracts worth $25,000 a year or more. The RTC is expected to take over about 600 failed S&Ls with assets of more than $300 billion. Its contracts will be a huge opportunity for lawyers, accountants, investment bankers, real estate brokers, appraisers, property managers and other professionals. But, the cleanup also will present massive opportunity for fraud. In a report last week, the General Accounting Office, Congress' watchdog agency, put the disposal of thrift assets at the head of a list of 14 areas in government most vulnerable to abuse. ``A sale of this magnitude is unparalleled in history ... (and) highly susceptible to fraud, waste and abuse,'' it said. Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House task force overseeing the RTC, said tough rules are necessary even though ``in some communities ... there is no one left to do the business except those that have been involved in the losses.'' ``The American public has a very low tolerance for this entire S&L issue,'' Vento said. ``To maintain any kind of public support, you will have to demonstrate there is an effort to try to limit those involved in creating the problem from profiting from it.'' However, Paul Horvitz, a business professor at the University of Houston, said regulators may be overreacting and causing delays that will cost taxpayers money. ``The RTC doesn't want to deal with crooks or people who've caused problems in the past. But ... in an attempt to be squeaky clean, they may just run into time delays,'' he said. In perhaps its most controversial provision, the contractor rules screen out anyone who caused a loss of $50,000 or more to government deposit insurance funds. Some contractors complain that such a low limit bars practically anyone who did business in Texas during the oil bust, when thousands of people defaulted on home mortgages and business loans from banks and S&Ls that failed. Stephen Katsanos, a spokesman for the agency, said there is a ``strong likelihood'' many firms in Texas and other Oil Patch states will be disqualified, creating a business opportunity for out-of-state firms. Katherine Corigliano, the RTC's ethics officer, said the agency will apply a ``rule of reason'' to interpreting the regulations. Any contractor excluded from doing business under the rules can offer an explanation and ask for an exception. That, however, places a burden on the agency's staff to make thousands of case-by-case reviews. Officials plan at first to conduct most of the reviews in Washington, but after precedents are established, farm most of the work out to the RTC's regional offices, which should be able to make decisions faster. ``It strikes me that it's going to be a terribly people-intensive process,'' said RTC board member Robert Clarke. Lamar C. Kelly Jr., director of RTC asset and real estate management, said the agency has already received about 10,000 inquiries from would-be contractors and expects that to increase dramatically. The RTC hopes to begin awarding contracts on a routine basis in April and May and could award up to $1.5 billion worth by the end of the year, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Tourists Post First U.S. Travel Surplus in History
DOC.TEXT: For the first time, foreign visitors are spending more in the United States than Americans are spending overseas, the Commerce Department reports. The United States gained a $450 million travel surplus last year, Commerce Undersecretary Rockwell Schnabel said Monday. And Don Wynegar, research director for the department's U.S. Travel and Tourism Administration, said the surplus is projected to reach $1.5 billion this year. Foreign visitors spent $34.3 billion in the United States in 1989 while Americans spent $33.9 billion abroad. American and foreign travelers spent an identical $8.7 billion getting to their destinations. The USTTA said the nation's record travel deficit was posted in 1985, when it climbed to $9.4 billion. It attributed the turnaround to foreign travel to the United States growing twice as fast as Americans' overseas travel. The USTTA is forecasting a 6 percent increase to 40.7 million foreign visitors this year and a 7 percent gain to 43.4 million in 1991. By the year 2000, Schnabel said, there are expected to be 67 million foreign tourists spending a projecting $89 billion in the United States. Neighboring Canada and Mexico, as might be expected, had the largest share of visitors to the United States in 1989, a combined 64 percent _ 15.2 million from Canada and 9.3 million from Mexico, Wynegar said. They were followed by 3 million Japanese tourists and 2.2 million British visitors. Schnabel said the greatest growth in 1990 is expected from Mexico, with an 11 percent increase to 10.4 million visitors. Overseas arrivals, he said, are projected to grow by about 8 percent and Canadian arrivals by 2 percent. Overseas markets with the largest potential for continued growth include Japan, Britain, Australia and Sweden. ``While arrivals from Japan and the United Kingdom seem to be slowing slightly, averaging 9 percent growth per year, growth from Australia and Sweden is expected to average 14 percent annually in 1990 and 1991,'' he said. Schnabel described the tourism industry as ``many different parts making up the largest service industry in the world.'' ``In fact, we are a $2 trillion industry worldwide, employing over 100 million people or one out of every 16 people in the world's workforce,'' he continued. In the United States, Schnabel said, the travel industry is the second largest employer after health services, employing nearly 6 million people. And, he said, ``Domestic and foreign travelers together spent $350 billion in the United States last year, making travel and tourism the third largest retail business in the country (after automobile and health services).''

DOC.HEAD: Easing Communists' Monopoly on Power Still Leaves Party in Charge
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Although the Soviet Communist Party appears poised to give up its constitutionally guaranteed grip on power, it is unlikely to soon follow fraternal parties in Eastern Europe and actually surrender the reins of power. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed to the party Central Committee on Monday that the Communists take the historic step of surrendering the guarantee they have in the constitution of being the country's ``leading and guiding force.'' Communists, he said, must earn the right to run the country. In taking that step, Gorbachev acknowledged the power of the pro-democracy movement he unleashed when he began his reform program upon rising to power five years ago. But he also understands that conditions are far different in his country than they are in other Eastern European nations where communist power crumbled, in some cases within a matter of weeks. Gorbachev repeatedly has said that no other political forces exist in the Soviet Union that are capable of the wide-ranging activities in which the party engages. For years, the party ruthlessly repressed any effort to oppose it. In addition, the Soviet Communist Party has been in power much longer than its fraternal former ruling parties in Eastern Europe _ which were forced on former satellites by Josef Stalin and thus resented for nationalist reasons by the people of those countries. Through the years of Stalin's absolute rule, the Soviet ruling party had no written guarantee of political power, and it was only in the last constitution, adopted in 1977, that its monopoly was assured. Encouraged by Gorbachev's reforms, opposition to authoritarian Communist rule has grown in recent months. But the forces of dissent still are widely scattered across this vast country of more than 100 nationalities. The most widespread phenomenon is the birth of People's Front political movements that have sprung up to press local demands for more autonomy. The movements are strongest in the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. They began there less than two years ago and are now leading to the formation of some small political parties that will contest local elections this spring. Despite growing contacts between the People's Front movements of various republics and regions, local issues still are paramount to the groups and no cohesive national organization or program has been established. In the Baltics, the People's Front organizations increasingly are setting their sights on complete independence from the Russian-ruled Soviet Union. Another organization, the Democratic Platform, has united disgruntled Communists who are close to declaring the party incapable of reform and forming a social democratic party. Democratic Platform joined with other groups to organize a huge rally in Moscow on Sunday, the eve of the Central Committee meeting, and demanded that the party give up its claim to exclusive power. Its founding conference in Moscow in mid-January drew representatives from many Soviet cities, but the organization lacks money and access to official media _ advantages enjoyed by the Communist Party. Many Communist leaders are likely to take a drubbing in the local elections this spring, repeating the embarrassing experience of balloting last March that were the country's first contested national elections in seven decades. However, because of what opposition members called the unfair rules of the game, about 80 percent of those elected to the Congress of People's Deputies were party members. Communist officials are faced not so much with the prospect of losing power to an organized opposition as they are with losing their cohesiveness and the trust of the people. They are blamed for the dismal state of the economy, which has wrought widespread consumer shortages, and resented for enjoying a higher standard of living than most Soviets by virtue of their power. Under Gorbachev's reform program, local and regional Communist officials are going to have to give up the perks and privilege if they wish to earn the public trust. But, as Gorbachev envisions it, centralized decision-making would be scrapped and local officials would be permitted the leeway to solve problems efficiently. That, the Soviet president feels, would boost the prestige of a party which otherwise would continue its steep decline.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mark J. Porubcansky has covered Soviet politics from Moscow since February 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,666.83, up 35.42 points, or 0.09 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Order May Lead to Constitutional Battle Over Presidents' Testimony
With PM-Iran-Contra, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A ruling that former President Reagan must testify at an Iran-Contra trial could lead to a major constitutional battle over the right of presidents to refuse to testify or reveal confidential documents in court. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene on Monday ordered Reagan to provide videotaped testimony at the trial of former national security adviser John Poindexter. But the judge gave Reagan and President Bush until Friday to invoke executive privilege to avoid testimony by the former president. Greene also renewed his order that Reagan immediately turn over 33 diary entries to Poindexter. Reagan promptly invoked executive privilege to avoid turning portions of his diaries over to Poindexter. However, there was no immediate decision on whether Reagan would agree to provide a videotaped deposition before the start of Poindexter's trial. ``It would be inconceivable ... to exempt Mr. Reagan from the duty of every citizen to give evidence that will permit the reaching of a just outcome of this criminal prosecution,'' Greene said Monday. Legal scholars said the judge's order could lead to a new Supreme Court test of executive privilege, the doctrine invoked to shield presidents from court appearances or divulging confidential information. ``It remains to be seen what Reagan will do,'' said Georgetown University law professor Samuel Dash, who was chief counsel to the Senate Watergate committee in the mid-1970s. When Reagan was president, Dash noted, ``he told the American people he believed he should be open completely in the Iran-Contra case. I don't know whether he has changed his mind.'' If Reagan refuses to testify on the basis of executive privilege, Greene could postpone the Poindexter trial _ now scheduled to begin Feb. 20 _ while the matter is appealed directly to the Supreme Court. Given the importance of the issue, the high court could expedite consideration of the case and hear arguments in the spring. The court's last word on executive privilege was provided in 1974 when it ordered President Richard M. Nixon to provide White House tape recordings to a prosecutor in the Watergate bugging case. The justices in 1974 unanimously said, ``The general assertion of privilege must yield to the demonstrated, specific need for evidence in a pending criminal trial.'' But New York University law professor Bernard Schwartz said the ruling's impact is not clear-cut. ``What would have happened if Nixon raised a claim of national security?'' Schwartz asked, suggesting the outcome might have been different. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements. Invoking executive privilege regarding the diary entries will allow Reagan to gain access to a secret filing in which Poindexter told why he needs the diaries. If Reagan determines the excerpts contain admissible evidence not available from other sources, ``the former president may decide to waive his claim of privilege,'' said Reagan attorney Theodore Olson. Greene said he will allow Poindexter to question Reagan on a wide range of subjects in the Iran-Contra affair, including whether Reagan approved Poindexter's denials to Congress that former White House national security aide Oliver L. North was raising money and providing military advice to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. Poindexter also will be allowed to ask Reagan about ``the president's knowledge regarding the relationship of Oliver North with specific individuals involved in Iran-Contra activities.'' The president told the investigative Tower Board on Jan. 26, 1987, that he did not know the National Security Council staff was helping the Contras. Poindexter has said Reagan took notes at meetings focusing on congressional inquiries into North's activities to help the Contras. North tried to subpoena Bush and Reagan to testify at his own trial. But U.S. District Judge Gerhard Gesell last year refused to order either man to testify, saying North failed to show their testimony would be relevant to his defense. North is appealing his convictions of obstructing Congress, destroying government documents and accepting an illegal gratuity. No sitting president ever has testified in court in a criminal trial, although some have provided testimony or the rough equivalent. In 1975, then-President Gerald R. Ford gave a videotaped deposition in the trial of Lynette ``Squeaky'' Fromme, convicted of trying to assassinate Ford. The videotape was played for jurors at Fromme's trial. President Jimmy Carter provided videotaped testimony twice while in office _ once in the prosecution of a Georgia state senator and once in a grand jury investigation of financier Robert Vesco.

DOC.HEAD: Sometimes Passengers Should be Told of Threats, FAA Chief Says
DOC.TEXT: Airline passengers should be told if their flight is the target of a terrorist bomb threat only if they notice and ask about increased security precautions, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration says. But FAA Administrator James Busey also maintains that because most bomb threats are hoaxes _ up to 600 a year proving false _ no public warning should be made in the vast majority of cases. Busey noted the FAA continues to insist airlines not disclose the contents of the agency's security notices and bulletins containing intelligence information on terrorist threats. ``I think passengers should operate on the assumption that if the plane is going, there is no threat,'' Busey told reporters Monday. ``If we cannot guarantee the security and the safety of that flight, the bird does not fly.'' But Busey said a distinction can be made when a passenger arrives at an airport departure lounge and observes bomb-sniffing dogs, the searching of carry-on luggage and other signs of heightened security. ``The experienced traveler will know that something is going on,'' he said. ``And they have every right to know'' what it is. Air travelers who ask should be told the reason for the precautions ``to have the flexibility to make his own personal decision independently,'' Busey said. But overall, he said, ``Our policy remains that we not go public.''
