The issue of whether passengers should be told of terrorist threats arose after reports that some U.S. diplomats were told of a 1988 bomb threat against Pan Am Flight 103. The aircraft exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland on Dec. 21, 1988, killing 259 people on board and 11 on the ground. In separate incidents last year, Northwest and Delta airlines broke from standard industry practice when they issued public announcements that some of their flights had been threatened. Busey called in representatives of all major U.S. airlines for a ``listening session'' over the issue, apparently concluding there are rare occasions when it is prudent to tell passengers their flight has been threatened. On Monday, Busey spelled out for the first time an example of such a rare occasion. Spokesmen for aviation watchdog groups and representatives of the family associations formed after the destruction of Pan Am 103 have harshly criticized the FAA and the airline industry for failing to give passengers adequate warning of threats. A presidential commission, formed to make security recommendations in the aftermath of the Pan Am flight, is addressing the issue of whether passengers should be informed of threats. The commission's report is due in mid-May.

DOC.HEAD: NYS Death Penalty Law Centers on Cancer-Stricken Legislator
LaserPhoto AB1
DOC.TEXT: The battle to restore the death penalty in New York again may rest on a conservative Republican senator whose bout with cancer has given him second thoughts about bringing back the electric chair. Sen. James Donovan missed Monday's vote in the state Senate on legislation to restore capital punishment, a measure Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo has promised to veto for the eighth straight year. A consistent death penalty supporter, Donovan was unable to vote because he was suffering the side effects of chemotherapy, said Edward Byrne, an aide to the 25-year Senate veteran. The legislation was approved 40-20. The measure now goes to the 150-member Assembly where a vote isn't expected until late February, at the earliest. Without Donovan's vote or a switch by one of the ``No'' votes, death penalty advocates lack the 41 Senate votes needed to override a veto. Thirty-seven states have death penalty laws. New York is the largest state without one. The state's last execution was in 1963. Last year, Donovan said his battle with cancer had caused him to have second thoughts about the death penalty. That was enough to prompt the Senate's Republican leadership to scrap any attempt at an override in 1989. On Friday, Byrne had confidently predicted Donovan would be on hand for Monday's vote, saying ``he hasn't missed a day yet this year.'' On Monday, Byrne said he was not sure how the senator would vote, but he insisted Donovan was not ``ducking'' the vote. The Senate's chief sponsor of the legislation, Republican Dale Volker, said he was confident Donovan would eventually vote for capital punishment. ``I've said from the beginning that Jim Donovan has always voted for the death penalty and I think he will again,'' said Volker, adding that he might even pick up some more votes when it came time for the override attempt. The Senate action began what's become an annual event at the Capitol. Every year, both houses pass the death penalty bill, Cuomo vetoes it, and legislators then count noses to see if they've got the votes for an override. Thus far, they have come up short. This year's battle has taken on additional meaning because the governor's job and all 211 seats in the Legislature go before the voters in November. Republicans, as in the past, are expected to make Cuomo's opposition to the death penalty a major campaign issue. The legislation would permit the death penalty for the most heinous murders, such as contract killings and the slaying of witnesses. Cuomo, arguing the death penalty is debasing and not a deterrent, has called instead for life-without-parole sentences for some murderers. The GOP-controlled Senate has refused to go along with that argument. New York state's electric chair hasn't been used since Aug. 15, 1963, when Eddie Lee Mays, convicted of murder in a Harlem bar shooting, became the 695th person put to death in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Tests Show No Antibiotic Residues in Milk
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration says tests for antibiotics in milk samples from 14 metropolitan areas show the nation's milk supply is safe. The FDA said its findings contradict the results of screenings by The Wall Street Journal and the Center for Science in the Public Interest, which recently found residues of potentially harmful drugs used to treat sick cattle. ``Our study indicates that the American dairy farmer is using animal drugs carefully and conscientiously, and that the milk supply does not contain unsafe drug residues,'' Gerald Guest, director of FDA's Center for Veterinary Medicine, said in a statement Monday. The Journal's tests, conducted by Rutgers University scientists, on 50 retail samples collected in 10 major cities, found 38 percent were contaminated with antibiotics and sulfa drugs used to treat sick cattle. This class of drugs includes sulfamethazine, a suspected carcinogen. The survey by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, conducted in conjunction with the Journal, tested 20 milk samples from store shelves in metropolitan Washington and found 20 percent were tainted. The FDA noted at the time the tests used in the screenings, known as Charm II, can detect only classes of drugs, not specific drugs within a class. It also said the levels of residues found in the Journal's testing did not pose a public health threat. The FDA also used the Charm II method in its tests and got ``positive'' readings for 51 percent of its 70 samples. However, the FDA said it also used new testing methods that are more sensitive and specific than Charm II. None of the Charm II positives was confirmed by the new methods, the FDA said. Also, testing for specific drugs found no contamination with sulfamethazine, which is not approved for use in any food-producing animal. The FDA samples were taken from Atlanta, Baltimore, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Denver, Kansas City, Los Angeles, Miami, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Philadelphia, New York, San Francisco and Seattle. Michael Jacobson, executive director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said the Charm II test is ``well documented and reliable.'' ``It's puzzling that the FDA would not be able to confirm any samples that Charm II found contaminants in,'' he said. ``I think the reason for the discrepancy has to be determined before one can say anything definite.'' The FDA said it plans to regularly monitor pasteurized milk for the presence of drug residues to supplement testing by the states. The agency also said it will work toward adoption by the states of new testing procedures. States currently rely on a method originally designed to detect penicillin and which also detects other antibiotics but not with the same sensitivity.

DOC.HEAD: Monument to Free Speech Revives Bitterness of Protest Movement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Finalists scheduled to be announced around 2:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: A monument commemorating the 25th anniversary of the free speech movement at the University of California at Berkeley has revived the bitterness over its legacy. Veterans of the protest _ which helped launch a decade of dissent by the nation's youth _ endorse the idea of a monument to their accomplishment, but the university's chancellor and some faculty deride the proposal as a ``gesture of remarkable arrogance.'' ``We want something that is meant as a tribute and inspiration to all freedom fighters,'' said Charles Schwartz, a physics professor who last year dreamed up the idea of commissioning artwork for the project. Since then, the proposal has garnered support from 100 professors, local politicians, students and most of the now middle-age leaders of the free speech movement. But Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman, who must accept the monument before it can be placed on campus, said he was troubled by the proposal. ``It is not clear why the free speech movement of 1964 deserves such special commemoration,'' he wrote in a public letter to Schwartz and Peter Selz, a retired art history professor and the former chief curator of the New York Museum of Modern Art. He added that those involved in the movement were ``not very good at designing public art to commemorate their own actions.'' In a subsequent statement, Heyman criticized public art on the campus, saying statues ``do not wear well and they are vulnerable to being defaced.'' More than 270 people, including internationally known artists, have submitted proposals for the artwork, and a seven-member committee was scheduled to name five finalists today. Their work will be displayed and a final selection announced March 3. Organizers, who have already raised $30,000, plan to give the winner $70,000 to build the monument, which will be donated to the university. The movement began in the fall of 1964 when philosophy student Mario Savio and friend Jack Weinberg set up a card table to distribute political material on the university's Sproul Plaza. The school had enacted a ban on campus political activities because it feared civil disobedience actions were disrupting classes. Weinberg was arrested and placed in the back of a patrol car, but hundreds of students surrounded the automobile and for 32 hours refused to let 600 police officers take him into custody. Photographs of Savio and others addressing the crowd from atop the police car were published around the world, leading to sympathy strikes by students until the university dropped its ban several months later. The often iconoclastic proposals to commemorate the confrontation include a huge screw; two chairs facing each other on two pedestals; a giant megaphone; three monkeys in a cage; a suspended exclamation mark, and a bronze fist breaking through the pavement with the middle finger extended. Supporters of the monument are casting the dispute as another free speech issue, accusing the university of trying to stifle a permanent reminder of its attempt to keep students and others from engaging in political activities on campus 25 years agao. ``The free speech movement had effects all over the world, and continues to inspire students everywhere,'' Selz said. Mayor Loni Hancock, who participated in the protests and endorses the monument proposal, said the event brought together students of all political persuasion, from leftists to Young Republicans. ``We're a country that too often forgets our past,'' said the mayor. ``The free speech movement was a milestone of the 1960s, the recognition by young people of all types that they would be participants in the governing forces around them. ``With what's happening today in Eastern Europe, how can we not pause to honor that?'' But others say the movement did not live up to the principles it espoused. David Littlejohn, a journalism professor, said the movement heralded an era of dogmatic liberalism, in which conservatives are routinely shouted down during public speeches on campus. In a letter to a local newspaper, he called the monument proposal a ``gesture of remarkable arrogance and unjustified self-assurance. ... To welcome it to this campus would be to reject and insult the opinions of any members of the campus who did not regard (the movement) as Berkeley's finest hour.''

DOC.HEAD: Gannett Announces Seven Executive Appointments
DOC.TEXT: Vincent E. Spezzano is the new chairman of Gannett Rochester (N.Y.) Newspapers, the company's newspaper division says in a statement announcing six other executive appointments. David J. Mack, who had been president and publisher of the Binghamton (N.Y.) Press & Sun-Bulletin, succeeds Spezzano as president and publisher in Rochester, the Gannett Co. statement released Monday said. Bernard M. Griffin, formerly president and publisher of the St. Cloud (Minn.) Times, succeeds Mack in Binghamtom and as a regional vice president for Gannett. Sonja S. Craig, former president and publisher of the Wausau (Wis.) Daily Herald, succeeds Griffin in St. Cloud. Frederick T. Jacobi, a former regional circulation director for the newspaper division, succeeds Ms. Craig in Wausau. Mary Parks Stier, president and publisher of the Iowa City (Iowa) Press-Citizen, and Denise H. Bannister, president and publisher of the Huntington (W.Va.) Herald-Dispatch, were appointed regional vice presidents of Gannett.

DOC.HEAD: Key Reforms Under Gorbachev
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Reforms in the Soviet Union since Mikhail S. Gorbachev took power on March 11, 1985:

July 1986: Communist Party Central Committee says local parliaments will take more responsibility. June 1987: First experimental contested elections held in some local districts. June 1988: Special party conference approves sweeping political reform, promising shift of power from party to government and a new legal system. Totalitarianism is rejected. Gorbachev suggests each local party leader should seek and win election to the corresponding government post. October 1988: Constitutional amendments proposed to change the rubber-stamp parliament to a real, nearly full-time legislature and provide for contested elections. March 1989: First contested elections for parliament result in humiliating defeats for dozens of Communist leaders across the country. May 1989: First Congress of People's Deputies opens, and new parliamentarians enthrall the country with their critical speeches. July 1989: Soviet Union's first parliamentary opposition, the Inter-Regional Group, takes form. December 1989: Lithuania approves multiparty system on its territory; later in the month, Lithuanian Communists create first split in the party by voting to break off and form independent Communist Party. Jan. 13, 1990: Gorbachev, on a visit to Lithuania, drops his opposition to a multiparty system. Jan. 21: Reform Communists meet in Moscow to write alternative party platform and threaten to split off into a new party unless reforms are made. Sunday: Hundreds of thousands march through Moscow to demand democratic reform. Monday: Gorbachev asks Communist Party leadership to give up its exclusive hold on power.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drops, Stocks Gain
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended lower against the Japanese yen Tuesday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange inched up. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 35.42 points, or 0.09 percent, ending trading at 37,666.83. It had lost 18.74 points Monday. The dollar closed unchanged from its opening Tuesday at 144.90 yen, down 0.70 yen from Monday's 145.60-yen finish. It ranged between 144.80-145.03 yen during trading. Traders attributed the dollar's overnight decline mainly to the strength of the West German mark. Confidence in the prospects for political reform in the Soviet Union bolstered the mark, which in turn aided the yen, they said. In his address Monday to the Communist Party Central Committee, Gorbachev proposed that the party give up its monopoly on power. Gorbachev's grip on power is believed to be key to stability and growth in Eastern Europe, which is expected to benefit the mark, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. ``Dollar-selling against mark resulted in dollar-selling against the yen,'' Kanai said. Traders said the dollar's fall against the yen also reflected concern among investors in New York that Japanese institutionsl might keep a lower profile in the U.S. Treasury Department's quarterly bond auction this week. Reduced Japanese purchases would mean less demand for dollars to buy the bonds. But brokers in Tokyo said they expected Japanese investors to pick up 30 percent to 35 percent the U.S. government bonds during the three-day bidding that starts later Tuesday. That would be in line with Japanese demand at previous auctions. ``Stability in overseas stock markets and expectations that Japanese investors may bid more than previously believed in the auction boosted the Nikkei's gains,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co.

DOC.HEAD: Expense-Account Probe Tarnishes Arkansas Attorney General's Image
LaserPhoto LR1
DOC.TEXT: The state attorney general's squeaky-clean image is taking a beating because of disclosures that the gubernatorial hopeful charged the state for meals with people who say they didn't dine with him. A judge, a congressman, and others listed in Steve Clark's records of how he used his state-issued Visa card have said the records are in error. Some others who agree they were with him say the meals were dates, not state business. Clark, 42, has found his bid for governor suddenly sullied, with some reports suggesting he ought to get out of the race, perhaps resign. ``I am redoubling my efforts to win this race,'' he said last week, but then he scrubbed two political events during the weekend and went into seclusion to consult advisers. State Police and legislative auditors began combing his expense vouchers Monday at the request of the prosecutor in Little Rock, who helped write the state's year-old ethics law. Clark, a Democrat in his 12th year as attorney general, said he is guilty of nothing more than memory lapses and keeping poor records. He has repaid the state almost $4,000. Although Clark has acknowledged nearly $4,000 in mistakes, reports by two Little Rock newspapers _ the Arkansas Gazette and the Arkansas Democrat _ say the errors exceed $4,000 and may amount to more than $6,000. In a state where the average monthly blue-collar salary is $1,525, Clark has had to explain why he needed $562 to entertain four political supporters at an August dinner, one of many instances of Clark billing the state for meals at posh Little Rock restaurants. He also has had to explain why many of the people listed as his guests in records dating from 1986 say they were not with him at the time. Among the phantom guests are U.S. District Judge Richard S. Arnold of the 8th Circuit Court of Appeals, Rep. Tommy Robinson, R-Ark., and state Supreme Court Justice Steele Hays. ``You must have the wrong Richard Arnold,'' Arnold replied when asked about the $243.76 meal Clark said he had shared with the judge and another man. ``I have never actually eaten dinner with Steve Clark.'' Rex Nelson, a spokesman for Robinson _ himself a gubernatorial hopeful for the Republican Party, said the congressman ``has never been to LaScala's before, with Clark or anyone else. I had to tell him where it was.'' Clark reported spending $29 on his meal with Robinson at the Little Rock restaurant. Clark, who is divorced, was on dates at two of his state-issued Visa-financed dinners, the women told the newspapers. The disclosures about Clark's records have set off a wave of jokes about the attorney on bumper stickers: _ ``Honk if you ate with Steve Clark.'' _ ``Honk if you didn't eat with Steve Clark.'' _ ``The businessman's diet _ lunch with Steve Clark. Zero calories guaranteed.'' A radio station offered prizes to anyone who could photograph Clark eating last weekend. A high school student caught him at LaScala's, and the Gazette published the picture. ``There is no doubt about it,'' Clark said of his records. ``It was an honest mistake, but I made a mistake. I'm sorry and I apologize.'' Clark said he would sit down every 60 to 90 days with his Visa bill and divide the personal and business expenses, using sketchy notes in his personal calendar as a guide. For example, he said, he may have seen Arnold at the restaurant, jotted that down, and 90 days later assumed he ate with the man. Clark did not have to keep the records that are getting him in trouble. The state's seven constitutional officers, including the governor, are not required to itemize their expenses. Clark said he tried to keep more complete records ``as a positive thing.'' The same two state police investigators who are looking into his books interviewed Clark in December in connection with an alleged bribe Clark said he was offered. The attorney general helped kill a multimillion-dollar bond issue when he said a lobbyist offered him $100,000 in campaign contributions to not oppose the deal. The lobbyist, Earl Jones, told police it was Clark who asked for the contributions. Jones' misdemeanor trial will be held next month.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Glassware Recalled by Massachusetts Importer
DOC.TEXT: OroFolio glass tableware is being recalled because of dangerous concentrations of lead in the Italian import, says the Food and Drug Administration. Long-term use of the glassware could result in damage to the central nervous system of children by lead that leached into food, the agency said Monday. The importer, Mariposa, a Gloucester, Mass., company, distributed more than 3,000 pieces to 166 stores in the United States and Canada since last August, the agency said. The FDA said Mariposa has advised the stores to post notices asking customers to return any items they have. The OroFolio line carries a gold band in the clear glass. The recalled pieces and item numbers are wine glass, 701; individual bowl, 710; salad plate, 711; dinner plate, 712; small round platter, 720; large round platter, 721; serving bowl, 722; small oval platter, 723 and large oval platter, 724.
DOC.HEAD: Texas Governor Says U.S. In No Position To Seek Foreign Collider
DOC.TEXT: Help

Texas Gov. Bill Clements says it's premature to be talking about getting foreign investors to build the huge super collider in his state. Clements said Monday after meeting with Energy Secretary James Watkins the Energy Department is not prepared to request foreign help until Congress has ``completely endorsed'' the collider and foreign countries have been assured of its total costs and design. Rep. Tom Bevill, D-Ala., chairman of the House appropriations subcommittee with jurisdiction over the collider, was adamant last year that the department come up with a plan to share the cost of the collider with foreign countries. ``We're not in a position to ask for (foreign help). Certainly no one overseas is in a position to make a commitment for `X' dollars until they know what `Y' cost is, and until Congress has completely endorsed the program,'' said Clements. ``And so foreign participation, which everybody likes to talk about, is premature to talk about at this point,'' Clements said. Only India has said it is willing to contribute to the collider, up to $50 million. President Bush is seeking a $318 million appropriation for the collider in next year's budget. Last year he asked for $250 million and Congress voted $225 million. The collider, when completed late in the decade, will allow scientists to test theories about the fundamental nature of matter by smashing together beams of protons at 20 times the energy now possible. The original cost, estimate at $5.9 billion, will rise by $1 billion to $2 billion if the original design is maintained, a course Watkins has indicated he favors.
DOC.HEAD: Export-Import Bank Makes Loan To China
DOC.TEXT: The Export-Import Bank has granted a multi-million dollar loan to China's National Offshore Oil Co., a bank official says. The official, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity Monday, said negotiations on the loan had been in progress for some time and did not signify a change in U.S.-Chinese commercial relations. ``It's not that big, and it was something that was in the pipeline,'' the official said. The New York Times reported that the $9.75 million loan, which was signed on Friday, is to help the company pay for engineering services at a gas processing plant it is buying from McDermott International Inc. President Bush removed restrictions on Ex-Im Bank loans to China on Dec. 19.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Kevin Costner, Universal File Suit Against Video Company
DOC.TEXT: Actor Kevin Costner and Universal Pictures Inc. are suing a video company, saying it is trying to profit from the hit movie ``Field of Dreams'' by marketing a film in which Costner played a minor role. The U.S. District Court lawsuit says Prism Entertainment Corp. has distributed a 1985 film, ``Chasing Dreams,'' in which Costner played an ``extremely minor role.'' The videocassette cover prominently displays Costner's picture and name, according to the lawsuit filed Monday. The lawsuit seeks an injunction barring ``misrepresentations'' in the marketing of ``Chasing Dreams,'' Prism's profits from the videocassette, and unspecified punitive damages. ```Chasing Dreams' was neither critically acclaimed nor financially successful,'' wrote plaintiffs' attorney Frank Rothman. ``It was shown only in approximately 40 movie theaters in the midwestern United States.'' Prism President Barry Collier declined comment, saying he had not seen the lawsuit. In the hit ``Field of Dreams,'' Costner plays a farmer who builds a baseball diamond in his corn field where ghost players, including ``Shoeless'' Joe Jackson and other members of the 1919 Chicago ``Black Sox'' come to play. Costner is shown on the cover of ``Chasing Dreams'' wearing a baseball uniform but does not play a baseball player in the film, according to the lawsuit. ``Field of Dreams'' has grossed $63 million since its release last year but has yet to be released on videocassette, the lawsuit says. Universal owns U.S. distribution rights to the film.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Starts for Washington Men Accused of Illegal Log Exports
DOC.TEXT: Logs cut on federal land were sold to a Japanese company by one of two men accused of conspiracy to illegally export the unprocessed timber, a Forest Service investigator testified. Michael Nitsch said Monday he traced several dozen logs at an Aberdeen, Wash., shipping terminal to Joh J. Tortorelli. Tortorelli had sold the raw logs to Nichimen American Inc., a Japanese exporting firm, Nitsch said. His testimony came in the first day of the trial of Tortorelli and Winston D. Bentley. The two are charged with orchestrating a scheme for exporting unprocessed logs cut on national forests in violation of a federal law designed to protect American jobs. Defense attorney Michael Moses said the logs purchased by Tortorelli with Bentley's help were all thought to have been cut on private land where the export ban does not apply. If convicted, the defendants each could be sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $20,000. The concern over exports has been heightened by timber shortages blamed for layoffs and sawmill closures. ``There are only so many logs for our mills,'' U.S. Attorney Pete Dunbar has said. ``If they are exporting logs illegally, doesn't that take away from the capability of Montana mills?'' A grand jury indictment last fall said Tortorelli arranged to buy timber from logging companies and resell the unprocessed logs on the lucrative export market. Bentley allegedly helped Tortorelli by managing a log-sorting yard in Mead, Wash., and acted as Tortorelli's agent by advertising, soliciting and inspecting logs. The indictment said both men falsely told sellers the logs would be processed in this country. Also charged were truck drivers Duane Farmer and Roger Britz, who worked for Northern Transport Inc. of Enumclaw, Wash. They were hired by Tortorelli to haul logs from forests in Washington, Idaho and Montana to ports in Washington, the indictment said. Farmer and Britz have been given immunity in exchange for their testimony against Tortorelli and Bentley. Forest Service officials have said 558,515 board-feet of timber were involved, with about two-thirds from forests in northwest Montana. Northwest timber exports in 1988 were at least 4.3 billion board-feet, up 20 percent from 1987. Nitsch said he received a tip in February 1988 that logs bearing Forest Service marks were being trucked to the Aberdeen port. He said he found about 70 such logs there, each bearing a tag indicating they had been sold to Nichimen. Nitsch said he tracked about 60 of the logs to forests in Washington and Montana and determined they had been sold by Tortorelli to the Japanese company. David Faulkner, a timber sales specialist for the Forest Service in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, testified an unprocessed log sold to another country can bring five times as much as one sold to a U.S. mill. In his opening argument, Moses said the national forest logs bought by Tortorelli were sold and processed in this country. His clients were not aware of any logs with Forest Service markings being exported, he said. The trial before U.S. District Judge Charles Lovell is expected to last at least a week.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Wreaks Havoc in South Pacific, Kills Three
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Ofa battered several South Pacific island groups with winds up to 115 mph before blowing out to open water today. Relief officials said three people were killed and hundreds left homeless. In a three-day run across the islands, the storm whipped up huge seas that washed away homes and its fierce winds uprooted palm trees and blew off roofs. The worst damage was reported in Western Samoa and Niue, about 450 miles to the south. The Australian Associated Press said three people were killed in Western Samoa, which was declared a disaster area by its government. ``People in Western Samoa, like other places of the South Pacific, live a traditional lifestyle under thatched roofs. So when they get a big blow, they get a lot of damage,'' said an Australian official involved in the emergency operation. ``We have reports of severe damage, but our information so far is that ... there is little loss of life,'' said a Foreign Ministry official in Canberra, the Australian capital. Both officials spoke on condition of anonymity. The Foreign Ministry official reported major damage in Western Samoa, where 170,000 people live on the islands about 1,700 miles northeast of New Zealand. There were sketchy reports of damage and injuries in the island nations of Niue, Tuvalu, Tonga, Wallis and Futuna, and Tokelau. Australian Foreign Minister Gareth Evans said Tonga as well as Wallis and Futuna had been hit badly. In American Samoa, at least two thirds of the U.S. territory's 38,000 residents were without water because a power outage caused the storm. Niue, a coral atoll nation of about 4,000 people about 450 miles south of Western Samoa, began cleaning up today. The storm wrecked the island's hospital and forced the evacuation of 50 patients. Homes were damaged and palm trees uprooted while the storm whipped up huge seas, the New Zealand Press Association reported. No deaths were reported there, but a fisherman was injured when his boat smashed onto rocks in heavy seas. Niue's communications with the outside world were ruptured for 18 hours. A few homes in Alofi, the capital, were ``annihilated'' by savage seas, acting New Zealand representive in Niue, Peter Hassell, told the New Zealand Press Association. He said a hotel was damaged beyond repair. Hassell said the capital was still without water and had only limited electricity. Australia dispatched a military C-130 Hercules transport plane with emergency supplies to Western Samoa. The New Zealand Government also promised relief supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein, Young, Launch Gubernatorial Bids; Rizzo Seeks Mayoralty
DOC.TEXT: Former mayors Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco and Andrew Young of Atlanta launched bids for governor of their states, and Frank L. Rizzo said he would try a third time to become a three-term mayor of Philadelphia. Also Monday, Sen. Jim Exon, D-Neb., said he was seeking a third term and four-term Indianapolis Mayor William H. Hudnut said he was accepting the pleas of Republican leaders to run for secretary of state. Feinstein and Young will seek the governorships on the Democratic tickets in races that would be a first in their states for women and blacks if they are elected. The two pro-business politicians said they oppose raising taxes and both will campaign as pro-choice candidates, but from there their styles differ. Feinstein, 56, called her bid a historic step for women. She is an underdog in polls and fund-raising to Democratic state Attorney General John Van de Kamp and Republican U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson in California's June 5 primary. The incumbent, Republican George Deukmejian, is not seeking re-election this fall. Young, 57, has avoided appeals based on race, and continued that strategy in his first official campaign speech. He spoke of a coalition campaign with ``young and old, rural and suburban folks.'' The former ambassador to the United Nations who stepped down as Atlanta's mayor last month after eight years in office leads a pack of five Democrats in a poll conducted by the Atlanta Journal-Constitution last fall. Georgia's primary is July 17 and if no candidate receives 50 percent of the vote there will be a runoff Aug. 7 for the November election. Young sounded campaign themes of progress and education and strove to reassure people outside Atlanta about his ideas and his qualifications. He was a key player in the civil-rights movement and represented Atlanta in Congress from 1973-77. ``I want you to get to know me,'' he said before embarking on a four-day road tour of 17 Georgia cities. ``I think you'll be pleasantly surprised.'' Feinstein launched her candidacy in San Francisco, Los Angeles and Sacramento. At a rally in San Francisco, Feinstein drew the loudest applause when she talked of abortion and the fact she is the first woman to mount a major campaign for governor in California. ``This is a big moment for me, and an historic one for women,'' she said. ``Much thought and deliberation preceded this decision. I am a non-incumbent in a race against two entrenched statewide figures _ a woman in a field of men.'' And on the abortion issue, Feinstein said: ``It's true men can protect women's rights, but it's also true the experiences of men and women are different experiences. I very strongly believe ... with a woman who is governor, I know if she believes in choice, she's not going to have anything to do with any erosion of that basic optional right.'' Young also addressed abortion and said he would push for a state lottery, prmosing ``leadership that will protect a woman's right to choose, and protect your right to vote for a lottery if you so choose.'' Rizzo, who served as Philadelphia's mayor from 1972 to 1980 as a Democrat, lost his latest effort to regain City Hall on the Republican ballot in 1987 when Mayor W. Wilson Goode was re-elected by 18,000 votes. But Rizzo, a former beat cop and police commissioner, said: ``This time they can't beat me. After Wilson Goode in this town, I even get the liberals now.'' When Rizzo squared off against Goode for the second time in 1987, voter turnout was more than 70 percent. Politicians viewed the high turnout, especially in predominantly black wards, as voting against Rizzo, rather than for Goode, whose popularity suffered after the city's violent confrontation with the radical group MOVE in 1985. The election is in 1991. In Indiana, Hudnut, 57, will likely face Democratic incumbent Joseph H. Hogsett. Hogsett, 33, was appointed after Evan Bayh left that office to become governor.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Sues to Keep Women Out of All-Male School
DOC.TEXT: The state's first female attorney general went on the offensive and sued the federal government over its order that Virginia Military Institute accept women. State Attorney General Mary Sue Terry filed the lawsuit in U.S. District Court in Roanoke on Monday less than an hour after the institute voted to uphold its men-only admission policy. The lawsuit asks the court to declare the policy constitutional at the 150-year-old tax-supported school in Lexington. Terry named U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and the Justice Department as defendants in the lawsuit, which came a week after the department threatened to sue the state over the admissions policy. ``This action is filed in order to prevent federal encroachment seeking to enforce unnecessary conformity in the state-supported system of higher education in Virginia,'' the lawsuit said. The Justice Department's finding ``was made without any inquiry into the state interest served by VMI and without any visit to VMI to review first-hand its program of instruction,'' the lawsuit said. ``Women are not denied equal educational opportunity by VMI's admission's policy.'' Terry said women who want a military-school education can enroll in the ROTC program at Virginia Tech, another state-supported university. ``The state-supported system of higher education in Virginia is richly diverse, consisting of both public and private institutions,'' the lawsuit said. After a nearly two-hour closed meeting, VMI's board unanimously approved a resolution affirming the men-only admissions policy at the 1,250-student school. ``We do not believe that VMI's admissions policy violates any provision of law, including the constitutions of Virginia and the United States,'' the resolution said. ``We believe that VMI's academic mission contributes to the diversity and balance of the Virginia system of higher education.'' The Justice Department said VMI's admissions policy violates the 14th Amendment to the Constitution and the Civil Rights Act of 1964. It set a Feb. 20 deadline for the state to respond with a plan for ending the single-sex policy or face a lawsuit. The department will stand by its original plan to sue if the state does not change its mind, said Deborah Burstion-Wade, a Justice spokeswoman. ``We're sticking by our case because we do feel very confident,'' she said. The department investigation was prompted by a complaint from a northern Virginia teen-age girl who had been told she could not apply to the school. Former Gov. Gerald L. Baliles told the VMI board last May that the admissions policy was illegal. He included $160,000 in his proposed 1990-92 state budget to provide barracks for women at institute. His successor, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, has declined to take a position. A bill to force VMI to admit women will come before the Senate Committee on Education and Health on Thursday. But the bill's sponsor, Sen. Emilie F. Miller said she has little indication of much support for the measure. ``Most people are tiptoeing around it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Council Votes Against Sale of Crime Guns
DOC.TEXT: City Council rejected a proposal to sell hundreds of guns confiscated in crimes since 1977 and to use the proceeds to buy new weapons for the police department. ``They tried all kinds of public tricks to get it passed, but it didn't work out, '' said City Council President Ray Denczak. Monday's 7-5 vote came despite an amendment that would have ordered about 350 small, easily concealable ``Saturday Night specials'' destroyed because of questions about the legality of selling them. Some council members worried that the guns might be used again to commit crimes. An affirmative vote would have authorized the guns' sale to the highest-bidding licensed gun dealer. The city tried to sell the guns last year but decided against it when the highest bidder offered only $31,000 for the lot _ about half its estimated worth. The police department has 1,048 confiscated guns in its storage room.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Move to Halt U.S. Chemicals Destined for South American Drug Labs
DOC.TEXT: Federal drug officials are trying to block exports of certain chemicals to 52 Latin American companies because the solvents are being used to process cocaine, a newspaper reported today. The solvents include methyl ethyl ketone, manufactured primarily by Exxon Corp. and Shell Oil Co., the Los Angeles Times reported, citing unidentified sources. The move was authorized under new legislation and targets about one in five of the companies that were regular importers of U.S. industrial solvents, the newspaper said. Disclosures indicating the extensive role of U.S.-originated chemicals in South American cocaine production were scheduled to be revealed today in a U.S. Senate subcommittee hearing looking into such chemical exports, the Times said. The Drug Enforcement Administration's action could force South American companies to turn to European suppliers. U.S. manufacturers argue they double check to make certain their international customers have legitimate uses for the solvents, but a senior official with the Chemical Manufacturers Association said U.S. exports often are diverted to cocaine producers. ``It can happen that products are sold to a customer who seems legitimate and that the product then is diverted into illegal drug marketing,'' R. Garrity Baker, the association's director of international activities, said Monday. The 52 companies were among 288 described as ``regular customers'' for U.S. exports. U.S. officials in Bogota, Colombia, said many of the businesses were fronts for Colombian drug cartels. Regular customer status allows Latin American companies to receive U.S. shipments with less documentation. Removing the status effectively bars them from receiving exported solvents, DEA officials told congressional investigators. The DEA refused to identify the companies. The date of the customer status reclassification was not reported. None of the U.S. exporters affected have challenged the ban. The Times reported earlier that 90 percent of the 13 million gallons of methyl ethyl ketone exported to Colombia last year was believed to have been used in cocaine laboratories. Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev., last week introduced legislation to outlaw export of the chemical. Sen. Richard H. Bryan, D-Nev., responsible for the subcommittee hearing probing the exports, said he will urge the President Bush to bring up the chemical export issue during his drug summit in Colombia. ``This is a serious problem, and there is more that (the United States) can do,'' Bryan said.

DOC.HEAD: Death Warrant Signed Ordering April 3rd Execution of Harris
DOC.TEXT: A judge signed a death warrant against double murderer Robert Alton Harris for what could be California's first execution in 23 years. Superior Court Judge Jesus Rodriguez on Monday ordered the execution for April 3 for the 1978 abduction and murders of two teen-age boys. ``We're really up against the gun now,'' said Michael McCabe, an attorney for Harris, 37. ``There's no question that we've been up and down both the state and federal habeas corpus (appeal) system more than anyone else.'' Harris, one of 273 inmates on San Quentin's death row, was convicted in the 1978 shootings of Michael Baker and John Mayeski, both 16. According to testimony, Harris abducted the boys as they sat in their car at a drive-in restaurant, drove them to a remote area, shot them and then laughed about it as he munched on their unfinished lunch. Last week, Rodriguez denied a defense request to delay setting an execution date. Three previous dates, the last set for 1982, were dissolved during appeals. Charles Sevilla, another defense attorney, said a request for a stay of the latest date would be filed soon with the California Supreme Court. In its fourth consideration of the case, the U.S. Supreme Court last month cleared the way for Harris' execution when it refused to hear his appeal. Sevilla said Harris is aware time may be running out. ``He's understandably frightened of this process,'' Sevilla said. ``But if he has to go, as he's said, he will go to the best of his ability with dignity. It's very difficult when you're about to be killed to go out with dignity, but he's going to try to do that.'' The last person executed in California was convicted police killer Aaron Mitchell, who died in San Quentin's gas chamber in 1967. Sevilla said the most appropriate sentence for Harris would be life in prison without parole. ``An emotional barrier will be broken if there is an execution which, I think, will psychologically open the floodgates to many more to come, and there are about 250 people on death row, so a lot rides on this case,'' Sevilla said. ``I say killing an individual is a very cruel event. It was a cruel event for which Mr. Harris was convicted, and the state is now going to repeat that event.'' Deputy Attorney General Louis Hanoian, who has opposed Harris' appeals for the state, disputed Sevilla's comparison. ``The cruel act was the murder of two young boys,'' Hanoian said. ``They received no trial, no appeal, no mercy. Mr. Harris has had 11 years of due process since he committed these brutal murders and the state can take away his life having given him due process.'' In a telephone interview from prison, Harris told radio station KFMB last week that the killings are ``not something I have relished over. ``I'm very tore up about this. Not only did they die on that day. I did, too.'' The father of victim Michael Baker, police Detective Steve Baker, said he doesn't believe Harris' expressions of remorse. ``He's lying through his teeth,'' said Baker, who added he plans to witness Harris' execution. ``I'm sure he regrets being caught, but that's about as far as it goes.'' Harris' latest appeal to the state Supreme Court includes claims that the death penalty is no longer appropriate because he has reformed while in prison and because he has been under the threat of execution for so many years that to carry it out now would be cruel and unusual punishment. ``We are not attempting to simply delay the inevitable. We feel that there are strong constitutional issues that have to be resolved,'' McCabe said. The state has until Feb. 16 to file its response, and the defense then has 30 days from then to file its rebuttal.

DOC.HEAD: Strangers Help Mother of Five Children Killed in Accident
DOC.TEXT: Contributions of clothes and money streamed in for a woman whose five children were among six victims of a fiery car crash. When the accident occurred Sunday, Marcella England and her boyfriend, Howard Bouchard, both 38, were moving with the children from New York state to Texas, where Ms. England has another daughter. ``I just felt like it was a need for someone passing through the area who didn't have any family and didn't know anyone,'' said Joe Wright, a Southwestern Bell employee who helped raise more than $400 for the couple among active and retired phone company workers. The single-vehicle accident occurred on an icy bridge on Interstate 44 near Mount Vernon in southwestern Missouri. Bouchard pulled Ms. England from the wreckage. They turned back to try to save the children, but saw only the flames engulfing the station wagon. The dead included Ms. Englund's daughters Edna, 16, Clara, 14, Ella, 12, and Virginia, and their 10-year-old brother, Virgil. Also killed was Edna's fiance, Arthur Brown, 20. Ms. England has one child left _ 19-year-old Tammy, who lives in Denton, Texas. ``I wanted to scream and holler,'' Ms. England said Monday night. ``I admit, I cussed at God. But I guess he wanted them for some reason.'' She and Bouchard are staying this week at the Ronald McDonald House of the Ozarks. The house, normally a home for parents of sick children, was pressed into service because the couple had nowhere to go, and no money for bus tickets to northern Texas. Others helping include Melody Esterline, who was working in the St. John's pharmacy Sunday when she heard about the accident. Soon after, she was collecting clothes for the two survivors. ``She decided she needed to do something for this family because they were from out of town and had no local ties,'' said Barbara Wright, a co-worker and Joe Wright's wife. The couple's most pressing need is money, said Bonnie Kellen-Engle, executive director of the Ronald McDonald House. Ms. England said she is grateful. The generosity of strangers won't bring back her children, but they live in her memories. She says Edna was stubborn. She called Clara her veterinarian. Ella was a joker and Virginia had dreams of being a doctor. Virgil, the only boy, was spoiled, but tough. She spoke calmly of her dead children. ``I have to make sure the children are finally taken care of,'' she said. ``There's a job that has to be done _ funeral arrangements in Texas.'' She said she and Bouchard plan to live in Texas. ``I'm going to stay with my children,'' she said. ``I want to be close to them. They're home.''
Donations may be made in care of The First Baptist Church, Malone Street, Denton, Texas, 76201.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Endorses West German's Proposal on Reunification
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New information, editing and reordering throughout to update with U.S. official's remarks on German Reunification; further top prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today embraced as a ``pretty good'' idea a proposal by West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher for reunification with East Germany. A senior U.S. official traveling with Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the French government also seemed taken with Genscher's plan to keep Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but without moving western troops into what is now East Germany. Genscher's proposal also would permit the Soviet Union to keep forces in what is now East Germany, where some 390,000 are now based. How long they might remain is not clear. Baker discussed the fast-moving German situation with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas at a refueling stop in Shannon, Ireland, and then flew to Prague for talks with leaders of Czechoslovakia's ``velvet revolution'' from hard-line communism toward democracy. The U.S. official, who spoke with reporters on condition that his name not be used, said, ``We think that proposal _ in terms of not having NATO forces move farther east _ is a pretty good one.'' The official said one of the virtues of Genscher's plan is that it would maintain Germany in NATO _ a condition set down by Baker on reunification. ``We think that is a very positive contribution,'' the official said. Asked about Dumas' appraisal of the plan, the official said: ``He didn't specifically address that issue, but I'd say from the tone of it, it was positive. He continues to believe NATO has a very positive role'' in Germany. The support given Genscher's approach was noteworthy because, until now, the Bush administration had been noncommittal about the future of the two Germanies. Baker has stressed only the importance of a NATO role and a peaceful evolution. The official acknowledged that developments were moving so rapidly that after East Germany holds national elections next month ``there is an extraordinarily high probability'' that the Soviet ally will be pressing for reunification with West Germany. ``You can expect a very quick process dealing with economic, political and legal aspects between the two German states,'' he said. In Prague, Baker arranged meetings with President Vaclav Havel, the dissident playwright chosen leader of the Central European country in the collapse last December of the Communist Party, and with Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek and leaders of the Civic Forum. He also scheduled a speech Wednesday morning at Charles University before flying on to Moscow to begin four days of talks. Although the Bush administration was withholding an appraisal of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call in Moscow for the Communist Party to release its iron grip on the Soviet Union, U.S. officials subtly voiced support for support for ``political pluralism,'' the likely result if the Communist Party's Central Committee follows through on Gorbachev's initiative. Gorbachev appeared to soften his opposition to German reunification last week and Baker is certain to probe the issue with him and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. France, vanquished twice this century by German military might, is observing with keen interest the quickening course taken toward unification by West German and East German leaders. Baker's 27-hour visit to Prague, meanwhile, is designed to show U.S. support for the smooth transition from a hard-line Communist state to an emerging democracy. Havel is demanding the withdrawal of the estimated 75,000 Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia as part of a complex disarmament scheme that also might require even deeper cuts in American forces in Central Europe than President Bush proposed last week. Bush would set a ceiling of 195,000 on U.S. and Soviet forces in the area. His national security assistant, Brent Scowcroft, said over the weekend that was the bottom line figure. But Havel's plan could put pressure on both the United States and the Soviet Union to go further. Baker, meanwhile, is ready of offer Czechoslovakia economic support, beginning with a lowering of U.S. trade barriers. Last month, Prague asked for readmittance to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund after a 35-year absence. But according to government officials, it is more in need of expert advice than credits. In his speech Wednesday, Baker is expected to register U.S. support for Gorbachev's proposal for a 35-nation summit meeting later this year. The idea is to reduce East-West tensions even further. Baker is likely to stress a need also for more action on human rights by the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Friends Remember Woman
DOC.TEXT: Friends gathered at a diner to pay their respects to a woman known for throwing stale bread to birds and sweeping sidewalks outside neighborhood businesses to earn extra money. Kate Brown lived alone in an apartment on the city's North Side. She died of a heart attack Jan. 29 at age 77. Authorities could find none of her relatives until a niece was located Sunday, the day about 50 people attended a memorial service at Edie's Restaurant. The niece, Margaret Bidek of Indianola, said police officers came to her door to say her aunt had died. Mrs. Bidek said she would come to Pittsburgh to help plan the burial. Many attending the service cried as they recalled Ms. Brown as a feisty, outgoing character who swept sidewalks to supplement her Social Security income. ``I hope Katie has a new broom in heaven,'' said Florence Andrews, who used to work at Edie's. ``I tried to buy her one and she wouldn't take it.'' Edith Schmidt, who owns the restaurant, decided to sponsor the memorial when authorities could not locate relatives.

DOC.HEAD: Former Slovak Politburo Member Hangs Himself
DOC.TEXT: A former high-ranking Communist official ousted during the November revolution for his part in crushing Czechoslovakia's 1968 reforms has committed suicide, the state news agency said today. The body of Viliam Salgovic, 70, was found by his wife hanging in the laundry room of his home in the Slovak capital Bratislava late Monday, CTK said. A preliminary investigation suggested Salgovic acted alone, it added. Salgovic, a former member of Slovakia's Communist party Politburo, was the first senior member of the leadership that crushed reform after 1968 known to have committed suicide following last fall's peaceful revolution. At least two police officers have killed themselves since November, while former Prague Communist party boss Antonin Kapek was hospitalized with severe injuries after trying to shoot himself last month. Salgovic, a longtime member of senior Communist ranks, served as deputy interior minister during the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' reforms of Alexander Dubcek. In this post, he is thought to have controlled the State Security forces and served as Czechoslovakia's link to the Soviet KGB secret police. Zdenek Mlynar, a member of Dubcek's leadership who now lives in Austria, charged in his memoirs of the 1968 invasion that Salgovic served as a virtual Soviet agent. After the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion that crushed Dubcek's policies, Salgovic assumed a series of high offices in Slovakia, becoming a member of the Politburo in that republic and chairman of its parliament. Like all the other senior figures associated with the post-1968 crackdown, Salgovic lost those posts in the November revolt, which ended the Communists' 41-year monopoly on power and installed a coalition government that pledged to organize free elections.

DOC.HEAD: Defector With Doctorates Turns to Groundskeeping
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ffrench in 7th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: After months of combing want ads and finding he was too old or too qualified for academic positions, Romanian defector Paul Petrescu says he was glad to find work as groundskeeper at a country inn. The job, which sometimes means shoveling snow and sweeping halls, might seem like a comedown for a man with two doctorates, five languages and an authoritative knowledge of Romanian folk art. But the 69-year-old defector is happy to have the work. ``It is very healthy exercise,'' said Petrescu, who has doctorates in sociology and political science from the University of Bucharest but now calls himself dean of the eight-man grounds crew. ``I was a soccer player in my time. I feel like I'm on a sports team. We are friends.'' And despite the revolution in his homeland, he plans to stay. Petrescu and his wife, Juliana, decided to try to leave Romania three years ago. The plan was for Petrescu to leave first, establish himself in the West and then send for his wife and son. When he was allowed to join a lecture tour in Switzerland, Petrescu took the opportunity to slip into the West German embassy and was granted a visa through his contacts in that country. But the West German government was reluctant to issue visas for Petrescu's family, so 11 months ago he applied for political asylum in the United States. He came to Stockbridge in the Berkshire hills by way of his friendship with local resident John C. ffrench, who met Petrescu 32 years ago at a traveling Romanian folk art exhibit in India. Petrescu got his job at the Red Lion Inn by answering a newspaper ad last summer, said Betsy Holtzinger, inn general manager. ``He's so intelligent and gifted and yet he is willing to do this work,'' she said. Petrescu does odd jobs, such as shoveling snow and raking leaves in season, and works as a gardener for owners John and Jane Fitzpatrick, Holtzinger said. Petrescu's wife and 20-year-old son have been granted permission to enter the United States and he took a month off at the beginning of this year to arrange for their travel. They are expected to join him soon. Petrescu said he was shocked at the speed with which revolution swept Eastern Europe. In Romania, people took to the streets in December in a fight that led to the execution of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife. ``That was the hope only,'' he said. ``We hoped this for so long time.'' He said that although he has always opposed the death penalty, he did not think the deaths of the Ceausescus were too hasty. ``For 25 years they destroyed Romania, economically and also biologically. The genocide they accuse him of is real. It is not a political metaphor.'' Petrescu doesn't have any immediate plans to return to Romania, saying he would rather stay here and find a way to use his education and knowledge. At the Romanian Folk Art Museum in Evanston, Ill., museum president Rodica Perciali was delighted to hear of Petrescu's whereabouts, although she said it could be difficult for him to find an outlet for his specialized knowledge. ``His books are some of the most important to Romanian culture,'' she said. Petrescu said he recently received good news about his writings, which had been banished after he left the country. ``My son called me. He said, `I was just in the bookstore and your books are back on the shelves,''' Petrescu said.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Calendars Prompt Protest, Distribution For Schools
DOC.TEXT: A lawmaker intends to show Philip Morris Inc. just what a long way consumers have come by sending the cigarette maker's datebooks to classrooms for a lesson in the politics of persuasion. The calendars _ built around the Virginia Slims theme: ``You've come a long way, baby'' _ feature pictures of fashionably and scantily clothed women with cigarettes. Two years ago, state Rep. Anne Seibert collected the calendars and returned them to the company on the grounds they were sexist and promoted a deadly habit. A letter sent by Seibert and 65 other lawmakers calls the books ``demeaning to women, their history and their accomplishments,'' and inappropriate mementos for lawmakers grappling with issues like health care and medical costs. However, Seibert said recently, the materials could inform students about sexism in advertising and about cancer risks with big profit motives behind them. Teacher Carol Barbagallo said she plans to use the datebook to teach Rutland Town Elementary School fifth-graders about drug and alcohol abuse. ``We're looking for healthy children, and a healthy future for children,'' she said. Part of the goal in Barbagallo's 20-lesson program is to look at how advertisers sell the public on a product. The children will clip and discuss ads from popular magazines and look at materials such as the Virginia Slims datebook. ``I call it tobacco humor,'' said Seibert, a Democrat. ``Their theme is `You've come a long way baby,' but they only picture women smoking in various fashion outfits.'' The calendars list what Virginia Slims considers important dates in women's history _ including Aug. 26, 1920, the day women won the right to vote, and the day in 1968 when Virginia Slims were introduced. Seibert said that approach belittles the accomplishment of the women's suffrage movement. A telephone call to Enud Houminer, president of Philip Morris' tobacco division in New York, was not returned. Philip Morris also has sent lawmakers copies of the Bill of Rights, complete with the company name at the bottom. Seibert said these, too, would be sent to Vermont schools, after removal of the ``commercial endorsement (that) defaces the replica of this historic document.''

DOC.HEAD: Two British Reporters Ordered Expelled
DOC.TEXT: The government has ordered two British journalists covering the ban-shattering tour of an English cricket team to leave the country because it disapproves of their reports. Paul Weaver of the newspaper Today and Gareth Furby of Independent Radio News were admitted to South Africa on temporary permits. Home Affairs Minister Gene Louw said both journalists had sent reports ``intended to damage South Africa's image.'' He said Weaver's reports were ``emotionally laden and exaggerated,'' and called Furby's dispatches ``distorted.'' Weaver was given a work permit to cover the visit of the English cricket team touring the country in defiance of an international sports boycott. Louw said that Furby had entered to country under false pretenses, saying he had come to visit friends when he was actually sending out reports on the cricket tour and other events. He said Weaver had filed a report which appeared to be a first person account of police action against anti-cricket tour demonstrators at the Jan Smuts Airport in Johannesburg when the reporter had ``arrived at the scene two hours after the incidents on which he had reported so recklessly.''

DOC.HEAD: New Sex Allegations Against Priest
DOC.TEXT: A second man alleges he had sex with the Roman Catholic priest who founded Covenant House, the nation's largest runaway shelter. Darryl J. Bassile, 31, of Ithaca, claimed the encounters occurred after he had sought refuge as a teen-ager at Covenant House, The New York Times reported today. Roman Catholic church officials are investigating the new charges, the Times said. The Rev. Bruce Ritter denied Bassile's allegations, calling him a ``sick kid.'' On Monday, the shelter conceded that it provided a dead boy's indentity to a former male prostitute who was the first runaway to allege he had sex with the Franciscan priest. Bassile said that in April 1973, when he was 14, he met Ritter after entering a Covenant House branch in Greenwich Village. He said he visited Ritter's apartment to discuss his anguished past and that on his second visit Ritter made sexual overtures. On the third visit, Ritter fondled him and they engaged in a sexual act, Bassile said. He said they had sex several times after that. Ritter said he remembered meeting Bassile briefly, and recalled only one conversation with him in which the teen-ager asked the priest to marry him to a man in a wheelchair. The priest also has denied allegations brought by former prostitute Kevin Kite, who has said Ritter gave him money, housing and gifts in exchange for sex. Kite's father has described his son as an emotionally troubled liar. Prosecutors have confirmed they are investigating whether Covenant House funds were used for Ritter's personal benefit. The organization, founded by Ritter in 1968, manages 17 shelters with more than 2,000 beds in the United States, Canada and Latin America, serving about 25,000 young people annually, making it the nation's largest runaway shelter. Its $85 million annual budget comes mainly from private donations. More questions have arisen with the disclosure shelter officials provided Kite with papers for a new identity. On Monday, the shelter confirmed that the identity was that of a dead 10-year-old boy. Officials refused to say how they got copies of the child's birth records. Covenant House said it had meant no harm to the parents of the dead child, Timothy Warner of Jamestown, who said they learned from a reporter about the use of their child's identity. ``The poor kid's dead. He suffered so. I wish he was still here. And here's somebody going around using his name,'' said the boy's mother, Betty Anne Warner. ``I don't think it's fair.'' Ritter has said he tried to help Kite get off the streets. In December, Ritter said: ``I ... even gave him the name of Timothy Warner on a new birth certificate so that he could get his life started again.'' Mrs. Warner said she and her husband learned of the matter only last week. She said they contacted the FBI and have been interviewed by a New York City prosecutor. Timothy Warner died of leukemia in 1980. It was unclear how Covenant House may have obtained copies of his birth record and baptismal certificate. Only a minor's parents, their lawyer or someone with a proven legal interest can legally obtain birth certificate copies, state Health Department officials said. Mrs. Warner said she has the originals. Stanley Arkin, Ritter's lawyer, said it would be legal to use such records as long as it was not for illegal purposes.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Weather in Northwest; Milder Conditions in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Mild weather continued in the upper Midwest today, while rain and snow fell on the Northwest. A cold front reached across northwestern Montana and California north of San Francisco with clouds, gusty winds and precipitation. Rain turned to snow in the higher altitudes. A low pressure system near the New Mexico-Texas border was expected to move northeast across the southern Plains by tonight, bringing rain or snow to Kansas, Missouri and southeastern Nebraska and Iowa. The western Gulf states looked for scattered showers today. Rain was due in the Ohio Valley and central Appalachinas tonight, with snow possible in West Virginia's mountains by Wednesday morning. On Monday, as much as 10 inches of snow fell in Washington's Cascade Mountains. Up to another foot may fall by today in the Cascades and Olympics. Forecasts call for skies in the Pacific Northwest to clear by Wednesday and for temperatures to sink about 20 degrees below normal. Snow advisories were in effect today for Oregon's mountains and interior southwest. Northern New England also braced for more snow. The lowest temperature in Alaska _ now in its 10th consecutive day of bitter cold, laced with ice and fog _ was 55 below at Fort Yukon. The northern Plains states of Minnesota, the Dakotas, Iowa, Missouri, Kansas and Nebraska basked in their warmest January since regional record-keeping began in 1931. Three Minnesota cities enjoyed record highs for the date Monday: Duluth hit 43 degrees; St. Cloud 45 and Minneapolis-St. Paul 47. Monday's warmest reading was 79 degrees at Jacksonville Beach, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Governor's Wife Returns Home
DOC.TEXT: Kitty Dukakis, wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, has completed out-of-state medical treatment and returned to their Brookline home, a spokeswoman for the governor said. Mrs. Dukakis was hospitalized in Boston in November after drinking a small amount of rubbing alcohol. Earlier she had said she had a drinking problem and had been addicted to diet pills. Spokeswoman Mindy Lubber said Monday night that Mrs. Dukakis was back home and probably would complete a book on her husband's failed presidential campaign, and occasionally accept speaking engagements.

DOC.HEAD: Former Wyoming Governor Dead at 71
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Ed Herschler, a Democrat who won a record three terms in the staunchly Republican state, has died at the age of 71. Herschler died Monday at Laramie County Memorial Hospital after an extended bout with cancer, according to hospital spokesman Dave Hall. Herschler was Wyoming's only three-term governor. A poll in 1986, his last year in office, showed he was the state's most popular politician. In 1986, the Democrats had hoped to capitalize on his popularity by having him seek a fourth term or challenge Republican U.S. Sen. Malcolm Wallop in 1988. But Herschler declined the offers, saying the party needed new blood. Herschler entered state politics in 1961 when he won a term in the House of Representatives after eight years as a county prosecutor. In 1970, Herschler lost his House seat, but returned to claim a surprising victory for governor four years later. Herschler's first term as governor coincided with the mineral industry's rapid growth, which was spurred by world oil prices. He was credited with pushing through the Republican-controlled Legislature the creation of the Wyoming Community Development Authority. During his second term, Herschler supported legislation establishing the framework for the state's water development program and expressed growing concern over federal intervention in state affairs. Herschler garnered nearly half the Republican votes cast in the 1982 gubernatorial election to defeat former Wyoming House Speaker Warren Morton and win his unprecedented third term. But he battled financial troubles during his last term, as the 18,500-acre Yellowstone Ranch, which he co-owned, failed and forced him to file for bankruptcy in September 1985. In his bankruptcy petition, the former governor listed debts totaling $5.9 million.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Seeks $80 Million in Concessions from TWA Pilots
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Inc. chairman Carl Icahn says he will buy new jetliners and expand the carrier's operations if TWA pilots agree to $80 million in wage concessions, according to a published report. Icahn said he needed the concessions because TWA lost more than $200 million in 1989, the St. Louis Sun reported in today's editions. With the lower pilot pay and other savings, he said the airline could break even in 1990. Icahn said in an interview that if the pilots reject the concessions, he will step up plans to sell more of the airline's assets, including marginally profitable routes and some aircraft. Icahn has asked the airline's 3,500 pilots to take a 10 percent wage cut, give up vacation days and make concessions in their retirement benefits _ all worth about $80 million. The request comes three years after the pilots gave up concessions that totaled $500 million. Union officials said Monday they weren't interested in more pay cuts. ``We've given up concessions twice, and both times, he's promised to grow the airline,'' said William Compton, chairman of the negotiating committee for TWA's chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association. ``He didn't live up to his promise in 1986, so we have a hard time believing he's going to live up to his promise'' this time. With more concessions, Icahn said, his long-range plans for the airline would include adding another major hub operation in addition to St. Louis, as well as acquiring another major airline. ``The fate of the airline, whether it grows or shrinks, is in the pilots' hands,'' Icahn said. ``We can shrink the airline or shrink the costs.'' Shrinking the costs will allow TWA to follow through on a plan to acquire up to 100 narrow-body jetliners, Icahn said. Airline analysts have said that one of the keys to TWA's long-term survival is new aircraft. The airline flies the nation's oldest fleet of jets _ the average age is 14.7 years _ and needs to re-invest in new equipment to attract passengers and decrease operating costs, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Warplance Crashes, Second In Two Days
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force A-10 ground attack plane crashed in Wales today, one day after a USAF bomber crashed into the sea off the east coast, police said. West Mercia Police said wreckage was found at Capel-y-ffin in the Black Mountains, about 8 miles south of Hay-on-Wye on the English border. Donald Dick of the 3rd Air Force Headquarters said a search involving helicopters and a mountain rescue team continued for the pilot, the lone crew member. USAF Capt. Raymond Martell said the A-10 was stationed at Royal Air Force base Alconbury, 20 miles northwest of the university town of Cambridge. He said it was reported missing after it lost radio contact. The plane is designed to support troops by attacking enemy tanks and other ground targets. It is highly maneuverable at low speeds and low altitude and can carry a large amount of bombs and ammunition. On Monday, an F-111 bomber with two USAF members crashed over a sea firing range known as Wainfleet during a routine training mission, the Defense Ministry said. The air force said the pilot, Capt. Clifford W. Massengill, 30, Edenton, N.C. was killed, and his body had been recovered. Missing and presumed dead is 1st Lt. Thomas G. Dorsett, 26, of Pensacola, Fla., the air force said. The coast guard at Great Yarmouth today that an air-sea search resumed this morning. ``The aircraft crashed on sand banks in The Wash and a lot of debris has been found,'' a coast guard spokesman said Monday night. The Wash is a shallow bay of the North Sea. The bomber was based at Upper Heyford, near Oxford, 50 miles northwest of London. Upper Heyford is one of two British bases for 84 American bombers, which are capable of carrying nuclear weapons. The F-111s flew from their British bases to mount a 1986 American bombing raid on Libya.

DOC.HEAD: Free Enterprise Legalized in Romania
DOC.TEXT: The interim government is permitting more free enterprise than ever allowed in 45 years of Communist rule under a new decree, but it is for now keeping large enterprises in the hands of the state. ``The development of free initiative ... is meant to improve and develop and vary products and services under free-market circumstances,'' said the National Salvation Front. The front's 11-member executive bureau has been ruling Romania since the bloody December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The decree signed Monday by interim President Ion Iliescu, read on state-run television, will allow privately-owned businesses with up to 20 employees. The law, which takes effect immediately, is aimed at improving the living standards of Romania's population of 23 million by offering a wider assortment of goods and services. In another move to improve living standards, the front announced that the lowest level of pensions for peasants would be increased. The monthly pension of $28 will be doubled, but is still far below the average national monthly salary of $336. During the 24-year Ceausescu dictatorship, basic foods and other commodities became a scarcity, especially in the last eight years when Ceausescu became determined to pay off Romania's $11 billion foreign debt. Ceausescu allowed a very small number of individual businesses to operate, with a maximum of two or three employees. In recent years, however, many shoemakers and tailors had to close because of high state taxes and chronic shortages of material. The interim leadership made clear that it plans to keep Romania's large enterprises _ including steelworks, shipyards and food processing plants _ state-owned at least until the May 20 elections decide who will govern the country.

DOC.HEAD: Archdiocese Excommunicates Rebel Priest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 9, A spokesman, with response planned.
DOC.TEXT: The Archdiocese of Washington says it will excommunicate any Catholics who join Rev. George A. Stallings Jr.'s breakaway African-American Catholic Congregation. The archdiocese announced Monday that Stallings and his followers had been excommunicated over Stallings' public break from the Roman Catholic Church. ``By his public declaration that he has separated himself from the church and by his renunciation of church teaching, Father Stallings has excommunicated himself,'' the archdiocese said in a statement by Vicar General William Kane. ``Any Catholic who would knowingly and willingly renounce his or her Catholic faith to become a full and active member of Father Stallings's congregation would also incur automatic excommunication,'' the statement said. Excommunication, which excludes a person from the sacraments and rights of the church, is the Roman Catholic Church's most powerful weapon against defiant members. The statement said members of Stallings' congregation could resume participation in the Catholic Church only if they go to confession and do penance. Stallings, a dissident black priest, publicly criticized the church's treatment of blacks last summer when he formed his Imani Temple, an independent congregation. He announced his decision to break all ties with the Vatican last week. On Sunday, Stallings said his congregation of several hundred followers would observe new church laws. Women would be allowed to be ordained as priests, he said, and his congregation will allow the practice of birth control and abortion. In addition, he said he would permit ``optional celibacy, which means our priests will be able to decide whether or not they want to marry.'' Stallings will respond to the archdiocese's action in a television interview Tuesday night, said William Marshall, his spokesman. Stallings told The Washington Post last week, ``Suspension and excommunication ... are all political tactics used by the powerful ... to further enslave and oppress the oppressed. Those terms have no meaning or significance to me whatsoever. ... I cannot be cut off from Jesus Christ.'' The last prelate to incur public excommunication was Swiss Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, according to Msgr. John Tracy Ellis, a historian. Lefebvre was excommunicated in 1988 after he consecrated four bishops for a new religious community that rejected the teachings of the Second Vatican Council.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item to fix spelling of `liaison.
DOC.TEXT: Debra Murphree, the former prostitute whose liaison with preacher Jimmy Swaggart rocked an evangelical empire, has signed away three-quarters of the $210,000 that Penthouse paid for her story. Murphree will receive about $54,000 for the article published in July 1988, said Louis H. Schultz, her attorney. Agents, attorneys and the Internal Revenue Service will get the rest. ``She's happy. I talked with her on the telephone,'' Schultz said Monday. Agents and the IRS had claimed they were owed $428,000 by Murphree, who claimed that the Baton Rouge-based TV evangelist was a regular customer in 1987. However, Schultz said their figures were based on inflated estimates of the amount Penthouse owed for the article and a promotional tour and _ in the IRS' $217,000 claim _ for income from prostitution. Murphree told Penthouse that Swaggart paid her $20 a visit to strike prurient poses and perform sexual acts.
