Swaggart tearfully confessed to an unspecified ``moral failure'' and was subsequently defrocked by the Assemblies of God. Layoffs and cutbacks followed at his multimillion-dollar Jimmy Swaggart Ministries.

DOC.HEAD: Regional Party Chief Resigns After Vote of No Confidence
With PM-Soviet-Party
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party leader in the Siberian city of Sverdlovsk has resigned in a growing wave of discontent over regional and local party practices, the newspaper Trud reported on today. The resignation of Leonid Bobykin was announced Monday at a meeting of party activists from the Sverdlovsk region following a six-month campaign to oust him, the newspaper said. He was accused of not acting in the spirit of glasnost, or openness, the report said. Last week, regular party members had charged the Sverdlovsk leadership with anti-democratic policies and passed a vote of no confidence in Bobykin, the Izvestia newspaper reported on Friday. Soviet newspapers and television recently have reported a series of resignations of party officials, including the party leader in the central Siberian region of Tyumen and the leader in Volgograd on charges of corruption. Increasing calls for greater democracy and shortages throughout the Soviet Union of everything from soap to shoes have made the people sensitive to the performance and attitude of party officials.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Gripped By First Epidemic of Children's AIDS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th `Doctors said...' to UPDATE with U.N. agency saying it is sending a team; picks up graf 5 `The Romanian...'
DOC.TEXT: This country is in the throes of the first known epidemic of childhood AIDS caused by contaminated blood and the constant reuse of needles, a French humanitarian organization says. Dr. Jacques Lebas, president of the Paris-based Doctors of the World, on Monday urged the international health community to provide Romania with disposable needles and blood-screening equipment. ``We know AIDS from people who take drugs, homosexuals, and heterosexuals in Africa, but for the first time in the history of AIDS, we are confronted with childhood AIDS,'' he said. ``It's an epidemic,'' he said. ``It's on the level of famine. It's an international emergency.'' Doctors said they do not know how many children have AIDS, but that at one hospital alone 33 of the 45 people who have died of the disease since 1985 were young children. In Geneva, a World Health Organization spokeswoman said the U.N. agency has sent two experts to Bucharest to investigate the extent of AIDS among Romanian children. Spokeswoman Therese Gastaut said the visit, which began Monday and is expected to last about a week, was requested by the Romanian Health Ministry. The Romanian outbreak is unusual because it does not involve the transmission of the virus from mother to fetus _ the manner in which most children around the world are infected _ but from contaminated blood transfusions and needles, he said. ``In the adult population, the incidence of AIDS is very low,'' Lebas said, adding that more than 98 percent of mothers of infected children do not carry the virus. Blood transfusions are routinely used in Romania as a treatment for premature babies, sick children and the thousands of youngsters suffering from malnutrition, he said. But needles are in short supply and are routinely used hundreds of times, encouraging the spread of the virus. Like other East bloc nations, Romania is short of disposable syringes and other medical supplies. Lebas said Romania's AIDS outbreak was considered a ``state secret'' under Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was toppled in a bloody revolution in December and executed on Christmas Day. Last month, Dr. Ludovic Paun of the infectious diseases department at Bucharest's Victor Babes Hospital said 69 people treated there had developed AIDS since 1985, among them 53 young children. He said 33 of the 45 AIDS fatalities so far were children 3 or younger. Lebas did not have updated statistics on AIDS deaths. But he said an initial screening of 1,025 children up to 3 years old at several hospitals and orphanages found 367 with the virus that causes AIDS _ human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. Dr. Ion Patrascu, a researcher at the Institute of Virology, said 60 percent of the 283 children with HIV who are hospitalized have full-blown AIDS. The children in orphanages who tested positive for the virus will be checked this week to see whether they have developed the disease, he said. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims vulnerable to a wide variety of infections and cancers. A person can carry the HIV virus for years without developing AIDS, but almost all cases lead to the disease. Children have been tested in Bucharest, Arad in western Romania, Focsani in the northeast and the southern Black Sea port city of Constanta, where the incidence was very high. Patrascu said tests would be carried out at hospitals and orphanages in Timisoara and other cities this week. ``This outbreak is unusual in the world,'' he said. ``We need specialists to come here from the United States, France, Britain and other countries to decide what to do.'' Doctors of the World signed a contract with the Romanian government on Monday to set up a laboratory in Bucharest to test for pediatric AIDS, he said. But Romania has no money to carry out a proper epidemiological study to determine the real number of AIDS cases in the general population, Patrascu said. ``We hope when the general population is tested, we won't have this result,'' Lebas said. He said he secretly took blood samples in July to test for the AIDS virus in children and was not able to confirm his results until after the revolution, when the French organization took 29 samples to Paris. Patrascu said the contaminated blood came from Romanians, although at first it was thought it came from foreign students. Lebas said one pint of blood from an adult could be used in transfusions for up to 15 children.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks Public Support for Plan to Streamline Pentagon
Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 4 grafs Bush departure, comments; picks up 3rd graf, He was ...; Bush arrives George AFB in Victorville, Calif., 1:40 p.m., arrives Fort Irwin for war games 2:15 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, facing demands from Democrats for steep defense cuts in the wake of the receding Soviet threat in Europe, headed West today on a three-day trip aimed at boosting support for his go-slow approach to streamlining the Pentagon. ``This should be a very good trip emphasizing some of our defense requirements needs and a little politics mixed in,'' Bush told reporters shortly after Air Force One departed Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. Bush plans appearances at fund-raisers for Republican candidates in California, Nebraska and Ohio. ``We'll be doing more of that this year,'' Bush told reporters. He was putting the emphasis on national defense during the official portions of the trip, including his first stop today to address troops and view war games at the Army's National Training Center at Fort Irwin in Barstow, Calif. On Wednesday Bush will visit Livermore Laboratory, the nerve center of Strategic Defense Initiative research where scientists will brief him on the latest development in space-based antimissile technology. His itinerary includes a million-dollar fund-raising dinner tonight in Los Angeles for Sen. Pete Wilson, hoping to succeed fellow Republican George Deukmejian as governor of the most populous state; a speech on defense policy Wednesday before the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco and a visit to Strategic Air Command headquarters in Omaha on Thursday. The San Francisco Bay area is home to five of the bases and military facilities on Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's list of 72 possible base closures or cutbacks _ a list disclosed the same day Bush sent Congress a proposed $292 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991. While Bush said his spending blueprint offers a chance to ``restructure America's defenses'' in the wake of the revolutionary shift toward democracy in Eastern Europe, it envisions troop reductions of only 38,000 in the year ahead and cutbacks in 20 minor conventional weapon programs while seeking $1 billion in new funds for Star Wars research and moving ahead on major weapons systems. After inflation, it amounts to a 2 percent defense cut. Bush also proposed last week to bring 50,000 more U.S. troops home from Europe but did not set a timetable. In any event, those savings would not show up in the 1991 budget. Democratic leaders, including House Speaker Thomas Foley, have said they will press for larger defense savings. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday, ``The Soviet challenge remains very much real. Their strategic buildup is continuing. ... This is not a time to lay down our arms.'' ``The president thinks it's important to talk to the American people about the changes that we're seeing'' in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, Fitzwater said. ``That's the whole reason for this trip _ that our posture is changing and he wants a chance to explain it.'' Fitzwater said, ``The president will stress his continued support for strategic modernization.'' That includes spending billions to put the MX missiles on rails and building the new multi-warhead Midgetman missile. ``Despite the lessening of tensions in many areas of the world, the United States must continue to maintain a robust and credible nuclear deterrent,'' Fitzwater said. Democrats have complained that most of the bases on Cheney's hit list are in districts represented by Democrats in the House. But Fitzwater said, ``For those who are interested in a peace dividend, they're seeing that that's where part of it will come from.'' Bush also will attend a breakfast fund-raiser for Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr in Omaha on Thursday and tour a Head Start facility in Columbus, Ohio, and attend an Ohio GOP dinner that night before returning to the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says U.S. in Excellent Economic Health
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today the United States is in ``excellent economic health'' and will experience ``strong, sustained economic growth'' for the foreseeable future. Bush offered the rosy assessment in the first annual economic report he has submitted. A summary of the message was released at the White House after Bush signed the document at an Oval Office ceremony. The report broadly spells out the economic principles that Bush said will guide his administration. After dispatching the report to Congress, Bush left on a three-day trip to the West in an effort to boost public support for his $292 billion defense budget amid demands from Democrats for steep spending cuts. In his report, Bush said, ``Our excellent economic health will allow us to build on the successes of the 1980s as we prepare for the next century. ``I am confident that the United States can enjoy strong, sustained economic growth and use the fruits of that growth to raise living standards, solve longstanding problems, deal with new challenges and make the most of new opportunities,'' Bush said. The president said that since the end of the 1981-82 recession, the United States has experienced the longest peacetime economic expansion in history, with the creation of 20 million new jobs. ``The containment of inflation during this long economic expansion is a milestone in postwar U.S. history,'' the summary said. ``Despite our successes,'' Bush said, ``we cannot be satisfied with simply sustaining the strong record of the 1980s. We must improve on that record, deal with inherited problems and meet the new challenges and seize the new opportunities before us.'' He said his primary goal was ``to achieve the highest possible rate of sustainable economic growth.'' Bush pledged to try to reduce government borrowing by slowing the growth of federal spending. He said economic growth would raise revenue to balance the budget and then reduce the national debt. He also said he would support ``a credible, systematic monetary policy program that sustains maximum economic growth while controlling and reducing inflation.'' In addition, Bush promised to remove federal barriers to investment, saving and innovation and work to ``avoid unnecessary regulation.'' The president said the United States would ``continue to lead the world to freer trade and more open markets, and to support market-oriented reforms around the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Stockbroker Sentenced to Prison For Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A former stockbroker who bilked his golf buddies, his lawyer, his accountant and others out of more than $2 million has been sentenced to five years in prison. U.S. District Judge Edward F. Harrington on Monday also placed Walter F. Curran on five years' probation and ordered the 47-year-old former broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. to reimburse his victims. Curran, 47, had pleaded guilty to fraud and violating currency transaction reporting laws. He was arrested in 1989 in the disappearance of $2.39 million he had persuaded friends and associates to invest. Defense attorney Robert Cordy said Curran promised eight people, including two golfing companions, interest of 20 percent if they invested in a deferred compensation account in his name. Instead, over the next eight years, Curran invested in the stock market, with some of the money going toward his living expenses. When the market crashed October 1987, he lost his investors' money, as well as much of his own, Cordy said. Curran fled to Canada. He was found to be carrying over $132,000 in cash when he was arrested at the border upon his return. ``He had tried everything, from gambling to long shots,'' Cordy said. ``Eventually when everything came crashing down, there was no way he could continue to juggle the balls and get the money back.''

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Rages in Christian Enclave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with 22 people killed today, calls for cease-fire, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian factions blasted each other with howitzers and rockets today as France tried to halt the ferocious struggle for control of Lebanon's Christian heartland. Police said at least 22 people were killed and more than 50 wounded in the fighting today between troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces militia of Samir Geagea, bringing the overall toll to at least 299 killed and 1,087 wounded. Most of the casualties have been civilians caught in the cross-fire. Aoun's command said its troops had ``crushed the last pockets of resistance'' among the Lebanese Forces in the northern suburb of Dbaye. The Lebanese Forces conceded the loss in a communique, saying its fighters were ordered to redeploy north of Dbaye. It said Aoun's ``hysteric shelling'' transformed Dbaye into ``ruins.'' The Hotel Dieu Hospital, the largest in Christian east Beirut, issued a statement saying its morgue was packed with decomposing bodies, and the situation was worsened by a power failure. ``We find ourselves obliged to bury the victims in a mass grave in Ashrafiyeh Wednesday if no one shows up to collect them,'' the hospital said in a statement broadcast by the Christian Voice of Lebanon radio. The international committee of the Red Cross, French humanitarian minister Bernard Kouchner and Maronite Catholic patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir issued separate calls for an immediate cease-fire. Today's barrages targeted the militia-controlled residential districts of Ashrafiyeh, Jemmayzeh, Karantina and Ein Rummaneh, according to the police spokesman. He said Geagea's gunners were responding by shelling the Aoun-held districts of Sin el-Fil, Furn el-Shubbak, Hazmiyeh and Fayadiyeh as well as the eastern suburb of Baabda, which houses the general' headquarters. Heavy rains helped put out small fires in east Beirut, but palls of thick, black smoke billowed out over the Mediterranean from blazing fuel and cooking gas depots in the Aoun-held Dora district on the northern edge of east Beirut. Aoun's tanks stormed through Lebanese Forces' defenses in Dbaye Monday, achieving the first significant gain in the showdown for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave, which encompasses east Beirut and communities to the north. The thud of shell explosions echoed across Beirut. ``The devil is behind these violations,'' said Archbishop Ronald Abi Nader, a representative of Maronite patriarch Sfeir, who has worked on a series of ill-fated cease-fire attempts. He said representatives of Aoun and Geagea would meet at the Vatican Embassy today. Abi Nader's statement was broadcast by the Moslem Voice of the Nation radio, based in west Beirut. His Catholic sect is the dominant Christian group that has controlled Lebanon's police, military and judiciary since independence from France in 1943. Both Geagea and Aoun are Maronites like President Elias Hrawi. However, Aoun rejects Hrawi's Syrian-backed Christian-Moslem government, while Geagea recognizes it. Hrawi, was elected by Parliament Nov. 24 with a mandate to oversee a peace plan brokered by the Arab League. He fired Aoun as interim prime minister and army commander, but Aoun refused to quit. Aoun rejected the peace accord, an attempt to end 15 years of sectarian civil war, because it fails to guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops from Lebanon. Aoun considers the Syrians, who entered Lebanon in 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate, to be an army of occupation.

DOC.HEAD: Central Florida Hit by Outbreak of Wildfires
DOC.TEXT: Drought and a vegetation-drying Christmas freeze have combined to cause central Florida's worst spell of wildfires in five years, officals say. Polk, Hillsborough and Pinellas counties, which include Tampa and St. Petersburg, have been hardest hit, with 122 brush fires reported since Jan. 1, almost triple last year's rate. Statewide, 817 fires have scorched more than 20,000 acres. The region south of Gainesville, from Tampa Bay on Florida's western coast to Daytona Beach on the Atlantic coast, is considered a high-risk fire zone, according to a state index that ranks fire danger as low, moderate, high, very high or extreme. And it doesn't look like any relief is on the way. January's rainfall did not reach the 2.4-inch average. ``Unless we get a lot of moisture very soon, we'll be in a very high fire system and then we'll become extreme,'' said Jim Brenner of the state Division of Forestry in Tallahassee. The Christmas freeze provided much of the fuel for the fires by killing large amounts of vegetation. The drought could bring a repeat of last year's springtime fires that blackened large sections of the Everglades. ``It may be even worse this year,'' Brenner said.

DOC.HEAD: Reformers Say Gorbachev's Proposal Not Radical Enough
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-10, `The 69-year-old ...bloc nations' with five grafs to UPDATE with Siberian leader resigning, Tass report on speakers at today's meeting; picks up 11th pvs: On Monday... ^By ANN IMSE
DOC.TEXT: Liberal Communist Party leaders today attacked Mikhail S. Gorbachev's daring plan for ending the party's monopoly on power as not radical enough to solve the country's pressing problems, participants said. But Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, a hard-liner, called for a careful review of the Soviet president's proposals to fundamentally alter this nation's system of government. Gorbachev on Monday opened a pivotal session of the Central Committee by proposing the party abandon its monopoly on power and be forced to compete with other parties for the right to lead the country. Some speakers at today's Central Committee session criticized the platform, saying it was ``based on old dogmas,'' said Alexander Fomin, a coal miner invited as a guest to the meeting. ``There were not enough radical proposals to solve the party's problems,'' Fomin said, summarizing today's debate he offered during a break in the closed-door session. He did not detail the objections, and the Soviet media carried no details of today's session. Another participant, Gen. Igor I. Kurenoi, said Ligachev, who last week came under attack in a newspaper for his conservative views, called in a speech for reviewing Gorbachev's proposals carefully. Libachev also pointed out shortcomings of the leadership's policies but did not propose solutions, Fomin said. The official news agency Tass said 16 people spoke today, including Ligachev and several other Politburo members. Gorbachev, as expected, is in the middle of an intense struggle between progressives and conservatives over whether to completely abandon the centralized system of government in favor of a multiparty political system with a more capitalist economy. The session has taken on crisis proportions because of the worsening Soviet economy and a rise in ethnic unrest throughout the country. It comes on the heels of a breathtaking series of revolts against old orthodox socialist governments in six East bloc nations. Meanwhile, the Communist party leader in the Siberian city of Sverdlovsk resigned because he refused to embrace reform, the newspaper Trud reported today. Last week, party members had charged the Sverdlovsk leadership with anti-democratic policies and passed a vote of no confidence. Soviet media have reported several resignations of party officials. Increasing calls for greater democracy and shortages throughout the Soviet Union have made citizens more sensitive to the performance party officials. On Monday, Gorbachev told the party's policy-making Central Committee that by letting outmoded ideas govern their policy, socialist countries had during the 20th century isolated themselves from ``the general flow of civilization.'' But his proposal met with stiff resistance in the largely conservative 249-member body. One participant said committee members did not applaud Gorbachev or anyone else on the first day of the two-day closed session. Speaking confidently just days after rumors swept the world that he might step down as party chief, Gorbachev on Monday presented a new political program for the Communist Party based on a bill of rights. ``Man and his well-being are put in the center of the party's policy from now on and forever,'' he said. The speech, released later by Tass, did not detail the rights he wants to enshrine in the party's platform. Gorbachev did not suggest that the party give up efforts to lead the country. Instead, he said it ``intends to struggle for the role of ruling party, but strictly in the framework of the democratic process, rejecting any kind of legal or political advantage.'' At some point, he said, growing pluralism ``can lead to the creation of parties.'' Gorbachev called for an end to a tenet of Leninism called ``democratic centralism,'' which demands strict allegiance by the party's 20 million members to decisions made at the top. He said the party's views on managing the economy and the government should no longer be pressed on Soviet society. The Communists have been widely assailed for the dismal state of the economy and for widespread abuses of power. Gorbachev acknowledged that the country, which suffers severe shortages of consumer goods, has not seen any fundamental improvement from the economic reform program he has championed since coming to power in 1985. He said key obstacles to those changes were old attitudes and the failure to reform prices. Transcripts released by Tass indicated Gorbachev underwent immediate, stinging criticism. One committee source said Leningrad party chief Boris Gidaspov, who has become a lightning rod for conservatives, demanded the establishment of strict law and order. The Soviet ambassador to Poland, Vladimir I. Brovikov, told the committee that democracy without discipline is unthinkable because it leads to chaos, Tass reported today. In his speech, Gorbachev advocated a stronger presidency for the Soviet state, according to Svyatoslav Fyodorov, a participant in the meeting. Many people think he hopes eventually to step down as head of a no longer supreme Communist Party and find a new power base as president with the support of elected legislative bodies. Participants said they expected easy approval of Gorbachev's proposal to drop Article 6 of the constitution, which guarantees the Communist Party the leading role in society. Final approval for the plaform would come at the next party congress, which Gorbachev suggested moving up to June or July from the fall. A new Central Committee is expected to be seated at the congress, giving Gorbachev the opportunty to remove aging hard-liners and replace them with supporters. He also said the Central Committee would meet again in about a month and consider creating a smaller, nearly full-time Central Committee. Voters are expected to soundly reject Communist candidates in local elections this spring and Gorbachev clearly wants to move quickly to reform the party before it loses more credibility. Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov acknowledged Monday that the country already has moved toward a multiparty system, with alternative parties cropping up in many places. Such parties have been active in the Baltic republics and in the southern Caucasus, where Gorbachev sent troops last month to put down a nationalist uprising in Azerbaijan and quell ethnic rioting. More than 1,000 people, including 100 non-voting members of the Central Committee, military district commanders and local party and government officials attended the meeting, a participant said.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. School Board Approves Year-Round Calendar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with coment from parent, board member; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `Board members ...'
DOC.TEXT: All Los Angeles students will have to go to school year-round by 1991 to ease overcrowding in the nation's second-largest district. In a four-hour session marked by name-calling and shouting, the Board of Education voted 4-3 Monday to put all schools now on traditional schedules _ nine months of class and three months' summer vacation _ on a full-year calendar. Nearly 100 schools already follow year-round schedules, under which students go to school for three months, take the following month off, and so on, for the rest of the year. About 500 schools are on regular schedules. The vote was met by opposition from hundreds of parents who feared children in the same family would be placed on varying schedules, making coordination of baby-sitting and vacations troublesome. ``I think this is going to drive us more toward a two-tiered education, where you have folks in private school and the people in public school are there because they don't have the money to go to private school,'' said Pam Bruns, a leader of a parents group in the affluent Pacific Palisades area. The Los Angeles district, which ranks behind New York City's with 610,000 students, becomes the biggest in the nation to move to year-round classes. The plan, endorsed by Superintendent Leonard Britton, would increase the district's student capacity by 62,000 in the next two years. ``It's very difficult because each of our areas has different problems, different points of view,'' board member Julie Korenstein said. ``At the same time, we have a district that's incredibly overcrowded and we have to come up with some way out.'' Board members Rita Walters and Leticia Quezada argued that the plan unfairly targets minority students attending overcrowded campuses. About 95 percent of those students already attending year-round schools are minorities, Quezada said. But only 16 percent of the first batch of students slated to convert to a year-round schedule are white, she said. ``Sometimes we try to ignore reality, and the reality is it is a racial issue,'' she said. ``Whether or not you want to accept it, it is a racial issue.'' The plan requires all public schools on traditional schedules to submit plans for year-round classes in time for the 1991-92 school year. Each school will be free to stagger its schedule, with some grades in class and others on vacation, so that the building is in continuous use. The superintendent had called for 109 schools with severe overcrowding to adopt a year-round schedule by July. But the board voted to give those schools until July 1991 to make the conversion. Members acknowledged that adopting a continuous calendar district-wide could set a precedent for other urban school systems. ``The time had to come when the issue has escalated to what it is today,'' said board member Roberta Weintraub. ``As Los Angeles goes as a school district, so goes the nation.''

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agents Investigating Mail Bombin Look For Buyer of Typewriter
DOC.TEXT: The FBI is poring over lists of auction bidders in a search for the manual typewriter linked to two mail bombings. ``We are no longer conducting large-scale searches, but we're still there in pretty substantial numbers,'' FBI agent Tom Moore of Birmingham said Monday of the investigation of the mail-bomb slayings of a judge and a lawyer. Federal agents believe the typewriter was used to write threatening letters sent by the bomber. Following a list of registered bidders, agents Monday began tracing typewriters sold at auctions at the nearby Fort Rucker Army base and looked over three typewriters at a piano store. Store manager Dean Powers said FBI agents were interested in typewriters bought at auction at Fort Rucker. He said the agents examined one electric typewriter and two manual typewriters but did not remove them from the store. The mail bombs exploded in December, killing 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance near Birmingham and lawyer Robert Robinson of Savannah, Ga. During the past two weeks, scores of agents searched homes, businesses, a lake, schools, a trash dump and even septic tanks in a hunt for the typewriter. The FBI probe in Enterprise has focused on a junk dealer, Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, and print shop operator Brian Joseph Fleming, who has been indicted in a separate case on charges of trying to illegally export firearms. Ken Holder, a Fort Rucker spokesman, said typewriters are sold at periodic auctions on the base. He said that O'Ferrell was a registered bidder at the auctions but that anyone who has a junk business probably would show up at the bidding. ``I can't locate whether he purchased anything,'' the spokesman said. O'Ferrell said he had been to at least three sales at Fort Rucker and had purchased typewriters. He has denied any knowledge of the bombings. He came under scrutiny because he had an employment compensation case that he lost on appeal before a three-judge panel of the 11th Circuit, including Vance, and because of alleged similarities in O'Ferrell's typed correspondence and letters apparently sent by the mail bomber. O'Ferrell last week acknowledged that he used at least four typewriters in filing his own legal documents with the 11th Circuit, but he said the one agents looked for at his business could have been sold. In Atlanta on Monday, about 200 judges, lawyers, friends and relatives of Vance passed through tight security to attend a memorial service in a federal courtroom a few feet from Vance's chambers.

DOC.HEAD: Army Starts Sealing Palestinian Homes to Punish Rock Throwing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with Sharon calling for Egypt to be excluded from peace process; CORRECTS in 2nd graf that civilian, sted troops fired on rock throwers; picks up 5th pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers sealed rooms in two Palestinian homes today in a new army policy that lets authorities close all or part of houses where residents are suspected of hurling rocks at troops. Another Palestinian was reported killed today when a civilian opened fire on rock throwers who attacked his truck in the West Bank. Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, leader of a hard-line faction in the right-wing Likud bloc, called for Egypt to be excluded from Middle East peace efforts, saying it backs the Palestine Liberation Organization. His spoke as bereaved families buried victims of a weekend bus attack outside Cairo. Egyptian authorities said they were searching for two Palestinian suspects in the attack, in which nine Israelis died when their tour bus was raked with gunfire and grenades. The new policy on sealing homes, which could affect hundreds of families in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, drew immediate criticism from civil rights groups and liberal politicians, who said the measure amounted to collective punishment. In the nearly 26-month-old uprising, the army has razed or sealed hundreds of homes to punish Arabs suspected of fire bombings or serious attacks. But the penalty was not used for stone throwing, the most common tactic of teen-agers at the forefront of the uprising against Israeli occupation. In Nablus, Mustafa Abed Kulab, 45, was fatally shot in the neck, Arab reports said. The reports initially said Kulab was shot by Israeli soldiers, but later reports indicated he was shot by an Israeli driver after his fuel truck was stoned. The army confirmed the death but said its troops were not involved. Kulab's death raised to 652 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began in December 1987. In addition, 181 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died. The new house-sealing policy was announced by Col. Ahaz Ben-Ari, the army's legal adviser for the West Bank. He said it was necessary because of ``the danger of stone throwing.'' ``Because this phenomenon is still deeply rooted and, lately to our great regret is on an increase, it was decided to widen this sanction for this phenomenon in an attempt to quell it,'' Ben-Ari told Israel radio. According to army figures, at least 395 houses have been demolished or sealed since the uprising began. Al Haq-Law in the Service of Man, a Palestinian group that monitors human rights abuses in the territories, puts the total at 550 or more. As Ben-Ari was announcing the new rules, the army said that troops had sealed rooms in two homes of suspected stone throwers. They included a house in Nablus, where a family member is accused of shattering the windshield of a car and injuring the Israeli driver, and another in Qalqilya, where a stone thrower injured a border policeman, army reports said. In each case, one room was left open for the families. The new rule was immediately challenged by Parliament member Dedi Zucker of the left-of-center Citizens Rights Movement. Zucker described the policy as ``another escalation of the circle of hate'' and said it constituted ``punishment without trial.'' Khaled Batrawi, Al Haq's specialist on house demolitions, said the demolitions and house sealings are illegal. They constitute collective punishment that is prohibited by international law, and they violate the 4th Geneva Convention.'' The 4th Geneva Convention, which Israel signed, protects the rights of civilians during war and under occupation. The United States and international human rights groups also have repeatedly criticized demolitions and sealings, noting the action almost always takes place before the suspect is tried.

DOC.HEAD: Author of 1980 Malathion Safety Report Disavows Findings
DOC.TEXT: An author of a 1980 state study used to defend the spraying of a Medfly pesticide now says his findings were edited to understate the danger to humans. Marc A. Lappe, professor of health policy and ethics at the University of Illinois, said Monday that he found that malathion could cause six extra cases of cancer for every million people _ a figure later reduced to one additional case. Lappe said in an interview with the Los Angeles Times that his findings indicated the health risk from malathion spraying is six times greater than what the report officially concluded. He said he resigned in 1981 because of the changes. ``The public has been ramrodded into accepting this without their basic right to have a full airing,'' Lappe said. ``It could be quite dangerous to infants, the elderly and the infirm.'' However, Ephraim Kahn, Lappe's supervisor at the state Health Department in 1980, said that the original findings had been based on false assumptions that the chemical could cause cancer and on overly negative presumptions that children would be drenched with it during night spraying. ``The implication that his numbers were changed to hide some serious effect is just ridiculous,'' Kahn said. State health researchers used worst-case probabilities in the 1980 report to be on the conservative side, Lappe said. Lappe's public reversal bolstered claims by malathion opponents that repeated aerial pesticide sprayings aimed at Medflies could cause illness among residents in affected areas. Lappe has filed an affidavit in support of a lawsuit brought by the Orange County cities of Garden Grove, Huntington Beach and Westminster to stop the aerial pesticide missions against the crop-destroying Mediterranean fruit fly. He did not say why he did not come forward sooner. State officials on Monday announced plans to create a Southern California panel that would study the air and water in spray areas and advise the state on any dangers. The panel will include local health experts. Five helicopters took to the sky overnight on a spraying mission in Glendale, Sun Valley and Burbank. The spraying is going on throughout Los Angeles and Orange counties. Agricultural officials warn that the Medfly in Los Angeles and Orange counties threatens California's $16 billion farm economy. The Medfly lays its eggs in more than 250 kinds of produce. Dr. James Stratton, an epidemiologist with the state Department of Health Services, said the National Toxicology Program determined in a 1985 study that a cancer risk from malathion virtually could not be detected. Researchers at the National Cancer Institute discovered a slightly higher risk of cancer from malathion exposure in rats and mice but reported no significant link between the pesticide and cancer in humans.

DOC.HEAD: Residents, Officials Angry Over Delay in Announcing Leak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th pvs, `It was ...' to UPDATE with comment from manager of injured workers.
DOC.TEXT: A small leak of the chemical that killed 3,500 people in India in 1984 has revived fears by residents of ``Chemical Valley'' that they are sitting on a time bomb. ``This is another Bhopal waiting to happen,'' said Mildred Holt, co-president of People Concerned About MIC. ``We're living in terror.'' Seven workers were injured when methyl isocyanate leaked Friday morning at the former Union Carbide plant along the Kanawha River about 10 miles west of Charleston. The leak was not announced until Monday. The workers suffered burns to their eyes, said plant manager Ron Bearer. Two required hospital treatment and were released. The ounce-size leak occurred as workers were performing maintenance on the methyl isocynate unit at Rhone-Poulenc, which purchased Union Carbide's agricultural products division in 1986. Bearer said the plant did not have to file a report with emergency officials because the leak involved less than a pound of material. He said the incident was considered to be of such little importance that he wasn't notified until hours afterward. ``It was such a minor thing ... the alarm didn't even go outside of the unit. My office is in the middle of the plant, and I wasn't aware of it until today,'' Rhone-Poulenc spokeswoman Bonnie Blashford said Monday. Paul Pribyl, manager for Brown & Root construction of Houston, whose workers were injured, said it is plant policy to notify personnel when potentially hazardous work is being done nearby. ``For some reason it wasn't followed in this instance. There was some sort of breakdown in communications,'' he said. The Brown & Root workers were building a new unit elsewhere in the plant complex. Bob Weser of the state Air Pollution Control Commission said there was no cause for alarm because the material stayed within the plant complex. Others expressed concern about the reporting delay. ``I think we have a problem,'' said Mark Wolford, Kanawha County public safety director. ``Plant officials said the leak was so small they felt it was not in the reportable quantity,'' Wolford said. ``We are still in the process of investigating this and are asking the plant to meet with us.'' The chemical is an ingredient in agricultural pesticides. A December 1984 leak at a nearly identical Union Carbide plant in Bhopal, India, killed 3,500 people. An August 1985 leak of a different chemical in Union Carbide's pesticide plant in Institute injured 135. In that incident, officials were angered that it took the plant nearly 20 minutes to notify emergency services. Chemical Valley gets its name from the more than two dozen chemical plants along a 15-mile stretch of the Kanawha River.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes New Constitution to Allow Multi-Party System
DOC.TEXT: Government leaders have proposed a new constitution that abolishes the Communist Party's 45-year monopoly on power in favor of a multiparty system, an official said today. Stipe Suvar, a member of Yugoslavia's ruling collective state presidency, told a press conference that the new constitution would also regulate ``a procedure'' under which a Yugoslav republic might se| forward by the eight-member presidency will start in the federal Parliament on Feb. 14, Suvar said. He added, however, that ``no one knows'' when the new constitution would be adopted since it needs the approval of all six often factious Yugoslav republics and two provinces to be passed. The proposals come at a time of seemingly irreconcilable differences between the republics. The Communist Party in Slovenia on Sunday broke away from the national party and declared itself independent. The current constitution, adopted in 1974 during the rule of Yugoslavia's Communist founder Josip Broz Tito, granted wide autonomy to the republics and is generally blamed for the country's worst political and economic crisis in history. Parliament earlier this month started began liberal amendments on political activity and free speech to the current constitution proposed by the reformist government of Premier Ante Markovic. The amendments, which also call for Western-style democracy, ``will only facilitate the adoption of the new constitution,'' Suvar said. He said he expected the amendments to be passed in spring, just ahead of the country's first free multi-party elections after World War II, scheduled for April. Yugoslavia's Communists were the first to break with the Soviet-led East bloc in 1948. But the country has been slower in adopting democratic reforms than other East European countries because of deep ethnic and economic divisions. Liberal-minded Slovenia has expressed increasing frustration at resistance to reform by the largest republic, Serbia, and there are increasing indications Slovenians might want to secede from the rest of the federation. ``The new Yugoslav constitution will precisely define the complicated procedure of secession,'` Suvar said, adding that a regional referendum within a republic might become a legal way for it to break off from the rest of Yugoslavia. In Yugoslavia, the federal government is generally responsible for economic policy while the collective presidency, which appoints the premier, dictates defense and foreign policy. But the bulk of political influence in the country is concentrated in the Communist Pparty, with power dispersed in eight often fractious central committees reflecting the administrative division of the country. The government essentially follows guidelines set by the party bodies that must themselves hammer out a consensus before any policies can be implemented.

DOC.HEAD: Gamma Ray Observatory Sent to NASA for November Shuttle Launch
Precede LOS ANGELES
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with observatory's arrival; PICKS UP 5th graf pvs, `The Gamma ...'; DELETES byline.
DOC.TEXT: The $550 million Gamma Ray Observatory arrived aboard a giant cargo plane today for liftoff next year on a mission to help scientists unlock the secrets of the universe from high above the Earth. The 17-ton observatory was trucked from TRW Inc. in Redondo Beach, Calif., which built the satellite, to Los Angeles International Airport on Monday. It was flown aboard an Air Force C-5A to the Kennedy Space Center. It is scheduled to be placed in Earth orbit in November by space shuttle Atlantis, and will be the heaviest spacecraft ever deployed by a shuttle, said TRW spokeswoman Montye Male. The Gamma Ray Observatory is the second of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Great Observatories, which the agency says will help scientists understand the birth and structure of the universe, and the origin and evolution of stars, planets and life. The first Great Observatory is the Hubble Space Telescope, which is scheduled to be launched from space shuttle Discovery in April. The others are the Advanced X-ray Astrophysics Facility, which is to be launched from a shuttle in 1997, and the Space Infrared Telescope Facility, scheduled for launch from a rocket in 1999. Each of the observatories will detect a different form of electromagnetic radiation: visible light, gamma rays, X-rays and infrared light, which is heat. The Hubble is an incredibly powerful optical telescope that will look back almost to the beginning of time to study light from stars and galaxies. The Gamma Ray Observatory will be equipped with four detectors to spend two to eight or more years studying gamma rays emitted by various processes in space, including the ``big bang,'' which is the gargantuan explosion scientists believe created the universe about 15 billion years ago. Gamma rays ``are called the messengers of creation because when the big bang started everything off, gamma rays were emitted,'' Male said. She said the observatory will conduct ``a comprehensive scientific effort to learn more about the origin and fate of the universe.'' ``Through the GRO's instruments, humankind may be able to witness the birth of elements, the death of stars, and discover clues about quasars, pulsars and black holes,'' she said. Most of the elements that make up Earth and all living things were created by the death of stars in fiery supernova explosions. Pulsars and black holes are the incredibly dense remnants of supernovas. Quasars, or quasi-stellar objects, are mysterious sources of vast amounts of light and other energy. The observatory is now 15-by-30-by-15 feet, but once its solar panels are deployed when it is in its 279-mile-high orbit, the observatory's width will grow from 30 to 70 feet, Male said. TRW built the observatory under a $250 million NASA contract. The total cost will be $550 million once its gamma ray detectors are installed in Florida, she added.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Tax Chief Quits Amid Scandal Allegations
DOC.TEXT: Florida's chief tax collector resigned today amid allegations she singled out a political opponent of her husband's for an audit. In stepping down, revenue director Katie Tucker told Gov. Bob Martinez and the Cabinet, ``I emphatically and unequivocally deny that I have ever abused the powers of my office for any purpose.'' Ms. Tucker, 46, has headed the Department of Revenue since June 1988. Martinez and the Cabinet had suspended Ms. Tucker with pay two weeks ago to allow her time to respond to a Florida Department of Law Enforcement report on a 1988 tax investigation of businesses owned by Donald G. Resha. The FDLE found that Ms. Tucker committed no crime but that she personally ordered the probe of Resha, who lost a 1985 election for the state AFL-CIO presidency to her husband, Daniel Miller. Ms. Tucker has maintained she ordered a larger investigation aimed at finding whether video stores like those owned by Resha were failing to pay taxes and whether they were involved in other criminal wrongdoing. Ms. Tucker and her attorney, Barry Richard, told Martinez and the Cabinet that the director could not defend herself against a perception of abusing her office. Ms. Tucker also said she is battling breast cancer and that her doctors said the stress of trying save her $85,292-a-year job could be harmful. ``It's not worth even a moment more of wasted energy on fights that can only hurt me,'' she said. ``The truth will prevail. Regardless of the outcome, you stand up for what's right.'' Last week, the FDLE began a new investigation into possible document tampering. On Friday, FDLE agents confiscated documents and a memory typewriter from Ms. Tucker's office. Ms. Tucker denied tampering with any documents.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first item to UPDATE with no comment from Harper & Row, Abernathy.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who claims the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy implied in his new book that she slept with the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. the night before he was slain has filed a $10 million libel suit. The lawsuit filed Monday in federal court names Abernathy; Harper & Row, the publisher of ``And the Walls Came Tumbling Down,'' and Harper & Row editor Daniel Bial. ``Everyone in Memphis knew that Dr. King had been at my house the night before his assasination,'' Adjuda Abi Naantaabuu, a beautician in the Tennessee city, said in a statement released by her lawyer. ``Dr. Abernathy's book has cast shadows on my character. Even my own granddaughter asked me whether I had had an affair with Dr. King.'' In the book, Abernathy wrote that he awoke for a nap in a woman's livingroom after a late-night dinner on April 3, 1968, to see King and the woman emerge from a bedroom. Calls to Abernathy's home and office went unanswered today. Steven Sorrentino, a spokesman at Harper & Row, said: ``We have not yet been served by a complaint, so we really have nothing to comment on.''

DOC.HEAD: Reilly Says Bush `Responding Well' to Global Warming Issue
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 9 grafs to update with Reilly remarks; picks up 5th graf pvs, Sen. Albert ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's top environmental adviser said today the president is ``responding very well'' to the challenges of global warming despite complaints from environmentalists of inadequate leadership from the White House on the issue. William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, defended Bush's speech to a global warming conference Monday, in which the president called for more research before specific commitments are made to reduce so-called ``greenhouse'' pollution. ``The speech that was delivered was first rate,'' Reilly told a congressional hearing. He said that while he was not directly involved in writing the speech, ``two-thirds to three-fourths'' of the suggestions he submitted to the White House were incorporated in the final draft. The remarks reportedly were toned down by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, who has expressed concern that efforts to reduce global warming might cause severe economic disruptions. ``I think the president is responding very well to the major problem we have'' on the global warming issue, Reilly told the Senate Government Affairs Committee. Reilly appeared before the committee to endorse bipartisan legislation that would elevate his agency to a Cabinet-level Department of the Environment. The Bush speech before the 60-nation Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on Monday was the president's most broad-ranging to date on his views of what should be done about the expected warming of the Earth as a result of increasing pollution, especially carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels. Environmentalists immediately denounced the remarks. ``The was more talk in the speech about economics than the environment,' said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club, calling the president's remarks ``a gross disappointment.'' Sen. Albert: 5th graf pvs.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Demands Talks on Monetary Union With East Germany
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl called today for immediate talks with East Germany on combining their currencies in an effort to stop people from fleeing the economically crippled Communist nation. Kohl made the announcement during a meeting with leading politicians of his Christian Democratic Union and the allied Christian Social Union. He said details will be worked out when East German Premier Hans Modrow visits Bonn next week. Discussions on using West Germany's robust currency to revive, replace or reinforce the comparatively puny East German mark have grown more intense as the Communist country's economy nears collapse. Earlier today, the influential president of West Germany's central bank said it was too early for a monetary union that would make the West German mark East Germany's currency. Deutsche Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl also said he is opposed to the idea of introducing the West German mark as a parallel official currency in East Germany. He spoke to reporters after talks in East Berlin with Horst Kaminski, president of the East German central bank. The East German economy has been crippled by a continuing exodus of skilled workers to West Germany, strikes and abstenteeism. More than 50,000 East Germans moved West in January alone, joining more than 340,000 others who resettled in West Germany last year. East German economic output is expected to drop by between 4 percent and 5 percent this year, the government says. East Germany has asked West Germany for immediate aid of up to $8.8 billion, but a West German spokesman has called the request ``unrealistic.'' East Germans are impatient with the pace of reform and have been drawn to the West by the prospect of earning valuable West German marks instead of the inconvertible East German marks. Poehl said the East German mark would have to be made gradually convertible before monetary reform is achieved. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann was quoted as saying today that the West German mark could become a ``parallel currency'' in East Germany as early as this year, if the East German government is willing to take such a step. Haussmann said the step was needed to stem the exodus to the West, according to the Neue Osnabruecker Zeitung newspaper. But central bank officials have taken a far more cautious approach on monetary union, stressing that major economic reforms must be undertaken first by the East German government. In Davos, Switzerland, Wolfgang Berghofer, mayor of the East German city of Dresden, today proposed making the East German mark convertible as ``the only way to avoid a complete collapse'' of the East German economy. Berghofer said the quickest route to make the East German currency convertible would be to link it to the West German mark at a fixed rate of four East German marks to one West German one. Speaking to reporters, Berghofer said ``hopelessness and desperation'' prevailed in East Germany and warned that the country only has ``a matter of days'' to give its citizens a measure of reassurance to avert an even larger exodus in the spring. Berghofer was in Davos attending an international economic forum. Late Monday, about 100,000 people rallied in Leipzig, with many speakers and demonstrators calling for quick reunification, the official news agency ADN reported. ADN said a group of ultra-rightist Republicans from West Germany joined the rally, marching with their arms raised in the Nazi salute.

DOC.HEAD: Reilly Says Bush `Responding Well' to Global Warming Issue
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's top environmental adviser said today the president is ``responding very well'' to the challenges of global warming despite complaints from environmentalists of inadequate leadership from the White House. William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, defended Bush's speech to a global warming conference Monday, in which the president called for more research before specific commitments are made to reduce so-called ``greenhouse'' pollution. ``The speech that was delivered was first rate,'' Reilly told a congressional hearing. He said that while he was not directly involved in writing the speech, ``two-thirds to three-fourths'' of the suggestions he submitted to the White House were incorporated in the final draft. The remarks reportedly were toned down by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, who has expressed concern that efforts to reduce global warming might cause severe economic disruptions. ``I think the president is responding very well to the major problem we have'' on the global warming issue, Reilly told the Senate Government Affairs Committee. Reilly appeared before the committee to endorse bipartisan legislation that would elevate his agency to a Cabinet-level Department of the Environment. Bush's speech before the 60-nation Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change was the most broad-ranging to date on his views of what should be done about the expected warming of the Earth as a result of increasing pollution, especially carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels. Environmentalists immediately denounced the remarks. ``The was more talk in the speech about economics than the environment,'' said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club, calling the president's remarks ``a gross disappointment.'' Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., a frequent critic of the administration's environmental record, accused the president of ``moving as slow as molasses'' on concerns by many scientists that manmade pollution accumulating in the atmosphere threatens to significantly warm the Earth by the middle of the next century. ``What we're hearing is talk of another year of waiting. I expected a lot more concern about the (global warming) problem,'' said Rafe Pomerance of the World Resources Institute. Bush, speaking to the 60-nation Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said, ``Our policies must be consistent with economic growth.'' He complained that in some areas of the debate over the greenhouse effect, ``politics and opinion have outpaced the science.'' ``Our goal continues to be matching policy commitments to emerging scientific knowledge _ and a reconciling of environmental protection to the continued benefits of economic development,'' the president said, promising to convene a White House conference on global warming in the spring. James Tripp, a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, said Bush failed to demonstrate ``the political will necessary to make the United States a leader in the effort to prevent global warming.'' But Tom Lambrix, head of the Global Climate Coalition, an industry group, called Bush's view of global warming ``an appropriate balance.'' ``We need a better understanding of the economic and social implications'' of dealing with global warming, said Lambrix, director of government relations for the Phillips Petroleum Co. The United Nations-sponsored conference of technical experts is meeting to work on a proposed treaty to deal with global warming. Reilly issued a statement saying the president's remarks ``made clear his determination to lead the world in addressing global climate change.'' Bush does not believe it is ``time for a call to arms'' on global warming, but instead favors continued research, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters after the president's remarks. But many environmentalists argue there is enough scientific evidence to warrant a commitment from the United States and other industrial nations to reduce global warming gases, especially carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels. Scientists fear such an accumulation of manmade pollutants will act like a greenhouse, trapping heat and reflecting it back to earth, causing a warming of the globe. Scientists disagree on how severe the warming will become or its effect, although some scientists predict droughts in some interior regions and coastal flooding because of higher ocean levels. Reducing greenhouse gases would require less reliance on coal, oil and natural gas and would require industry to develop more energy-efficient automobiles and industrial plants _ which industry fears could result in widespread economic disruption.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Appointed Czech Premier
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer forced by the former Communist leadership to work as a gardener after signing a key human rights manifesto was appointed premier today of the Czech republic. Petr Pithart, was named to the job during session of the Czech National Council, parliament of one of Czechoslovakia's two constituent republics. The other is Slovakia. Pithart has been the leader of the Civic Forum, an opposition group considered to be the most influential political force during Czechoslovakia's whirlwind revolution in November that ended 42 years of Communist dominance. Pithart, 49, led the Civic Forum's delegation to all the talks of Czechoslovakia's political parties during the last two months, hammering out the shape of the current political structure in the country. Pithart is a signatory of Charter 77 _ the manifesto criticizing Czechoslovakia's human rights record that because the foundation for the opposition movement. A lawyer, Pithart was a veteran member of the dissident community in Prague under the old leadership. He replaced as Czech premier Frantisek Pitra, who resigned last week as the last of the old-guard Communist leaders. Pitra, 57, was linked to the orthodox Communist leadership that took over after a Warsaw Pact invasion crushed 1968 reforms and was swept from power late last year. However, he survived as Czech premier after revamping his regional government to become the first in Czechoslovakia since 1948 that was not dominated by Communists. The Slovak and federal governments followed suit shortly afterward. Pitra's resignation came Jan. 31, a day after the Communists also lost their majority in the Federal Assembly, or Czechoslovak parliament.

DOC.HEAD: HUD Official Says Department Probably Defrauded
DOC.TEXT: A top Department of Housing and Urban Development official acknowledged today that the federal government was probably defrauded when a New Jersey housing authority gave its director four salaries for four job titles. ``I think that's a reasonable assumption,'' Inspector General Paul Adams told Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., as Congress resumed its investigation of the troubled federal housing system. Lantos, chairman of the House Government Operations employment and housing subcommittee, said the report on the Passaic, N.J., Housing Authority would be a ``starting point for hearings on abuses and mismanagement'' in the use of federal funds by local authorities. ``We happen to be dealing with New Jersey, but we are not singling out New Jersey,'' Lantos said. He questioned how the executive director of the Passaic Housing Authority, Paul Marguglio, could ``find enough hours in the day to perform two full-time jobs and two part-time jobs ... and still have enough time left over to earn $47,115 for time-and-a-half compensatory pay.'' A January audit of the Passaic authority said Marguglio had been paid salaries totaling $245,000 in 1988. A. Paul Kane, the regional inspector general who wrote the report, said Passaic officials defended Marguglio's multiple job titles, saying ``the work has been completed.'' The subcommittee last year heard revelations on the multi-billion-dollar scandal of influence-peddling, fraud and mismanagement at HUD during the Reagan administration. The subcommittee's findings prompted Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to ask a federal court last week to appoint an independent counsel to investigate fraud allegations against Pierce and other HUD officials. On Monday, at the panel's first hearing since October, the former director of HUD's office of insured multi-family housing development refused to testify, becoming the fifth former official to invoke his constitutional right against self-incrimination before the subcommittee. James Hamernick had been questioned about his dealings with another former HUD official, Lance Wilson, once an aide to then-HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. Wilson quit his HUD job to become a housing consultant for an investment firm. In that position, he wined and dined Hamernick. The audit of the Passaic housing authority also outlined nearly $1 million in unacceptable agency expenses. Passaic housing officials maintain the HUD office in Newark, N.J., approved their budgets and was aware Marguglio held multiple job titles. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp on Jan. 22 suspended Marguglio and four other Passaic officials after the audit was released. Kemp also authorized a strike force to examine housing authorities across New Jersey. Marguglio and his wife declined an invitation to testify at today's hearing. If they do not agree to appear voluntarily at a second session, the subcommittee will consider subpoenaing them, said congressional aides. Three of Passaic's suspended housing officials _ August C. Michaelis, chief counsel to the agency; Peter Marrocco, the authority's chairman, and William P. Scruggs, the board's vice chairman _ declined to testify today but may be willing to appear later, Lantos said. A federal judge in Newark last week gave HUD control of the authority, allowing the federal government to temporarily oversee its operations and protect its records. At the same time, three of the suspended officials filed papers seeking reinstatement.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney, Powell Defend Military Budget
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOP 8 grafs new with comments from Aspin, Cheney, Aspin, Powell; picks up 2nd graf pvs, The defense.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee charged today that the Bush administration's $292.1 billion defense budget fails ``to match the new political realities at home or abroad.'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said the administration's argument that it needs a modernized force to get a U.S.-Soviet agreement on reducing strategic weapons no longer holds true. ``You can get an arms control agreement without a robust'' strategic budget, Aspin said, noting economic pressures in the Soviet Union to reduce defense spending and congressional opposition to the administration's proposed increase in strategic programs. But Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said that without a strong strategic budget, the United States might get a poor agreement that would not serve its best interests. ``This administration's approach reflects old thinking rather than these new realities,'' Aspin said. ``The problem is the budget doesn't match the political realities at home or abroad.'' In their third appearance before a congressional panel in less than a week, Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, defended the administration's budget against charges that it is a poor response to the tumultuous changes in Eastern Europe and the diminishing Soviet threat. ``The notion that it is not responsive to the changes does not hold up,'' Cheney said. ``There is new thinking in the Pentagon,'' Powell said. The defense secretary said Monday the Bush administration's plan to modernize its strategic forces, reduce troop levels in Europe and cancel some 20 conventional programs ``preserves the elements of what we think is essential in terms of protecting the nation's security.'' The budget proposal for fiscal 1991 would allow the United States to look back in a decade and say, ``we did in fact undertake a build-down, a careful, orderly restructuring of our forces,'' Cheney told the Senate Budget Committee. Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee targeted the administration's call for an increase in funds for several big-ticket, strategic weapons, including the B-2 stealth bomber, the Strategic Defense Initiative and the two land-based, nuclear missiles. ``I think you're behind the power curve with regard to world events,'' Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Budget Committee, told Cheney. The Democratic chairman questioned why the administration wants to raise spending on SDI by nearly $1 billion to $4.5 billion, and spend $5.5 billion for five B-2 bombers and $2.8 billion for the multiple-warhead, rail-garrison MX missile. The president's budget also includes $202 million for the single-warhead, Midgetman missile. ``Why don't we wait and see what kind of world we're going to be living in in a very short period of time rather than going ahead and committing ourselves to these programs?'' Sasser asked. Cheney said the Pentagon is reviewing the strategic programs and will decide later whether to scale them back. ``I inherited all these systems,'' Cheney said. ``That's what Congress approved at the recommendation of the administration. You have to look at each one on its merits in terms of deciding.'' Sasser suggested that perhaps the administration should ``push these programs off until your review is completed.'' But a Republican on the panel, Sen. Warren Rudman of New Hampshire, took a different approach, suggesting that an additional increase in strategic modernization might be in order. ``When you have that kind of instability, you don't drop your guard,'' he said. The administration also came under attack from some Democrats for the president's plan to reduce forces in Europe to 225,000, a cut of 80,000 from present levels. Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., said further reductions in troops could result in considerable savings for the United States. ``I don't think we can continue to afford maintaining, nor should we, nor do I think the threat as it's now radically changed requires us to maintain anything like 200,000 troops in Europe,'' Riegle said. Cheney backed the president's total and said the only way to realize significant savings would be to remove divisions and demobilize forces. ``Simply bringing home a unit from Europe and base it in the United States, you don't save very much money,'' he said. Riegle interrupted: ``You do save some money. You keep the money in the country. You fellas don't seem to understand it.''

DOC.HEAD: Rural Laborers Need Licenses to Work in Cities
With AM-China-Economy
DOC.TEXT: The government will require rural laborers seeking work in the cities to obtain licenses, in an effort to stem rural migration and counter rising urban unemployment, a Labor Ministry official said. Vice Minister Li Peiyao said people from rural areas must have a license from a labor department and a temporary residence permit from police before being allowed to take city jobs, the official China Daily said Tuesday. Li said the measures were aimed at preventing a mass exodus of rural laborers from further burdening overcrowded urban labor markets. China officially put urban unemployment at about 3 percent at the end of 1989, up from 2 percent a year earlier as a government austerity plan halted construction projects and slowed down the economy. A year ago, millions of rural unemployed flocked to cities looking for scarce jobs in construction and factories, contributing to rising health, crime and housing problems. More than 2.5 million converged on Canton alone. China has always required people seeking work in the cities to have residence permits, but the regulation was often ignored in the past when the fast-growing economy created a need for millions of peasants to fill manual labor jobs in urban industries. The nation's ``floating population'' of rural people moving in and out of cities has been estimated at 100 million. The official Guangming Daily reported Monday that 10 million peasants had returned home recently as the austerity program and a sharp economic downturn left them without jobs. It said many had gone to work on water conservancy and other rural public works projects, although millions more probably returned to farms, which are plagued by a surplus of workers.

DOC.HEAD: Tribesman Killed During U.S. Artillery Practice
DOC.TEXT: A Negrito tribesman scavanging an artillery range for spent shells was killed during a live-fire exercise by U.S. Marines, officials said Tuesday. The body of Ben Fapauan, 23, was discovered Monday about 4,500 yards inside the boundary of the Wild Horse Creek training range in Zambales province, about 70 miles west of Manila, according to a Philippine military report and the U.S. Navy at Subic Bay naval base. Preliminary reports from a joint Philippine-U.S. military panel found that Fapauan was an ``unauthorized scavenger who intentionally evaded range safety personnel and hid from range safety observers during a scheduled live-fire exercise.'' Fapauan was last seen Sunday when he entered the range to collect spent shells and unexploded projectiles, the Philippine military said. The shells are sold as scrap and the projectiles are sold to fishermen. A search was conducted when he failed to return Monday, and his body was found with multiple wounds inflicted by a 105mm howitzer cannon, it added. It added that residents had been warned about the practice two weeks ago. An investigation is continuing.

DOC.HEAD: Imperial Poetry Party Commemorates Late Emperor
DOC.TEXT: A 1988 poem by Emperor Hirohito was read Tuesday at an imperial poetry reading party, the first since his death in January 1989. Such parties are an annual New Year fixture, but the 1989 party was canceled because of Hirohito's illness, and the 1990 party was postponed because of a one-year mourning period following his death. The 31-syllable traditional tanka poems were on the theme ``fine weather.'' Hirohito's described the scenery around an imperial villa in Nasu, northeast of Tokyo, where he stayed in the summer of 1988. The 87-year-old emperor fell ill in September 1988 with cancer. A poem by his son, Emperor Akihito, told of maple leaves turning red in the changing season as he visited his ailing father. Prince Aya, second son of Akihito, wrote of early morning winter fog at Oxford University in Britain, where he is attending school.

DOC.HEAD: Kennel Fined in Beagles Suffocation Case
DOC.TEXT: A magistrate Tuesday fined a British kennel $22,100 for the deaths of 79 beagles it was shipping to a Swedish pharmaceutical firm. The dogs suffocated in a truck trailer aboard the ferry Tor Britannia in the North Sea on Sept. 5. Perrycroft Farm Kennels, which breeds animals for scientific research, had pleaded guilty to two charges of causing unnecessary suffering to 100 beagles during the 24-hour ferry trip from Harwich, England to Goteborg, Sweden. The 8-month-old beagles were being shipped to the Astra pharmaceutical company in Sodertalje, south of Stockholm, for use in testing drugs, said Astra spokesman Staffan Ternby. Five hours after the vessel left Harwich the truck driver, Henry Stevens, found that only 21 beagles were alive, and 10 of them unconscious. The temperature in the container was 95 degrees Fahrenheit, Swedish police said. The British Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, which prosecuted the kennel, said the trailer was nearly airtight and unsuited for animals. The company denied a charge of loading the beagles in a vehicle inadequate for transporting them. A further charge is pending against Monock Freight, which provided the truck. The 21 surviving beagles were placed as pets in Swedish homes, Ternby said. The dogs were spared after the West German newspaper Bild-Zeitung appealed to readers to call the company in protest. The animals usually are given lethal injections after 18 months of observation on the side-effects of experimental drugs, Ternby said. Astra specializes in drugs for the heart, stomach and the central nervous system.

DOC.HEAD: Inefficiency Threatens China's Economic Retrenchment Policies
DOC.TEXT: Inefficiency, waste and poor returns are threatening China's policy of making large state-run industries the vanguard of the nation's economic development, an official report said Tuesday. The government report, quoted in the official media, sounded one of the first notes of pessimism about a three-year retrenchment program aimed at reviving central controls, giving priority to state-run industries and slowing down market-oriented reforms. Per capita productivity rose only 1.6 percent in 1989, compared with 9.3 percent in 1988, while wages increased 14 percent and bonuses 23 percent, according to the report. Production costs of state-run industrial firms covered by the central government budget jumped 22.4 percent, a result of rising wage and material bills, and 19 percent of state-backed enterprises were operating in the red, compared with 13 percent in 1988. The State Statistics Bureau said taxes and profit turnover from state-owned industry rose only 0.2 percent in 1989. The Communist Party's official People's Daily quoted Finance Minister Wang Bingqian as saying the retrenchment program started in 1988 must increase economic benefits. ``If in the course of rectification economic benefits still do not rise, then you cannot say the aim of rectification has been completed,'' he said. The official China Daily, in a commentary, noted that if efficiency in large state-owned firms continues to erode, ``no matter how the government adjusts, the economic retrenchment program would fail to achieve its purpose.'' The government, led by conservative Premier Li Peng, has insisted China won't veer from its socialist system relying on state-run enterprises and giving only a supplemental role to collective and private businesses. But the figures showed that state firms, long-troubled by inefficiency, surplus labor forces and poor management, are costing the state a huge amount of money. Finance Vice Minister Chi Haibin told the weekly Beijing Review the government must budget $19 billion a year to cover business losses and subsidies, about one-third of annual financial expenditures. The China Daily quoted a Chinese Academy of Social Sciences economist as saying industrial efficiency has been declining since 1985, and that in 1988 enterprises' contributions to state revenue was only 20.63 percent of state funding for industry, compared with 24.2 percent in 1984. The economist said aggregate financial losses incurred by money-losing enterprises grew from $723 million in 1984 to $2.5 billion in 1988. The daily said inefficiency and low productivity were due to slowness in adapting to new market situations, low levels of technology, and blind expansion during years of rapid economic growth. It quoted former State Economic Commission Minister Lu Dong as saying that more than 30 percent of the nation's processing industry is idle, a result of overcapacity and the 18-month-old austerity program that has meant weakened demand and a cutoff of government credit. The government report said newly granted state loans to industry totaled $39.4 billion last year, exceeding the planned quota of $34 billion. Two-thirds of the new loans were issued in the last quarter of the year. The last quarter is traditionally the main lending season, but this trend was more pronounced last year as the government, concerned by the first negative growth rates in industrial output in a decade, eased up on its tight credit policy.

DOC.HEAD: Asia Watch Blasts China's Human Rights Record
DOC.TEXT: Despite lifting martial law, Chinese authorities persist in arresting peaceful dissenters and are carrying out new death sentences, the human rights group Asia Watch alleged in a report obtained Tuesday. The Washington-based group also criticized the Bush administration for ``kowtowing'' to the Chinese and it attempts to ``patch things up with those responsible for the slaughter and arrests following the June 4 crackdown.'' Asia Watch said tens of thousands of dissenters are languishing in cramped jail cells where guards regularly torture them.
