It said all political detainees are denied access to a lawyer as they await trial and are interrogated. ``China's criminal justice system is among the most deeply flawed in the word,'' the report said. ``Indeed, it is essentially pre-modern.'' Asia Watch also accused Chinese authorities of harassing many of the 40,000 Chinese students studying in the United States. It printed one letter from a Chinese student who claimed security forces went to his parents' house in Henan province and demanded a recent letter he had sent them regarding the June 4 crackdown. After an all-night interrogation, his brother gave police the letter and police later investigated his family and previous letters, Asia Watch said. The 89-page report lists many political trials and executions occurring after the crackdown in June, although it does not supply any new information as all of its findings are based on Western press reports. It says most of the estimated 10,000 to 30,000 people still in jail for taking part in the pro-democracy movement are workers who, unlike many intellectuals and students, ``have no contact whatever with the outside world.'' The report, titled ``Punishment Season,'' said that despite the lifting of martial law in January, the political climate throughout the country remains repressive. It charges that many People's Liberation Army soldiers have simply traded uniforms to the paramilitary People's Armed Police. It also charges that the People's Armed Police has increased in strength. The human rights group said it had documented several dozen arrests and trials between October and January, including one man who was convicted of ``counterrevolution'' for painting pro-democracy slogans. It said it had received reports but not confirmation of hundreds more. It charges that several executions had occurred of men the Chinese called ``hooligans,'' who were killed for participating in the movement for freedom. ``To sum up,'' it said, ``the continuing arrests and executions in China form the cutting edge of a protracted, government-led campaign of punitive repression, and they serve a purely political purpose.'' The report devotes one section to criticizing the response of the Bush administration to China. A month after the crackdown began, President Bush sent National Security Advisor Brent Scowcroft on a secret mission to Beijing. Scowcroft returned to China in December. Bush responded to criticism of his policy by saying he did not want to isolate China. Asia Watch accused the U.S. government of ``cleaving to a flawed and outmoded strategic analysis which holds the maintenance of close ties with China to be the key to any successful containment of Soviet expansionism.'' It said such a policy has ``reverted to a shabby double standard insofar as the question of human rights in China.'' The Asia Watch report follows the completion of a study by the U.S. State Department on human rights abuses in China. According to press reports, the study says the ``massacre'' in Beijing and subsequent crackdown violated almost every internationally recognized human right. The State Department report will be released later this month.

DOC.HEAD: After 20 Months, Odor Report Released
DOC.TEXT: This won't come as any surprise to people who live here, but Jacksonville stinks. So says a grand jury report that has been under wraps for 20 months because of objections by four corporations to its findings. It was unsealed Monday by order of an appeals court after a challenge by The Florida Times-Union. The report found that odors from Jacksonville's paper mills and other plants are an embarrassment and that industry has failed to police itself. The 23-member grand jury also found that the odors have hurt property values and interfere with residents' health and enjoyment. At the same time, the panel indicted four industries on air-pollution charges. But the charges since have either been dropped or struck down. The four industries were SCM Glidco Organics Corp., Jefferson Smurfit Corp., Seminole Kraft Corp. and Union Camp Corp. The report was released after an eight-month investigation requested by Mayor Tommy Hazouri. George Robbins, president of SCM Glidco, said his company fought release of the report because it is ``grossly biased, factually deficient and very misleading to the general public.'' State Attorney Ed Austin said he was not surprised that the industries fought release of the report so vigorously. ``It's been a mentality that they could wear us out and beat us down and not comply. We're showing the world we're going to stay at it until we accomplish our objectives, and that is to breathe fresh air,'' he said. The grand jury concluded that if industries fail to get rid of the stink, city, state and federal officials should pursue civil and criminal remedies.

DOC.HEAD: 22 Injured in Riots, Troops Called Out
DOC.TEXT: Riots broke out between two rival political parties Tuesday, and 22 people were injured, police and hospital sources said. The army was called in to patrol affected areas and police said tension remained in some neighborhoods. The unrest began as supporters of the Mohajir Qaumi Movement, representing Moslem immigrants to Pakistan, carried the bodies of two students killed Monday. The movement has blamed the killings on supporters of the ruling Pakistan Peoples Party. Members of the movement converged on a police station Tuesday demanding the arrest of several party officials for the murder of two students. When police declined to act against senior party officials in the case, the movement's supporters erected roadblocks and pelted police with rocks. Police opened fire to disperse the crowd, and some protesters shot back. Eight people, including three police officers, were injured. Trouble rapidly spread to other parts of the city and another 14 people, all belonging to the movement, were injured, police said. The Pakistan Peoples Party is supported by Sindh nationalists, while the Mohajir Qaumi Movement represents immigrants from India after Pakistan's independence in 1947. Hundreds of people have been killed and thousands injured in ethnic clashes between the Sindh nationalists, who want greater autonomy, and Mohajirs, who want to be recognized as a fifth ethnic group.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela: De Klerk's Speech Didn't Go Far Enough
With PM-SAfrica-Black Fear, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13grafs to UPDATE with Mandela quoted as saying de Klerk's speech doesn't open way to talks, other details; picks up 12th pvs, `The actions...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela called President F.W. de Klerk's concessions to the anti-apartheid movement ``courageous'' but does not believe they will lead to talks between guerrillas and the government, a Mandela associate said today. The Rev. Allan Boesak, president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, met with Mandela today. Later, Boesak said the jailed African National Congress leader described de Klerk's speech on Friday _ during which he legalized the ANC and lifted many emergency restrictiosn _ as ``bold, couragous and hopeful.'' But Mandela does not believe the speech cleared the way for negotiations, Boesak said. He ``has not given up on any of his principles,'' Boesak added. He also said that although Mandela has presented demands to the government, he will accept freedom whether or not they are met. ``His release is not in his own hands,'' Boesak said. ``It is the responsibility of the South African government to release him.'' Earlier, his wife, Winnie Mandela, had indicated that Mandela had demanded a complete lifting of the state of emergency as a condition of his release. Boesak said Mandela wants the government to end the 3{-year-old state of emergency and release all political prisoners, including guerrillas convicted of acts of violence. If these conditions are not met, Mandela would still agree to leave prison, ``but he will state his unhappiness with the government,'' Boesak said. Cabinet ministers said today Mandela will be released ``very soon'' but that the date hasn't been decided yet. Earlier today Walter Sisulu, an ANC leader who was freed in October after 26 years in prison, said the ANC has no intention of starting negotiations with the government and called on de Klerk to make further reforms. He said the ANC would pursue its guerrilla campaign despite de Klerk's decision to legalize the group, which had been banned since 1960. In his speech Friday, de Klerk lifted bans or restrictions on more than 60 anti-apartheid groups, promised to free Mandela and many other political prisoners, ended restrictions on 374 anti-government activists, and declared a moratorium on hangings. The actions met most, but not all of the ANC's conditions for opening talks with the white-led government. De Klerk did not say he would accept the principle of one-man, one-vote. De Klerk said ANC members can return from exile and will not be arrested unless they have been accused of committing ordinary crimes. However, the government has not said who among the ANC's estimated 15,000 members in exile will be liable for prosecution. Sisulu said no ANC exiles will return until the government clarifies its position. He also said the group would formally establish offices in South Africa, but declined to specify a date. Meanwhile, opposition among right-wing whites to de Klerk's concessions continued to grow. On Monday, Andries Treurnicht, the Conservative Party leader, said South Africa's whites faced ``the hour of truth.'' His party, which won 31 percent of the white vote in September, applied for a permit for a mass march in Pretoria on Feb. 15 to launch a ``freedom struggle'' aimed at protecting whites from domination by the black majority. Several far-right groups have vowed to resist de Klerk's reforms. Fears of an extremist blacklash increased after an attack Sunday on the British Embassy in Pretoria. Five whites were arrested recently on suspicion of planning attacks against de Klerk and other government leaders as well as anti-apartheid activists. Most right-wing whites are Afrikaners. Primarily of Dutch descent, they began settling in South Africa more than 300 years ago and now account for 60 percent of the 5 million whites. There are about 28 million blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Bound Victim Rolls to Freedom
DOC.TEXT: A 69-year-old man was robbed of his money, boots and false teeth and then tied up and left in an abandoned house, but rolled himself out onto the driveway to get help. State Police investigator Bob Buckley spotted Emmette McGough in rural Ouachita Parish on Monday. ``I just happened to be driving that way when I saw someone laying on the ground. I slowed down and saw he was tied up, so I turned around and went back,'' Buckley said. McGough gave Buckley descriptions of the two robbers, and within a half hour two suspects were under arrest. McGough, who lives in Monroe, said he had parked his truck in the driveway so he could hunt in nearby woods. When he returned, two men carrying sawed-off shotguns jumped out of the house, struck him in the head and tied him up, stealing his truck, Buckley said. McGough was treated for a cut on the head and tested for a possible concussion.

DOC.HEAD: Charges Dropped Against Journalists, But They Remain Held
DOC.TEXT: A judge dismissed charges Tuesday against two Ugandan journalists accused of defaming President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, but both remained in custody. A Kampala magistrate threw out the charges against Festo Ebongu of the government-owned newspaper New Vision and Alfred Okware of the independent monthly magazine Newsdesk. The government's defamation charges against the two stemmed from questions they asked Kaunda at a Jan. 29 news conference as he was ending a state visit to Uganda. Okware asked Kaunda why he didn't consider stepping down as president after 25 years in office. Ebongu asked Kaunda to explain why Zambia's national airline flies from Johannesburg to New York when the president is in the forefront of those calling for sanctions against South Africa. Magistrate Hensley Ephrahim Okalebo dismissed the counts after defense attorneys pointed out that the statute under which they were brought requires the publication of a defamation. Okaware, however, was ordered held on another charge of being in possession of a seditious article and Ebongu was arrested again without charge by security police as he was leaving the court.

DOC.HEAD: Former Banker Gets Six Years in Plot to Kill Wife
DOC.TEXT: A man upset with his wife for failing to lose weight after she had a baby drew six years in prison for trying to have her killed last Mother's Day. Kevin Wilson, clutching a Bible and tissue, wept as he told U.S. District Judge Odell Horton on Monday that he and his wife wanted to reconcile. ``Our decision is to restore our family,'' said Wilson, a former vice president of United American Bank and a former trumpet player for the Memphis Symphony Orchestra. Investigators said Wilson, 30, tried to hire a killer and planned to collect $220,000 on his wife's life insurance policy. The plan unraveled when a woman whom Wilson asked to help find a hit man went to the police instead. Wilson was upset about his wife's weight after she gave birth two years ago, said his attorney, Mark McDaniel. Prosecutor Dan Newsom told the judge that Mrs. Wilson ``doesn't believe he wanted to have her murdered, but the government is 100 percent sure that he wanted her dead.'' Wilson pleaded guilty in September to using the telephone and the mail to try to solicit a murder.

DOC.HEAD: Unarmed ICBM Launched, Successfully Reaches Target 4,200 Miles Away
DOC.TEXT: An unarmed Minuteman Intercontinental Ballistic Missile launched Tuesday successfully reached targets 4,200 miles away, the Air Force said. The ICBM was launched from an underground silo at Vandenberg, 150 miles northwest of Los Angeles, at 12:01 a.m. PST, said Major Suzanne Chapman. It was the 142nd in a series of Strategic Air Command test launches of the Minuteman ICBM, she said. ``After about a 30-minute flight, the unarmed re-entry vehicles impacted their assigned targets at the Kwajalein missile range,'' she said. The military target area is 4,200 miles southwest of Vandenberg in the Marshall Islands. The launch was conducted by the 321st Strategic Missile Wing, Grand Forks AFB in North Dakota.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Chief Draws Fine for Disrupting Town Meeting
DOC.TEXT: A municipal judge has fined the fire chief $100 after he refused to apologize for allegedly making noises and faces during a Board of Aldermen meeting. ``If I was wrong, I'd apologize. But I'm not wrong. I was right. I won't apologize,'' Chief Kenneth Pirtle said Monday night after Municipal Judge Kenneth Thomas found him guilty of disturbing the peace. Pirtle said he intended to appeal the decision to Bolivar County Court. The fire chief remains free on $150 bond pending appeal. Thomas told Pirtle that he would waive the fine ``for the sake of the citizens of Shaw'' if Pirtle would apologize in court or at the regularly scheduled board meeting Tuesday night. Mayor Gregory Flippins and two of the town's five aldermen, Diana Drake and Herman Love, testified that the fire chief made noises and faces as he left the board meeting on Jan. 2. They also accused Pirtle of calling the mayor names. ``He made a sound ... like a blubbering sound, like a person is making when they're sticking their tongue out of their mouth. A gagging type,'' Flippins testified. ``He turned around at the door, stuck his tongue out, making a blabbering sound and wagging his tongue.'' Drake also testified the Pirtle ``stuck his hands in his ears and said, `Oooh-ooh,'' a remark that drew giggles from those in the courtroom. Pirtle and three volunteer firefighters in this town of 2,500 residents, disputed that testimony. Public Works Director Evereth Stanton, also a volunteer firefighter, testified he didn't see who made the noise. Pirtle also denied calling the mayor names.

DOC.HEAD: New York State Moves to Protect Tasty Turtles
DOC.TEXT: The terrapin is a gourmet delicacy and key soup ingredient to some, a noble creature and wonderful pet to others, but to state environmental officials it's a threatened species that needs protection. The turtle's salt water habitat is imperiled by development and its ranks are declining because of its regained popularity on some dinner tables. The state Department of Environmental Conservation recently issued regulations setting up a ``terrapin harvest,'' or hunting season, for diamondback terrapin. Under the regulations, would-be terrapin hunters must buy state licenses, and terrapin capturing is forbidden during the turtles' nesting period in May, June and July. The regulations also set minimum and maximum size limits on captured terrapin. ``We think that because of loss of habitat and loss of nesting areas, in addition to a continued desire to eat them, primarily with the ethnic groups and gourmet restaurants, its survival could become a problem again,'' said Alvin Breisch, a state wildlife biologist. This isn't the first time the turtles have been threatened by their own good taste, said Breisch. ``They were completely wiped out in many locations in the early 1900s,'' said Breisch. ``The food fad kind of died off about the same time the turtles died off. But they've been slowly coming back.'' In New York state, the terrapins are found only in the brackish, salty water off Long Island and at the mouth of the Hudson River. The DEC doesn't keep a terrapin tally, Breisch said. ``We don't know how many there are, but they're certainly not as numerous as they were 100 years ago,'' he said. Jim VanAbbema can see evidence of a decline just by going to a fish market. He's a member of the New York State Turtle and Tortoise Society, which petitioned the DEC to regulate terrapin capture. ``Many of our members had been alarmed by the quantity of diamondback terrapin that were sold in Chinatown and other fish markets across the city,'' said VanAbbema, editor of the 20-year-old society's newsletter, Plastron Papers. The plastron is a turtle's bottom shell. They're not very big turtles, seldom growing to more than 9 inches long. Their scutes _ the individual pieces that make up their shells _ have very elaborate, concentric patterns. A distinctive mark on a terrapin's face makes it look like it has white lips, Breisch said. ``If you see the turtle, it basks in the open water rather than crawling up on logs or sitting on the beach, it basks just by floating on the surface and it sticks its head up and you'll see the w hite lips. If you see that, you'll know it's a terrapin,'' he said. Terrapins are not aggressive, make good pets and can live 30 or 40 years, said VanAbbema. Some of the turtle society's 1,000 members are also concerned about the conditions in which the turtles are kept after capture, said VanAbbema, who owns 18 turtles and a parrot. ``They are kept at best in a dry tank, maybe two or three layers deep, sometimes even worse,'' he said. ``They are often in a diseased state ... they are in very poor health because of the extreme stress of being without food or water for weeks or longer.'' The fact that turtles must be butchered shortly before cooking should contribute to their continued existence, said Breisch. ``Whoever buys them has to take them home and kill them and clean them,'' said Breisch. ``Turtle meat doesn't last very long after it's been killed, just like lobster meat. ``I think that discourages a lot of people. They actually wouldn't want to kill it themselves.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Move Is Survival Tactic, U.S. Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal to end the Communist Party's monopoly of power was an effort to keep ahead of a political avalanche that was threatening to bury him, say U.S. analysts. Changing Article Six of the Soviet constitution to deprive the Communist Party of its guaranteed ``leading role,'' as proposed Monday by Gorbachev, would ratify rather than unite opposition groups scattered among the 15 Soviet republics, the analysts predicted. But there was no clear consensus on the question of Gorbachev's survival In the West, where Gorbachev's popularity is high, his proposal ``will be interpreted as a show of great skill, to enable him to prevail,'' said Adam Ulam of Harvard University. ``But he is really trying to keep up with a bolting horse.'' ``Of course he has to survive, in the lack of any alternative. The right does not want to take a chance at cataclysm, by removing him,'' said Ulam. ``If they announced tomorrow that Gorbachev was out, you would have demonstrations in every Russian city,'' and that would force an unwanted test for the Red Army and KGB security forces. A crowd estimated at 200,000 marched through Red Square last weekend demanding more democracy, an indication of the growing pressure on Kremlin leaders to hand over more power to the people. Gorbachev's chances of success are mixed, said Jerry Hough, a Duke University analyst who has described the Soviet leader's political position as strong, but he said the latest development is forcing him to reconsider. If the Communist Party's constitutional grip on power is removed, said Hough, ``there is no reason it should not have the result it did in Eastern Europe,'' where Communists are being forced from power. Gorbachev may be planning to surrender his job as general secretary of the Communist Party, traditionally the top Kremlin post, and concentrate on his role as president, an office which he has strengthened since taking over the party in March 1985. But Gorbachev may be miscalculating popular pressure toward more democracy and underestimating the backlash among Russians who are angered by three things, the collapse of the economy, the weakening of the East European alliance, and separatist movements in the non-Russian republics, said Hough. ``If Gorbachev in five years has done nothing but give up Eastern Europe and create economic chaos, why shouldn't one decide that he is not worthy of running a great country?'' said Hough. The Communist Party faces a test at the ballot box in local elections in the Soviet republics in February and March. The results promise to be just as embarrassing as those from national balloting last year, when many Communist functionaries were defeated in Russia, and popular fronts won majorities in the three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. The Communists are expected to lose again in the Baltics, as well as Moldavia, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia, said Leon Aron, a Soviet-born scholar at the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington. Aron predicted that depriving the Communist Party of its guaranteed leading role will cause it to ``collapse. I give it half a year. It could take longer.'' The Communists will be convulsed for months by the elections and by preparations for a party congress, which had been scheduled for October but which Gorbachev now wants in late June, apparently immediately after his planned summit in Washington with President Bush. The likely embarrassment of the elections and the expected foreign policy success of the summit may strengthen Gorbachev's hand at the Communist Party congress, where he will have his first chance in more than four years to clear his conservative opponents off the policy-making Central Committee. It was at a meeting of the 249-member Central Committee that Gorbachev proposed amending Article Six, and thus sparked a conservative firestorm.

DOC.HEAD: Pardon Sought for Man Serving Life Prison Term
DOC.TEXT: The district attorney is seeking a pardon for a 49-year-old man who has spent five years in prison for an armored car robbery that police now say he did not commit. The man, Martin Kimsey, wrote a letter that set in motion a chain of events that led investigators to another man. ``I used to think everybody in prison was guilty and just saying they were innocent, until it happened to me,'' said Kimsey, who goes to court Wednesday for a hearing that could lead to his freedom. If District Judge Larry Baraka sets bail, Kimsey will be free for the first time since 1985, when he was arrested for the robbery of a Wells Fargo armored-car driver in the Dallas suburb of Garland. Kimsey read a newspaper account of similar robberies and wrote a letter in 1987 to one of the men convicted of them, asking the team to admit to the Garland robbery. Kimsey got no response, but prosecutors got a call late last year from the wife of one of the men saying he wanted to confess to a crime someone else was jailed for. ``I guess he sat on the letter or didn't do anything about it until he decided to talk to the FBI about it,'' First District Attorney Norman Kinne said Tuesday. Investigators talked to James Clayton Garrett and said he provided details of the robbery only the robber would know. He and Kimsey passed a lie detector test before the pardon was recommended for Kimsey. Kimsey said he wrote a thank-you note to Garrett. Kimsey says he doesn't blame anyone for the wrongful conviction that has cost him five years. ``I tell you what, when I first got arrested I was bitter at everything,'' Kimsey told the Dallas Morning News. ``But after five years you've got to go through everything in your mind. You can't really change things. ``I don't hold a grudge. All I want to do is get out of here and get out of Dallas,'' Kimsey said. ``I want to get my life back together.'' Kimsey testified that he and his brother Maurice were in Fort Worth when the robbery occurred and that his brother's car, whose make and color matched a car seen at the robbery, was in a body shop. A Dallas jury convicted Kimsey in 1985. Kimsey, who had a record stemming from forgery and robbery charges, was sentenced to life in prison. A grand jury refused to indict Maurice Kimsey.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Resume, Superpowers Urged to Help Speed Global Accord
DOC.TEXT: Talks on a global ban on chemical weapons resumed Tuesday with European appeals for the United States and Soviet Union to increase efforts toward an agreement. Swedish envoy Maj Britt Theorin told the 40-nation Conference on Disarmament that long-running negotiations on a convention could be completed within a year. But in thinly veiled criticism of U.S. policy, Theorin said a ``glaring loophole'' would result from proposals to allow states to keep some chemical weapons until all countries with a production capability sign the planned treaty. Dutch Foreign Minister Hans Van Den Broek said it is ``necessary to make it crystal clear that destruction of all chemical weapons is the principal objective'' of a convention. ``We do not want `haves' and `have-nots,''' he said. The conference, resuming full sessions after a five-month break, also received offers from The Hague and Vienna to be the site of an international agency for monitoring adherence to a future chemical weapons ban. The conference's spring session is set to run 10 weeks. Difficulties over verifying the proposed ban have been one of the main sticking points in completion of the treaty, which would forbid the production, stockpiling and use of poison gas. Negotiations in Geneva date back to 1968. Improved superpower relations have boosted progress in 5-year-old bilateral talks between the United States and the Soviet Union and spawned hopes that an international treaty might be ready by the end of the year. Chief Soviet negotiator Sergei Batsanov last month described talks as ``at a very advanced stage.'' But he added that the superpower still disagree on an offer made by President Bush to destroy 80 percent of stockpiles prior to the signing of an international treaty provided Moscow follows suit. In a speech to the U.N. General Assembly last year, Bush also proposed to keep two percent of U.S. stockpiles of weapons until all countries deemed capable of producing chemical weapons have signed an international treaty. Without mentioning the United States, Ms. Theorin described this plan as ``potentially crippling'' a global accord. She said it would leave ``a glaring loophole in the regime, thereby providing an excuse for other countries to retain _ or to acquire _ chemical weapons,'' the Swedish delegate said. About a dozen countries, including Libya and Iran, are thought to possess chemical weapons, although only the United States and Soviet Union admit having the deadly substances. Van Den Broek offered to base the treaty's monitoring agency in The Hague, seat of the Dutch government and the World Court. Foreign Minister Alois Mock proposed Vienna, the headquarters of several U.N. agencies and the venue for East-West talks on conventional weapons. Theorin warned against optimism on an early signing of the convention. ``We have become very familiar with the claim that the comprehensive chemical weapons convention will be concluded soon,'' she said. ``Such statements cannot credibly be repeated forever by diplomats, politicians and governments.''

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Deserter Won't Be Court-Martialed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Kephart's release and comments, plans for visit, family background. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A GI who fled to East Germany 30 years ago for fear a truck accident would land him in the stockade was set free today after the Army decided against court-martialing him as a deserter. ``I'm going to live it up,'' said 53-year-old Pvt. Arnold Kephart after his release from confinement at Fort Sill. ``And then I'm going to sit down and try to work my way in life as I did before.'' Kephart was arrested last week upon arriving in Omaha, Neb., to see his family for the first time since he fled to the Communist bloc in 1960. About 30 family members were waiting at the airport, but only two got to speak to him. Instead of a court-martial, the Army today granted Kephart's request for an other-than-honorable discharge. He had been held at the Army base since Thursday and was to fly to Nebraska later today for a family reunion. ``I don't know how I'm going to say it, but I'll say I'm proud to be back in the United States,'' Kephart told reporters outside Fort Sill. Kephart took refuge behind the Iron Curtain after an Army truck he had been driving on an assignment to France crashed while he was returning to his base in Heidelberg, West Germany. The truck also contained three corked bottles of French wine, he said. ``In the crash, the wine got broke up on our uniforms. The police, they thought that we had been drunk. ... We didn't have one single drink from the wine,'' Kephart told the Omaha World-Herald on Monday. Kephart said French police locked them up, and the soldier's superiors took them into custody. ``They told me that I would get prison, I would so many years locked up and then I would have to pay for that rig. They told me a lot of things,'' Kephart said. ``After they told me things, I waited till I got my chance and I went over the barbed wire.'' Kephart tried several times to escape to the West but was caught each time at the border, said his attorney, James Martin Davis. He decided to return to the United States after East Germany opened its borders late last year, Davis said. The other-than-honorable discharge means Kephart will be eligible for virtually no veterans benefits, said base spokeswoman Sheila Samples. Kephart said today he would probably spend five or six weeks with family in Council Bluffs, Iowa, across the Missouri River from Omaha. After that, he said, he will probably go to Texas with his sister. Kephart brought his 12-year-old son, Frank, with him. His ex-wife, Brigitte, and his twin 8-year-old daughters, Kathleen and Katharina, remain in Schmalkalden, East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Coast Guard Arrests Hong Kong Captain
DOC.TEXT: The Maritime Safety Agency said Tuesday it has arrested the captain of a 7,027-ton Liberian freighter that struck a rock off western Japan last week and spilled much of its cargo of fuel oil. Capt. Cheung Wai Kay, 39, of Hong Kong, was accused of professional negligence, for which the maximum penalty is three years in prison, said an offical of the agency, which is Japan's coast guard. Cheung allegedly failed to take proper measures in rough seas, the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said Cheung would appear Wednesday before prosecutors, who would decide whether to indict him. The Maritime Gardenia struck the rock Jan. 25, one mile off the coast of Kyoto prefecture, and about 650 tons of fuel oil leaked before divers sealed pipes. All 23 Filipinos and Chinese crewmen were rescued. An official of the fishermen's cooperative in Ine village said seaweed farming in the area, which produced $24,000 worth of seaweed last year, was completely ruined. The Liberian freighter, owned by International Maritime Carriers Co. of Hong Kong, had been heading for southwestern Yamaguchi prefecture, about 500 miles southwest of Tokyo, after unloading lumber in Uchiura, near Ine.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Focuses On Reagan Absence At North Trial
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals judge asked government lawyers today why Oliver North was not permitted to call former President Reagan as a witness at North's Iran-Contra trial or allowed to see written answers Reagan supplied to investigators. ``You never turned over answers from Reagan to the defendant,'' Judge Laurence Silberman of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals told a government attorney during a hearing on North's appeal of his conviction. ``Why, as a matter of basic fairness,'' wasn't North permitted to examine written answers that Reagan supplied to a federal grand jury investigating the Iran-Contra affair, the appeals judge asked. A government attorney, Gerard Lynch, told the appeals court that the former president's written answers would not have been helpful to North. But the U.S. system of justice is based on providing a defendant with a wide range of material for possible use in his defense, said the judge. ``What troubles me is we don't have a very good idea'' of what the president's testimony would have been, said Silberman. North's attorney, Barry Simon, argued that Reagan should have been called to testify to show that he authorized keeping secret the U.S. connection to a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles from Israel to Iran. Reagan's appearance had been called for at the time of North's trial last year but the trial judge, Gerhard Gesell of U.S. District Court, quashed a subpoena. He ruled there was no evidence in the record to suggest that the former president authorized any illegal activities by North. On Monday U.S. District Judge Harold Greene ordered Reagan to provide videotaped testimony at the trial of former national security adviser John Poindexter. The judge gave Reagan and President Bush until Friday to invoke executive privilege to avoid testimony by the former president. Greene also renewed his order that Reagan immediately turn over 33 diary entries to Poindexter. Reagan promptly invoked executive privilege to avoid turning portions of his diaries over to Poindexter. North was convicted on May 4, 1989, of obstructing Congress, altering and destroying National Security Council documents and accepting an illegal gratuity. Silberman said that if North had been working for the secretary of state instead of the president, there would have been no question that the cabinet member would have been called to testify. Lynch responded that North had no direct contact with Reagan and that the former National Security Council aide formed ``impressions'' of what he was to do from his immediate boss, Poindexter. ``The question is, did the jury get sufficient information to make a judgment'' on North's guilt or innocence, Silberman said at one point in the appeals court argument. North's attorneys contend Reagan's testimony would have been critically important in North's defense aginst the obstruction charge. The defense contends Reagan would have corroborated North's assertion that the president and his top advisers decided that in order to protect the lives of U.S. hostages held in Lebanon, they wouldn't disclose U.S. involvement with the November 1985 Hawk shipment. But Iran-Contra prosecutors say North was unable to identify a single instance where Reagan directly told him to obstruct Congress. On another point, North's attorney asked the appeals court to overturn the former presidential aide's conviction because of the ``pervasive dissemination'' of his congressional testimony. Witnesses, jurors, prosecutors and grand jurors could not avoid exposure to testimony North gave a congressional committee investigating the Iran-Contra affair, Simon said. North was granted immunity from prosecution for his congressional testimony. Prosecutors said they had not read or seen any of that testimony and had gathered their own evidence. The congressional testimony was carried on live television and reported widely throughout the media. ``In light of the pervasive dissemination ... there are no procedures that could ensure a fair trial,'' Simon argued. He said grand jurors hearing testimony that resulted in indictments against North were not instructed to avoid reading newspapers or watching television. Instead, he said, the government's special prosecutor told the grand jurors to avoid ``tainted material,'' or news that related to North. ``They were told they could watch, but if it came to tainted material, then skip over it,'' said Simon. ``You could read, but when you get to an article that is tainted, skip over.'' He said the special prosecutor ``chose convenience'' instead of absolutely forbidding the grand jurors from reading newspapers or watching television. ``The publicity was absolutely pervasive,'' he said. ``This grand jury was not shielded.'' Lynch, the government's attorney, responded that North's lawyers ``are equating...exposure with taint.'' He called it ``overreaching of what the law requires.'' The obstruction charge involved a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran, while the documents that were destroyed showed North's assistance to the Nicaraguan Contras. The gratuity was a $13,800 home security system which North accepted from Richard Secord, who North enlisted to run supplies to the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan government. Gesell on July 5 placed North on probation for two years, fined him $150,000 and sentenced him to 1,200 hours of community service. North is performing the community service while appealing the convictions and fine. The three-member panel hearing his appeal includes Judges Laurence Silberman and David Sentelle, both Reagan administration appointees, and Carter administration appointee Patricia Wald, chief judge of the appeals court.

DOC.HEAD: Jailed Terrorist Linked to Freedom For U.S. Hostages, Paper Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th, `The name ...' to UPDATE with Washington denying report; picks up 6th graf: Bush asked ...
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper has reported that Iran wants France to free an imprisoned Lebanese before it will seek the release of American hostages in Lebanon. Anis Naccache is serving a life term for the attempted assissination of a former Iranian prime minister. The conservative daily Le Figaro reported Monday that President Francois Mitterrand may trim the sentence to 20 years, making Naccache eligible for parole in 1991, when he will have served 10 years. Le Figaro, citing sources close to the Foreign Ministry, said President Bush told Mitterrand that Iran asked for Naccache's release as a condition for intervening with Iranian-backed extremist groups believed holding the captives. ``President Bush personally telephoned Francois Mitterrand to inform him of an unexpected change during talks that the Americans held with Tehran to obtain the liberation of their countrymen,'' the newspaper said. ``The name of Naccache suddenly appeared from the Iranian negotiators, who made the release of their protege one of the conditions for a favorable outcome of the discussions,'' the newspaper said. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the story was ``nonsense, total nonsense. We don't make deals for hostages.'' Bush asked Mitterrand whether the Naccache affair might soon be settled, Le Figaro maintained. The French leader answered that ``nothing remains in the way any longer and that the release of the American hostages could be an extra reason to move things along,'' the newspaper said. Le Figaro did not specify when the conversation took place but said Mitterrand's response had reached Beirut at the end of last week via the United States and Tehran. The story was the latest report in the French press that Naccache will be freed after he recently ended a 19-week hunger strike protesting his imprisonment. Naccache and senior Iranian officials claim his release was part of the 1988 deal that won release for all French hostages then held in Lebanon. French officials deny that Naccache's release was part of the package. The weekly newspaper Le Canard Enchaine reported last week that Mitterrand would free Naccache this year. The French leader's promise was transmitted to Naccache by way of ``the highest Iranian leaders,'' the newspaper said. Naccache's lawyer Jacques Verges, has said Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani and spiritual leader Ali Khameini ordered an end to the hunger strike, in which Naccache was kept alive by occasional intravenous feedings. Mitterrand had said during the long fast that he might consider releasing Naccache, but not under the pressure of a hunger strike. Naccache, born in Beirut in 1951, led an assassination squad in a failed 1980 attack against Shahpour Bakhtiar, Iran's last prime minister before the Islamic revolution of 1979. Bakhtiar was uninjured but two other people were killed. At Naccache's trial two years later, both prosecution and defense lawyers said Naccache acted under orders of senior Iranian officials. Eighteen Westerners are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups in Lebanon, including eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. Longest held is Terry A. Anderson, 41, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Activist Says Delay on Mandela Release Risks Peace Initiative
LaserPhotos JOH1,2
DOC.TEXT: The government is delaying the release of Nelson Mandela to deal with his political demands and that could jeopardize its peace initiative, an activist said Tuesday after conferring with Mandela. The Rev. Allan Boesak said Mandela wants the government to lift the state of emergency and free all political prisoners, including those convicted of violent acts, but would accept freedom whether or not these demands are met. ``His release is not in his own hands,'' Boesak said. ``It is the responsibility of the South African government to release him.'' If his demands aren't met, Mandela would still agree to leave prison, ``but he will state his unhappiness with the government,'' said Boesak, who is president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches. ``If they come in here and they tell him, `We are releasing you,' he will not hold onto the chairs and tables and kick and say `I won't come out.' But he will warn them: `If you do release me and the conditions that we have put have not been met, then I will be obliged to make a statement on those conditions,''' Boesak said. The government has made clear it wants Mandela, the most popular leader among South Africa's blacks, to play a conciliatory role when he emerges after more than 27 years in prison. President F.W. de Klerk's hopes of initiating negotiations on black-white power-sharing could be dashed if a freed Mandela were to take a tough stance against the government. Boesak said Mandela did not know when he might go free, but was engaged in ``intense contacts'' with the government. ``He must be released soon or de Klerk will lose momentum,'' Boesak said after he and his wife, Dorothy, met with Mandela for more than three hours at Victor Verster prison farm north of Cape Town. De Klerk, in a speech Friday, lifted a 30-year ban on Mandela's African National Congress movement, eased restrictions on other opposition groups, and said Mandela, 71, would be freed soon. Mandela considered the speech ``bold, courageous and hopeful,'' but did not believe it had cleared the way for talks between the government and the ANC, Boesak said. Mandela ``has not given up on any of his principles,'' Boesak added. ``He is a statesman whose place is not in prison.'' Gerrit Viljoen, the Cabinet minister assigned to open negotiations with leaders of the voteless black majority, said Mandela's release ``is something that is to take place very soon.'' ``The date of his release is to be determined as a matter of urgency,'' Viljoen said at a briefing Tuesday. In a later speech to Parliament, Viljoen said he envisioned South Africa being led by a coalition of parties in 10 years, with the long-ruling National Party no longer in charge. Viljoen and Foreign Minister Pik Botha challenged claims that the government was obstructing Mandela's release by not repealing the state of emergency or freeing all political prisoners. ``Don't believe people who say the government is the only obstacle,'' said Botha. He repeated de Klerk's assertion that Mandela's safety and personal considerations were factors behind the delay. On another topic, Botha said it did not matter whether a future president of South Africa was black or white as long as the new political system had the support of a majority of the people. Walter Sisulu, an old friend of Mandela who was freed in October after 26 years in prison, said Tuesday after returning from abroad that the ANC leadership was not aware of Mandela setting pre-conditions for his release. Mandela has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life term for launching the ANC's guerrilla campaign against the white government. Government officials agree with opposition leaders that his freedom is a key to creating a climate for negotiations on a new constitution, ending apartheid, and giving blacks a voice in the national government. However, Sisulu said, ``There is no question yet of direct discussions with the government.'' He described de Klerk's reforms as a ``progressive'' step, ``but unfortunately it was only a half-measure.'' He said the organization was still studying de Klerk's speech and would need up to two weeks to issue a formal response. He said the ANC's armed struggle remained ``part and parcel'' of its campaign for black rights because ``nothing fundamentally has changed.'' At the same news conference, Popo Molefe, a leader of the United Democratic Front, said 20 leaders of the anti-apartheid coalition would meet Mandela on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Gotti Jury Begins Deliberations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with deliberations under way. PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Gotti, known ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Its members' names kept secret to guard against tampering, a jury today began deliberating whether reputed mob boss John Gotti ordered a union leader shot. The jurors got down to work after the judge in the assault trial of the so-called Dapper Don told them, ``You have only yourselves to answer to.'' Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin also granted a defense request and reminded jurors that the Mafia was not on trial. The judge told the jurors that to reach a guilty verdict, they must find the prosecution proved the crime and not simply that Gotti and his co-defendant might be members of organized crime. Gotti, known as the Dapper Don for his expensive suits, is reputed to be the boss of the Gambino crime family, the nation's most powerful mob organization. McLaughlin told the jurors that that if they can face themselves the day after the verdict and feel good about what they've done, then they will have done their duty. Gotti said earlier that he wasn't worried about being convicted. ``There's no problem,'' Gotti said after closing arguments Monday. ``There's never been a problem.'' When the case began, he said odds were 3-to-1 in his favor. If convicted, Gotti faces 25 years to life in prison because of his prior record. The jurors have been sequestered since being sworn in about three weeks ago to shield them from publicity and possible jury-tampering, and their names have not been disclosed. Court officials estimate the cost of their hotel, food and transportation at $1,200 a day. In closing arguments, defense lawyers Bruce Cutler and Gerald Shargel portrayed Gotti as a noteworthy person who is being persecuted by prosecutors because of his reputation. ``In their lust to convict Mr. Gotti, they created a case and they forgot integrity,'' Cutler told jurors. ``In the Mafia hysteria that they create and perpetuate, they forgot what was right.'' But the prosecutor, Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky, insisted Gotti had ``the motivation'' to arrange the shooting. He said Gotti, 49, and co-defendant Anthony Guerrieri, 61, had the Westies gang shoot John F. O'Connor, former vice president of Carpenters Union Local 608, on May 7, 1986. According to Cherkasky, O'Connor was shot because he arranged the trashing of a mob-run restaurant, Bankers and Brokers, which used non-union labor. The defense ridiculed the quality of the prosecution's key evidence _ hard-to-hear tapes secretly recorded in 1986 at Gotti's hangout and in the visiting room at the Rikers Island jail. The defense says a key sentence, in which Gotti allegedly says, ``We're gonna, gonna bust him up,'' is inaudibe. Shargel and Cutler contend prosecutors are making it up to suit their theory. The defense attorneys also asked why prosecutors didn't warn O'Connor that his life was in danger or why Gotti wasn't indicted in 1986 when the tapes were made. ``When the smoke clears, you will realize one thing _ that there is no proof, let alone proof beyond a reasonable doubt, that John Gotti and Anthony Guerrieri had John O'Connor shot,'' Shargel told the jurors. Cherkasky explained the discrepancies by telling the jury: ``Law enforcement waited to have a case that came together.'' Gotti's lawyers disparaged the truthfulness of the criminals who were called to testify, saying they were lying to save themselves. ``We are in America,'' Cutler said. ``That's not how it's supposed to be. People are not supposed to be convicted because of who they are, who their friends are, what their background is.'' The principal witness linking Gotti to the O'Connor shooting was James ``Studs'' McElroy, 45, a former Westies gang member who is serving a 60-year federal sentence. McElroy testified that he was introduced to Gotti as the Westie who was going to ``whack'' O'Connor. Cherkasky said of McElroy: ``The simple fact is, this man is not smart enough, not subtle enough to lie.'' But Cutler said McElroy testified to help his girlfriend get favorable treatment in a drug case and increase his own chances of getting out of jail. O'Connor recovered from at least four shots in the buttocks and testified for the defense, invoking his right against self-incrimination several times when cross-examined. He has been charged with extortion, perjury, larceny and labor racketeering.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demonstrate For Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people filled Prague's Old Town Square on Tuesday and demanded the estimated 75,000 Soviet troops be unconditionally withdrawn from Czechoslovakia by May 31. The Soviet troops were denounced as occupiers who came to crush the ``Prague Spring'' reforms of 1968. The crowd, estimated at about 8,000 by a Western reporter and at 30,000 by the state news agency CTK, applauded a speaker who demanded that Vasil Bilak and other former leading Communists thought to have been responsible for inviting the troops to Czechoslovakia be put on trial. The new coalition government, headed by President Vaclav Havel, has demanded the withdrawal of the Soviet forces by the end of 1990, declaring void two 1968 agreements with Moscow that legalized their deployment after they headed the Warsaw Pact invasion. Talks on the troop withdrawal resume in Moscow on Wednesday, before Havel makes his first visit to the Kremlin at the end of this month to present plans for European change to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The crowd chanted ``That's the end, Ivan!'' and ``Nobody wants you!'' and showed overwhelming support for a declaration demanding the withdrawal of the troops by May 31, supervised by a Czechoslovak-Soviet commission. They also urged the restoration of all facilities used by the Soviets to their original state. All damage caused by the troops should be assessed and compensated, said the declaration, read to the crowd by Social Democrat Slavomir Klaban. Banners waving in the crowd read, ``At home you will be people, here you are just occupiers.'' Others in Russian urged the troops to go home. The demonstration, which ended with a minute of silence for the 72 Czechoslovaks killed and 266 wounded in the 1968 invasion, was organized by the Social Democratic party, one of about 40 parties that have emerged since Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution in November overturned one-party Communist rule. The demands of the crowd went further than those of the coalition government, which is pushing for a 50 percent withdrawal of Soviet forces by mid-May, with the remainder leaving by year's end. The first round of talks on the withdrawal, the most sensitive issue in Czechoslovak-Soviet relations, took place in Prague Jan. 15-16 but failed to produce tangible results. Unlike Hungary, where initial talks on a Soviet troop withdrawal took place last week, Czechoslovakia considers the matter of Soviet troop withdrawal separate from Vienna talks on arms reduction in Europe. The Soviet forces in both countries are viewed as occupiers who crushed movements for democracy, in Hungary in 1956 and in Czechoslovakia in 1968. The demands from Prague and Budapest for a Soviet troop pullout have increased pressure on Moscow for a radical cutback in central Europe, under discussion at the Vienna talks. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who met Havel on Tuesday, travels to Moscow on Wednesday for talks with Gorbachev on the U.S. proposal to cut U.S. and Soviet troops in all Europe to 225,000 on each side, with a limit of 195,000 in central Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Challenge to Ban on Polystyrene Foam
DOC.TEXT: A judge today dismissed a legal challenge by McDonald's restaurants and others to Portland's new ban on food containers made of polystyrene foam. The law, which took effect Jan. 1, prohibits the use of the packaging by restaurants and food vendors. It was not being enforced pending resolution of the legal challenge. Circuit Judge Douglas R. Spencer heard arguments Monday on whether to dismiss the lawsuit and granted the request this morning. He ruled that the city was within its authority in enacting the ban. The lawsuit, filed by three recycling companies and several restaurants, including McDonald's franchises, claimed the ban violates state solid-waste law and policies. McDonald's uses foam in packaging Big Macs and other items. But City Attorney Jeffrey L. Rogers argued that state policies on solid-waste management don't prohibit the city from banning foam. The city contends foam food containers fill up landfills, take generations to break down and are not recyclable. Mark L. Cushing, representing the plaintiffs, contended that the ban conflicts with state priorities for waste management. He said a trial would prove that polystyrene foam is recyclable, and his clients are recycling it. McDonald's and other foam users have argued that the alternative to foam is paper products, which would end up at a landfill, the last alternative on the state priority list.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Shows Gephardt How It's Done _ Illegally
DOC.TEXT: When Mayor David Dinkins gave House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt a lesson on how to ride the subway while drinking a cup of coffee, it was more than the java jive _ it was illegal. The mayor, the Missouri Democrat and other members of Congress took a four-stop ride on a subway train Monday as part of an effort to stop Bush administration plans to cut federal highway and mass transit aid. Dinkins sipped his coffee while straphanging. ``You note, I have the ability to ride holding on (with) one hand and drinking coffee without spilling it all over,'' Dinkins said, a bit didactically. ``I learned to do this by riding the subways.'' Mr. Dinkins, meet section 1050.6 , paragraph F of the New York City Transit Authority's rules and regulations: ``No person shall bring or carry on a conveyance liquid in an open container.'' The violation is punishable by a $25 fine. Nine people were ticketed last year for drinking coffee or soda on a train, along with 948 passengers who drank more potent spirits. Others were just ordered to dump their drinks. Not surprisingly, Dinkins was not ticketed. Said Termaine Garden, a TA spokesman: ``It's a discretionary call. It's up to the police officer.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The cameras are rolling on actor Kevin Spacey as fallen PTL evangelist Jim Bakker and Bernadette Peters as his wife, Tammy Faye. ``Fall From Grace,'' which ends with the couple's ouster from the television ministry in 1987, is in its first full week of production in Los Angeles, The Charlotte Observer reported Tuesday. The NBC movie, suggested by the Bakkers, should be broadcast sometime in May. NBC bought rights from the couple, but won't say how much was paid. NBC publicist Catherine Boxberger would say only that the agreement stipulated the couple would not have script approval. Actress Annie Rubanoff will play former church secretary Jessica Hahn, whose revelations of a sexual encounter with Bakker started an investigation into his ministry. Bakker is serving 45 years in a federal prison in Minnesota after being convicted last fall in federal court in Charlotte of fraud and conspirary charges.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Steve Garvey, the former baseball star whose sexual exploits made him grist for the tabloid mill, is set to pick up another broadcasting job not long after he was fired by a San Diego radio station. ``Somebody said to me that I was like President Reagan, that no matter what happens to me, it bounces off and I end up on my feet,'' Garvey said Monday. Garvey is going to Prime Ticket, a local cable network focusing on sports, to provide commentary on college baseball games and produce a series on charity sporting events. Garvey was fired less than two weeks ago as a sports talk show host at XTRA, where Garvey debuted last June with a four-hour morning show. Within about two months Garvey's air time dwindled to about 15 minutes each hour. Last year, it was revealed Garvey had relationships with three women at the same time. Two of the women became pregnant by him; he married the third. Don Corsini, Prime Ticket's program director, said the publicity surrounding the former Los Angeles Dodger and San Diego Padre had no bearing on his hiring. ``It's all in the past. It wasn't a factor,'' Corsini said.

Actor Kevin Costner has filed a lawsuit claiming a movie in which he played a minor role is being marketed to profit from his hit film ``Field of Dreams.'' Costner is shown on the video cover of ``Chasing Dreams'' wearing a baseball uniform but does not play a baseball player in the 1985 film, according to the lawsuit filed Monday in U.S. District Court against Prism Entertainment Corp. In ``Field of Dreams,'' Costner plays a farmer who builds a baseball diamond in his corn field where ghost players, including ``Shoeless'' Joe Jackson and other members of the 1919 Chicago ``Black Sox'' come to play. It has grossed $63 million since its release last year. ```Chasing Dreams' was neither critically acclaimed nor financially successful,'' wrote Costner's attorney Frank Rothman. ``It was shown only in approximately 40 movie theaters in the Midwestern United States.'' Universal Pictures Inc., which owns U.S. distribution rights to ``Field of Dreams,'' is Costner's co-plantiff in the lawsuit. Prism President Barry Collier declined comment, saying he had not seen the lawsuit.

Success can have its drawbacks, says singer and Grammy award winner Bobby McFerrin. ``It can be a burden,'' the soft-spoken McFerrin said. ``People want you to repeat what you've already done. You have to watch that you keep growing, stretching. ``I found myself getting bored,'' the San Francisco-based singer said. ``I'd begun to pander to the audience _ they wanted `Don't Worry, Be Happy' and `The Wizard of Oz.' It was all getting too easy.'' McFerrin and his 11-person all-vocal ensemble ``Voicestra'' are here preparing for a sold-out concert Saturday. ``Don't Worry, Be Happy,'' was McFerrin's 1989 Grammy hit.

DOC.HEAD: Schools Closed As Demonstrations Continue Over Superintendent's Dismissal
DOC.TEXT: Student protests over the dismissal of Selma's first black school superintendent forced the closing of two schools today. The action came a day after four protesters were arrested at a City Hall demonstration, and after officials canceled a board meeting when hundreds of protesters took over the stage at an auditorium the board planned to use. A spokeswoman in Mayor Joe Smitherman's office said students were sent home this morning as demonstrators gathered at the predominantly black, 1,500-student Selma High School, the city's only public high school. Eastside Middle School's 400 students also were dismissed, assistant superintendent James Carter said. Officials were considering whether to close Westside Junior High, which has some 900 students, said the mayor's office. An unidentified worker who answered the telephone at the high school said protesters had left school grounds by late morning. There were conflicting accounts as to whether demonstrators had entered the building. No arrests were immediately reported. Students later gathered at a Baptist church, where a protest leader, Ronald Peoples, said parents had gone to the high school to remove their children because of ``allegations it was unsafe and not a learning environment.'' The dispute began in December, when the six white members of the Selma Board of Education voted not to renew Norward Roussell's contract when it expires in June. That prompted the five black members _ who voted to retain Roussell _ to walk out. Protesters have charged Roussell was dismissed because he is black, an allegation denied by white school board members. They cited an unfavorable job evaluation and an authoritarian management style in his firing. Critics have organized school boycotts and other demonstrations. One day last month, more than a third of the system's 6,000 students stayed home. The school system is 70 percent black. Last week, the remaining members of the board decided to remove Roussell from the $80,000-a-year job this week, a move they said was necessary to restore ``peace and tranquility.''

DOC.HEAD: Cherokees Largest Indian Tribe
DOC.TEXT: Cherokees are the largest American Indian tribe, Tlingits the richest and Navahos the poorest, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday. Chickasaws registered the highest median age, 27.6 years, while the best high-school graduation rate, 68.4 percent, was attained by the Comanches, according to the bureau. The report on American Indians essentially completed the agency's publications of 1980 census data _ just two months before the 1990 census gets underway. Though data about Indians as a whole was published previously, the tribal breakdown had to wait because of budgetary constraints, the bureau said. The report said that members of the Blackfoot tribe have the highest rate of labor force participation, while the top family income was reported by the Tlingit tribe, many of whose members live and work in Alaska, where salaries are routinely higher. The greatest poverty rate was among the Navajo. Overall, the 1980 census counted 1,478,523 American Indians, with Cherokees by far the largest tribe at 232,080. In second place were Navajos at 158,633, followed by Sioux, 78,608; Chippewa, 73,602 and, Choctaw, 50,220. Rounding out the top 10 were the Pueblo, 42,552; Iroquois, 38,218; Apache, 35,861; Lumbee, 28,631 and Creek, 28,278. Here are some comparitive statistics for various tribes, listing the top 10 in each category: Median age (U.S. 30.0): Chickasaw, 27.6; Cherokee, 27.3; Choctaw, 26.1; Iroquois, 24.9; Blackfoot, 24.6; Potawatomi, 24.5; Creek, 24.4; Comanche, 23.7; Seminole, 23.5; Lumbee, 22.4. Percent high school graduates (U.S. 66.5): Comanche, 68.4; Kiowa, 68.1; Creek, 65.1; Potawatomi, 65.0; Tlingit, 64.7; Seminole, 64.4; Chickasaw, 63.0; Crow, 61.2; Cheyenne, 60.3; Iroquois, 59.9. Labor force participation rate (U.S. 62.0): Blackfoot, 65.3; Potawatomi, 63.2; Seminole, 62.4; Cherokee, 61.7; Iroquois, 61.4; Comanche, 61.3; Lumbee, 60.8; Creek, 60.7; Choctaw, 60.5; Chickasaw, 59.4; Tlingit, 59.4. Median Family Income (U.S. $19,917): Tlingit, $20,033; Chickasaw, $16,311; Potawatomi, $16,286; Comanche, $15,662; Creek, $15,287; Iroquois, $15,079; Cherokee, $14,809; Choctaw, $14,542; Blackfoot, $14,424; Kiowa, $14,051. Poverty rate (U.S. 12.4): Navajo, 45.5; Pima, 43.3; Papago, 42.1; Sioux, 38.8; Cheyenne, 34.7; Apache, 34.1; Shohone, 32.3; Pueblo, 31.0; Athabaskan, 29.8; Chippewa, 28.2.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Job Chief Appeals to East Germans to Reconsider Emigration
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's labor chief on Tuesday urged East Germans to think twice before emigrating to the West because of the already overcrowded job market. The continuing flood of East Germans resettling in West Germany has raised enormous concerns in both countries, leading to warnings of serious economic and social problems. Federal officials say that so far this year, 66,000 East Germans have emigrated to West Germany _ an alarming average of nearly 1,800 per day arriving in one of Europe's most densely populated countries. Heinrich Franke, the head of West Germany's federal labor office, said 132,100 East Germans were registered as unemployed last month. ``I appeal to all potential resettlers to consider their future job and housing possibilities before leaving the German Democratic Republic,'' Franke said in Nuremberg. ``Whoever plans to resettle should not simply give up their old job and apartment and head off to the West by car,'' he added. As an added service to East Germans, Franke said, government employment offices near the border and in West Berlin were counseling potential immigrants on their chances. Job opportunities vary widely for the newcomers. East German craftsmen and bakers, for example, often take jobs that many young West Germans snub. But newly arrived physicians are finding a market so overcrowded that many have proposed sending doctors to East Germany as a humanitarian gesture and as a way to keep the medical personnel busy. Franke added that East German factory workers and engineers were also having a difficult time finding work in West Germany. The overall West German unemployment rate climbed to 8.5 percent in January from 8 percent in December, Franke announced. That meant that nearly 2.2 million workers were jobless in West Germany. West Germany also has been coping with an influx of tens of thousands of ethnic Germans from other parts of Eastern Europe, including Poland, Romania and the Soviet Union. They accounted for 137,500 jobless workers in addition to those from East Germany, Franke said. The influx straining the job market and the housing market has led to growing calls for curbs, including appeals from Saarland state Governor Oskar Lafontaine. Lafontaine, virtually certain to be the opposition Social Democrats' chancellor candidate this year, has said the country cannot maintain its open-door policy indefinitely. The Social Democrats' economics expert, Wolfgang Roth, predicts the influx of East Germans could jump even further in the coming weeks. ``We have the impression that about 3 million GDR citizens (East Germans) are sitting on packed suitcases,'' Roth said in an interview on Saarland state radio. Roth, a member of Parliament, added: ``When spring comes and it gets warmer, they'll get into their cars, stick a tent in the back and drive into the Federal Republic (West Germany) whether there are emergency shelters here or not.'' Reports from East Germany have said that tens of thousands more people are ready to leave if conditions do not rapidly improve in their troubled homeland. In Bonn, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has been seeking a halt to the exodus, which comes on top of more than 340,000 East Germans who arrived in West Germany last year. Kohl previously insisted that any fundamental changes would have to wait until a democratically elected government takes over in East Berlin, even though free elections won't take place nearly six weeks. On Tuesday, however, Kohl called for immediate talks with East Germany on a monetary union between the two states, to try to rescue East Germany's crumbling economy and stop the growing exodus. Several state governments have proposed curbing the massive financial assistance paid to the East German resettlers and the ethnic German newcomers.

DOC.HEAD: Tunnel Explosion Injures 10 Workers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with injured railroad workers at 10, number of commuters served by Metro-North. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A maintenance crew working in a commuter railroad tunnel below midtown Manhattan apparently sliced through a live cable today, causing an explosion and fire that injured 10 workers, authorities said. The 12:38 p.m. blast under the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel shut down all service to and from Grand Central Terminal, the starting and ending point for trains serving 95,000 commuters between New York City and its northern suburbs. There was no word on whether service would resume for the evening rush hour, said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. The blast occurred after a machine used by Metro-North workers to tamp down railroad ties apparently cut through a power cable, he said. Ten Metro-North workers were taken from the scene suffering from smoke inhalation, including one who suffered a smoke-induced asthma attack, authorities said. Two firefighters were reported slightly injured. Three of the railroad workers were taken to a hospital; the rest of the injured were treated at the scene or at a firehouse, authorities said. There were no trains in the tunnel at the time of the explosion, Brucker said. Smoke wafted into the Waldorf lobby but caused no major problems, hotel spokeswoman Marilyn Marks. The smoky fire was extinguished within about an hour, said Fire Department spokesman Efrain Parrilla.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Tax Chief Ends Fight For Job Over Probe of Businessman
DOC.TEXT: Florida's revenue director resigned Tuesday over allegations she abused her powers, denying wrongdoing but saying her battle with breast cancer and the prospect of a long fight left her little choice. Katie Tucker, 46, who served almost 20 months as chief of the Department of Revenue, was under fire for ordering a 1988 tax investigation that singled out a former political opponent of her husband's. ``I emphatically and unequivocally deny that I have ever abused the power of my office for any purpose,'' Ms. Tucker said. ``I just feel like I was blocked at every turn.'' The resignation does not necessarily end her troubles. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating whether she tampered with documents in an effort to clear her name, a third-degree felony. Ms. Tucker and her attorney, Barry Richard, told Gov. Bob Martinez and the Cabinet that the director could not defend herself against a perception of abusing her office and that she did not want to put her family through ``a protracted defense where right or wrong has little to do with the outcome.'' She also brought up her ongoing battle with breast cancer, noting her doctors said the additional stress of the battle to save her job could contribute to her health problems. ``It's not worth even a moment more of wasted energy on fights that can only hurt me,'' she said. ``God knows the truth, has a purpose to all of this, and God knows what you have lost.'' Despite previous statements that indicated Ms. Tucker hoped to persuade the governor and Cabinet to retain her, Richard said a Monday night meeting convinced her there was no chance of that. Martinez, who previously called for her resignation, said Ms. Tucker did not manage to convince him of her innocence and made contradictory statements about what happened. ``If anything, I'm more convinced now than I was at the time we suspended her that she no longer needs to stay at the state Department of Revenue,'' the governor said. ``I think it was not only the incident itself but how she went about trying to explain the incident that gives you great cause for concern.'' Deputy Comptroller Larry Fuchs was named interim director. Fuchs, 47, said he would not seek the job on a permanent basis. A search committee is to find candidates for a replacement. Ms. Tucker was suspended by Martinez and the Cabinet two weeks ago to allow her time to respond to a Department of Law Enforcement report on the tax investigation of businesses owned by Donald G. Resha. The FDLE found that Ms. Tucker committed no crime but ordered the tax probe against Resha, who lost a 1985 AFL-CIO election to her husband, Daniel Miller. Ms. Tucker has maintained she ordered a larger probe aimed at finding whether video stores such as those owned by Resha were failing to pay taxes and whether they were involved in other criminal wrongdoing. She denied the probe was a vendetta. After reports that Ms. Tucker had visited her office at night and was seen typing documents, the FDLE last week confiscated some files and her typewriter to find out whether any documents had been tampered with. Ms. Tucker denied the allegations. As for her future, Ms. Tucker said she intended to take some time off ``to ski and to fish'' before deciding what to do next.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Says Legalization of ANC a Sign of Hope
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson said Tuesday that South African President F.W. de Klerk's lifting of a ban on the African National Congress is a sign of hope for the nation's black majority. The lifting of bans on the ANC and some 60 opposition groups, announced by de Klerk on Friday, will help pave the way toward ``a new South Africa,'' Jackson said in Lusaka. Jackson is scheduled to travel to South Africa on Wednesday, his first visit since 1979. His visa requests repeatedly were turned down until his most recent application. In Cape Town, Foreign Minister Pik Botha indicated it was not the most opportune time for Jackson to visit because of rapid political changes in the country. ``Right now we are in the midst of important decisions, and it's not easy to deal with all of the fanfare of some of our American friends,'' Botha said at a briefing. But he said Jackson was welcome. Jackson arrived in Zambia on Tuesday after visiting Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Britain and was to hold talks with President Kenneth Kaunda, who is also chairman of the six-nation African Frontline bloc neighboring South Africa. The civil rights leader has said he hopes to meet de Klerk and jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela on his current trip. He was invited to South Africa by freed ANC leader Walter Sisulu and the South African Council of Churches. Botha complained that Jackson, a former candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, alternates his statements on sanctions depending on his audience. He said Jackson has told South African officials he favors an end to punitive sanctions against the country to pressure for an end to apartheid, but then makes public speeches appealing for new sanctions. ``The time has come when Jesse and I must talk straight to each other,'' Botha said. He added that Jackson's visit will have nothing to do with Mandela's release, because the decision already has been made. ``He can enjoy the aftermath, but not claim any credit,'' Botha said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Accepts Bank's Plea Agreement to Forfeit $15 Million
DOC.TEXT: An international bank sentenced to forfeit $15 million for laundering drug money has begun turning records over to prosecutors, including documents of financial dealings with Manuel Noriega. The deposed Panamanian dictator was a longtime customer of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International branch in Panama. Court records show he maintained accounts totaling at least $23 million at various BCCI branches before he was indicted in drug cases in Tampa and Miami in February 1988. The government is trying to trace his money. Although prosecutors didn't mention Noriega, they said the bank had pledged full cooperation. Sentencing Monday resolved charges against the bank. Five bank officers remain on trial, including Amjad Awan, longtime personal banker to Noriega. U.S. District Judge W. Terrell Hodges listened to bank attorneys and government prosecutors defend the plea agreement before deciding to stick to terms of the agreement despite calls from Congress for harsher penalties. The Luxembourg-based bank, with branches in 73 countries, could have faced up to $28 million in fines. Subsidiaries BCCI, S.A. and BCCI Overseas Ltd. admitted to conspiracy and 30 acts of money laundering. The two divisions pleaded guilty Jan. 16 to cocaine-related money-laundering charges, agreed to forfeit a record $14 million plus $1 million in interest frozen earlier, and promised to open their books. The plea agreement called for the bank to receive a suspended fine and five years probation, with banking practices supervised by the Federal Reserve System. Prosecutors also said they wouldn't bring any other charges against the bank arising from the $32 million international money-laundering case. ``Those who have criticized the agreement are misinformed and did not understand the facts of the case,'' said bank attorney Lawrence Wechsler. ``This is no slap on the wrist,'' said Greg Kehoe, first Assistant U.S. Attorney.

DOC.HEAD: Maori Protesters Disrupt Queen's New Zealand Celebrations
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Maori protesters plunged into the water and jeered Tuesday as Queen Elizabeth II came ashore to mark the 150th anniversary of the treaty that ceded New Zealand to Britain. About 400 protesters were among the 5,000 people who gathered to greet the queen at the site where the treaty of Waitanga was signed by 500 Maori chiefs and Navy Capt. William Hobson, who represented the queen's great-great grandmother, Victoria. The protesters, some shouting ``Go home, Queenie,'' plunged into chest-deep water as the queen's spectacular flotilla neared the shore. The queen arrived by navy launch, escorted by 22 giant war canoes, some with up to 200 crewmen. After she got into an open car for a short drive to the ceremonial treaty site, a woman threw a black T-shirt at her as she drove by. Police spokesman Tony Bouchier said there were five arrests for minor offenses, including an unidentified Maori woman who threw the shirt. The queen looked startled as the T-shirt landed in her car. Bouchier said onlookers held the woman and called police. The queen, accompanied by her husband, Prince Philip, wore a feather cloak in the hot sun. Several Maori dancers in the procession fainted in front her her car and were carried off. Fire department trucks sprayed torrents of cold water on the sweltering crowds.
