In a traditional welcome, Maori warriors with tatooed faces challenged the queen as she arrived at the treaty site, dancing forward, jabbing the air with spears, rolling their eyes, and sticking out their tongues in a symbolic test to determine if a newcomer is friend or foe. In the open stands, Maori activists unfurled banners and kept up a chant of of ``Honor the treaty! Honor the treaty!'' They booed Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer, but stayed silent for the queen's address in which she said, ``I am a descendant of one party of the treaty of Waitangi and many here today are the descendants of the original Maori signatories.'' In an unusually frank admission, she admitted the treaty had its weaknesses and that it had not always been followed. Many Maori were disappointed, but ``it is encouraging to know ... progress has been made in putting things right,'' she said. ``Today we are strong enough and honest enough to learn the lessons of the last 150 years and to admit that the treaty has been imperfectly observed,'' she said. Later, she met with the descendants of the original chiefs, many of whom are demanding land, forests and fishing grounds be returned to Maori people under terms of the 1840 treaty. The treaty is regarded by European and Maori New Zealanders as the foundation of modern New Zealand, a nation of 3.4 million people of whom 12.5 percent are Maori. The queen flew to Waitangi on the Bay of Islands from Auckland as part of a 16-day visit.

DOC.HEAD: Mild Earthquake Triggers `Unusual Event' at Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: A mild earthquake off California's coast triggered a routine alert at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant Tuesday, but few people felt it and there were no reports of damage or injuries. The U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park said the quake at 10:14 a.m. PST measured 4.1 on the Richter scale, but the California Institute of Technology seismology laboratory in Pasadena said the magnitude was 3.6. The agencies gave about the same location for the epicenter, with the Geological Survey placing it 33 miles southwest of San Luis Obispo and Caltech putting it 40 miles west of Santa Maria. ``We didn't feel it and we didn't get one call from anybody outside Diablo Canyon,'' said San Luis Obispo County sheriff's Sgt. Leon Cole. As is routine for earthquakes detected at the twin-reactor nuclear plant, the quake triggered an ``unusual event,'' the lowest-grade emergency declaration, but both reactors kept operating at full power, said Brad Thomas, spokesman for Pacific Gas & Electric Co., which runs the plant. ``One person reported here at the plant they felt it,'' Thomas said. ``That requires us to declare an unusual event. We do a plant walkdown and make sure there was no damage of any kind.'' Diablo Canyon's accelerometer, which measures the force exerted by earthquakes, detected quake-caused motion equal to only one five-hundredth the force of gravity, Thomas said. The Richter scale is an indirect gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, while 4 can cause moderate damage.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Caviar isn't kosher, but the Technion institute in Haifa says it has developed a substitute that is. The delicacy is off limits to observant Jews because it is made from the eggs of sturgeon, which do not have scales. Kosher dietary rules ban the eating of fish without scales. The new product, which took three years to develop, is made from a kosher fish, Technion said in a statement. It also will sell at a bargain price, Technion said. Russian caviar sells for about $48 an ounce on world markets, but the kosher substitute will go for about $2, it said. The new product is reported to look and taste like the real thing. Martin McDonald, a chef at the Dan Panorama Hotel in Tel Aviv, taste-tested the new product and proclaimed it ``as close to the real thing as you can get.''

An advertising campaign promoting an Italian restaurant landed an advertising executive in the hot seat when a television station misinterpreted notes about a coming ``hit.'' It started when a black bag containing a water pistol and a note scrawled on a burned piece of paper reading ``Be Prepared for the Hit'' was delivered to television station KCNC last week. No other explanation was included. Station employees called police. Then came a bottle of Chianti with a second note that said: ``Save this _ the hit is coming next Wednesday.'' KCNC photographers videotaped a car leaving the station. Police traced the car's plate and staked out the Sales 1 On 1 advertising office operated by Scot Rogers and Terri Radcliffe. Rogers, who was driving the car, was apprehended Friday when he arrived at work. Police took him to their station and gave him a four-hour grilling. ``We lost days of work and our neighbors think we're criminals,'' Radcliffe said. ``It was just a different way of marketing _ and no one else took it seriously.'' They had sent the same packets to most entertainment-food writers in Denver. The final piece of the promotion will come Wednesday _ a lunch from Berardi's restaurant with the message ``Mike Berardi's _ The Hit of Denver,'' Radcliffe said. Radcliffe said she even plans to send one to the officer who arrested Rogers _ to show there are no hard feelings.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Accused of Subsidizing Pornographic Stage Show
DOC.TEXT: A Republican congressman is beginning a new attack on the National Endowment for the Arts, promising weekly examples showing the federal agency uses tax dollars to subsidize pornography. In his first ``Dear Colleague'' letter to fellow House members, Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., accused the arts endowment of underwriting a series of sexually explicit performances by porn video star Annie Sprinkle at the Kitchen, a private performing arts center in lower Manhattan. At one point in her act, he wrote, she commented that ``Usually I get paid a lot of money for this, but tonight it's government funded.'' Endowment Chairman John E. Frohnmayer denied that was the case. Frohnmayer said in a telephone interview Tuesday that the endowment gave a $60,000 grant to the Kitchen last year solely for operating expenses, but did not award any grant for Miss Sprinkle's 12-performance show. ``I want to make it very clear that we do not fund anything that is obscene and, in fact, my view is that art and obscenity are mutually exclusive terms,'' he said. ``I think those who oppose obscenity _ and I count myself among them _ might more fruitfully look elsewhere.'' He added, ``I don't intend to rise to the bait any time someone comes up with a new horror story.'' Barbara Tsumagari, executive director of the Kitchen, said in New York that Miss Sprinkle's show was not financed with federal funds. Ms. Tsumagari said the New York State Council on the Arts gave a $25,000 grant to the Kitchen to underwrite part of its season of 54 performances, but specifically excluded Miss Sprinkle's show. That was confirmed by council spokesman Tim Mulligan. Frohnmayer said the NEA gave the New York arts council a $500,000 grant last year for staff salaries and other administrative expenses. Under a headline that read, ``The National Endowment for the Arts Is At It Again,'' Rohrabacher charged that ``Annie Sprinkle's titillating masterpiece received your constituents' tax dollars.'' He urged his colleagues to remind Frohnmayer that ``he is dealing with taxpayer funds and is accountable for how they are spent, just like every other head of every other federal agency.'' Rohrabacher added: ``If the NEA can't hold itself responsible to the U.S. taxpayer, it's our job to make them responsible.'' The congressman's press secretary, David Eisner, said his boss plans to publicize similar examples every week or so, highlighting what he called the endowment's ``use of tax dollars for triple-X, hard-core pornographic stuff.'' Eisner said the NEA's supporters dismiss such cases as ``isolated incidents,'' but ``we are starting a campaign to really work hard to show that's not the case. This is a systemic problem.'' Frohnmayer, a former Portland, Ore., lawyer, took command of the NEA last September amid a political controversy over a touring exhibition, including sexually explicit pictures by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, that was partially financed by the endowment. That controversy prompted Congress, in approving a $171 million budget for the NEA last October, to ban federal financial support for obscene art _ deemed to be lacking in ``literary, artistic, political or scientific value.'' The House defeated a Rohrabacher proposal to abolish the endowment, an independent federal agency that underwrites a wide variety of artists and arts institutions with tax-paid matching grants. Rohrabacher's new campaign could prove politically embarrassing for the NEA at a time when the House and Senate are planning hearings on legislation that would authorize extending the life of the endowment. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., the endowment's most vocal Senate critic, peppered NEA officials last November and December with demands for details of the endowment's history of support for eight arts groups and nine artists. Helms' letters indicated he was concerned about the sexual content of their work. Arts supporters say Helms is conducting a campaign of intimidation against NEA grant recipients who specialize in experimental and controversial arts projects. Frohnmayer, asked about the Helms letters, said, ``I deem all congressional inquiries to be legitimate and I respond to them, and that's what I intend to do in this case.''

DOC.HEAD: National Press Club Won't Rename Mencken Library
DOC.TEXT: The library at the National Press Club will continue to bear the name of journalist H.L. Mencken despite what the club's secretary described as ``despicable'' remarks about Jews and blacks in Mencken's recently published diaries. The club's board of governors voted 7-4 Monday to retain Mencken's name after receiving appeals from notables including historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., who urged the club not to rename its library ``in an excess of self-righteousness.'' Mick Rood, a reporter for the States News Service and the club's secretary, argued for removing Mencken's name, saying his ``remarks about Jews and blacks were ... despicable.'' ``In all his years of running down, say, the Methodists, the context was ideological _ a hard-edged social commentary,'' Rood said. ``Whenever he excoriated the Philistines, he presented a body of convincing evidence. The only evidence behind his anti-Semitic remarks was venom.'' ``This club needn't honor this man in this way,'' Rood said. ``We can admire, but we needn't revere.'' Schlesinger, in a letter to the club, said, ``Mencken had his faults, like all the rest of us, and he made his mistakes, some of them awful, but he was a great newspaperman and basically a liberating influence on American society . I hope the National Press Club will not turn its back on him in an excess of self-righteousness.'' Economist John Kenneth Galbraith and journalist Lawrence E. Spivak also wrote to the board urging that the Mencken name be retained. ``His comments on Jews and blacks are no worse than those one could have heard around Harvard or any other major university in those days and without evident shock,'' Galbraith said. ``You are not, I trust, expelling Ivy League graduates of that period to the extent that they survive.'' Spivak, who succeeded Mencken as editor of The American Mercury magazine and later moderated ``Meet the Press'' on NBC radio and television, wrote, ``Mencken was a great journalist, but like many of us, was stupid about a lot of things. Actually, his attitude toward Jews was like that of many self-satisfied Jews that he knew. Because they were Jewish, they felt they could say whatever they wanted about other Jews without being considered anti-Semitic.'' Morton C. Paulson, associate editor of Changing Times magazine, told his fellow board members: ``I am convinced that he was far from being a racist, a bigot or sympathetic to the Third Reich. ``The last column he wrote for the Baltimore Evening Sun before he suffered a disabling stroke was a withering attack on the city for segregating a public park.'' ``In any event,'' he added, ``nothing will change the fact that his contributions to journalism were extraordinary and he was one of the greatest literary scholars of all times.'' The library was named the H.L. Mencken Library and Reference Center when it opened in 1984. In naming it, the board noted that Mencken once said he could be the the second best expert on any subject if he had a first-class library behind him. Mencken, who died in 1956, was a long-time columnist for The Evening Sun in Baltimore, as well as the author of a highly praised work on the American language and a classic memoir. His recently published diaries contain such phrases as ``a brisk clever Jew'' and ``a highly dubious Jew'' and he says of ``colored'' women that ``they are all essentially child-like, and even hard experience does not teach them anything.'' The motion defeated by the board would have removed Mencken's name and left the renaming of the library to future action. Those voting against the motion, and thus to keep the Mencken name, were Kathryn Kahler of Newhouse News Service, board chairwoman; John Peterson, The Detroit News, vice president of the club; Gil Klein, Media General, vice chairman of the board; Tom Squitieri, USA Today, club treasurer; Ed Prina, retired Washington bureau chief for Copley Newspapers, financial secretary; Greg Spears, Knight-Ridder Newspapers; and Rick Thomas, Roll Call Report Syndicate. Board members voting for the motion, and thus to remove the name, were Frances Hardin, Cable News Network; Dennis Melamed, free-lance journalist; Clayton Boyce of Knight Ridder; and Rood.

DOC.HEAD: Upscale Restaurateurs Scale Back for Price Conscious Consumers
DOC.TEXT: Some of nation's restaurateurs are scaling back their prices to lure the cautious customers of the '90s, who have become as concerned about their wallets as they are about their waistlines. ``Instead of breast of duck, we're serving cheddar-stuffed meatloaf,'' said Brad Grill, manager of the upscale Harvest restaurant in nearby Cambridge. ``The days of the $27 free-range chicken are over,'' Richard Krause, chef and restaurant owner in New York City. ``No one wants to pay that. It's too much money, no matter how good it is.'' At Krause's new restaurant, The Rose Cafe, entrees range from $12.95 to $17.95. He charged $17 to $24 for entrees at his recently closed Melrose. ``With the shrinking discretionary dollar, people are choosing places more intelligently, where there's a better value,'' Krause said in a phone interview Tuesday. The changes also reflect a better-informed customer, he said. ``Who wants to eat baby purple whatever beans at $35 a pound in the middle of winter, when there are great string beans locally?'' he said. Peter Romeo, special projects editor at Nation's Restaurant News, a trade publication, said the restaurant industry is definitely seeing a slowdown. ``It's certainly slower than the heyday of the early '80s,'' Romeo said. People have leaner budgets and baby boomers who are starting their own families are eating out less, he said from New York City. Coupled with new restaurants entering the scene every day, these developments mean ``everyone has to settle for a smaller piece of the pie.'' ``People are battening down the hatches a little bit. They want to go out two or three times a week, rather than blow the whole wad on a fancy meal,'' Romeo said. Changes in tastes were also responsible for the downturn, he said. ``The infatuation with cutting edge cuisine has kind of ended. There's not so many flower blossoms on the plate, just familiar foods,'' Romeo said. Statistics confirm a slowing of growth in the restaurant business nationwide, according to Anne Papa of the National Restaurant Association in Washington, D.C., which tracks the industry. The number of orders placed in upscale restaurants nationwide increased 5.4 percent from 1982 to 1983. By 1988, there was an annual decrease of 1.4 percent, and then it went back up slightly in 1989, by 0.5 percent, Papa said. Cambridge's Harvest, which brings in about $3 million a year, is taking steps to relieve the financial pinch, including cooking with locally grown spices and fruits rather than those flown in from Hawaii and Australia. Prices for entrees have dropped from an average of $20 to $16-$17, and they are offering more $18-$25 wines than $25-$35. ``We're trying to be more accessible to the person who wants to eat here more frequently rather than once a month,'' said Grill. Renato Burkhardt, the general manager at Locke-Ober, a famous Boston restaurant, said cutting prices is risky. ``Shaving prices can have a couple of reactions _ either people say the establishment is panicking, or they say it shouldn't have had those prices anyway,'' Burkhardt said. Locke-Ober, which grosses about $6 million a year, instead broadened its menu to include cheaper alternatives, called ``winter fare,'' Burkhardt said. The winter fare includes venison and duck from the restaurant's farm, and prices for entrees range from $18 to $20, as compared to the regular menu offerings of seafood and continental cuisine priced at $22 to $24. ``Until the storm is weathered, you have to do that to stay alive, or, let me put it this way, to get the least rained-on,'' Burkhardt said.

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Orders Trial for Braun on Weapon Possession Charge
DOC.TEXT: A man charged with killing five people in four states last July waived a preliminary hearing Tuesday and was bound over for trial for allegedly having a homemade knife in jail. Gregg Francis Braun was ordered to stand trial on a charge of possession of a deadly weapon by a prisoner. Magistrate Archie Valdez continued Braun's bond at $100,000. No trial date was set. Braun, 28, also is being held on $1 million bond in the July 23 shooting death of Springer convenience store clerk Geraldine Valdez, no relation to the magistrate. The weapon possession charge was filed after Braun allegedly threatened jail administrator Chuck Talley with a homemade knife when Talley entered the day room on Christmas Day to give Braun coffee. Talley was not injured. Assistant District Attorney Leslie Skinner said Tuesday that the weapon was never found. Braun's trial on a first-degree murder charge in the death of Ms. Valdez is scheduled May 7. Braun also is charged with two counts of murder in the July 19 shooting deaths of two convenience store clerks in his hometown of Garden City, Kan., and with first-degree murder in the July 21 shooting death of a woman in an Ardmore, Okla., flower shop. He also is charged with murdering the owner of a photo processing shop in Pampa, Texas, on July 20. Braun said at an August preliminary hearing that he killed Ms. Valdez but has denied involvement in other slayings. Ms. Valdez, 48, was shot twice in the head. Finney County Attorney Rick Pierce in Garden City has said Braun will be sent to Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas, in that order, after his murder trial in New Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Families of Slain Hmong Boys Target of Threats
DOC.TEXT: Death threats have forced the family of one Hmong teen-ager who was slain by a police officer to flee St. Paul and the family of another boy is changing apartments, relatives say. ``We got lots of phone calls, and they were telling us they were ... so happy about the shooting,'' said one of the boy's relatives, who was afraid to be identified. ``And he was telling us he was going to kill our cousin and he was going to kill our family, and after that he was going to kill the Hmong people.'' Two men made telephone death threats against a cousin of one of the dead boys, against the boy's family and against Hmong people, the families said. ``I think it would be prudent to take action to protect the family,'' Christopher Thao, an attorney representing the families, said Monday. Thai Yang and Ba See Lor, both 13, were killed in suburban Inver Grove Heights on Nov. 15 by a single shotgun blast to their backs after they ran from a stolen car. Officer Kenneth Murphy said he fired after he saw one of the boys raise what he thought was a gun. No weapon was found, but police discovered a screwdriver on the ground near the bodies. A Dakota County grand jury declined to indict Murphy. Mayor Jim Scheibel said he was notified last week of the harassment against the boys' families and was asked to ensure the cooperation of the St. Paul Public Housing Agency. Both families lived in public housing. Jon Gutzman, housing agency executive director, said he became aware of the trouble Thursday. He said his agency will process and approve a housing transfer for the family that has not left the city. The families, who fled Laos after the Vietnam War, said they have received numerous phone calls from people saying they should leave the country and quit trying to pursue prosecution or a civil lawsuit against the officer. Members of the Hmong community and their supporters reacted with outrage to the killings and the grand jury decision and sought a renewed investigation. Minnesota Attorney General Hubert H. Humphrey III refused that request in December. But Humphrey agreed to set up a task force to look into the issues of racism, police-community relations, the use of deadly force by police and sensitivity training by law enforcement officers. Those who sought the renewed investigation said the task force proposal addressed their concerns and that they would stop pushing for another probe.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Sends Farm Bill Proposals to Congress
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter sent Congress new farm proposals on Tuesday that he said maintain the federal-benefit principles of the expiring 1985 law but give farmers more flexibility. He did not, however, offer any advice for financing the proposals, saying, ``We'll have to legislate in cooperation with Congress.'' ``We don't intend to make specific recommendations on how to meet budget requirements,'' he said. The budget proposals President Bush released last week call for a cut in fiscal 1991 commodity spending of $1.5 billion. When asked specifically about those cuts, Yeutter said, ``This document doesn't deal with budget, it deals with policy.'' He said the proposals generally are modifications to the 1985 Farm Act designed to ``provide the flexibility to adjust to changes in the international marketplace; maintain the successful course set in the 1985 legislation, ... and balance the need for an abundant, safe and affordable food supply with conservation and improvement of our environment.'' To give farmers the planting flexibility Yeutter said they consider the most important part of any new legislation, he has proposed a ``normal crop acreage concept.'' This would allow farmers to plant crops based on market demand without loss of farm program benefits. It would define crops that could be substituted for program crops, authorize crop-specific acreage reduction programs and provide authority to plant on idled acres in exchange for giving up specified deficiency payments. The administration proposals follow the introduction Monday by the House Agriculture Committee of its 1990 farm bill. After a glance at Yeutter's recommendations, the House Agriculture Committee chairman, Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said he thought Congress would come up with legislation acceptable to the White House without much trouble. The Senate Agriculture Committee chairman, Sen. Patrick Leahy, responded negatively to Yeutter's proposal. ``Unfortunately, the heart of the farm bill is not there,'' said Leahy, a Vermont Democrat. ``The administration fails to tell farmers what it thinks target prices should be. ``American farmers don't know what their income will be and Congress does not know how much the administration will be willing to spend on farm programs.'' A spokeswoman for the National Farmers Union, Cheryl Cook, said her biggest criticism of the proposal was ``the lack of any information whatsover on price'' levels relating to commodity supports and targets. ``For our money, the whole purpose of the price-support program is income protection for farmers, and that seems to be the one area ... that the administration has chosen not to look at at all.'' Questioned about farm income at a news conference, Yeutter said, ``I see no reason why we should not be able to provide net farm income that would give a very satisfactory standard of living to farmers even though the federal contribution will decline.'' He also said that the effect of his proposals on consumer prices would be ``nominal.'' The administration's recommendation that crop insurance be replaced with a new crop disaster resistance program has already been floated in Congress and is likely to produce lively debate during discussion of the farm bill. The Federal Crop Insurance Corp., which provides subsidized all-risk coverage to farmers, has been losing money for many years, with many farmers spurning the insurance and relying on Congress to bail them out when an emergency arises. ``We have not found a way to make crop insurance work within realistic budget targets,'' said the secretary. He said his proposal would provide payments for individual losses whenever county-wide harvested yields fall below 65 percent of normal on a crop-by-crop basis. He envisions a standing law designed along the lines of the ad hoc disaster legislation passed in 1988 and 1989 to provide farmers drought relief. His proposal would eliminate the need for such ad hoc bills, he said. Other highlights in Yeutter's recommendations include: _A grain reserve and stocks policy based on annual contracts that give the farmer more say in deciding when stocks should be released into the marketplace. _Changing the trigger for acreage-reduction programs to be more consistent with market and farmer needs. _Extending the loan rate formula for wheat and feedgrains to upland cotton, extra longstaple cotton and rice. The 1985 loan rate formula for soybeans also would be extended. _Incentives to use perennial cover crops on set-aside acreage as a means to naturally improve soil fertility. _Methods for cutting down fraud in the use of food stamps and grants to organizations that test innovative ways to get food stamps to the homeless. _Tightening of the Farmers Home Administration programs so borrowers can't so easily abuse its loan policy. _Requiring all exported corn to be tested for aflatoxin.

DOC.HEAD: First Private TV Station in Poland Launches Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: Poland's first privately owned television station began regular broadcasts Tuesday, offering viewers in the southwestern city of Wroclaw an alternative to state-run TV, the state news agency reported. Called ``The Echo,'' the channel relays excerpts of programs from the European Astra satellite, mixed with locally produced news geared to Wroclaw and the Lower Silesia region, the PAP agency said. Broadcasts are to be limited to four hours a day for the next few months, PAP said. The station is located on the 10th floor of a student hostel in Wroclaw. A law passed last year by the new Solidarity-led government permitted private companies to set up broadcast stations for the first time in Poland's postwar history. Wroclaw residents previously could receive only Polish Television's Channels One and Two and the two Czechoslovak channels from Prague.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Proposal Offers Greater Crop Planting Flexibility
With AM-Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: An important part of the Bush administration's farm bill proposals announced Tuesday involves a ``flexibility'' plan to ease some of the government's restraints on crop plantings. One of the complaints of farmers is that Agriculture Department rules to control production are too severe and often penalize them for not following program regulations straight down the line. Wheat farmers must abide by rules in the wheat program; feed grain producers must following feed grain regulations, and so on. If there is deviation, the acreage base or history of a crop may be reduced, thereby meaning reduced USDA payments and other benefits. Current law passed in 1985 expires at the end of the 1990 crop season. It generally denies program benefits if farmers harvest crops other than the ``program'' crop for which they have a base acreage. A change in the strict rules is being sought by the administration as well as by many farm groups and members of Congress. The American Farm Bureau Federation favors acreage flexibility, with a couple of stipulations of its own. And the National Farmers Union, which is often at odds with the administration on farm policy, also likes the idea but wants to study the fine print on the administration's plan. Meanwhile, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter explained the administration's version of flexibility at a news conference. And it's not exactly a new idea, he said. Here's how it might work: Each farm is assigned a normal crop acreage, or NCA, which is the total acreage bases of program crops such as wheat, feed grains, upland and extra-long staple cotton. Plus a farm's historical plantings of oilseeds: soybeans, sunflowers and rapeseed, including canola. As it does now, the USDA each year determines whether to apply individual crop ``acreage-reduction programs'' called ARPs, if necessary, to each crop's base acreage. If so, a percentage of the farm's base _ with the exception of oilseed acres _ must be idled as an ``acreage conservation reserve,'' or ACR. To qualify for price supports and other program benefits, the farmer must comply with the ARP requirement for that crop. In addition, the sum of all NCA-crop plantings, plus land idled under the acreage reduction programs, cannot exceed the NCA for the individual farm. In return, the farmer is allowed some flexibility without losing benefits or suffering penalties on the farm's acreage base. ``We're proposing that we would establish ARPs, acreage reduction programs, on a crop-by-crop basis, just as we do now,'' Yeutter said. ``In other words, there'll be a wheat ARP and a corn, or a feed grains ARP, and a rice ARP, whatever it may be.'' Basically, on the rest of the acreage, the farmer will be able to grow any of the so-called program crops, plus any of the oilseed crops, he said. ``It's really what I would call a modified NCA program ... as the NCA existed back in the '70s or thereabouts,'' Yeutter said. In an example, a 300-acre farm included a 100-acre wheat base, a 100-acre corn base, and 100 acres of soybeans. The mythical wheat program included a 5 percent ARP and the corn program, a 10 percent ARP. ``That means the farmer has to pull out 5 acres of land for his wheat ARP, 10 acres for his corn ARP, and then under present law, that means he'll plant 95 acres of wheat and he'll plant 90 acres of corn,'' Yeutter said. ``And then on the other 100 acres he'll grow soybeans or whatever.'' Shifting to ``the simplest example'' of flexibility as proposed in the administration plan, Yeutter said the ARPs would be the same as they are now _ five acres of wheat and 10 acres of corn. But on the remaining 285 acres, Yeutter said, the farmer would be allowed to grow wheat, corn, any of the oilseeds, rice, cotton or whatever. ``And he can plant that in any proportions he wishes,'' Yeutter said. ``If he wants to plant it all to wheat, he can plant it all to wheat. If he wants to plant it all to corn, he can plant it all to corn.'' Yeutter described several variations of the plan in which the 300-acre farmer could plant certain crops on his set-aside acres, provided his acres eligible for payments are reduced accordingly. Oilseeds and experimental crops such as kenaf used for newsprint are among the options under the flexibility plan, he said.

DOC.HEAD: California Couple Gets Warm Surprise in `Cold' North Dakota
DOC.TEXT: A retired couple from California borrowed jackets and parkas and set out to experience first-hand a real blowing, snowing, below-zero North Dakota winter. They got a warm surprise. When Al and Felicia Phillips, of Escalon, Calif., east of San Francisco, arrived about three weeks ago, they discovered unseasonably warm temperatures with highs around 40 degrees. Tuesday's temperature in Bismarck had climbed to 40 by 1 p.m. In the eastern part of the state, Devils Lake reached a record 44, within 10 degrees of that day's temperatures in parts of northern California. The Phillips, who travel on a modest retirement budget and didn't want to rent a car all the time they were here, also found Bismarck has no city bus system. ``As a result, we've done a lot of walking,'' said Phillips. They're making the best of things while hoping for a blizzard. The Phillips, who have been married 48 years, have kicked up their heels at a square dance, sampled German food and joined the cheering at a high school hockey game since they arrived Jan. 18. ``The nice people have more than made up for the lack of cold weather,'' Phillips said. They said they had been hankering for cold weather and decided to spend a winter month in some city that fit the bill. ``We thought North Dakota had to be a sure thing,'' Mrs. Phillips said. They considered other North Dakota cities but decided Bismarck sounded colder. ``We just came for the weather. That was the main thing,'' Mrs. Phillips said. But her husband added:, ``Now that we're here, the people are the main thing.'' They plan to return home on Feb. 20, after renting a car long enough to check out other North Dakota cities. And they promise to come back to see what the state is like in the summer. They aren't bothered by the fact that their California friends think they're crazy, Phillips said. ``If I had had a nickel for every time I heard that word, we could have paid for our plane fare,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Founding Priest of Covenant House Ordered to Take Leave
DOC.TEXT: The founding priest of Covenant House was directed by his order to take leave of his duties Tuesday while it investigates the allegations of sexual misconduct against him. Earlier in the day, the Rev. Bruce Ritter issued a statement saying he had elected to take several weeks off from running the shelter program for runaways so he could rest and recuperate from stress. But Ritter's order of Roman Catholic priests, the Franciscans, said it had instructed him to relinquish his duties until its investigation was done. A spokesman, the Rev. Juniper Connelly, said he had no idea how long that may be. The New York Times on Tuesday reported the Franciscan authorities' investigation of charges by a former Covenant House client that the 62-year-old Ritter had a sexual relationship with him in 1973, when he was 14. Ritter, a prominent campaigner against the sexual exploitation of youth, characterized such charges, now made by three men, as ``garbage,'' telling the Times he ``never, never'' had sexual relations with any youth in Covenant House. In his statement, he said: ``I am profoundly saddened by the allegations against me and the need to deny them constantly. I have no way of proving my innocence. My accusers cannot establish my guilt. ``I devoutly hope the inquiries currently under way will bring an end to this incredibly painful chapter in my life.'' Besides the Franciscan investigation, the Manhattan district attorney's office is investigating Covenant House's use of funds and its provision of false identification to at least one youth. Moreover, Covenant House said Monday that it had provided a former male prostitute with the identity of a 10-year-old boy who died of leukemia in 1980. It acted without the knowledge of the boy's parents, saying it sought to protect the ex-prostitute from enemies. The former prostitute, Kevin Kite, 26, is one of those making charges against Ritter. In December, the New York Post reported Kite's allegations that he had an eight-month sexual relationship with Ritter beginning a year ago. He said Ritter gave him money, housing and gifts in exchange for sex. Ritter has denied Kite's charges, and Kite's father stepped forward to describe his son as a chronic liar. The accusation struck at a time of great success for Covenant House, which has grown to become the nation's largest shelter program for runaway youths since he founded it in 1968. It runs 17 shelters with more than 2,000 beds in the United States, Canada and Latin America, and planned a broad expansion this year. But donations, after tripling in four years, have declined since Kite's charges were made public _ Covenant House took in $3 million less than its expected $15 million in December _ and expansion plans are on hold. At a Dec. 14 news conference, Ritter warned that ``copycats'' might make charges similar to Kite's. But the newly public accusations from two more former Covenant House clients appear to predate the December disclosure. On Jan. 24, the Village Voice reported that John Melican, now of Seattle, charged in an unpublished interview in 1986 that he had a 13-year sexual relationship with Ritter. Melican repeated the charges to the Times, saying the relationship began when he was 13. The Times reported that the third man, Darryl Bassile, 31, now of Ithaca, charged that he had sexual relations with Ritter in 1973. After learning of Kite's charges, Bassile said, he made his own complaint to the Franciscan Friary in Union City, N.J., and contacted the Times when he had not heard back from the friary. The Franciscan minister provincial, the Rev. Conall McHugh, sits on the board of Covenant House. McHugh said the order tried unsuccessfully to reach Bassile before succeeding on Jan. 24. Now, he said, Franciscan leaders ``have directed Father Bruce to begin a period of rest and recuperation without responsibility for Covenant House until this inquiry is completed.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush's First Economic Report Says Nation Thriving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs with Boskin comments from briefing after after 10th graf pvs, He also; adds 4 grafs with congressional reaction. ^By MARTIN CRUTSINGER
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, proclaiming the United States in ``excellent economic health,'' sent his first economic report to Congress on Tuesday. He promised to restrain government spending and push for tax cuts to foster even more prosperity. Bush said he would continue his fight to get Congress to reduce the capital gains tax and pledged anew to fight protectionist trade barriers. His message did not dwell on what many see as the biggest failures of the Reagan years, the record federal budget deficits and the huge trade imbalances that transformed America from the largest creditor nation to the largest debtor country. Bush did pledge to deal with ``inherited problems,'' but his formula for dealing with the budget deficit tracked Reagan's approach, promising to oppose new taxes while relying on economic growth and restraints in government spending to erase the deficit by 1993. Many private economists say the administration's economic outlook for the next five years is too optimistic. The administration foresees no recession with the gross national product expanding at annual rates of 3 percent or higher from 1991 through 1995. ``Economic expansions ... do not die of old age. A recession is not likely in the near term,'' the economic report states. While stressing traditional Republican free-market themes, the 419-page, annual ``Economic Report of the President'' avoided some of the more doctrinaire positions on monetary policy and supply-side economics sounded during the Reagan years. Instead, Bush used the message, the first presented by his administration, to lay out generally mainstream economic goals such as the need for growth-oriented policies and renewed efforts to bring the federal deficit under control. On taxes, Bush said, ``One of my highest legislative priorities this year is to reduce the captial gains tax rate. This tax reform would promote risk-taking and entrepreneurship by lowering the cost of capital. ... A capital gains tax cut would stimulate saving and investment throughout the economy.'' He also said that ``the primary economic goal of my administration is to achieve the highest possible rate of sustainable economic growth,'' Bush said in the report. ``Growth is the key to raising living standards, to leaving a legacy of prosperity for our children, to uplifting those most in need and to maintaining America's leadership in the world.'' Addressing the differences between Bush and Reagan on economic issues, Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, suggested that the administration was more willing to use government to address problems in such fields as boosting spending for research, fighting illegal drugs and expanding Head Start. ``I think that President Reagan believed that not only was government the problem, but that it was rare indeed that government could be a positive force in solving the problem,'' Boskin said at a briefing for reporters. ``(Bush) does believe in some areas the federal government has an important role to play.'' In the economic report, Bush reviewed the period since the end of the 1981-82 recession, a peacetime record of seven years of expansion. In that time, more than 20 million jobs have been created, driving the unemployment rate down to a level not seen since the early 1970s. ``Our excellent economic health will allow us to build on the successes of the 1980s as we prepare for the next century,'' Bush said. Bush declared his top trade priority was successful completion of the current 96-nation round of trade talks. The president is seeking to eliminate farm subsidies and expand trading opportunities in banking, insurance and other service industries in which American firms excel. ``We cannot remain competitive by avoiding competition. My administration will therefore continue to resist calls for protection and managed trade,'' he said. Bush also rejected proposals for the federal government to promote an ``industrial policy'' of picking winners and losers among emerging technologies, declaring that ``second-guessing the market is the way to raise government spending and taxes, not living standards.'' While sometimes critical of the Federal Reserve Board's interest rate policies in his first year in office, the president praised the central bank for a ``high degree of policy credibility.'' In a departure from the monetarist leanings of the Reagan administration, Bush's economic outlook warned against a reliance on ``rigid monetary targeting,'' the process promoted by certain economists in which the central bank focuses solely on controlling the growth of the nation's money supply as the way to keep inflation at bay. On other topics, the economic report: _Devoted an entire chapter to environmental regulation, including the president's proposed amendments to the Clean Air Act, which environmental critics contend do not go far enough to safeguard the environment. ``A healthy environment and a sound economy can be compatible if _ and only if _ environmental regulation is well-designed,'' the report states. _Deplored Americans' low savings rates, offering as remedies a cut in the tax on capital gains, profits earned on the sale of assets, and proposals to expand the use of Individual Retirement Accounts to first-time home buyers and to create a new Family Savings Account that would allow married couples to invest up to $5,000 tax-free as long as the money was held for seven years. The administration's tax-cut proposals came under heavy fire at a congressional hearing. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said that such tax breaks have done little to boost saving. ``Tinkering with the tax code is the worst thing we could do,,'' he said. ``This is just gimmickry that we are going to suffer for in the long run.'' Other Democrats on the committee assailed Bush's proposed cut in taxes on capital gains as a giveaway to the rich, but Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady responded by saying it ``may be viewed as unfortunate'' that most of the benefit of cutting taxes on capital gains would go to those with incomes over $200,000 a year. It is those people who have the most to invest, Brady noted.

DOC.HEAD: Rightist Movement Figure Dead at 91
DOC.TEXT: Bin Akao, an activist in Japan's rightist movement, died of heart failure Tuesday at the age of 91. For 35 years, Akao was a fixture in central Tokyo's Ginza district, where he preached to passing shoppers and office workers through a loudspeaker from a truck painted with such slogans as ``Japanese unite under the emperor.'' Akao, a native of Nagoya in western Japan, started as a socialist activist when he organized a farmers' union after graduating from junior high school, but he became a rightist after he was jailed in 1925 for his union activism. Akao was elected to the House of Representatives, the lower house of Parliament, from a Tokyo district in 1942, but said he was expelled in 1943 because he opposed Japan's attack on the United States. He said he called instead for Japan to join with the Western powers in a move to crush the Soviet Union. After the war, the Allied occupation forces banned him from holding public office. When the ban ended in 1951, he established the anti-Communist Great Japan Patriots' Party, of which he was president. The rightist political organization has a membership of 150 in Japan, according to National Police Agency figures. Akao also was a leader in the nationwide rightist movement, comprising 840 groups with 120,000 members. After the war, he ran unsuccessfully more than 20 times for Parliament and other offices. Akao was believed associated with a series of right-wing terrorist acts in postwar Japan, including the 1960 assassination of then Japan Socialist Party Chairman Inejiro Asanuma by one of Akao's followers. Akao had a record of 25 arrests for violent political activities. On his sound truck, flanked by several flags of Japan, the United States and anti-Communist Taiwan, Akao would call in his gravelly voice for a strengthening of the U.S.-Japan military alliance and Japan's emperor system, and the toppling of the Communist government of the Soviet Union. In some of his speeches, he referred to leaders of Japan's conservative governing party, the Liberal Democrats, as ``idiots'' and ``money-grubbers'' after a series of money scandals. His party headquarters was decorated with portraits of emperors, Buddha, Jesus Christ, the Chinese philospher Confucius and Otoya Yamaguchi, the 17-year-old who stabbed Asanuma. He spoke of hoping to unite Confucianism, Buddhism, Communism and Christianity into a culture of unity and peace. Japan's emperor would be a suitable leader, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Schools Closed in Zambia Capital to Curb Cholera Outbreak
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday closed all schools in the capital for an indefinite period as a preventative measure to help stop the spread of cholera, the health ministry said. Twelve people have died and 57 remain hospitalized since the cholera outbreak began affecting central and suburban Lusaka, an area encompassing 1 million people. The government announced Monday night that it had allocated $1.3 million toward fighting the intestinal disease, which is spread mainly by poor sanitation and hygiene. Zambia is one of Africa's most indebted nations. Its capital, long plagued by bureaucratic mismanagement, is surrounded by mud-built shanties without plumbing. In heavy seasonal rains open-air pit toilets have overflowed, adding to the city's health hazards, city officials said. Health minister Mavus Muyundu said the money would pay for drugs, transport, fuel and the manning of eight 24-hour clinics in affected areas of the city. She also appealed to city dwellers to bury piles of garbage that accumulated in the streets because only six city garbage trucks were in running order.

DOC.HEAD: November Outflow the Lowest in 4 Months
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan depositors withdrew $4.9 billion in November as the thrift industry continued to shrink in response to tougher financial standards enacted last summer, the government said Tuesday. It was the lowest level of withdrawals in four months, but was still the 17th outflow in 18 months and brought total deposits at the nation's 2,889 S&Ls down to $947 billion, the Office of Thrift Supervision said. Withdrawals in the first 11 months of 1989 totaled $64.9 billion. Outflows, which hit a record of $10.8 billion in January 1989, were $6.4 billion in October. The withdrawals early in the year were attributed to eroding depositor confidence and rising interest rates offered by investment alternatives such as money market mutual funds. Economists say outflows in the last half of the year are part of a deliberate strategy by S&Ls to comply with bailout legislation enacted Aug. 9. ``Most of the shrinkage was likely due to thrifts' continuing strategy to reduce assets to comply with new capital requirements,'' said economist James Freund of the thrift office. The new standard, effective Dec. 7, requires S&L owners to put more of their own money behind their institutions. Weak thrift associations that have trouble raising capital are finding they must reduce their portfolios of loans and other investments. As they sell assets, they need fewer deposits. The industry's assets declined by $8.8 billion in November after a $6.3 billion drop in October. They totaled $1.28 trillion, compared with $1.33 trillion a year earlier. The 275 failed thrifts under government control at the end of November, like the rest of the industry, experienced shrinkage. Government-controlled thrifts lost $2.2 billion in deposits and $2.3 billion in assets. Privately controlled thrifts shed $2.7 billion in deposits and $6.5 billion in assets. Weakness in housing and construction was reflected in a decline in mortgages originated by thrifts to $14.5 billion, compared with $15.8 billion a month earlier and $18.3 billion a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Six Die in Mobile Home Fire
DOC.TEXT: A woodburning stove installed just a day earlier was believed to have caused a fire Tuesday that killed six people, four of them children, officials said. ``Apparently the flue pipe was a couple of inches too short where it ran through the ceiling,'' said Washington County Sheriff Ronnie L. Skiles. ``The stove had also been mounted on wooden blocks. We're not sure yet whether it fell off or just what happened.'' Washington County Coroner Mal Gum said all of the victims died of smoke inhalation and were badly burned. He said their bodies were found in or near their beds. Killed were Michelle Miller, 22; James Miller, 3; Alicia Miller, 1; Davie Light, 18; 3-week-old Jessica Light, and Rachel Hafley, 3. Skiles said the fire, in the Jarvis trailer court about a mile north of Potosi, was first reported at 5:26 a.m. and a deputy was at the scene minutes later. Skiles said all of the children except Rachel Hafley, a neighbor he believed, belonged to Michelle Miller or Davie Light. Skiles said officials believed the fire was caused by a woodburning stove that was removed and reinstalled in a new place in the trailer Monday. Skiles said there were no smoke detectors in the trailer.

DOC.HEAD: US Official Says Other Nations Lag in Controlling Drug Chemicals
DOC.TEXT: Governments in West Germany, the Netherlands and Japan are unwilling to control the export of chemicals used to manufacture drugs, a Bush administration drug official said Tuesday. ``It does not seem likely that European chemical legislation, as contemplated, will have a significant impact on the diversion and trafficking of chemicals, particularly those destined for the illicit production of cocaine,'' said Gene R. Haislip, deputy assistant administrator of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. Haislip, testifying before the Subcommittee on Foreign Commerce of the Senate Commerce Committee, said great quantities of chemicals are shipped through the Dutch port of Rotterdam. ``Whereas in the past most of these shipments have come from the United States, I think the shift is on and in the future we're going to see that Europe, and to some lesser extent Brazil and other countries, will become the predominant suppliers, with the Netherlands and the Federal Republic of Germany... being the two principal exporting countries,'' he said. He cited a case to show that several countries can be involved. ``A broker in London ordered the materials from a supplier in the Netherlands and the materials were shipped from Rotterdam to Colombia,'' he said. ``The customer was a fiction. The material _ acetone _ was falsified on the manifest and shipping papers and the labels on the containers themselves were spray-painted over so that the merchandise could not be identified. ... The Europeans would like to pretend that voluntary efforts will solve their problems and it's quite clear that that is the thinnest kind of pretense.'' In an interview after his testimony, Haislip said the West German and Dutch governments are reluctant to interfere with what they see as legitimate business. He said there is also a problem in trying to halt shipments of chemicals for the manufacture of heroin in Burma and Thailand, especially acetic anhydride from India and Japan. He reported that he had some discussions with Indian authorities but that it was harder to interest the Japanese. ``They're not accustomed to interfering with commerce,'' he said. At the hearing, Sens. Harry Reid and Richard Bryan, both Nevada Democrats, accused U.S. chemical companies of selling chemicals that help make drugs in Colombia. ``The evidence is inescapable that some American chemical manufacturers and distributors have contributed to America's $100 billion cocaine habit,'' said Bryan. ``The record shows that 52 out of 288 requests for `regular customer status,' almost one in five, were rejected by the Drug Enforcement Administration.'' Reid focused on a chemical called methyl ethyl ketone or MEK, which can be used to refine cocaine. ``Why is Exxon permitted to sell MEK to companies associated with the drug cartel in Colombia?'' he asked. John Rutledge, Latin American manager for Exxon Chemical Company, testified that he was confident that its shipments of MEK were not being diverted from their legitimate use to remove wax from lubricating oil. ``All of our sales of chemicals covered by the (law) are cleared with the Drug Enforcement Administration prior to each individual shipment,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Allies Approve Bush Proposal on Troop Cuts
DOC.TEXT: NATO allies have given unanimous support to President Bush's proposal for further deep cuts in American and Soviet troops in Europe, an alliance official said Tuesday. He said the offer probably would go to the bargaining table Thursday at East-West negotiations in Vienna on reducing conventional forces in Europe. The official, speaking privately, said the allies might offer additional proposals, possibly concerning combat aircraft and helicopters, at the Vienna talks. He did not give details. Negotiators for the 16 NATO members and the seven nations of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact are trying to complete an agreement this year for dramatic reductions in personnel, tanks, artillery, armored troop carriers, combat aircraft and helicopters from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains. They still must agree on definitions of equipment to be covered by an accord and a verification system for ensuring compliance. In his State of the Union message last week, Bush proposed a ceiling of 195,000 each from the United States and the Soviet Union in Central Europe. The United States would have 30,000 more in Britain and southern Europe. Last May, Bush recommended a limit of 275,000 for each side. An estimated 565,000 soldiers Soviet soldiers are in Europe outside their national territory, about 400,000 of those in the central region. The United States has 305,000 in Western Europe, including 250,000 in the central zone. According to the NATO source, the alliance's High Level Task Force of officials from member nations, which works on Western positions for the arms talks, approved the Bush proposal unanimously on Monday. The Vienna negotiations began in March 1989, supplanting talks that had spanned 15 years without result.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the second item of a0674, the AM-Brites package that moved on Jan. 16, a New York-dated item about videocassettes of museum exhibits, may wish to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press article Jan. 16 about a videocassette of a Museum of Modern Art exhibit failed to identify the producers of the 60-minute tape. It was produced by Philip Morris Companies Inc. and Minkoff-Clayman Productions.

DOC.HEAD: Fewer Men, More Women Expected to Die From Lung Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Fewer men, but more women, will die this year from lung cancer _ and cigarette advertising is partly to blame, the American Cancer Society said Tuesday. In its annual Cancer Facts and Figures, the society predicts 92,000 men will die this year of lung cancer, down from 93,000 last year and the first decline since the projections began in 1953. That's because men have been quitting smoking over the last two decades _ first, younger men, and now, all age groups, said Cancer Society spokeswoman Joann Schellenbach. That is translating into fewer cases of lung cancer. About 50,000 women will die of lung cancer, up from 49,000 last year, the organization said. Schellenbach said women also are starting to give up smoking. But their health trend hasn't caught up to men's yet _ because men started smoking at the turn of the century and women started smoking in the 1930s. In addition, she said, while many older women are trying to quit, many younger ones don't _ because they're afraid of gaining weight. ``There's a tremendous campaign, not only directed at women but playing on the concern about weight,'' said Schellenbach, noting a variety of cigarettes with ``slim'' in their brand name and new cigarettes touted as having a pleasant, socially acceptable aroma. The Cancer Society is planning its own campaign to counter the advertising. Lung cancer will account for 142,0000 of the 510,000 predicted cancer deaths this year. In addition to smoking, risk factors include exposure to radon, radiation, asbestos, arsenic and some chemicals. The other 1990 predictions included: _600,000 new cases of non-melanoma skin cancer, the majority of them curable, and another 27,600 of melanoma, the most serious skin cancer. There will be 6,300 deaths from melanoma and 2,500 from other skin cancers. _150,000 new breast cancer cases, up from 142,000 last year _ partly due to the aging population. The five-year survival rate for localized breast cancer has risen from 78 percent in the 1940s to 90 percent today.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Group Urges Passages of Senate Assault Weapons Bill
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of city officials, doctors, lawyers, educators and religious groups joined gun control activist Sarah Brady Tuesday in urging prompt congressional action on a bill to ban 14 specific semi-automatic assault weapons. ``This is the first time these fine groups have gathered together to speak out for sensible gun laws,'' Mrs. Brady, wife of former Presidential Press Secretary James Brady, said at a news conference. ``But I'm angry that we have to be here at all.'' Mrs. Brady's husband was severely wounded during an assassination attempt on President Reagan in 1981. The bill supported by Mrs. Brady would ban the import, manufacture, sale and possession of the 14 weapons. It was approved last year by the Senate Judiciary Committee and is awaiting action by the full Senate. She called on Senate leaders to call it up to the floor this week and ``let the American public know where their senators stand.'' Gun owner support groups have opposed the legislation on the grounds that semi-automatic weapons _ one pull of the trigger fires one round _ are essentially the same as many hunting rifles, and would force many sportsmen to give up their weapons. Rabbi Lynne Landsberg, assistant director of the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism, said at the news conference, ``We cannot begin to curb crime and the epidemic of random violence which plagues our cities while we continue to legitimize the wholesale arming of ordinary citizens, including the mentally defective and the street gangs.'' Warren Eisenberg, director of the International Council of B'nai B'rith, said his organization does not believe the bill would ``interfere with the legitimate activities of sportsmen.'' ``In an age when hate criminals and narcoterrorists use assault weapons to commit their crimes, it is ridiculous to try to defend certain categories of domestic and imported weapons as sporting equipment,'' Eisenberg said. The American Federation of Teachers distributed a statement supporting the bill as ``a positive first step'' and saying, ``Because of the access people have to semi-automatic assault weapons, we have to add violent crime to the list of problems facing our children. We should be doing everything in our power to insure that American students are protected from violence.'' Dr. John Seward, member and past chairman of the American Medical Association Council on Legislation, urged approval of the legislation, saying, ``As a physician and a county coroner in Northwestern Illinois, I have seen first-hand the devastating wounds inflicted by assault weapons fired during violent crimes.'' Robert Z. Alpern, director of the Washington office of the Unitarian Universalist Association, said passage of the bill ``would be a small step toward limiting the supply of semi-automatic weapons that have taken an unconscionable toll of human lives and terrorized our nation.'' Stanley Chauvin, president of the American Bar Association, urged action on the bill ``to prevent a permanent military-like escalation of drug crime in our nation.'' Jim Moran, mayor Alexandria, Va., and chairman of the Human Development Policy Committee of the National League of Cities, said he spoke for the bill ``on the basis of NLC policy, which I also happen to fervently and wholeheartedly endorse as a mayor, as a citizen of my community and as a worried parent, as well.'' The 14 weapons are the MAC-10 and MAC-11, Steyr Aug, Colt AR-15 and Colt CAR-15, Uzi carbine and Uzi pistol, Beretta AR-70, Galil, Avtomat Kalashnikovs, FN-FNC, FN-FAL-LAR, Striker 12 Streetsweeper and TEC-9.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant Doesn't Take Witness Stand Before Defense Rests Case
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for a man charged in the disappearance of a multimillionaire's wife rested their case Tuesday, without putting their client on the stand, after saying a potential witness wouldn't tell them his location. U.S. District Judge Tom Lee told jurors they would hear closing arguments Wednesday in the kidnapping conspiracy trial of 65-year-old Newton Alfred Winn. Winn, prosecutors and defense attorneys spent much of Tuesday morning in a closed session in chambers with the judge after Winn and his attorneys disagreed about whether Winn should testify. Winn, a St. Petersburg, Fla., attorney, is charged with plotting the July 26, 1988, kidnapping of Annie Laurie Hearin in Jackson, and with extortion and perjury. Mrs. Hearin, the wife of Jackson multimillionaire Robert Hearin, is still missing. The defense presented few witnesses. Sheriff's Deputy Granville Ratcliff of Cheatham County, Tenn., testified he had talked to Marilyn Taylor, then Marilyn Phillips, a key prosecution witness and Winn's former lover. Ratcliff said he talked to her about where to get an unregistered or stolen license tag. He said he was reasonably certain the discussion took place in late spring 1988. Taylor's testimony, given this past week, implicated Winn in the kidnapping of Mrs. Hearin. Don Ward, a former employee of Winn's, testified as a prosecution rebuttal witness that he didn't write a postcard Taylor testified she received from Winn in 1986. The card was signed ``Alice Johnson,'' a name Taylor said she later learned Winn sometimes used. Ward said that while working as a private investigator he sometimes used the name ``Al Johnson.'' During the trial Monday, defense attorneys asked the government to help them locate and subpoena Taylor's ex-husband, Mark Phillips, who Taylor testified was a mob hit man. ``The government informs me it has found Mark Phillips and is trying to get him to agree to come in,'' defense attorney Ed Marger said Tuesday before resting the case. ``We've talked to him, but he won't tell us where he is,'' sxaid defense attorney John Colette. FBI Agent Patrick McGlenon testified Monday that the FBI found nothing indicating Phillips was a hit man, was linked to the Mafia or had any involvement in the kidnapping. During cross-examination of Taylor, Marger accused her, Phillips and Ward of being the masterminds behind the kidnapping. On Monday, prosecutor James Tucker named Ward, who was granted immunity from prosecution, as the person the government thinks conspired with Winn to kidnap Mrs. Hearin. Tucker was arguing against a defense request that the conspiracy to kidnap charge against Winn be dismissed. The defense had argued that the government could not pursue a conspiracy case with only one conspirator. The judge denied the request. No one besides Winn has been charged. Ward testified last week that Winn sent him to Mississippi four times between 1986 and 1988 to investigate Hearin and his businesses and photograph the couple's home. Hearin is former chief executive officer of School Pictures, Inc., in which Winn once held a franchise in Florida. Legal disputes with the company caused Winn to lose real and personal property in 1988, when he went into bankruptcy. ``While it is true Mr. Ward is not willing to admit at this particular time that Mrs. Hearin was to be kidnapped, he knew Mr. Winn's situation,'' Tucker said. Ward has testified that, at Winn's request, he lied to a federal grand jury investigating the kidnapping, corroborating Winn's story that he was with a prostitute in St. Petersburg the day of the kidnapping.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League President to Lead Delegation to Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 3 `Israel expects' to CORRECT spelling of Shamir's name. Picks up 4th, `The Palestinians...'
DOC.TEXT: The president of the Arab League will lead a delegation to the Soviet Union to protest the flow of Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel, league sources said Tuesday. Also Tuesday, Jordan's King Hussein called for an urgent Arab summit to forge a unified stand against the influx. Israel expects between 300,000 and 500,000 Soviet Jews to arrive in the next three years, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has indicated Israel might need the occupied West Bank and Gaza strip to settle all the arrivals. The Palestinians aim to establish an independent state in those territories, which were captured by Israel during the 1967 Middle East War. The delegation of Arab diplomats also will visit the United States, France, Britain and China in their roles as permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, the league sources said. Arab League President Chedli Klibi and PLO chief Yasser Arafat chaired a three-hour closed-door meeting of ministers from Algeria, Iraq, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Syria and Tunisia. The ministers form the standing committee on the Palestinian uprising. The gathering marked the first time the committee, formed to coordinate Arab strategy toward the uprising or ``intefadeh'' in the occupied terrories, has met in more than a year. Hussein, meanwhile, called on Arab leaders to open a dialogue with the Soviet Union and new governments in East Europe because he said Israel was attempting to exploit the downfall of Communist regimes there in its favor. He told the daily Al-Watan that the Soviet Jewish influx ``will add to the Israeli strength already realized as a result of support it receives from the Jewish and world Zionist movement, the influence of the extremist Israeli right on the American decision makers _ at least in the legislative branch _ and the pro-Israel attitudes of the United States. ``Where will these thousands settle? At the expense of whom?'' he asked. Hussein said that in talking to Moscow, ``we (Arabs) cannot say to it that it should not allow its people to exercise their rights, but at the same time we should warn against the dangers besetting the rights of Palestinians and the Arabs on their soil.'' Also Tuesday, 85 members of the Palestine National Council, the Palestinian parliament-in-exile, signed a petition to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, urging him to halt the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. ``In the name of human rights, we call on you to quickly intervene ... to stop Soviet Jewish exodus, which is considered another Jewish invasion of our homeland,'' the petition said.

DOC.HEAD: Rock Star Billy Idol Injured in Motorcycle Accident
DOC.TEXT: Rock singer Billy Idol was seriously injured in a motorcycle accident Tuesday and underwent several hours of surgery to repair a badly broken leg, his publicist and a hospital spokesman said. Idol suffered a serious fracture of his right leg between the knee and the ankle and a fracture of his left wrist, said Ron Wise, spokesman for Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. The singer was brought to Cedars at 9:10 a.m. and was listed in serious condition while undergoing surgery, Wise said. Neither Wise nor Idol's publicist, Ellen Golden, knew details of the accident except that it involved a car. ``He had completed an album and was on his way home. It involved another car but it wasn't Billy's fault, and he wasn't intoxicated,'' Ms. Golden said.

Pap smear screening to detect cervical cancer, combined with appropriate treatment, could save the lives of many elderly women, according to a study Tuesday by the Office of Technology Assessment. Medicare, the federal health care program for the elderly, will begin paying for Pap tests in July 1990, and OTA said the screening will be most cost-effective it is combined with efforts to encourage high-risk women to be tested. According to the study: _Women at high risk of cervical cancer are smokers, poor, non-white, were young at first intercourse and have had multiple sexual partners. _Studies have found that women who have been screened are one-half to one-tenth as likely to develop cervical cancer as other women. _Elderly women appear to have lower rates of localized, noninvasive cervical tumors than younger women, but the elderly have higher rates of invasive cervical cancer and higher death rates from cervical cancer. _Since elderly women are less likely to be screened for cervical cancer than younger women, older women are more likely to be in advanced stages of the disease when it is diagnosed. Citing National Cancer Institute figures for 1985, the report said 1.1 white women per 100,000 under 50 _ but 2.4 black women _ died of cervical cancer. Among women over 50, the rate was 7.5 for whites and 21.1 for blacks. The average Medicare payment for a Pap smear will be $11.37, though actual physician and laboratory charges may be higher, the report said. The program will cover Pap tests once every three years.

Fifteen years after the death of a law enforcement officer's wife was ruled an accident, her daughter's long-dormant memories have led authorities to call it a homicide. Wilma Anderson Graham died on her kitchen floor in April 1975 with two knife wounds in her heart and other wounds on her hands and arms _ all suffered during a struggle with her husband, Kenneth Graham. Graham claimed that his wife plunged the knife into her own chest, then later slipped and fell on the blade as he tried to keep her from stabbing herself a second time. While Alachua County authorities concluded it was an accident, someone else reached a different conclusion. Paula Hearndon, 29, who witnessed at least part of the struggle between her mother and stepfather said it was murder. For 14 years, she said, she suppressed the traumatic memory. But a year ago, after repeated flashbacks allowed her to recall more and more of what happened, she told authorities she remembers seeing Graham pull the knife out of her mother and stab her again. At the request of Gov. Bob Martinez, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement reopened the investigation. In a report released Monday, the department concluded that Mrs. Graham was the victim of a homicide and that there is ``probable cause to believe that Kenneth Graham committed'' the crime. The report also criticized the chief investigator for the state attorney's office _ a friend of Graham's _ for overlooking and discounting key facts during the original investigation. When the department took the case to a grand jury last month, jurors had two choices _ to indict for first-degree murder or not indict at all. The statute of limitations has expired on any lesser charge. The grand jury declined to issue an indictment. Instead, they issued a report that is sealed by the court. Ms. Hearndon's attorneys are seeking to make that report public in hopes of re-opening the case. Graham is a former FBI agent, former Alachua County sheriff's deputy, police academy instructor, community college security director and associated with many law enforcement officials in Gainesville. He declined to discuss the case this week, but his attorney, Larry Turner of Gainesville, said he is convinced that Mrs. Graham's death was accidental. ``The grand jury didn't indict him 14 years ago or this time and this is what matters,'' Turner said. ``I'm surprised and skeptical of a sudden restoration of memory after 14 years. But Ms. Hearndon and her attorney, Norm LaCoe, suggest that Graham's close ties to law enforcement caused a miscarriage of justice 15 years ago, and they are not confident the renewed investigation will do much more. ``I don't have any confidence in anything any more,'' Ms. Hearndon said last week. ``I want the world to know this guy is a ... murderer.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Senators Call for Aid Cutoff
DOC.TEXT: Six senators called Tuesday for a complete cutoff of U.S. aid to El Salvador, saying the millions now sent by the United States make it ``an accomplice in repression'' and death squad murders. The legislation, which has little chance of passage, was an apparent effort by Senate liberals to increase pressure on the government of Alfredo Cristiani to undertake negotiations with leftist rebels, to pursue further prosecutions in the murders last year of six Jesuit priests and to reform the military. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said while there has been progress in the murder investigation _ trials are scheduled to begin in May for eight military men _ it is ``too little and too late.'' ``Serious questions remain about whether justice is being done in these particularly brutal murders, including whether all those involved in the massacre have been identified,'' Kennedy said at a news conference. Asked about the case during a visit to Washington last week, Cristiani said, ``We are not here to do justice by using scapegoats ... or by speculation. We will only go by the results of a professional investigation.'' ``The judicial process, at least at the beginning, is working well and moving forward,'' Cristiani added. At the State Department, spokesman Richard Boucher said Tuesday that ``the U.S. government, President Cristiani, (and) the high command of the Salvadoran military all share the view that heinous crimes such as these should be investigated and that the perpetrators should be brought to justice.'' In addition to Kennedy, sponsors of the bill are Sens. John Kerry, D-Mass., Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., Paul Simon, D-Ill., Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and Brock Adams, D-Wash. Congress, after the murders last year of the priests, their housekeeper and her daughter, declined to attach strings to U.S. aid to El Salvador. That aid will total about $315 million this year, including military, economic, food, and development aid. Since then, Cristiani has surprised many by pursuing the case and bringing indictments against the soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Limited Train Service After Tunnel Explosion
DOC.TEXT: An underground electrical accident shut down all train service to Grand Central Terminal for three hours Tuesday, authorities said. Ten workers were injured. The 12:38 p.m. accident, in a tunnel beneath the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, set off a smoky fire, said Metro-North railroad spokesman Dan Brucker. Limited service into and out of Grand Central resumed at 3:30 p.m., the railroad said, but some tracks were without power. Widespread track and time changes were expected throughout the evening rush hour for the railroad's 85,000 daily commuters, a spokeswoman said. By 4 p.m., hundreds of commuters stood in Grand Central Terminal staring at the indicator board and trying to determine when and from where their trains might leave. Several trains listed as delayed had been assigned track numbers and taken on passengers. Metro-North employees walked around the station offering assistance. ``Up in Westchester we're a little more civil,'' said Lucille Declet of Bronxville, north of New York City. ``The farther north you go, the more that holds true.'' The lobby crowd was thick but not overflowing, and by 4:45 p.m. announcements of train departures were coming more frequently. Bob Reilly, of Brewster, stood on a staircase and had just finished complaining: ``It's a mess. Nothing's moving. I knew I should have taken the bus,'' when the announcer called his train, the 4:15 p.m. After the accident, smoke from the blaze floated up into the hotel and into the train station a half-dozen blocks away, said Fire Department spokesman Efrain Parrilla. The fire was extinguished within about an hour, he said. Waldorf spokeswoman Marilyn Marks said smoke got into the lobby, but ducts were closed immediately and the problem was minor. Railroad spokeswoman Marjorie Anders said a 28-ton tamping machine, used to pack down ballast around the tracks, ``accidentally cut into a third-rail power feeder cable. That cable shorted out, created that big popping, sizzling explosive sound and it shorted out along the cable into a splicing chamber where there are a lot of other cables. ... That's where all the smoke came from.'' Ten Metro-North workers suffered smoke inhalation, said Capt. Ellen Scibelli of the Emergency Medical Service. Three of them were taken to a hospital, and the others were treated at the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Assailed for Cut in Jobs for Elderly
DOC.TEXT: A Labor Department plan to scale back an employment program for older Americans came under fire Tuesday from a Senate chairman who complained it would hurt 10,000 impoverished senior citizens. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, appearing before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee to push the agency's $26.3 billion budget, said the Bush administration chose to cut $14 million from the program because of overall budget constraints. Under the program, older citizens are placed in community service jobs such as in hospitals, schools and libraries. The jobs usually pay the minimum wage. ``It's a great employment opportunity that keeps elderly Americans off welfare and gives them some respect, some dignity,'' said Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa and committee chairman. ``This is one cut that just does not make sense.''
