President Bush's budget proposes that $343 million be spent on the program in budget year 1991; $357 million went for it in the current fiscal year. ``It's a result of the budget constraints. I wish that it did not have to be so,'' Mrs. Dole said. Harkin, noting that the hourly minimum wage is set to increase from $3.35 to $4.25 next year, said the job program would require more funding just to employ the same number of older Americans in 1991 as in the 1990 budget year. He suggested funding be restored through the supplemental appropriations process to account for the minimum wage difference, but Mrs. Dole said that process should be reserved for ``dire emergencies.'' ``Dire emergency is in the eye of the beholder,'' Harkin said. On another budget issue, Mrs. Dole said the department's proposed $252.6 million increase for new youth job training programs would provide help to an estimated 683,000 of the nation's ``most at-risk youth.'' ``If we're going to remain competitive in a global market, we must address ourselves to this skills gap and a motivational gap that exists in many areas as well,'' Mrs. Dole said. She said the department was working on ways to help high school students make the transition to the workforce, since many now ``kick around for a couple of years trying to find the right spot.'' Many senators praised the labor secretary for her role in bringing about a tentative settlement in the Pittston-United Mine Workers strike, but she again found herself explaining the government's hands-off approach at Eastern Air Lines, where machinists remain on strike. ``I think you always have to go case by case,'' Mrs. Dole said, citing different federal labor laws that govern the transportation industry. She also said the strike was not causing an emergency in the airline industry. ``This was not the kind of situation that would tie up transportation in a section of the country,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Party Reform Would Squeeze Out Committee Hard-Liners
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal for reforming the Communist Party would be the climax of a five-year squeeze play against elderly hard-liners of the Central Committee. Gorbachev took the helm of the Communist Party in March 1985 and since then has almost completely changed the 12-man Politburo, which handles everyday business. But he still cannot count on a majority on the 249-member Central Committee, the one body with the power to fire him. To push through radical changes, such as Monday's call for the party to give up its monopoly on power, Gorbachev needs Central Committee members who ``pulse with fresh young blood,'' as the newspaper Argumenti i Fakti put it this week. The newspaper, in a scathing indictment of the age and tenure of the party leadership, noted that 61 percent of the Central Commmittee members were past retirement age, and some have been in positions of power almost since Josef Stalin's time. Many were appointed only to qualify for ``personal pensions'' _lavish retirement benefits reserved for the nation's elite, the article found. ``The party hardly has the right, having chosen such a Central Committee, to expect dynamism, revolutionary energy, flexibility and extraordinary thinking,'' the article concluded. Gorbachev's proposal for secret, multicandidate elections of delegates to the party congress, which elects the Central Committee, would result in replacing all but perhaps 10 percent of the current members, estimated Justis Paletskis, ideology secretary for the breakaway Lithuanian Communist Party. Paletskis is one of hundreds of progressive party leaders invited to attend and speak at this week's crucial Central Committee meeting. Guests cannot vote on the final document, but Paletskis said he is certain the election proposal will be approved. While Gorbachev is changing the rules of the game at the top, pressure from rank-and-file communists and non-party members alike is providing the bottom jaw of the vise. High-ranking local party officials were embarrassed in national elections last year, when voters were given a choice for the first time in decades. A repeat performance is likely this spring when elections for local and republic governing councils are held. In recent weeks local communist leaders also have been facing a new phenomenon: large-scale protests that have forced them to quit their posts. Party leaders in the Siberian petroleum center of Tyumen, the southern Russian river city of Volgograd, and the industrial cities of Chernigov in the Ukraine and Sverdlovsk in the Ural Mountains all were forced out by popular discontent. These actions likely will serve as a example for other disgruntled Soviets. Party rules still hobble Gorbachev's maneuvering. They have prevented him from adding anyone to the Central Committee since the last party congress in March 1986. At that time he managed to change one-third of the group that had been elected under Leonid I. Brezhnev. But he had been in power for only a year and his own grip still was tenuous. He dropped 10 of his original 108 appointees last April. Another has died. He promoted 24 in April, but had only the ranks of candidate members, also chosen in March 1986, from which to choose. Candidate members do not vote. That means only 121 of Central Committee's 249 members, just less than 50 percent, were appointed under Gorbachev. Many were far from being strong supporters of reform, and only a handful are clearly identifiable Gorbachev allies. Among rank-and-file Communists, ``many express doubt about the possibility of the Central Committee as it is currently constituted to adopt radical decisions about reform,'' Y. A. Gankovsky, a Siberian party leader, told Tuesday's meeting. Gorbachev twice has sought and failed to win a mandatory retirement age or a limit of two five-year terms for party officials, in hopes of weeding out more deadwood. Most of the 74 people retired last April were so-called ``Dead Souls.'' Named after a famous Russian novel by Nikolai Gogol, these are people who have lost the jobs that entitled them to a Central Committee slot. Now, less than a year later, Western diplomats estimate there are 50 to 60 more dead souls. They include Dzhumber Patiashvili, the former party chief in Georgia who was ousted after being blamed for ordering troops to clear a crowd of peaceful independence protesters, resulting in 19 deaths. With the prospect of real political competition coming up on the horizon, Gorbachev needs to remove such unpopular figures from the leadership as the party competees for power.
Ann Imse is based in the Moscow bureau of The Associated Press and has been covering the Gorbachev reforms since September 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Secret Police Curtailed and Othere Reforms Made
DOC.TEXT: Eighty percent of the secret police have been fired, the telephones of opposition activists are no longer tapped and other reforms are being made in the security services, the interior minister said Tuesday. Gen. Atanas Semerdjiev said a prison camp on the Danube River island of Belene, ``one of the most typical symbols of the old regime ... many of whose inmates have been wrongfully convicted,'' would be closed. Semerdjiev spent five hours at a meeting of the Communist Party and opposition leaders condemning past abuses and promising to make his ministry ``a guardian of society,'' the official news agency BTA reported. He rejected opposition demands for access to secret police files and a public investigation of state security, citing constitutional prohibitions he did not specify, the agency said. Semerdjiev made his presentation four days after a Communist Party congress that sought to bridge differences between reformers and party conservatives seeking to preserve Communist domination of Bulgarian society. Bulgaria has followed its East European neighbors in promising to remodel the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for the police agencies that have repressed the people with survellience and force. The Communist Party remains in firm control in Bulgaria, however, and the public s skeptical of the legitimacy of change even after the election last week of moderate reformers as prime minister and party leader. Although they participate in the weekly negotiations with the party, opposition leaders have refused to join a provisional government to run the country until free elections scheduled for May. The Union of Democratic Forces opposition alliance describes the Communist proposal of a government of ``national concord'' as too vague and says that, because the party controls Parliament, there is little chance of a real opposition role. In the BTA report of Tuesday's negotiations, the Interior Ministry was described as becoming ``new and modern ... independent of any political party and guided solely by the interests of the people and the state.'' BTA said the ``traditional'' structures of state security had been disbanded. It quoted Semerdjiev as saying the Security and Protection Department had been replaced by a security service one-fifth its size, and that the security service and a new national intelligence service would report directly to the head of state. A new national service for protection of the constitution was being formed and its composition would be announced to Parliament soon, the report said. Semerdjiev said the criminal investigation unit was being taken out of the Interior Ministry and would be reorganized as a national investigation service reporting to Parliament. ``We don't want to be regarded as a shield and a sword any longer,'' he said. ``We want to be seen as a guardian of society and the people in the noblest sense of the word.'' He said the Interior Minister employs no more than 50,000 people and is being reduced ``dramatically, especially in senior positions.'' BTA quoted him as saying ``those who have committeed abuses in the past can no longer serve.'' The BTA report said Semerdjiev told participants in the talks neither their telephones nor those of ``intellectuals'' were being tapped, and signed a pledge that no listening devices were installed in Union of Democratic Forces offices. When the minister acknowledged past abuses and apologized, Premier Andrei Lukanov said without elaborating that he qualified for an apology because his telephone also had been tapped, BTA reported. Semerdjiev said monitoring would not stop, but would be carried out in compliance with the constitution, with orders from a court or prosecutor.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Officials Recommend Lower U.S. Imports
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit with Japan is declining but higher U.S. import prices may be needed to bring the results wanted by Congress, officials of the Japanese government and industry said Tuesday. ``Congress wants a quick fix, so ... your demand for imports has to go down,'' said Kazuo Nukazawa, managing director of the powerful Japan Federation of Economic Organizations. He and Masaru Yoshitomi, director of the government's economic planning agency, gave reporters an array of figures showing strong growth of American exports to Japan, but accompanied by continued growth of U.S. imports. A better trade balance will mean lowering U.S. demand for imports by cheapening the value of the U.S. dollar and driving up the value of the Japanese yen to make Japanese goods cost Americans more, said Nukazawa. The officials suggested an exchange rate of 90-100 yen per dollar. One dollar currently buys about 145 yen, compared to as few as 120 yen last year, 240 yen in 1985 and 360 yen for several years after World War II. Some economists said those proposals could translate into lowered consumption by Americans, triggering a recession. But ``our confidence in the American economy is much higher than your confidence,'' Nukazawa said, predicting there would be no recession if the United States maintains a modest 1 percent to 1.5 percent annual economic growth. ``The best thing,'' he said, would be to induce the American people to spend less and save more to provide more investment capital. The slowly rising U.S. savings rate is 4 percent to 5 percent, compared to 12 percent in Western Europe, he said. Japanese real estate investors are becoming hesitant about buying up U.S. ``landmark properties,'' such as skyscrapers and New York's Rockefeller Center, because theose investors are becoming aware of the negative public reaction aroused in the United States by high-profile purchases, Nukazawa said. Predicting the criticism of foreigners ``buying up America'' would blow over, he said the United States ``has a very strong stomach; it can digest almost everything. Now you love Gorby, two years ago you hated him,'' Nukazawa said, referring to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Nukazawa and Yoshitomi have been holding informal talks with officials of the Bush administration, members of Congress and business leaders in Washington and New York.

DOC.HEAD: Local Official's $245,000 Quadruple Dipping Believed Unique
DOC.TEXT: Housing and Urban Development officials said Tuesday they have found no evidence that quadruple dipping salary abuses uncovered in a local New Jersey housing authority exist elsewhere but added they are expanding an investigation to find out. ``We are informed this is a unique situation,'' HUD General Counsel Frank Keating told a House subcommittee. ``We're in the process of expanding this nationally.'' HUD officials said they will first put together strike forces to examine 20 more local housing agencies in New Jersey. ``It may well be there are no other Passaics,'' Keating said. Paul Adams, the department's inspector general, said the federal government was likely defrauded when the Passaic, N.J., Housing Authority's commissioners approved more than $245,000 in 1988 to pay Executive Director Paul Marguglio four salaries for four job titles. ``I think that's a reasonable assumption,'' Adams told Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., adding that his office is conducting a criminal investigation of the Passaic agency. Lantos, chairman of the House Government Operations employment and housing subcommittee, questioned how Marguglio could ``find enough hours in the day to perform two full-time jobs and two part-time jobs ... and still have enough time left over to earn $47,115 for time-and-a-half compensatory pay.'' Local housing authority executives are prohibited from earning overtime compensation, Adams said. Lantos also questioned the $95,000 paid between January 1986 and April 1988 to Marguglio's wife, Louise, including $50,000 in disability pay that an audit called improper. The audit said Mrs. Marguglio worked ``only one day'' in that period. ``It seems to me this was a system designed to fail,'' said Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn. ``This was a ripoff and it was a ripoff in which the commissioners participated.'' Housing Secretary Jack Kemp on Jan. 22 suspended Marguglio and four other Passaic officials and authorized a strike force to examine housing authorities across New Jersey, including Perth Amboy. Under extensive questioning, Paul Kane, HUD's regional inspector general for the Northeast, acknowledged problems in Passaic were first hinted at in a 1985 report. Rep. Donald Payne, a Newark, N.J., Democrat, called it unconscionable that HUD failed to pursue tenant complaints as far back as 1982 to then-Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. Marguglio and his wife declined to testify Tuesday and face subpoenas if they do not volunteer to appear at the next session on the Passaic agency, Lantos said. Three of Passaic's suspended housing officials _ August C. Michaelis, chief counsel to the agency; Peter Marrocco, the authority's chairman, and William P. Scruggs, the board's vice chairman _ have indicated willingness to testify, Lantos said. A federal judge in Newark on Thursday will review last week's decision to grant HUD temporary control of the authority. Three of the suspended officials have filed papers seeking reinstatement. Lantos' decision to call the hearing marks a resumption of last year's subcommittee focus on the multi-billion-dollar scandal of influence-peddling, fraud and mismanagement at HUD during the Reagan administration. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh last week asked a federal court to appoint an independent counsel to investigate fraud allegations against former Pierce and others.

DOC.HEAD: Goodbye Endless Summer: Year-Round Schools Coming To LA
DOC.TEXT: Afternoons at the beach, jobs and summer loves will have to be squeezed into the schedule of Los Angeles public school students as the traditional three-month vacation becomes a thing of the past. Beginning in July 1991, all 646 schools in the Los Angeles Unified School District will go on a year-round schedule; 102 Los Angeles schools already operate year-round. The plan will about double the number of U.S. schools on year-round schedules and provide an impetus for other districts to adopt such plans, proponents said. ``It will put increasing pressure on other city districts to re-evaluate the wisdom of remaining on an agriculturally based calender,'' said Charles Ballinger, executive director of the National Council on Year-Round Education in San Diego. Approved by a 4-3 school board vote Monday, it is intended to ease severe school overcrowding in the 594,802-student Los Angeles district, second in size only to New York City's district. For 10th-grader Michelle Smith, the new schedule will cut into her traditional summer plans and social life. ``I don't like it because all my friends go to private school and they don't have year-round school. So I can't be with them,'' she said. ``I also won't be able to go to summer camp, which is all summer long.'' But Sarah Ponce, another 10th-grader, said she's keeping an open mind. ``I'd be willing to try it. It's a new experience. Maybe I'd be able to do different things, like over the winter,'' she said. ``Maybe it would conflict with a lot of things. But I could probably work around it.'' What most concerns many parents and students is the year-round schedule's overlapping ``track'' system of enrollment, in which different blocks of students begin the year at different times and have different vacations. All students will have shorter summer vacations and longer winter vacations. Most students will have the same number of days off as before, but some will have to go a week or two extra. The system will give schools as many as four student body presidents _ one for each track _ and disrupt interscholastic sports. ``My feeling is that you're going to lose some kids from teams when they're off track and on vacation or something. You could lose a key kid and cost you a full season,'' said Duane LaRue, athletic director at University High School. Parents expressed mixed emotions about year-round schools. Some were happy that the schools should be less crowded and their children will be home fewer summer days, but others complained the schedule will disrupt vacation plans and leave them with children around the house during the winter. ``We have parents who think it's wonderful and we have parents who think it's the worse thing that ever happened. It depends on their lifestyle,'' said Barbara Topkis, president of one of the two Parent-Teacher Association districts in Los Angeles. Students and teachers at the schools now on year-round schedules said the plan works well, with only a few minor glitches. Yanira Perez, a 10th-grader, said the year-round schedule still leaves time to work at a clothing store after work and gives her more hours to work over the winter when many students are still in school. ``A lot of students like it this way. We're all used to it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: India `Fully Prepared' on Military Level
DOC.TEXT: India on Tuesday accused Pakistan of causing border tensions and said it was prepared militarily for any threat from Islamabad. ``We urge upon Pakistan authorities to heed to our request and scale down the propaganda level,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Aftab Seth said. Indian border guards fired Monday on a mob of 4,000 Pakistani protesters, some of whom crossed into Indian territory in the northern state of Jammu-Kashmir, where Moslem separatists are demanding independence. Officials said no Pakistanis were killed but Indian newspapers and Pakistani officials reported deaths. The Indian government began a crackdown on Moslem separatists in the Kashmir region of Jammu-Kashmir state on Jan. 20, and at least 77 Indians have been killed in clashes between protesters and security forces. Police sources said Moslem militants Tuesday bombed an empty bus on the outskirts of Srinagar, Kashmir's largest town, and threw a grenade at a paramilitary patrol, wounding three people. Amnesty International said Monday that Indian security forces searched for survivors at the height of the protests last month in order to kill them. The Lonon-based human rights group, quoting witnesses, also said some protesters were shot from behind. It acknowledged that security forces faced a difficult situation in maintaining order and also that police were killed in the clashes. But it called for an investigation into the killings and urged the governor of Jammu-Kashmir to order troops not to use lethal force on demonstrators unless their own lives were at risk. Indian officials said about 10 people were wounded Monday during the Pakistani border demonstration. Pakistani officials said one person was killed and 13 were shot in the legs. Two Indian newspapers also reported fatalities. The pro-government Times of India said 10 people were killed, while The Statesman, an independent paper, said three died. ``We do not want to sound alarmist (but) we regard all such unprovoked incidents as serious,'' Seth said. ``We are fully prepared on (the) military level,'' Seth said. He did not elaborate. Seth said three more anti-Indian demonstrations were held on the Pakistan side of the frontier Tuesday but that the protesters did not try to cross into India. Both days the demonstrators shouted slogans in protest of India's crackdown on the Moslem separatists. The Pakistan-based leader of Moslem militants who support the separatist movement in India promised Tuesday to rein in his emotionally charged followers. ``I have issued a sort of martial law order to our people today to not storm across'' the border, said Amanullah Khan, chairman of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. His decree generated threats of mutiny, particularly among student in his organization, Khan said in Islamabad, Pakistan's capital. But greater tension between India and Pakistan would hurt their cause, he said: ``If there is a war we'll be sandwiched in between and made a scapegoat.'' India accuses Pakistan of aiding the militants in Kashmir, a predominantly Moslem region claimed both by India and Pakistan. Pakistan routinely denies the charge but says it supports the separatists' quest for self-determination. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people are Moslem, making it the only Moslem-majority state among predominantly Hindu India's 25 states. India and Moslem Pakistan were formed largely along religious lines when the Indian subcontinent gained independence from Britain in 1947. Jammu-Kashmir is part of a larger Kashmir that was divided into Indian and Pakistani segments after the nations went to war in 1948. A U.N. monitored cease-fire line separates the regions. The two countries went to war again over Kashmir in 1965, but the border question is still unresolved.

DOC.HEAD: Excommunicated Black Priest Will Keep Title
DOC.TEXT: Dissident black Roman Catholic priest George A. Stallings said Tuesday he will remain a priest despite his formal separation from the church and the creation of his independent African-American Catholic congregation. ``The church teaches you that once a priest, always a priest,'' Stallings said. ``I have also stated...that the Roman Catholic Church cannot excommunicate me or anyone else.'' The Archdiocese of Washington on Monday issued a statement saying Stallings effectively excommunicated himself following his public renunciation of church teaching. Stallings also declared that there was nothing in Catholic doctrine that prohibited the use of birth control or prohibited women from being priests. The priest announced recently that his African-American congregation would an autonomous and independent congregation that would no longer answer to Rome. Eileen Marx, a spokeswoman for the archdiocese, said Tuesday that Stallings would remain a priest, but one no longer associated with the Roman Catholic Church. ``It is true that in the Catholic Church once a priest always a priest, but the church can also regulate who is to speak in her name,'' Ms. Marx said. ``He is no longer authorized to speak as a Roman Catholic priest in the church's name.'' Stallings said his formal separation from the Catholic Church would allow his own congregation to solidify its discipline and laws. ``We have no desire to in any way denounce our Catholicism,'' he told reporters. ``And we will remain true to revealed doctrine of the Catholic faith and continue to give full expression of Catholicism out of an African-American perspective.'' Stallings said that ``revealed'' doctrine will include the ordination of women, the marriage of priests, the use of birth control and allowing divorced or remarried Catholics to be in full communion without the annulment process. ``The African-American Catholic congregation holds to the sanctity of life from the moment of conception to birth,'' Stallings said. ``But ultimately it is the responsibility of the woman who must stand before God to render an account for her action and her conduct to make that decision for which only she alone can be held responsible.''

DOC.HEAD: Second U.S. Warplane in Two Days Crashes in Britain
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force A-10 ground attack plane crashed Tuesday in Wales, killing the pilot, less than 18 hours after two airmen died when an Air Force F-111 bomber crashed off east England, the Air Force said. Gen. Marcus Anderson, commander of the 3rd Air Force division, grounded all British-based U.S. tactical fighters for a one-day safety review, although press spokesman Capt. Raymond Martell said the crashes were unrelated. He called it ``a terrible coincidence'' they occurred in so short a span. The air force said no suggestions emerged of mechanical faults in the jets. Martell said the A-10 crashed in the Black Mountains of Wales, about eight miles south of Hay-on-Wye on the English border. The name of the pilot, the lone occupant, was not released. The plane was stationed at the British air force base at Alconbury, 20 miles northwest of Cambridge. On Monday, an F-111 carrying two men crashed in a North Sea bay during a routine training mission. The air force identified the two men aboard as Capt. Clifford W. Massengill, 30, of Edenton, N.C., the pilot, and 1st Lt. Thomas G. Dorsett, 26, of Pensacola, Fla. One body, so far unidentified, was recovered. A search for the second airman continued. The F-111 was based at Upper Heyford, 50 miles northwest of London, one of two bases here for 84 U.S. bombers, which are capable of carrying nuclear arms.

DOC.HEAD: Key Drug Suspect Nabbed, Reportedly Carried List Headed by Noriega
DOC.TEXT: Authorities captured a man reputed to be a leading cocaine trafficker and said he was carrying a list that included the name of former Panamanian ruler Manuel Antonio Noriega, a newspaper said Tuesday. Jesus Humberto Vega Escobar, arrested Monday in Bogota, is wanted by U.S. authorities on charges of shipping 6 tons of cocaine into the country, according to the daily El Tiempo. The Bogota newspaper said the government had begun extradition proceedings. Vega Escobar allegedly controlled an important cocaine transportation network in Panama, Central America and Mexico for shipments to the United States, the newspaper said. A national police spokesman reached by telephone confirmed Vega Escobar's capture but said he could not comment on El Tiempo's report that a list containing Noriega's name was found in the suspect's possession. Colombia has sent 14 trafficking suspects to the United States since August, when the administration of President Virgilio Barco intensified a crackdown on the country's cocaine cartels. Vega Escobar, a resident of Medellin, was reportedly working for Pablo Escobar, the most important figure in the powerful cocaine cartel based in that city. El Tiempo said Noriega's was the first of 28 names on the list and apparently was a guide to Vega Escobar's organization. The list also contained the names of businessmen in Panama and Mexico, the newspaper said. Noriega was ousted from power in Panama during the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion. The former chief of the Panamanian Defense Forces, who controlled the country, is awaiting trial on drug trafficking charges in Miami. El Tiempo quoted a police spokesman as saying authorities captured Vega Escobar in a raid on his luxury apartment in the capital after being tipped off by area residents.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Group Stands Aside as Senate Focuses on Judicial Nominee
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights forces split Tuesday as the NAACP promised not to fight confirmation of conservative Clarence Thomas as an appeals judge, while other groups assailed his record as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. ``While we cannot give him our unqualified endorsement, we will, however, not oppose the nomination,'' NAACP executive director Benjamin L. Hooks said in a statement as the Senate Judiciary Committee conducted its confirmation hearing. Thomas, 41, one of the more prominent blacks in the Reagan and Bush administrations, came in for criticism from representatives of working women and senior citizens groups. The nomination of Thomas to succeed Robert Bork on the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington once appeared likely to trigger concerted resistance from the cvil rights community. In recent days, however, the NAACP balked. Hooks did say that ``we do have questions about his management of EEOC.'' Thomas told the senators that as an appeals judge he would not ``have the option of roaming unfettered through judicial terrain'' and injecting his personal views into decisions. He vowed ``to faithfully adhere to the Supreme Court decisions'' and not ``torture a case to reach a preconceived notion of what a result should be.'' Thomas acknowledged that the statute of limitations on 900 cases of alleged bias against the elderly lapsed before the commission acted on them. He accepted responsibility. ``It happened on my watch,'' he said. But he said the reason was that he intiated more extensive investigative procedures and the new program may have been ``too ambitious.'' Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., told Thomas there as ``a lot of debate'' over whether the correct number was 13,000 cases rather than 900. Thomas said: ``With regard to the number 13,000, I don't have the slightest idea where that number comes from.'' Thomas said in response to a question that as a conservative he holds a number of positions at odds with ``an expected orthodoxy from black Americans.'' He said criticism from civil rights groups over his views ``is something that is uncomfortable, but it is something that I'll have to live with.'' ``I think the choice between principle and popularity is something that each individual will have to make and I've made mine and I'll live with the consequences,'' Thomas said. Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., who twice hired Thomas as an aide, praised him as ``a person who calls them as he sees them.'' ``Frankly, I have questions about the nominee's commitment to the law,'' said Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. He said, however: ``We haven't always agreed, but I respect your views.'' Nancy Kreiter of Chicago, research director of the Women Employed Institute, told the committee that under Thomas the commission ``failed to fulfill its mandate to protect the rights of victims of discrimination.'' ``Mr. Thomas' actions in the areas of policy and enforcement performance demonstrate a lack of respect for law and a disregard for individuals,'' she said. `` ... A careful look at his record raises serious questions about his qualifications for a lifetime appointment to administer justice on the federal bench.'' She said enforcement by the commission has been lax while there has been slippage in staff competence. Rutgers law professor Alfred W. Blumrose, an advocate of rights for senior citizens, told the committee that the commission had apparently violated its own regulations by eliminating a policy of persuing hiring goals and timetables in 1985 without taking any formal action under the federal government's ``sunshine'' law. He said there was a ``sort of quiet suggestion by innuendo leading the lawyers in the agency to alter the process.'' He said he believed the action to be illegal. ``The agency can suspend the policy ... what they cannot do is simply slide away from the policy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Commission to Investigate Police Role in Putting Down Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with shooting incident Tuesday night, INSERT 2 grafs after 10th pvs; pickup 11th, `About 20,000...'
DOC.TEXT: A commission has been established to investigate complaints against security forces that put down the violent ethnic unrest in Kosovo Province, the police chief said Tuesday. Chief Jusuf Karakusi told Kosovo's parliament that 26 ethnic Albanians had been killed in clashes with police since the latest round of protests started Jan. 24. He said 94 demonstrators had been wounded by gunfire and 83 police officers had suffered various injuries. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people and thousands have taken to the streets to demand more autonomy for the province, which is part of the republic of Serbia. Serbia tightened its control of Kosovo's police, judiciary and schools last year, saying the measures were necessary to protect the Serbian minority in the province. The actions sparked violent demonstrations and Kosovo has been under virtual martial law for a year. Ethnic Albanian leaders have been critical of what they call indiscriminate use of force by security forces seeking to quell the recent unrest. One ethnic Albanian delegate, Cemail Bairam, told parliament he had witnessed uncontrolled shooting by police in the village of Malisevo. He said the killings ``cannot be justified by anything.'' Until an investigation identifies those responsible, tension will remain high in Kosovo, Bairam said. The security forces, backed by columns of tanks and low-flying air force jets and helicopters, have kept an uneasy calm, and no additional deaths have been reported since Feb. 2. Karakusi told the legislature about 1,000 protesters had been arrested, and that 200 of them had been sentenced by magistrate courts to up to 60 days in jail. Tensions rose Tuesday night in Janjevo, a town 16 miles southwest of Pristina, when a Serbian police officer, apparently drunk, shot two ethnic Albanian teen-age boys in the legs and harassed residents, the mayor and other witnesses said. The officer opened fire after he was seen drinking at a bar, Mayor Josip Dodid said. He said the boys were hospitalized for treatment and that the unidentified officer was arrested. About 20,000 people massed on the downtown street in front of the parliament Tuesday to pay homage to those killed in the protests. As car horns sounded, people in the crowd raised their hands in the V for victory salute and shouted ``Glory to the dead!'' They then dispersed peacefully as police watched. Ethnic Albanians also observed a minute of silence at 2 p.m. for a second day in honor of the dead. About 20,000 people gathered in the provincial capital of Pristina Tuesday night, lighting thousands of candles they then left on sidewalks. Protest leaders have called for the release of jailed ethnic Albanian activists and free elections to replace provincial officials they say are loyal to Serbia. The leadership of Yugoslavia's liberal northern republic of Slovenia called for the lifting of the yearlong state of emergency in Kosovo. The presidency of the Slovenian Socialist Alliance, a Communist-dominated mass organization, said the problems of the region ``should be resolved by democratic means'' and appealed for an end to ``demonstrations of force ... by the Serbian leadership.'' Slobodan Milosevic, the president of the Serbian republic, has accused Slovenia and neighboring Croatia of supporting Albanian ``terrorists'' in Kosovo.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Army Says It Will Seal Homes of Rock-Throwers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `Also Tuesday' to ADD dropped word `who;' picks up 4th, Col. Ahaz...'
DOC.TEXT: The army said Tuesday it has begun punishing Palestinians who hurl rocks at Israelis by sealing off their houses or blocking off individual rooms. The policy, which could affect hundreds of families in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, drew immediate criticism from civil rights groups and liberal politicians, who said the measure amounts to collective punishment. Also Tuesday, two Israeli civilians shot and killed a Palestinian who stoned their truck and 33 other Palestinians were wounded in clashes with Israeli troops, the army and Arab reports said. Col. Ahaz Ben-Ari, the army's legal adviser for the West Bank, said the new penalty was necessary because of ``the danger of stone-throwing,'' the main tactic of the nearly 26-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. ``Because this phenomenon is still deeply rooted and, lately to our great regret, is on an increase, it was decided to widen this sanction for this phenomenon in an attempt to quell it,'' Ben-Ari said. Since the Arab uprising broke out in December 1987, the army has destroyed or sealed at least 395 homes to punish Arabs suspected of firebomb or other serious attacks. But the penalty was not usually used for rock-throwing. The army generally seals rooms, or whole houses, by blocking the doors and windows with concrete blocks or bricks and cement. Sometimes the family is told to do the labor. At times, the army has welded metal doors or shutters shut. The first sealings under the new policy occurred overnight in the West Bank. The army said several rooms of a house in Nablus were blocked off because one family member threw a rock through a car's windshield, injuring the Israeli driver. In the town of Qalqilya, several rooms were sealed off in the home of a Palestinian charged with wounding a border policeman with a stone. The families were allowed to remain in one room of each house, the army said. It did not say how many members there were in each family. Also Tuesday, Mustafa Abed Kulab, 45, a Palestinian bus driver, was fatally shot when Israeli civilians opened fire after their fuel truck was stoned in Nablus, Arab reports said. The army said police were questioning the driver and his security guard, who said they fired in the air after the stoning. Kulab's death raised to 652 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the Palestinian uprising began. In addition, 181 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died. In the occupied Gaza Strip, 22 Palestinians were shot and wounded by Israeli troops in stone-throwing clashes in the Rafah refugee camp, Arab reports said. They said the clashes broke out as students were leaving their schools and that the injured ranged in age from 13 to 17. Eleven other Palestinians were shot and wounded in clashes elsewhere in the coastal strip, Arab reports said. The army confirmed four injuries and said it was checking further. The new house sealing policy was immediately challenged by Parliament member Dedi Zucker of the left-leaning Citizens Rights Movement as ``another escalation of the circle of hate.'' He said it constituted ``punishment without trial.'' Khaled Batrawi of Law in the Service of Man, a Palestinian-run human rights group, said the policy was illegal. Demolitions and house sealings ``constitute collective punishment that is prohibited by international law, and they violate the 4th Geneva Convention,'' he said. The 4th Geneva Convention, to which Israel is a signatory, protects the rights of civilians during war and under occupation. The United States and international human rights organizations also have repeatedly criticized demolitions and sealings, noting that the action almost always takes place before the suspect is tried. Liberal Parliament members have proposed legislation that would make the 4th Geneva Convention part of Israeli law. Amnon Rubinstein, a member of the left-wing Shinui Party, said the legislation would oblige Israel to honor the humanitarian regulations.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Reach Fragile Agreement on Some Key Elements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Following tops with 10 new grafs to CORRECT that no agreement has been reached generally made on auto emissions, though Mitchell and Levin have agreed. Picks up 8th graf: ``While not,''
DOC.TEXT: Senate negotiators have reached tentative compromises on several key portions of clean-air legislation, including tighter controls on toxic industrial releases, Senate sources said Tuesday. Progress also was made toward an agreement over tighter emission controls from automobiles with discussion of a proposal aimed at easing auto industry opposition, the sources said. But the sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, cautioned that major parts of the pollution-control package, including the one dealing with acid rain, have yet to be considered and even the compromises already worked out are tenuous. ``Right now you're in the middle of some very delicate bargaining,'' said one Senate staff member. As negotiators broke after a day-long session, Senate sources said a tentative compromise had been reached on auto questions between Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., who has been a strong opponent of tougher auto exhauswt controls. While the Mitchell-Levin compromise would retain tough second-stage tailpipe standards scheduled to go into effect in the year 2003, it leaves a way for the Environmental Protection Agency to return to Congress in six years to scrap those requirements. The compromise also eliminates a provision that automakers develop cars with greater fuel efficiency by meeting new carbon dioxide emission requirements, a portion of the Senate bill that environmentalists have argued is key to dealing with global warming. One source close to the discussions said the Bush administration had not yet agreed to the compromise, however. Additionally, Sens. Max Baucus, D-Mont., and John Chafee, R-R.I., the two floor leaders of the bill, were said to be unhappy about the revised auto tailpipe agreement. While not commenting directly on the compromises, Baucus said Tuesday he wants to ``make sure that all that has been written (into the legislation) in public is not unwritten in these closed sessions.'' The private meetings, which have been going on for more than a week, include the Democratic and Republican leadership as well as senior officials from both the Enviornmental Protection Agency and the White House. ``Good progress is being made,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who has been orchestrating the private talks. The Senate clean-air bill, which is tougher on polluters than either a House version or legislation sought by President Bush, has been the target of intense attack by industry, especially utilities and automakers, who charge it is far too costly and restrictive. Mitchell said he hoped to reach overall agreement on the legislation this week, but acknowledged that he has yet to gather enough support to head off a possible filibuster when the bill is taken up on the Senate floor in the coming days. ``I think that is a probability,'' Mitchell said when asked about a potential filibuster, which would stall progress on the legislation. In addition to the pollution controls on automobiles, according to the sources, the private talks also have produced tentative agreements on: _A provision requiring industry to install the best available technology to curb toxic chemical releases and eventually meet specific health standards based on cancer risk. The compromise, however, would make it easier for industrial plants to avoid the health-standard requirement because it requires the EPA to adopt a ``real world'' procedure taking into account circumstances at specific plant sites to determine cancer risks instead of the mathematical models now used. _Tougher pollution controls on a broad range of businesses and industrial plants in urban areas that are failing to meet federal air quality standards. The compromise, however, exempts smaller polluters by raising the cutoff for emission levels. In addition, there is agreement that the bill would contain no requirement for automakers to produce or sell alternative-fuel automobiles. Chafee and other senators had hoped to insert such a requirement on the Senate floor.

DOC.HEAD: Power Cuts, Closed Ports as Strikers Challenge Greek Gov't
DOC.TEXT: Power supplies were disrupted, public transport was halted and ports remained closed Tuesday as the country's unions pressed their challenge of government austerity policies. Public Power Corp. employees began a 48-hour nationwide strike and demanded a 4.3 percent wage increase over inflation, which was 14.1 percent last year. Power failures occurred in the capital periodically, and the fire department reported 750 people had been trapped in elevators. Traffic lights worked only intermittently, creating chaos at intersections. The country's 2,800 longshoremen entered their fourth day of an indefinite strike for higher pay, and bus drivers staged a walkout, also demanding raises. The port workers' strike has created a backlog of cargo ships waiting to enter Piraeus, the country's main port. Several unions have staged crippling strikes in key industries since the beginning of the year, demanding the government back down on its austerity policy and continue to hire public employees. The nation's largest labor organization, the General Confederation of Greek Labor, warned that it will call on its 1.3 million members to stage a 24-hour general strike this month, the second this year. The organization is demanding a ``national general labor agreement'' that would include assurances of wage increases over inflation. The Federation of Greek Industrialists so far has refused to consider this. Premier Xenophon Zolotas has said repeatedly that his government cannot raise wages in the face of inflation expected to run at 17 percent this year and a $1.8 billion budget deficit. Zolotas said Monday the government could do no more than repeat a promise to protect present wages from inflation. He chastized trade unions for staging daily protests in central Athens, blocking streets and occupying public buildings. He said the demonstrations presented a climate of anarchy and discouraged foreign investment. The 85-year-old Zolotas was appointed to head a government coalition after inconclusive elections in November. The government is supported by the conservative, socialist and Communist parties and has a mandate to work on economic problems before holding elections on April 8.

DOC.HEAD: Protest Movement at Berkeley to be Honored with Monument
DOC.TEXT: Artists, professors and veterans of the free speech movement on Tuesday unveiled finalists in a contest to commemorate the protest that was the forerunner of a decade of dissent. The proposals for the monument, to be built with private donations and given to the University of California at Berkeley, include a metal soap box; a suspended electronic billboard broadcasting computer messages from around the world; giant cracks in a plaza; bricks inscribed with speeches; and an ``autonomous nation'' within a 6-inch circle. ``The idea of freedom of speech and action should be memorialized and done so in the place where it all started,'' said Peter Selz, former chief curator of the Museum of Modern Art in New York and a project organizer. The sculpture, to be commissioned with $70,000, has revived a bitter debate over the movement's legacy at Berkeley, which sparked four months of demonstrations in 1964 after the school banned political activities on campus. Student tactics, including sit-ins, humorous music fetes and an alternative press, became the model for the 10 years of civil rights and anti-war demonstrations that followed. Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman suggested that he may refuse the artwork, saying he's unsure the movement deserves an honor. In his only public comment on the proposal, he wrote in a letter to project organizers that those involved in the movement were ``not very good at designing public art to commemorate their own actions.'' Journalism Professor David Littlejohn derided it as a tribute to the ``unjustified self-assurance'' of the campus liberal elite, which he characterizes as ironically intolerant of divergent views. The free speech movement began Oct. 1, 1964, when student Mario Savio and friend Jack Weinberg began distributing political material on the university's Sproul Plaza. Weinberg was arrested and placed in the back of a patrol car, but hundreds of students surrounded the automobile and for 32 hours refused to let 600 police officers take him into custody. Photographs of Savio and others addressing the crowd from atop the car were published around the world, leading to sympathetic student strikes until the university dropped its ban several months later. The protests culminated in a December sit-in at Sproul Hall where 773 people were taken into custody, then the largest mass arrest in California history. ``I feel there's a lot of pride among students today in the students who were here before us,'' said Matthew Miller, an architecture student and a member of the committee that selected the finalists from 277 applications. The proposals will be displayed at the University Art Museum through March 3, after which the committee and project organizers will announce the winner. The public can register their favorite with ballots. At a Tuesday news conference, committee members, including internationally known artists, said the proposals would be refined and possibly modified. They reserved the right to combine several of the ideas. Charles Schwartz, a physics professor since 1960, devised the idea of the monument last year after finding a recently installed campus statue of two black bears, which he labeled ``big, fat, powerful, complacent _ representative of the worst of California.'' Since then, the proposal has receieved support from 100 professors, politicians, students and most of the leaders of the free speech movement.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Says Investment Ban Should Go When Mandela Is Free
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Thursday a ban on new investment in South Africa should be lifted when President F.W. de Klerk's government frees imprisoned black leader Nelson Mandela. She said reforms de Klerk announced Friday had been welcomed internationally and, ``as we agreed both at the last meeting of the European Community and in the Commonwealth, it is necessary to have encouragement for such steps as well as chastisement for what has not yet been done.'' ``We do believe that, when Mr. Mandela is released, it would be advisable to release some of the very minor sanctions ... in particular the voluntary ban on new investment,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in the House of Commons. At Britain's insistence, foreign ministers of the 12-nation European Community will review sanctions against South Africa at a Feb. 20 meeting in Dublin, Ireland. Diplomatic sources said the Netherlands and Portugal also want to ease restrictions, but Ireland, which holds the rotating six-month presidency of the community, feels no action should be taken. Mrs. Thatcher, an opponent of sanctions, lifted academic and cultural restrictions within minutes of de Klerk's announcement Friday. Among other things, he legalized the African National Congress guerrilla movement and promised Mandela would be freed soon. British opposition parties and the Anti-Apartheid Movement criticized her. They feel sanctions should be maintained until apartheid is abolished. Some sanctions imposed by Britain are mandatory under international agreements, including a ban on arms exports and the import of South African iron, steel and Krugerrand gold coins. Voluntary measures could be lifted by Britain unilaterally or after persuading some others to follow suit in the European Community or the 49-nation Commonwealth, the association of Britain and its former colonies. Non-binding measures include bans on investment and tourism promotion. Mrs. Thatcher reacted mildly to the expulsions from South Africa earlier Tuesday of two British journalists who were covering the tour of an unofficial English cricket team. ``We have told the South African authorities that we regret these expulsions,'' she said, then noted that South Africa said one was working illegally on a tourist visa and the other filed a vivid account of police breaking up a demonstration he had not witnessed. Before leaving Johannesburg, Paul Weaver, a sports writer with the London newspaper Today acknowledged he had not seen the demonstration, the British news agency Press Association reported, but it quoted him as saying: ``I saw the bloodstains which remained after the police had used dogs and tear gas on demonstrators and I spoke to many people who were there at the time.'' The other expelled journalist was Gareth Furby of Independent Radio News, whose reports, the government in Pretoria said, were ``intended to damage South Africa's image.''

DOC.HEAD: King Confers With Members of Foreign Relations Council
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd has met with 25 members of the Council on Foreign Relations led by banker David Rockefeller, the official Saudi Press Agency reported Tuesday. It said the meeting with the U.S. government, academic, and business leaders was held Monday. The Foreign Relations Council is based in New York. Hisham Nazer, the oil minister and acting minister of planning, sat in on the meeting on ``bilateral relations and ... regional and international issues of mutual concern.'' Also present at the two-hour meeting were Mohammed Ibrahim Massoud, acting acting information minister, and Abdul-Rahman al-Mansouri, foreign affairs undersecretary. Included in the Council delegation were Richard Murphy, former assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs; political fundraiser Pamela Harriman; and publisher Mort Zuckerman. The Americans held separate meetings with Minister of Finance and Economy Mohammed Abal-Khail; Prince Salman, governor of Riyadh; Prince Sultan, the defense minister, and Ibrahim Tawfiq, the deputy trade minister. Saudi Arabia has close military and economic ties with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Community Action Key to Ending Gang Violence
DOC.TEXT: Escalating gang violence despite increased arrests and prosecutions is forging an alliance between community groups and law enforcement, participants in a state summit on gangs said Tuesday. Educators, law enforcement authorities and leaders of community programs were taking part in a two-day conference to fight gang influence in neighborhoods. State and local law enforcement authorities, who have seen death tolls rise from gang violence, said enlisting people in gang-plagued neighborhoods may be the only hope in fighting the problem. ``I don't think that we can any longer assume that by putting more and more gang members and drug dealers into jail we are going to force them somehow into submission,'' said Los Angeles police Cmdr. Lorne Kramer. ``Communities need to be mobilized. We definitely need to develop more comprehensive preventative programs.'' Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department figures show 554 gang-related homicides in the county in 1989, exceeding the record 452 homicides in 1988. There are an estimated 80,000 gang members today in the Los Angeles area, up from 30,000 in 1980, said Steve Valdivia, executive director of the city's anti-gang agency, Community Youth Gang Services. The conference, which ends Wednesday, focused on training small community organizations to work together and with law enforcement in developing and expanding programs to help neighborhoods rid themselves of gangs. ``You've got to look for some quick-fix successes that you can take into neighborhoods,'' said Natalie Salazar, executive director of Los Angeles' Community Reclamation Project. ``You've got to get rid of the graffiti, knock down some of the crack houses in the area, make sure the street lights are fixed, make sure the streets are swept.'' CRP is a federally funded pilot program based in the harbor area of Los Angeles, an area inhabited for generations by Hispanic and Filipino gangs. Salazar said the year-old program works with schools in anti-gang and anti-drug education and sponsors recreational activities and citizens meetings with law enforcement agencies. Federal officials hope to expand the program, scheduled to end in July, to other cities and states. Working on a small scale, sometimes just a two-block area, the program teaches how to cope with such problems as graffiti and loitering, Salazar said. To combat the factionalism inherent in gang culture, the program sponsored a basketball tournament that involved 500 junior high school-age youths. ``Kids from particular neighborhoods often feel they can't go into other neighborhoods, or learn to hate people from other neighborhoods,'' she said. ``The basketball tournament helps form bonds with kids from other neighborhoods.'' In the Los Angeles Police Department's Newton Division, which has one of the highest homicide rates of any police precinct in the nation, a citizens' group called 100 Men Plus has started a private initiative against gangs, patrolling schools and parks, removing graffiti and befriending neighborhood youth. The group recently formed its fourth Los Angeles chapter. ``There's no way we can claim any kind of success because the homicides are still there,'' said Valdivia, whose agency works with 100 Men Plus. ``But the signs are there.''
