DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE Voter Registration ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Two Schools Close Amid Racial Tension; Interim Superintendent Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The city's first black school superintendent was reinstated and five black school board members were urged to return to their posts Tuesday after racial turmoil forced the closing of two public schools. The all-white Selma Board of Education announced Norward Roussell's reinstatement as superintendent and the closing of all 11 schools in the system Wednesday in a compromise aimed at ending weeks of protests. The Rev. F.D. Reese, Selma High's black principal who was named interim superintendent Sunday, announced he was resigning so Roussell could resume his duties. Moments after Reese's announcement, black protest leaders met with Mayor Joe Smitherman to discuss ways of ending weeks of racial conflict over the operation of the predominantly black school system. The 6,000-student city school system is about 70 percent black. Smitherman and black leaders gave no details of the proposed compromise, but both sides made clear that Roussell's return would be a crucial element in any resolution of the conflict. The board announced later Tuesday that Roussell would resume his duties and all 11 schools in the system would be closed Wednesday ``due to recent disturbances and turmoil which have prevented normal operation of our school system.'' ``Selma city schools will reopen upon adequate assurances to Dr. Roussell and the board that the safety and physical welfare of our students and all school employees can be ensured,'' the school board said in a statement. The board has been made up of six whites since the five black members announced they were resigning following a vote _ along racial lines _ in December against extending Roussell's contract beyond its June expiration date. The five later said they had not signed any official resignation papers, leaving open their return. Mostly black Selma High School, with 1,508 students, and almost all-black Eastside Middle School, with 407 students, closed Tuesday as racial tensions rose following the arrest of four black leaders in a melee at Smitherman's City Hall office the day before. Reese said there were instances of racial fighting at Selma High School, and called for the orderly dismissal of students from the city's only public high school because ``we could certainly see and feel the level of tensions among the students.'' Police were called to the school, but Smitherman said no arrests were made. Dozens of the black students joined in a series of demonstrations outside City Hall on Tuesday. With adults, they carried signs saying ``Smitherman Must Go,'' sang songs of the civil rights movement and called for Roussell's reinstatement. Roussell was at Selma High School as throngs of parents and students left the building. He joined in helping disperse crowds of students ``so we would not have any trouble.'' Protesters have charged Roussell was dismissed because he is black, an allegation denied by white school board members. They cited an unfavorable job evaluation and Roussell's management style as the reason for his firing. Last week, the remaining white board members decided to remove Roussell from his $80,000-a-year job immediately, and on Sunday installed Reese as interim superintendent.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Race to Save Near-Extinct Marmoset from Blaze
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters Tuesday raced to save about 250 near-extinct golden lion marmosets from a forest fire that has ravaged a wildlife reserve for rare animals in southeastern Brazil, officials said. More than 200 firefighters, police and biologists were unable to halt the fire, which started Saturday in the Poco das Antas Wildlife Reserve 80 miles northeast of Rio, said reserve director Dionizio Pessamilio. Pessamilio said the fire had burned about half the 12,300-acre reserve, the last remaining natural habitat for the marmoset and a sanctuary for rare sloths, alligators and jaguars. ``The situation is bad,'' he said in a televised interview. ``The dense forest where the tamarins live is now burning, worsening their chances of survival.'' Tamarin is another name for the marmoset, a monkey the size of a cat with a lion-like mane and a bushy tail. Pessamilio said biologists had already lost contact with several of the creatures, which are monitored by means of tiny radio transmitters tied around their necks. Environmentalists are concerned the fire may kill all of the shy animals because they hide in tree holes for warmth and shelter. High wind, difficult access to the mountainous area and a lack of water caused by a long dry spell hampered firefighters' efforts, Pessamilio said. Only several days of heavy rain would put out the fire, he said. Rain was not forecast for the region until Friday. Globo TV, the nation's largest network, showed helicopters airlifting firefighters to burning areas and crews battling flames with portable water tanks and rubber mats. Fernando Mesquita, president of the Brazilian Institute of the Environment and Renewable Resources, said more firefighters would join the effort and work around-the-clock. The cause of the fire was not known. But officials said unusually dry weather and 100-degree summer temperatures could have caused the fire to begin spontaneously. Poco das Antas has become the center of an international crusade to protect the environment. The reserve was founded in 1974 and funded by the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, the World Wildlife Fund and the Brazilian and Canadian environmental groups. The marmoset first faced extinction in 1972 when just 70 remained on Earth after poachers, hunters and ranchers trapped them and cut down their forest habitats. But the animal slowly had been reproducing after naturalists released them in groups from foreign zoos into the Brazilian forest.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Gets Winter Weather; Rain Along the Gulf Coast
DOC.TEXT: Snow and rain fell on sections of the Northwest on Tuesday, and rain dampened the the Gulf Coast from Texas to Mississippi. The winter weather extended west of a cold front that reached from central Idaho to the central coast of California. Winter storm warnings were posted across the Washington Cascades and Olympic Mountains and the northern coastal mountains of Oregon. In western Oregon, lightning strikes around Coos Bay knocked out two radio transmitters, left a television station on reduced power and caused local power outages, said Drew Walker, station manager for KBBR radio in North Bend. More than a foot of snow had fallen by Tuesday in Stevens Pass and Snoqualmie Pass in Washington state. More snow was expected in parts of Oregon, including the Cascades. Snow was also expected over the western slopes of the Sierra Nevada in California, south of Lake Tahoe. Rain extended from the northern coast of California to central California, with rain changing to snow in the mountains and extending across northern Utah, Idaho, northwest Wyoming and western Montana. A winter storm watch was posted through Wednesday over western Wyoming. A cold snap continued across inland Alaska, with low temperatures ranging from minus 30 to minus 50. The cold spell began Jan. 26, and temperatures have been 15 to 20 degrees lower than normal for early February, although no records have been broken. Scattered snow fell from northeast New York state to west central New England. Rain showers streched from southern Mississippi to southern Louisiana and the upper Texas Gulf Coast. Light rain extended from eastern Kansas and southeast Nebraska, to northern and west central Missouri. Snowfall during the 6 hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 1 inch at Astoria, Ore., and Quillayute, Wa. Heavier rainfall during the same period included one third of an inch at New Orleans. High-temperature records for the date were set in Devils Lake, N.D., where it was 44 degrees; Roanoke, Va., 64; and Williamsport, Pa., 53. The low for the Lower 48 states was minus 8 degrees at Hibbing and International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 22 degrees at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 78 degrees at Miami, Key West and Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Front Registers for Romanian Elections; Iliescu to Run, Aide Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 3 grafs SUB for 19th and final graf, `Lupoi, an ... to UPDATE with merchant marine academy agreement
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XBUC2
DOC.TEXT: Interim President Ion Iliescu registered the former ruling National Salvation Front on Tuesday to run in the May 20 elections, and a top aide said Iliescu will be its presidential candidate. The Front, unelected and ruling by decree since longtime Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was toppled and executed in December, is considered the front-runner in the race against 29 political parties. ``Our candidate for president will be Mr. Iliescu, that's for sure. That's what everyone wants,'' said Dan Radulescu, chief of the Front's commission for press and public relations. Interim Prime Minister Petre Roman said in an interview for U.S. television that he too wanted Iliescu, a former Communist official who fell out with Ceausescu, to run for president. ``I hope it will be Iliescu,'' he said in the interview for John McLaughlin's syndicated ``One on One'' program, which will be broadcast in the United States next weekend. A transcript was made available here. Roman said he would not campaign to be prime minister but would probably accept the post if the Front wins the election and he is asked by a majority of the movement. The Front on Jan. 23 reversed its pledge to stay out of the election. It has refused to become a political party, choosing instead to remain a political movement. Iliescu went to the central tribunal to officially register the Front, which has split from the government and the eight-member ruling council. The Front agreed to form a Council of National Unity with opposition parties to run the country until Romania's first multiparty elections since World War II are held in May. The new National Unity Council will meet for the first time Friday. In its platform released Tuesday, the Front said its aim is ``realization in Romania of a democratic society based on political pluralism, the separation of powers in the state, the assurance of liberty and human dignity.'' The Front said it also sought to guarantee ``the inviolability of human rights, the respecting of the rights and liberties of all national minorities, the guarantee of freedom of religion.'' Another platform goal is ``creation of a modern national economy'' based on efficiency and individual as well as collective initiative. Roman said Romania was moving slowly toward a market economy and faced two major economic problems: that it produced only basic products and that its largest industries had far greater capacity than the country needs. The platform included membership guidelines and an outline of the party's structure from villages on up. It bars from membership anyone convicted of crimes against the revolution. The platform made no mention of the Communist Party. Last month the Front announced it would outlaw the party. Then it decided to submit the question to a referendum, only to cancel the vote a short time later. Asked in the interview whether the Communist Party was dead for all practical purposes, Roman replied: ``The Communist Party doesn't exist any more. Practically, it was a self-dissolution.'' He said the Front and every political party had former Communists as members. Sources in the Front, speaking on condition of anonymity, meanwhile said Tourism Minister Mihai Lupoi had resigned. Radulescu said he could not confirm the resignation. On Tuesday night, Roman acceded to cadet demands that Romania's only merchant marine academy, the Mircea Cel Batrin Institute, be demilitarized. He signed an agreement transferring authority over the institute from the Defense Ministry to the Ministry of Education. Representatives of the 1,265 cadets expressed skepticism that the Defense Ministry would cooperate. More than 200 cadets who began a hunger strike Tuesday morning said they would continue through the night.

DOC.HEAD: GOP's War Chest Triples That of Democrats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 15: ``We feel,'' to add first name of Farmer
DOC.TEXT: The three major Republican fund-raising committees reaped more than $80 million in 1989 and entered this election year with more than $14 million on hand, nearly triple the combined war chest of their Democratic counterparts, the Federal Election Commission said Tuesday. The Democratic National Committee and the party's separate House and Senate campaign arms raised and spent more than $19 million in 1989 and carried over $5.4 million to this year. Last year was an unusually costly off year because of eight special congressional elections. But while they spent considerable amounts on those races, the national parties focused much of their resources on building stronger fund-raising machinery for this year. The performance of the Democratic groups, while an improvement over past non-federal election years, was again dwarfed by that of the GOP's money machines. But tempering the Republican edge is the fact that more Democrats, who hold a majority in both chambers of Congress, enjoy the lopsided donor preference for giving to the individual campaign coffers of incumbents. Thus Republicans, with more challengers than incumbents, are more reliant on national party support. The FEC data showed that the three Republican committees spent $72.2 million of the $80.4 million they took in last year. But because of cash left over from 1988, the GOP groups entered this year already armed with $14.4 million. The overwhelming bulk of that money _ $10.6 million _ was in the coffers of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which is hoping to erode the Democratic majority in that chamber this year as part of a strategy aimed at recapturing the Senate in the 1992 presidential elections. The GOP Senate committee, which raised $35.4 million and spent $27 million, reported $589,734 in debts as of Jan. 31, about half its $1.1 million debt at the end of 1987, the last comparable non-election year. The National Republican Congressional Committee, the GOP's main fund-raising arm for House candidates, raised $14.2 million and spent $13.1 million, according to its year-end filing with the FEC. The NRCC had $2.3 million heading into this year and debts of $794,654, up dramatically from the $34,922 in red ink it reported two years ago. The Republican National Committee, meanwhile, reported receiving $30.6 million in 1989 and spending $31 million. Because of its 1988 reserves, it carried over $1.5 million into this year while reporting no debt, according to the FEC. On the Democratic side, the Democratic National Committee and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee reported significant strides last year in reducing debts. But the party's cash-poor Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee nearly doubled its debt from two years ago and entered this year with just $22,179 on hand. The DCCC said it raised $4.1 million last year and spent $4.2 million. Its reported debts grew from $828,889 at the end of 1987 to $1.6 million as of Jan. 31. The $22,179 it had on hand entering the year was less than one-tenth of the nearly $233,000 it held at the beginning of 1988. Far more impressive was the fund-raising of the Democratic Senate committee, which said it collected $8 million in contributions and other receipts and spent $6 million. The Democrats' Senate campaign operation had nearly $1.6 million in the bank as the year began and had sliced the $1 million debt it reported two years ago down to $319,201. The Democratic National Committee, meanwhile, reported receipts of $6.8 million and said it drew on 1988 reserves in spending $8.4 million last year. Those reserves, comparatively deep for the Democratic Party, allowed it to enter the year with $3.8 million on hand _ up dramatically from the $722,288 the party coffers held at the end of 1987. The DNC also reported debts of $111,837 at the end of last year, down from more than $1.6 million in red ink reported in its year-end filing two years ago. ``We feel very good about it and look forward to a very good 1990,'' DNC Treasurer Robert Farmer said, adding the DNC hoped to raise at least $10 million. He said national party groups will face competition for money because of 36 gubernatorial elections and other state races vital to the outcome of congressional redistricting. For all of the committees, the totals raised include contributions and other receipts such as interest on bank accounts and certificates of deposit. Separate FEC data on the special elections last year show that nearly $11 million was spent on the eight races. There were 41 initial candidates in the eight elections, with the 16 who survived to participate in the final, head-to-head contests accounting for $8.9 million of the spending total. The national parties and their state affiliates invested heavily in those races, with total expenditures by the major parties reaching neatly $1.2 million. jk

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Men Take Suburb; Hospital Says Morgue Overflows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with report of papal nuncio delivering message of Aoun, INSERT new 8th graf; pickup 8th pvs, `Hrawi dismissed...'
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's soldiers drove rival militiamen from a northern suburb Tuesday and turned their guns on a surrounded garrison in an intra-Christian war that has cost hundreds of lives in eight days. Beirut's largest Christian hospital said its morgue had overflowed and the bodies would have to be buried in a mass grave. Voice of Lebanon, a Christian radio station, said said thousands of people were going hungry in bomb shelters made cold and dank because of heavy rain and a power failure caused when shellfire knocked out the main power station. Police said 38 people were killed and 111 wounded Tuesday. That raised casualties to 315 killed and 1,148 wounded since the battle for Christian supremacy began Jan. 30 between Aoun's men and the Lebanese Forces militia led by Samir Geagea. President Elias Hrawi appealed to the superpowers, Vatican, European governments, the United Nations and Arab leaders for help in ending the fighting. ``I appeal for your support in any effort or endeavor I might find myself compelled to take ... to end the plight of the Lebanese people and salvage Lebanon,'' he said in telegrams to President Bush, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Pope John Paul II and other leaders. Arab leaders receiving the telegram included President Hafez Assad of Syria, who keeps 40,000 soldiers and 300 tanks in Lebanon and supports Hrawi, whom Parliament elected in November as part of a peace plan designed to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun's television station reported that Papal Nuncio Pablo Puentes delivered a message from the pope to Aoun but gave no details except to say that it concerned the fighting in the Christian enclave. Hrawi dismissed Aoun as military chief, but the general, who rejects the peace plan and does not recognize the president, has refused to relinquish his command. On Tuesday, Hrawi called Aoun ``a mutineer against legitimacy'' and blamed him for the latest carnage. His statement was seen as a threat to intervene militarily. He would have to call on the Syrians for that because the 22,000 Moslem troops loyal to him are poorly trained and equipped. Syrian troops fought a six-month war last year with Aoun, who calls them an ``army of occupation.'' It ended when the Arab League arranged a cease-fire in September. During a visit to Syria by Hrawi last month, Assad publicly pledged to help him crush the general. After the Lebanese Forces abandoned the strategic suburb of Dbaye on Tuesday, Aoun's gunners trained their artillery on a surrounded militia garrison in Christian east Beirut. The militia, which said Dbaye was destroyed by ``hysterical shelling,'' responded by shelling areas controlled by Aoun. The Hotel Dieu hospital in the Ashrafiyeh district of east Beirut said its morgue was full and the bodies were decomposing because of the power failure. ``We find ourselves obliged to bury the victims in a mass grave in Ashrafiyeh Wednesday if no one shows up to collect them,'' it said in a statement broadcast by Voice of Lebanon. A Moslem station, Voice of the Nation, said: ``Those who would emerge from shelters to collect the bodies would end up dead.'' French official Bernard Kouchner met with Hrawi and Prime Minister Salim Hoss about helping residents of the 310-mile enclave north and east of Beirut where 1 million Christians live. Kouchner organized an evacuation of wounded Lebanese civilians to a French hospital ship in April 1989. He said a French plane with ``about 150 seats for sitting wounded'' landed early in the day at Beirut Airport, in the Moslem western sector. A spokesman for the Health Ministry, which is helping coordinate Kouchner's mission, said word had been sent ``to the warring factions, but no practical responses have been received to help get the mercy mission going.'' Lebanon became a French mandate after World War I and gained independence in 1943. Aoun's command said it had ``crushed the last pockets of resistance'' in Dbaye and cut off militiamen north of the suburb from besieged Lebanese Forces strongholds in east Beirut. Aoun commands nearly 20,000 men and Geagea has 6,000 militia regulars, with an estimated 30,000 reservists. The Lebanese Forces said its men redeployed along the northern entrance of the 300-yard Dog River tunnel north of Dbaye. Police reported that Aoun's tanks chased the militiamen to the edge of the Dog River valley. Other tank units hammered the militia's besieged Kassardjian garrison in the east Beirut district of Ein Rummaneh all day Tuesday in apparent preparation to storm it, police reported. According to Aoun's command, ``all escape routes'' from Kassardjian were sealed. The garrison backs up on the hostile Shiite Moslem district of Shiyah across the capital's sectarian dividing line. Gunners loyal to the general pounded the militia-controlled residential districts of Ashrafiyeh, Jemmayezeh and Karantina with U.S.-made 155mm howitzers. Police said militia gunners replied with Soviet-designed 122mm rockets fired at the Sin el-Fil, Furn el-Shubbak, Hazmiyeh and Fayadiyeh districts held by Aoun, and at the Baabda suburb, where he has a headquarters bunker beneath Lebanon's shattered presidential palace.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rules Mississippi Universities Insufficiently Desgregated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with reaction from state and university officials, further quotes from court opinion. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that Mississippi's public universities are insufficiently desegregated, overruling a lower court judge. In its 2-1 decision, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said that, with few exceptions, the state's five historically white and three historically black universities remain virtually as segregated as they were when black citizens sued the state in January 1975. In their majority opinion, Judges Irving Goldberg and Sam D. Johnson said ``there were many steps, but no discernible degrees of progress ... Unfortunately, this case lingered, loitered and lulled for more than a decade.'' The court sent the case back to U.S. District Judge Neal B. Biggers Jr., who had dismissed the lawsuit after declaring Mississippi's university system sufficiently desegregated. Most state and university officials could not be reached immediately for comment, and those who could were guarded in their comments. ``I have learned about this decision secondhand. I have not seen any legal documents. I'm quite sure our attorneys will be briefing us soon,'' said Aubrey Lucas, president of the University of Southern Mississippi. The appellate court ordered further proceedings involving a broader cast of characters. ``Psychologists, sociologists, economists, engineers, doctors and professionals from all relevant areas of learning play a role,'' said the majority opinion. ``Windows must open to ventilate the courtroom with ideas from the winds of truth,'' it said. ``To this end, testimony, depositions, cross-examinations and opinions can assist. Only then should the parties come forth with a definite plan for'' achieving desegregation. In a dissent, Judge John Duhe said Mississippi had fulfilled its legal obligation to open its universities to all students, regardless of race. ``The majority, relying on district and other circuit court decisions, has ... imposed upon the state the same constitutional duty required for primary and secondary education, where freedom of choice is unavailable and services are free of charge. ``In doing so,'' wrote Duhe, ``it takes a liberty that is simply not available to courts of appeals.'' In its review, the 5th Circuit said racial imbalances of students, faculty, undergraduate and graduate programs, appropriations, and admissions policies, among other things, have continued since the court ordered the University of Mississippi to enroll James Meredith, its first black student, in 1962. To this day, the majority said, historically white Delta State University, Mississippi State University, Mississippi University for Women, the University of Mississippi and the University of Southern Mississippi enjoy distinct advantages over historically black Alcorn State, Jackson State and Mississippi Valley State universities. Standardized college admissions examinations, as administered by Mississippi, also discriminate, the court said, and the Board of Trustees of State Institutions of Higher Learning spent more money on educating students at mostly white institutions than they did on students at black schools. For instance, the court said, the state spent an average $1,351 in 1960 and $8,516 in 1986 on each student enrolled at historically white institutions. The average at historically black schools was $718 in 1960 and $6,038 in 1986, the court said. ``The badge of inferiority that marks black institutions has not been removed,'' Goldberg and Johnson wrote. ``As such, there remains in Mississippi's higher educational system vestiges of discrimination which distort the perceptions of black students. ``Vestiges of de jure segregation permeate the public university system of Mississippi. Admissions policies, the racial composition of the faculty and administration, funding practices, academic offerings and mission designations all perpetuate a stigma of inferiority.''

DOC.HEAD: Gotti Jury Begins Deliberations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with jury ending deliberations for the day, rehearing tapes; picks up 7th graf, `Assistant District ...'
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the assault and conspiracy trial of reputed mob boss John Gotti concluded their first day of deliberations Tuesday after listening again to 11 tapes that are the prosecution's key evidence. The jury retired at about 7:15 p.m., and was to resume deliberations Wednesday morning. Law enforcement officers secretly recorded a dozen tapes of conversations at Gotti's hangout in the borough of Queens and in the visiting room of a jail. Among the conversations jurors heard again were one in which Gotti allegedly says, ``We're gonna, gonna bust him up,'' which the prosecution says is a reference to a former union leader, and another in which members of the Westies gang allegedly say they shot the man as a favor to Gotti. The defense has ridiculed the tapes as inaudible, and claims prosecutors transcribed them to suit their theory that Gotti had John F. O'Connor shot. As the jury began deliberations earlier in the day, Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin told the four alternate jurors they would be held in court custody and he could not tell them why. A court source said the alternates were being held ``at least until tomorrow, and maybe longer'' to minimize chances of their being found and bothered for information about the 12 main jurors. Since their swearing-in about three weeks ago, all the jurors have been sequestered to shield them from publicity and possible jury-tampering. Court officials estimate it costs $1,200 a day to feed, house and transport them. About two hours after getting the case, the jurors sent a note requesting a rereading of the definition of first-degree intentional assault, the first count on their verdict sheet. They then began rehearing the tapes. Gotti, 49, and his co-defendant, Anthony ``Tony Lee'' Guerrieri, 61, are accused of commissioning the Westies, a gang from Manhattan's Hell's Kitchen district, to shoot O'Connor, former vice president of Carpenters Union Local 608, on May 7, 1986. O'Connor was shot in the buttocks and survived. Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky said Gotti, alleged boss of the Gambino crime family, arranged the shooting because O'Connor ordered goons to trash Bankers and Brokers, a mob-run restaurant in Lower Manhattan that was being built with non-union labor. The judge told the jurors that, to convict, they must find the prosecution proved the specific elements of the crime charged in the trial and not simply that Gotti and his co-defendant might be members of organized crime. He also reminded them that the prosecution's key witness, former Westies member and confessed killer James McElroy, 45, testified he had previously lied under oath. The judge told the jurors it was up to them to decide whether they believe McElroy was testifying truthfully against Gotti. Just before the jurors left to deliberate, McLaughlin admonished them: ``The person that you were when you left your apartment those weeks ago is the person you're supposed to be in the jury room,'' he said. ``Do not become somebody else. Don't turn the jury room into the Twilight Zone. Don't expect divine intervention.'' ``You do not have to answer to anybody but yourselves regarding the verdict,'' McLaughlin said. ``If you can look at yourself in the mirror every day for the rest of your life and say, `I conscientiously followed the law and called it as I saw it,' then whatever your verdict turns out to be, it will have been the correct one.'' In closing arguments Monday, defense lawyers Bruce Cutler and Gerald Shargel said Gotti was being persecuted because of his reputation. ``When the smoke clears, you will realize one thing _ that there is no proof, let alone proof beyond a reasonable doubt, that John Gotti and Anthony Guerrieri had John O'Connor shot,'' Shargel said. The judge told the jurors the charges they are to consider _ intentional first- and second-degree assault; reckless first- and second-degree assault; fourth-degree conspiracy, a felony, and fifth-degree conspiracy, a misdemeanor. If convicted, Gotti could face 25 years to life in prison as a persistent felon because of convictions in 1969 and 1974.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Tests Criticized
DOC.TEXT: A Food and Drug Administration survey that found the nation's milk supply to be free of veterinary drug residues was attacked Tuesday in a congressional hearing. The challenges to the FDA survey of milk in 14 cities came from Rep. Ted Weiss, chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on government and human resources, and FDA scientist Joseph Settepani. ``Too many government officials seem to think their overriding responsibility is to reassure the public that the milk supply is safe, even when it may not be,'' said Weiss, D-N.Y., alleging that FDA is more concerned with public relations than science. The FDA released a study Monday that contradicted findings of two surveys by The Wall Street Journal and an advocacy group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, as well as findings of its own. Both private tests were done using a relatively new test known as the Charm 2. The test is highly sensitive, able to test drug residues in amounts as low as five parts per billion, its advocates say. But the FDA said the test yields too many false positives and none of its positive findings could be validated in what it considered to be better, even newer tests. The Charm 2 test is limited also because it detects only classes of drugs, not individual drugs within a class, FDA says. The FDA said that using Charm 2, it found a variety of drugs in 36 out of 70 samples. Of those, 14 contained sulfa drugs. Those 14 were tested by high pressure liquid chromatography, which found sulfa drugs in 11 samples. That test was sensitive to at least 10 parts per billion. The test has been accepted by federal regulators for detecting only a single drug, sulfamethazine, and not for the purpose it was used in the newest test, according to FDA testimony. The 11 samples were further tested by mass spectrometry, and none was found to be positive for individual sulfa drugs. The test is capable of isolating specific drugs, but it is less sensitive than Charm 2, able only to detect amounts of 20 parts per billion. Six of 11 samples were below 20 parts per billion by the other tests. ``There is just no way to believe that mass spectrometry, which is sensitive to only about 20 parts per billion, could have picked those up even by your expectations,'' Weiss said. Settepani, who testified with the FDA panel and earlier with a member of the consumer group, complained that FDA had earlier tried to discredit tests that find potentially dangerous residues in milk. ``The initial reaction to each new report of residues in milk has been attempts to discredit the assay used to obtain the reported results,'' he said. He said a 1988 internal memorandum listed 30 drugs believed to be used by milk producers, 16 of them extensively. But current standard tests used by state inspectors can only detect two, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Judge Questions Why Reagan Didn't Testify for North
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 7-10: ``Silberman also,'' on argument over North's immunized testimony
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals judge hearing Oliver North's Iran-Contra case Tuesday questioned why North wasn't allowed to call former President Reagan as a defense witness at his trial. During nearly 2{ hours of arguments, U.S. Court of Appeals Judge Laurence Silberman noted that Reagan's written answers to questions in the Iran-Contra affair were submitted to a grand jury, but were never provided to North's lawyers. Silberman, one of three judges who will rule on North's appeal of his conviction on three felony counts, asked why, ``as a matter of basic fairness'' Reagan's written answers weren't turned over to the defendant. Government attorney Gerard Lynch said the judgment was made that Reagan's written answers would not have been ``helpful'' to North and so weren't turned over. ``But our system ... is based on'' giving someone accused of a crime wide latitude in obtaining information for his defense, responded Silberman. The appeals court panel consists of Silberman and David Sentelle, both Reagan administration appointees, and Carter administration appointee Patricia Wald, chief judge of the appeals court. Silberman also questioned whether the case against North was tainted by his own immunized testimony to Congress in 1987, another basis on which North is urging that his convictions be reversed. Senior Reagan administration officials testified at North's trial ``after being drenched in the immunized testimony'' he gave on national television, said Silberman. ''You have a prima facie violation'' of the requirement that no part of a case be derived from a defendant's immunized testimony. But Lynch said North's lawyers are incorrectly equating ``exposure with taint and use'' and that the prosecution was based on independent recollection of all witnesses. Indicating that Reagan's written answers in the Iran-Contra inquiry may have been more general than specific, Silberman said that ``what troubles me is we don't have a very good idea'' of what Reagan might have said as a defense witness for North. If North had worked in the State Department and Reagan had been secretary of state, there would have been no question that he would have been called to testify, said Silberman. North, who was convicted of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, altering and destroying National Security Council documents and accepting an illegal gratuity, argued that all his activities were approved by his superiors, national security adviser John Poindexter and Reagan. Silberman also questioned whether Poindexter's videotaped testimony on Capitol Hill should have been admitted as evidence at the North trial. ``Only two people were north of North ... the president and Admiral Poindexter,'' said Silberman. Lynch emphasized that ``North's own testimony'' was that he never met alone with Reagan, and that North ``never said the president told him to do anything.'' Silberman said that even if Reagan didn't specifically authorize the actions for which North was convicted of crimes, the ex-president's testimony might have been helpful to North. ``Suppose the ex-president says that `I never gave specific authorization' (but) `I did indicate that I didn't wish this information to be revealed,'' said Silberman. Defense attorney Barry Simon said Reagan should have been called to confirm that he authorized keeping secret from Congress the U.S. connection to a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles from Israel to Iran. Lynch conceded that North may have gotten the ``impression'' from Poindexter that the U.S. role was to be kept secret. But Lynch argued that North knew he was committing a wrongful act when he obstructed Congress from learning of the issue. ``We're not talking about keeping secrets from enemies of the United States'' or ``even the public,'' said Lynch. At North's trial, U.S. District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell quashed a subpoena for Reagan's appearance. The judge ruled there was no evidence in the record to suggest that the former president authorized any illegal activities by North. Gesell also rejected a request to admit as evidence portions of Poindexter's congressional testimony on videotaped segments which were prepared by North's trial team. Gesell on July 5 placed North on probation for two years, fined him $150,000 and sentenced him to 1,200 hours of community service. North is performing the community service while appealing the convictions and fine.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Thwarts Attempt To Scrap Teacher Certification Board
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4th graf: ``The National,'' and edits throughout to clarify that the board already exists; other editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Tuesday defeated an attempt to strip federal funds from a national school teacher certification board, setting the stage for passage of a nearly $1.5 billion educational improvement bill. By a 64-35 vote, lawmakers turned back an attempt by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and others to strike from the Excellence in Education Act a provision giving federal money to the panel. Critics argued that it would give the federal government too great a say in setting teacher standards. Supporters of the provision, tacked onto sweeping education legislation President Bush sent to Capitol Hill in April 1989, said a well-financed board would give badly needed prestige to the teaching profession. It would bestow the kind of credential review that doctors, lawyers and others now get, they said. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards was created in 1987 at the urging of the National Governors' Association. It is an independent, nonpartisan organization governed by a 64-member board of directors, including representatives of teachers' unions. Activities so far have been low-key. The Senate is considering a wide-ranging education bill which, among other things, seeks to combat drugs in public schools, establish a presidential merit schools program and increase aid to schools seeking to lower dropout rates. The Senate planned a vote Wednesday on the overall bill. According to Congressional Budget Office estimates, the bill cost nearly $1.5 billion over the next five years. Earlier Tuesday, the Senate passed 99-0 legislation that would provide $50 million in the next fiscal year to attack illiteracy _ said to affect at least 23 million Americans _ with a goal of eliminating illiteracy by the year 2000. Helms argued that activities of the teaching standards board would be dominated by these unions _ the National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers. ``What this board wants is for it to be the sole voice of setting the standards by which teachers operate _ that only teachers and their unions should decide who can and who cannot teach,'' Helms argued. ``Now, I think that's an outrage.'' ``The control of these unions over the board will enable them to use taxpayers' money not so much to professionalize teachers as to finalize who does and does not teach in America'' he said. Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., said a vote against the bill was ``a vote for parents.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., charged that ``misinformation'' was being spread about the board. He and other supporters noted that none of the $25 million could be used to pay the board's operating expenses _ that the panel would have to raise those funds through private means. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said, ``This board represents a unique opportunity to improve education. ``I think one thing everyone can agree on is that our educational system has serious deficiencies,'' he said, ``and it is adversely affecting our competitive position in the world.'' Bush had proposed a $25 million authorization for federal grants to states to improve teacher certification. That was changed in the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The money would be used instead by the national board for research and development of a national certification program, under which teachers could voluntarily seek review of their qualifications.

DOC.TEXT: Eliminate BC-WEA--Temps, a9502; BC-WEA--Temps UNJUSTIFIED, a9505, and BC-WEA--Temps EXPANDED, a9507, headlined ``The Weather Elsewhere.'' They contain outdated data provided by the National Weather Service. A 1st Ld-Writethru to each table with the correct, updated data will move in about 20 minutes.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Bus Driver Detained, Suspected of Collaborating with Gunmen
DOC.TEXT: The driver of the tour bus that was attacked by masked gunmen, leaving nine Israeli tourists dead, has been detained on suspicion he collaborated in the assault, newspapers reported Wednesday. Al-Ahram newspaper said police evidence indicated the attack Sunday was planned abroad and carried out by three gunmen in addition to the bus driver. Earlier reports spoke of two gunmen. Al-Ahram quoted police sources as saying the guns, grenades and ammunition used in the attack were smuggled into Egypt from another country. The nine were killed when the assailants opened fire with machine guns and tossed hand grenades on a desert road between Cairo and the Suez Canal city of Ismailiya. Twenty people were injured, including an Egyptian tour guide. The incident has shocked Israelis and provoked right-wing calls to exclude Egypt from the peace process. It remains unclear who carried out the attack. Three Arab groups have claimed responsibility. Al-Ahram reported that bus driver Saeed Abdel-Raouf, a Palestinian, was detained after witnesses said he stopped the bus immediately after the attackers signaled him to do so. Abdel-Raouf, who was said to have gained Egyptian nationality some time ago, said in an interview televised Monday night that he was taken by surprise and that he stopped the bus after he heard a ``bang'' that he thought came from a tire explosion. Reports by other government newspapers said the man who rented the attack car is a 34-year-old Palestinian with a Jordanian passport named Akram Deeb Ihab. Ihab came to Egypt Jan. 21 and left the country a week later, the daily Al-Akhbar reported. Al-Ahram said about 60 suspects, mostly Palestinians, and an unspecified number of Egyptian non-commissioned police officers on board the tour bus were detained for questioning. Police sources who demanded anonymity said those detained included a Palestinian believed connected with the ambush but not as a gunman. The non-commissioned officers boarded the bus from Rafeh, a divided city on the border with Israel in the Sinai Peninsula and left the bus when ordered to do so by the attackers, Al-Ahram said. A senior police official, Maj. Gen. Bahaa el-Din Ibrahim, denied a report Monday by the state-run Middle East News Agency Tuesday that one gunman had been arrested. A spokesman at the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for internal security, refused to discuss the newspaper reports. Newspapers reported Tuesday that police had found the passport of a Palestinian they believe was involved in an attack, and that authorities were searching for two Palestinians with Jordanian passports. Al-Ahram said police suspect the passports are forged. Newspapers identified the Palestinian whose passport was found as Akram Shihab, 25. They said he and another man arrived in Egypt on Jan. 21 and rented a furnished apartment at Shibin el-Kanatir, a Nile River delta town just north of Cairo. A senior Jordanian official in Amman said Shihab, the user of the seized passport, ``is not a Jordanian'' but was from Rafah refugee camp in the occupied Gaza Strip. Israel has occupied the Gaza Strip since the 1967 Middle East war. Many Gaza Palestinians carry Jordanian passports but Jordan does not consider them citizens. Al-Akhbar carried a statement attributed to Ahmed Jebril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestinian-General Command claiming responsibility for the attack. It said the claim was broadcast Tuesday over Libya's Tripoli radio but monitors in London said they heard no such statement. The official Libyan news agency did not carry the claim. Two Arab groups have claimed responsibility for the bus attack. One, in Cairo Sunday night, was made by an anonymous caller to a Western news agency who said he spoke for the previously unknown Organization for the Defense of the Oppressed in Egyptian Prisons. In Jordan, a handwritten message sent Monday to the French news agency Agence France-Presse claimed the assault for an obscure group calling itself Islamic Jihad-Beit Al-Maqdis, Arabic for holy war-Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Scraps English-Only Law in Arizona
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday threw out Arizona's voter-approved measure making English the state's official language, saying it violated the U.S. Constitution's First Amendment. U.S. District Judge Paul Rosenblatt said in a 20-page decision that the measure was ``substantially overbroad.'' Rosenblatt ruled on a lawsuit by Maria-Kelly Yniguez, a state Department of Administration worker, and state Sen. Jaime Gutierrez. Ms. Yniguez, who evaluates and arbitrates medical malpractice claims, said the law inhibited her constitutional right to free speech and threatened her job if she used Spanish while speaking with a co-worker. Gutierrez, a Tucson Democrat who represents a partially Hispanic district, said the law could block him from communicating effectively with constituents. Rosenblatt dismissed Gutierrez from the case but said Yniguez was justified in her concerns. The Arizona initiative, approved by a 580,830-to-569,993 vote in the state's 1988 general election, changed Arizona's constitution to designate English as the state's official language and impose sharp limits on use of other languages in state or local government affairs. ``I thought it was a longshot,'' Gutierrez said of the ruling. ``It took a lot of courage on the part of the judge. I hope the decision can be used nationwide, but we'll just fight the battles one at a time.'' Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford, the only person with legal standing to appeal the decision, said she was happy the courts ruled it unconstitutional and considered the law flawed. Mofford's press secretary, Vada Manager, said the governor would not appeal the ruling. But the measure's backers said Mrs. Mofford should appeal the decision, especially because a state court had upheld the measure's constitutionality last year and since similar laws in 16 other states had been allowed to stand. ``It's a surprise and a disappointment,'' said Bob Park, head of Arizonans for Official English. ``Federal courts have upheld (English language amendments) wherever they have been challenged. I am quite confident we would win an appeal.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Won't Prosecute Deserter; He's Going to `Live It Up'
LaserPhoto AH1
DOC.TEXT: Pvt. Arnold Kephart returned to Omaha and was welcomed by his family Tuesday after the Army said it wouldn't court-martial him for desertion for fleeing to East Germany after crashing a truck 30 years ago. Kephart's request for a less-than-honorable discharge was granted Tuesday, allowing him to fly to Omaha for the second time in a week to be given a tumultuous welcome from about 40 relatives, friends and well-wishers. He was arrested at Omaha's Eppley Airfield when he arrived from Europe last week to see his family for the first time since 1960. When he stepped off the plane from Dallas on Tuesday, Kephart spotted his 12-year-old son. ``Frankie,'' he exclaimed, and embraced the boy born in East Germany and left with his father's relatives for the past week. Others at the airport included Kephart's 86-year-old father, Ernest Kephart of Council Bluffs, Iowa, two sisters and two brothers. When he hugged his father and sister, Flossie Dunbar of Council Bluffs, Kephart sobbed: ``This time nothing's going to stop us.'' At the airport arrival gate, relatives had unfurled a 20-foot red-and-white banner that read, ``Welcome Back, Arnold and Frankie!'' ``It's just wonderful,'' Ernest Kephart said through tears as he hugged his son. ``I can't believe it.'' About 30 family members were waiting Jan. 30 at Eppley Airfield, but only his father and a sister were allowed to speak to Kephart before he was taken away. ``I'm going to live it up,'' the 53-year-old Kephart told reporters outside the Army's Fort Sill in Oklahoma earlier Tuesday after he was given his discharge. ``I'm going to live it up first ... and then I'm going to sit down and try to work my way in life as I did before.'' ``I don't know how I'm going to say it, but I'll say I'm proud to be back in the United States,'' Kephart said, who said he deserted for fear a truck accident would land him in the stockade. His attorney, James Martin Davis, said Kephart tried to escape the Communist bloc country on several occasions. When East Germany opened its borders late last year, Kephart decided to return to the United States with Frankie. ``This time, the Army did it right,'' Davis said, saying he hopes to get a thorough medical exam for Kephart, whose poor diet in East Germany may have harmed his health. Kephart, originally from Langdon, Mo., said he probably would spend five or six weeks with relatives in Council Bluffs, Iowa, across the Missouri River from Omaha. His ex-wife, Brigitte, and his twin 8-year-old daughters, Kathleen and Katharina, remain in East Germany. He said he would like to have them come to the United States. Kephart was declared absent without leave in November 1960 while a private stationed in Heidelberg, West Germany. He was driving back to his base from France when the truck crashed. There were three corked bottles of French wine in the truck, he said. ``In the crash, the wine got broke up on our uniforms. The police, they thought that we had been drunk. ... We didn't have one single drink from the wine,'' Kephart told the Omaha World-Herald on Monday. Kephart said French police locked them up, and the soldier's superiors took them into custody. He said his superiors told him he would be sent to prison and would have to pay for the truck. He said he waited for his chance, then scaled the barbed wire. ``I didn't decide on East Germany. I had a girlfriend back then ... she said I'd be safe over there,'' Kephart said. Kephart's discharge will be finalized when he receives the discharge papers from the Army, which his lawyer said should be by week's end. Fort Sill spokeswoman Sheila Samples said the other-than-honorable discharge means Kephart is eligible for few benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Gives German Reunification a Boost
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 10-11: ``Baker's visit,'' to note Modrow also in Prague
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, trying to guide the drive to German reunification, registered his support Tuesday for a plan that would keep the country in NATO but bar Western troops from moving into what is now East Germany. The proposal, advanced by West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher last week, also would allow Soviet troops to remain in the eastern region _ at least at the outset. A senior U.S. official familiar with Baker's thinking said the move to reunification had accelerated to the point that the two Germanies are likely to begin a process of economic, political and legal integration after East Germany holds national elections March 18. ``The process of unification is taking place on the ground right now, and will continue to take place at a quick pace,'' said the senior official, traveling aboard Baker's plane and commenting only on condition he not be named. Later, in a speech scheduled for delivery Wednesday at Charles University, Baker proposed that the United States, Canada, the Soviet Union and 32 European nations send observer delegations to eastern and central Europe to ensure that the emerging democracies hold elections that genuinely represent their people. In his text, Baker also voiced support for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for a summit of the 35 nations later in the year, and proposed it establish free elections as a human right. He said the Soviet leadership apparently had agreed that ``legitimacy, not force, is the only way to ensure European stability.'' Baker has publicly lent support to the general idea of German reunification without committing himself to any specific approach. He has stressed only that the country be in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and that it evolve in a peaceful, step-by-step way. His support for the Genscher plan, therefore, could be significant. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, with whom Baker will open four days of talks in Moscow on Wednesday night, has called for an international referendum, while expressing concern over ``the revival of sinister shadows of the past.'' Baker's visit to Prague coincided with a visit by East German premier Hans Modrow for talks with Czech premier Marian Calfa. There has been speculation, but no confirmation, that Baker and Modrow might meet. Modrow told reporters in a no-questions briefing that he ahd Calfa agreed that German reunification ``should only be completed in a process which respects and preserves the interests of neighbors and European states.'' Baker discussed the situation with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas during a refueling stop in Shannon, Ireland, and then flew here for talks with leaders of Czechoslovakia's ``Velvet Revolution.'' Baker met with Vaclav Havel, the dissident playwright who was elevated to the presidency with the disintegration of the Communist Party in December, and separately with Roman Catholic Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek and leaders of the Civic Forum, the pro-democracy group that toppled the hardliners. Baker told reporters that he had ``a very productive discussion'' with Havel about troop and weapon reductions in Europe and that it would be resumed when Havel visits Washington in two weeks. He announced a series of moves by the Bush administration to assist Czechoslovakia's economy, including the dismantling of U.S. trade barriers _ provided laws are enacted permitting free elections _ and support for Czechoslovakia's entry into the International Monetary Fund the U.S. Export-Import Bank. But he cautioned the Prague government that ``it is up to you to provide a conducive legal environment, to turn over or sell factories to private owners, and to lift the heavy hand of excessive government intervention.'' He brought an offer of technical advice to assist the country's adoption of a free market system and other capitalistic wrappings that are enticing American businesses. But he brought no aid. ``They do not want a handout,'' said a U.S. official who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Here, as elsewhere in Europe, attention is riveted on Germany and the future of American and Soviet troops. Havel has demanded the withdrawal of the estimated 75,000 Soviet soldiers in Czechoslovakia. His plans for disarmament could be an impetus for further U.S. cuts, beyond the 100,000 or so that would be withdrawn under President Bush's latest proposal. But a U.S. official said, ``There are many statements by Havel and others in Czechoslovakia who recognize an important U.S. role in political, economic and security terms.'' Baker and Dumas, in their 90-minute meeting in Ireland, ``both recognized that unification is moving ahead very quickly,'' the senior U.S. official said. ``They thought that all things considered that it's actually moving along in a pretty effective fashion.'' While the French foreign minister did not specifically endorse the Genscher plan, the official said, ``from the tone of it, it was very positive.'' Moreover, the official said, the 16-member NATO alliance is moving toward a consensus in support of the plan. Genscher discussed it with Baker at the State Department last Friday night, and it is bound to be a major item in the agenda for Baker's talks with Shevardnadze and with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``Genscher has come up with one proposal, and we think that the proposal in terms of not having NATO forces move further east is a pretty good one,'' the official said. Also, he stressed, it would keep the new and larger Germany in NATO, a move that is designed to reassure other European countries who have suffered in two devastating wars this century.

DOC.HEAD: Actor John Merivale, Companion of Vivien Leigh, Dies
DOC.TEXT: John Merivale, who played English gentlemen with stiff upper lips in such movies as ``A Night to Remember,'' ``King Rat'' and ``Arabesque'' in the 1950s and '60s, died Tuesday, his family said. He was 72. Merivale, who appeared on stage, film and television, died in his sleep in London's Charing Cross Hospital, his family said. Cause of death was pneumonia following a long illness resulting from renal failure, a hereditary illness that killed his actor father. Although not a leading man, Merivale was a dependable support player and an integral part of the entertainment world throughout his working life. Handsome, tall, courteous and charming, he was born into a theatrical family in Toronto. His father was actor Philip Merivale. His mother was actress Viva Birkett. His father later married actress Gladys Cooper. Merivale was educated at Rugby, a prestigious private school, and Oxford University. But his Oxford stay was cut short, partly because of his father's financial problems after an investment in a disastrous Shakespearean production. Merivale entered movies in 1933; his first role was a newspaper vendor. In 1938, he appeared on stage in London and met actress Vivien Leigh, future wife of actor Laurence Olivier. In 1940, Merivale appeared in a short-run New York production of Shakespeare's ``Romeo and Juliet'' produced and financed by her and Olivier. During World War II, Merivale served as a pilot in Britain's Royal Air Force and the Royal Canadian Air Force. Merivale made much of his early acting career in the United States. He appeared in Cecil Beaton's New York production of Oscar Wilde's ``Lady Windermere's Fan'' in 1946 and in Rex Harrison's New York production of ``Anne of a Thousand Days'' in 1948. He married actress Jan Sterling in 1941. Following their divorce in 1948, he returned to England, appearing in London stage comedies like ``The Reluctant Debutante'' while making a name for himself in movies. One of his best remembered movie roles was in ``A Night to Remember'' (1958), about the sinking of the Titanic in 1912. He played a husband who sees his family safely into the crowded lifeboats, then goes down with the liner. During the 1950s, while continuing with his stage and movie work, Merivale made a successful career in television, appearing in ``The Third Man'' series, ``The Gentle Goddess,'' ``The Verdict is Yours'' and other shows. Merivale and Vivien Leigh began a discreet affair following her separation from Olivier. She and Olivier were divorced in 1961 and she and Merivale lived together until her death in 1967. Miss Leigh and Merivale acted together in London and on a world tour in 1958 in the play ``Duel of Angels.'' They also appeared in John Gielgud's Broadway staging of ``Ivanov'' in 1965. In 1986, Merivale married his second wife, actress Dinah Sheridan, who survives him, together with stepchildren from his marriages.

DOC.HEAD: Brother Of New Haven Mayor Charged With Running Drug Factory
DOC.TEXT: A brother of this city's new mayor on Tuesday turned himself in to another brother who is a police detective on charges of operating a drug factory and other narcotics violations, officials said. Robert Daniels, 48, surrendered to his brother, Melvin, said Khalid Lum, Mayor John Daniels' spokesman. Lum said the mayor knew his brother had a drug problem and has tried to help him at various times, but said Robert Daniels apparently had even more problems than the family realized. The mayor was very saddened by the arrest, Lum said. ``He loves his brother very much.'' The mayor had been aware a warrant had been issued for his brother's arrest, the spokesman said. Daniels, who was being held on $50,000 bond at a city jail, was charged with operating a drug factory, possession of cocaine, possession with intent to sell cocaine, sale of narcotics and conspiracy to sell narcotics, police said. John Daniels, a state legislator, took office Jan. 1 with a pledge to step up the war on drugs in this coastal city best known as the home of Yale University. The mayor came out strongly in favor of a plan by Gov. William O'Neill to send state troopers into New Haven to help fight drug-related crime. The program, which was opposed by the local police union, got under way last month. Tuesday's arrest gives the mayor an added personal incentive ``to see this drug menace cleared from the streets,'' Lum said. The arrest resulted from a monthlong investigation of a house suspected of being a center of drug activity, said police Lt. James Sorrentino. Three people were arrested in a raid on the house last Thursday, and a warrant was issued for Robert Daniels' arrest, Sorrentino said. Two television stations reported the search turned up three ounces of cocaine. Lum said Robert Daniels had not been involved with his brother's political campaign but said he had no other biographical information about him.

This country is in the throes of the first known epidemic of childhood AIDS caused by contaminated blood and the constant reuse of needles, a French humanitarian organization says. Dr. Jacques Lebas, president of the Paris-based Doctors of the World, on Monday urged the international health community to provide Romania with disposable needles and blood-screening equipment. ``We know AIDS from people who take drugs, homosexuals, and heterosexuals in Africa, but for the first time in the history of AIDS, we are confronted with childhood AIDS,'' he said. ``It's an epidemic,'' he said. ``It's on the level of famine. It's an international emergency.''

The state's first female attorney general went on the offensive and sued the federal government over its order that Virginia Military Institute accept women. State Attorney General Mary Sue Terry filed the lawsuit in U.S. District Court in Roanoke on Monday less than an hour after the institute voted to uphold its men-only admission policy. The lawsuit asks the court to declare the policy constitutional at the 150-year-old tax-supported school in Lexington. Terry named U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and the Justice Department as defendants in the lawsuit, which came a week after the department threatened to sue the state over the admissions policy.

The Archdiocese of Washington says it will excommunicate any Catholics who join Rev. George A. Stallings Jr.'s breakaway African-American Catholic Congregation. The archdiocese announced Monday that Stallings and his followers had been excommunicated over Stallings' public break from the Roman Catholic Church. ``By his public declaration that he has separated himself from the church and by his renunciation of church teaching, Father Stallings has excommunicated himself,'' the archdiocese said in a statement by Vicar General William Kane. ``Any Catholic who would knowingly and willingly renounce his or her Catholic faith to become a full and active member of Father Stallings's congregation would also incur automatic excommunication,'' the statement said.

The Board of Education voted to place all district schools on a year-round schedule by July 1991 to ease overcrowding. In a divisive session that lasted more than four hours, the board voted 4-3 Monday to adopt most of a Los Angeles Unified School District plan. The plan requires all public schools currently on traditional schedules to submit plans for year-round classes in time for the 1991-92 school year. Nearly 100 schools already follow year-round schedules.
