DOC.HEAD: Passions Mount in Soviet Moldavia for Reunion with Romania
DOC.TEXT: The republic of Moldavia secedes from the Soviet Union and becomes part of neighboring Romania? For a growing number of native Moldavians it would be going home _ Moldavia was Romanian until Stalin seized it 50 years ago. ``There's nothing unnatural in our people's desire to reunify,'' said Leonida Lari, a poet who represents Moldavia in the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow. ``We are as Romanian as those living across the border.'' Romania's revolution against Nicolae Ceausescu has awakened a passion among native Moldavians for reunification and it has grown so intense that even the republic's leaders may find it difficult to control. Leaders on both sides of the Prut River border, mindful of the dangers for Romania as it rebuilds and the Soviet Union as it lurches from one ethnic crisis to another, say the future relationship between Romania and the territory Josef Stalin attached to his empire in 1940 need not be decided now. But the first calls of ``Unire'' (unity) echoed through this Moldavian capital at the start of the Romanian revolt in December. Moldavians speak a nearly identical language as Romanians and admire the same cultural heroes. But during their history, they often have been separated. Before the breakup of czarist Russia in 1917, Moldavia was the Russian province of Bessarabia. Many Russians, Ukrainians and Jews have lived in Moldavia for generations. Inspired by the Romanian revolution, thousands of Moldavians took to the streets in a show of support for the anti-Ceausescu forces. Some young people offered to cross the border to join the battle. The republic's government, as well as the Moldavian People's Front movement, sent medicine and food. The People's Front already had been pressing demands on Moscow for greater autonomy. It won a battle to establish Moldavian as the official language of the republic and returned to the Latin alphabet used by Romanians, dropping the Cyrillic letters imposed under Stalin. The People's Front has drawn thousands into the streets of Kishinev for rallies, and even its opponents acknowledge it is likely to sweep local elections this spring. In the wake of the revolution, People's Front leaders still treat the issue of reunification cautiously, mindful of dangers for themselves as well as for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms. ``Today we are not putting the issue of reunification among the urgent tasks,'' said Nicolae Kostin, the 53-year-old chairman of the group's executive committee. ``We will not attempt any steps in this direction without analyzing carefully how that may backfire against Gorbachev and his policy of perestroika.'' Ms. Lari said in an interview that she worries a determined push for reunification with Romania could lead to military intervention or even a coup against Gorbachev. For now, People's Front leaders say they would be satisfied with what they call a ``Brandenburg variant,'' which envisions broader contacts across the border without full reunification. Berlin's Brandenburg Gate, after which the variant is named, became a symbol of the division between East and West Germany and was recently reopened to traffic and travelers. But that course may not satisfy Moldavians who are the most intense about reunification and are disgruntled with the Soviet system. A 19-year-old student who identified herself only as Tanya said reunification with Romania now offers Moldavians a chance to escape communism. ``We are sick and tired with the way we have to live only because some half-literate leader `Can't let down the ideals of socialism' _ and we all have to suffer for it. Secession is the only chance for us to live properly and enjoy life while it is not too late, while we are still young.'' ``We have been lied to for 72 years,'' said Valentin Barda, a 40-year-old printer. ``Now it's time we went our separate ways. We will go to any length to achieve reunification.'' The People's Front president, Ion Hadirka, said that after the Romanian revolution, some members of organization broke away and formed the Stephan Chel Mare society. Named for Stephan the Great, the 15th century Romanian king whose statue stands in a Kishinev park, it calls for the question of reunification to be decided immediately. And there are other indications the People's Front has little control over more radical elements pressing for reunification. In November, demonstrators climbed on Soviet tanks to halt the traditional Revolution Day military parade and attacked the Interior Ministry headquarters with gasoline bombs, stones and iron rods. Many of them refused to listen to People's Front leaders who appealed for calm. Protesters calling for Russians to leave the republic of 4.2 million people and chanting ``Long live Greater Romania'' now share the streets with reinforced police patrols. Vladimir Solonar, an ethnic Ukrainian leader of the Unity movement formed to protect the rights of the 1 million Russians, Ukrainians and other minorities in Moldavia, said he fears the People's Front might be too disorganized to control the situation. The new Moldavian Communist Party chief, Pyotr Luchinsky, told the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda that ethnic tension is his biggest worry. Demands for reunification were primarily an emotional reaction to the Romanian revolution, he said. He added that the ``absolute majority of residents of the republic are not for union with Romania but for more intensive contacts with our neighbor.'' Mikhail S. Platon, a deputy premier of Moldavia, said, ``We would like to raise the issue in such a way that people could travel (to Romania) by car or by bus, to go to the theater, to meet each other freely.'' But if reunification comes, Nina Tsurcanu, an ethnic Russian with a husband and 3-year-old son, says she won't be part of it, even it means breaking up the family. ``My husband is Moldavian,'' she explained. ``I love him, but if he decides to stay here after they secede, I will leave no matter what. I will go away with my son and parents. ... ``They call us occupants and oppressors. My parents came here after the war to help restore the ruined industry. Do we deserve all this now?'' As young people marched recently in Kishinev with Romanian flags and shouts of ``Russians, go away! Long live Greater Romania,'' a lanky Russian youth of 14 named Alex wondered about his future. He said that his Moldavian friends no longer have anything to do with him and that his parents are thinking of moving to the industrial city of Chelyabinsk in the Ural Mountains, where they have relatives. ``I wonder if there are some native people there, too, who don't want Russians,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: `Men Don't Leave,' `Mountains of the Moon'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Men Don't Leave'' opened in New York and Los Angeles on Feb. 2, wide later; ``Mountains of the Moon'' opens in limited release Feb. 23, expanding to additional cities March 9.
DOC.TEXT:
``Men Don't Leave''
Beth Macauley wanders catatonically through the basement web of a Maryland hospital, trying to find the morgue so she can check the remains of her dead husband. She throws open a door and happens upon a bevy of chefs chopping up raw chickens, and collapses into uncontrollable sobs. It is this quirky blend of the ordinary, the extraordinary, the absurd and the surreal that makes Paul Brickman's ``Men Don't Leave'' more than just another soapy look at a family tragedy. Jessica Lange continues to fascinate with her range of emotions and faces. As Beth, she reverts to an unexceptional housewife and mother, whose entire existence is focused on her family. When left with a bundle of bills after her husband dies in an explosion, an enraged teen-age son and a younger, more introverted son, she copes by leaving comfortable suburbia for the rough and crowded confines of Baltimore's inner city. She finds work as an ``assistant manager'' (a gofer, really) for a shrill neurotic who runs a gourmet food store, and meets the understanding ``sensitive man.'' Her youngest son, Matt (Charlie Korsmo), takes up with a middle-class juvenile delinquent, and her oldest son, Chris (Chris O'Donnell), finds love in the arms of an all-knowing, all-seeing, amazon of an older woman, Jody (Joan Cusack). Brickman takes us, in fits and starts, through the inevitable mother-son fights and confrontations, bouts of depression, lessons in friendship, loyalty and trust. In the end, it all works out: Beth learns acceptance and believes in herself. But the package is not as neat as it sounds. Beth's journey is all too episodic, like a made-for-television movie. And there are too many cute pieces of business, such as when she delivers a basket of lunch to a rehearsing orchestra and drops oranges along the way and finally the entire basket. Brickman seems to see middle-class America through barbed wire glasses and he takes marvelous risks. In ``Risky Business,'' he gave us an aspiring college student who earned money by turning his parents' house into a brothel. It was funny and it worked. In ``Men Don't Leave,'' Mrs. Average Upstanding Housewife learns to like her child's lover, a woman close to her own age. Cusack is a delight as the ``older woman.'' She steals the scene the minute she appears, commanding presence that she is with her measured tone and wide-eyed wonder. The yougsters are fine without being cloying. Corey Carrier, as the juvenile thug Winston Buckley, is carved from the same mold that coughed up the Little Rascals decades ago. He's bad, but he's cute. Brickman directed from a screenplay written by himself and Barbara Benedek. The story was by Benedek. The Brickman-Jon Avnet Production is released by the Geffen Company and is rated PG-13. _ By Dolores Barclay, AP Arts Editor.

``Mountains of the Moon''
When ``Lawrence of Arabia'' was re-released last year in all its big-screen, uncut glory, the cry went up: ``Why don't they make movies like this anymore?'' Answer: They do. ``Mountains of the Moon'' has all the excitement, adventure and human conflict of ``Lawrence of Arabia.'' While the Carolco production may lack the polish that perfectionist David Lean gave to his 1962 classic, ``Mountains'' is still first-rate movie storytelling. The discovery of the source of the Nile in the mid-19th century was as clouded in controversy as the journey to the North Pole a half-century later. The contenders: Richard Burton, the larger-than-life Irish adventurer-author-scientist; and John Speke, an English army officer from an aristocratic family. Director Bob Rafelson and William Harrison based the script on Harrison's biographical novel about the two explorers as well as their original journals. What emerges is a complex tale of two men of widely divergent backgrounds who become brothers on their perilous journey. The African adventure is magnificently portrayed, and it is bookended by episodes in England that are less engaging. The first part delineates the characters of Burton (Patrick Bergin), a dashing, adventurous figure who wins the heart of a strong-willed English lady (Fiona Shaw); and Speke (Iain Glen), a blond, blue-blooded young man who comes under the sinister influence of a homosexual publisher (Richard E. Grant). The final part of the film concerns the aftermath of the exploration, as the two comrades are torn apart by misunderstanding and dispute over which one should be honored by the National Geographic Society. Rafelson conveys the complicated story with admirable concision. Despite the cost, some big scenes last only a few seconds, just long enough to establish needed story points. Known mostly for intimate films such as ``Five Easy Pieces'' and ``Stay Hungry,'' Rafelson displays a rare talent for the epic. His battle scenes are extraordinary. Bergin captures all the brusque authority and zest for life of Burton. In the less showy role as Speke, Glen is equally impressive. Fiona Shaw is wise, knowing and sensual as Mrs. Burton. The Tri-Star release was produced by Daniel Melnick and bears an R rating, presumably for brief nudity and considerable violence. Running time: 135 minutes. _ By Bob Thomas, Associated Press Writer.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
Ave Verum Corpus: Motets and Anthems by William Byrd (Collegium) _ The Cambridge Singers, directed by John Rutter. Peter Philips: Paradisus Sacris Cantionibus (Accent) _ Currende, directed by Erik Van Nevel.
It is a comfort to have a recording at last of William Byrd's ``Non vos relinquam orphanos'' (``I will not leave you comfortless''). Not even two minutes long, the motet is a little masterpiece of Elizabethan music. Byrd combines a powerful feeling of sadness at parting with a quietly affirmative ``alleluia.'' Though he enjoyed the patronage of the Protestant Queen Elizabeth I, Byrd clung to his Roman Catholic faith _ a devotion that cost others their lives. ``Non vos relinquam,'' like most of his later work, was written for Catholic services held in homes and probably sung by musical amateurs. The Cambridge Singers, all adults, never approach the grandeur of a cathedral choir of men and boys. However, with 71 minutes of music and excellent notes, it's an exemplary addition to the small but growing number of Byrd recordings. Peter Philips was also an English Catholic and may have been Byrd's pupil before fleeing to the Low Countries, but he belonged to another world. ``Ecce vicit leo'' (``Behold the lion''), the first of the 22 motets presented by the Belgian choir Currende, sounds very like Giovanni Gabrieli's double-choir compositions for St. Mark's Cathedral in Venice. The feeling is confident, extravagant, in contrast to Byrd's restraint. Philips has been sorely neglected in recordings, and this generous, polished recording is a solid beginning. _ By Robert Barr, Associated Press Writer.

``Evidence'' (Chrysalis) _ Boo Hewerdine and Darden Smith
This is a serendipitous musical meeting that almost makes the Traveling Wilburys seem calculated by comparison. Boo Hewerdine fronts an obscure British band called the Bible. Darden Smith is a struggling Texas singer-songwriter. In New York City for the 1988 New Music Seminar, they were introduced by a mutual friend, hit it off and began writing songs together. It took just eight days to write a terrific album's worth of songs. ``Evidence'' exudes good feeling. This is folk-rock with a smile, music with the spark of inspiration close to the surface. ``Out of This World'' vividly evokes the walking-on-air feeling of new love, and does it with such simplicity that nursery rhymes are quoted for lyrics. On ``Reminds Me a Little of You,'' a listener can practically feel the presence of the woman for whom the narrator is pining. Like so many albums today, the acoustic guitar is the musical centerpiece, with other instruments added for dashes of colors. Call it the Tracy Chapman Effect. It allows the artists to sink or swim solely on the strength of their songs. Of the 12 songs on this record (a lucky 13 on CD), there's not a weak cut. ``I want my cake mixed in with my pie,'' Hewerdine and Smith sing on the slightly absurd ``All I Want (Is Everything).'' Here's hoping they get their wish. _ By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer.

``Human Soul'' (RCA) _ Graham Parker
Graham Parker is one of those artists the critics love but most of the public has never heard. He's too intelligent and quirky for Top 40 and AOR stations, and not quite radical enough for many college stations. That's where home stereos come in. ``Human Soul,'' Parker's 12th LP, will tickle your tape deck, rev up your record player. He continues in the bright pop rock groove of his last album, ``The Mona Lisa's Sister,'' but here he quickens the pace on many tracks and cranks up his colorful imagination. ``Little Miss Understanding'' kicks it off with danceable, ska-inflected sounds and typical wordplay: ``You're a woman with a crazy man, Like a wasp that's stuck in jam, But I won't sting you if you don't sting me.'' After a few ballads and pop songs, Parker closes out the ``Real Side'' _ or Side 1 _ with ``Soultime.'' The ska sound comes back bigger _ with horns reminiscent of The Specials _ and blends with a reggae-ified beat (something he's dabbled in on other albums). But the real action is on the ``Surreal Side'' _ or Side 2. ``Everything Goes'' starts off a suite of five continuous songs that are faster and darker than those on the flip side. ``Everything'' showcases Parker's unusual talent for combining heavy lyrics with lighthearted, punchy melodies. To a sweet tune, he sings about a serial killer and more mundane horrors. He jumps right into the hyped-up ``Sugar Gives You Energy,'' then a sardonic tale of suburbia, ``Daddy's a Postman'' and ``Green Monkeys,'' a cryptic doodling about AIDS. The suite closes out with ``I Was Wrong,'' where the music stops cold, sucked right out of existence. On the last cut, ``Slash and Burn,'' he bites hard, but he still offers a head-bobbing beat. Parker gets more urgent with this LP than he did on his last record or in his mellower ``Another Grey Area'' period around 1982. The world could end dead in its tracks, just as this record does, he suggests. But not if Parker can help it. _ By Giselle Price, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
On Show: Museum and Gallery Shows and Exhibits
DOC.TEXT: John Marin is an artist who helped give credibility to watercolor, and remove it as the stepchild of oil. Through his landscapes, treescapes, cityscapes and seascapes of New York, Maine and New Mexico, he demonstrated a brilliant use of color and form, running shapes and lines into ideas and form. For 40 years, Marin contributed to modern art. A retrospective of his work is now at the National Gallery of Art in Washington through April 15. There are close to 150 works in ``Selections and Transformations: The Art of John Marin,'' including watercolors and oil paintings. Marin was born in Rutherford, N.J., in 1870. He died in 1953. Two of his finest watercolors are ``Wave on Rock'' (1937), and ``Related to Brooklyn Bridge'' (1928). In Boston, the Museum of Fine Arts has opened ``Monet in the '90s: The Series Paintings.'' Monet, the leading French Impressionist, is known to have done 218 ``series'' paintings, all but 12 during the 1890s when he was in his 50s. He chose 16 subjects, some for their historical or cultural significance. Among the works were 30 paintings each of grain stacks and the Rouen Cathedral, 24 paintings of poplars, and 18 of the Japanese bridge over his waterlily garden at Giverny. There are 86 in the exhibition, more than twice the number Monet ever showed at one time. The works are on loan from all over the world, including Leningrad, Paris, Tokyo and Boston. The show runs through April 29 before going to the Art Institute of Chicago from May 19 through Aug. 12, and at the Royal Academy in London from Sept. 7 through Dec. 9. Here is a list of exhibits and shows in some American museums and galleries:
Minneapolis Institute of Arts: ``Impressionism: Selections From Five American Museums.'' Through March 25.
Virginia Museum of Fine Arts: ``American Painting From a Century of Collecting: The Maier Museum of Art, Randolph-Macon Woman's College.'' Through March 4.

Seattle Art Museum: ``Preserving an Architectural Heritage,'' Frank Lloyd Wright's furnishings and decorative designs. Through Feb. 25. ``Documents Northwest,'' the early residential works of Robert Reichert and Mark Millett. Through March 11.
Toledo Museum of Art: ``Baroque: Splendor and Drama, 1600-1750.'' Through March 18.
Bergen Museum of Art and Science: Work of Greg Wyatt, fantasy-realist sculptor. Through March 25.
National Museum of African Art: ``Icons: Ideals and Power in the Art of Africa.'' Through Sept. 3.
Whitney Museum of American Art, Fairfield County: ``The Eighties in Review: Selections From the Permanent Collection of the Whitney Museum of American Art.'' Through Feb. 28.

Metropolitan Museum of Art: ``American Paintings From the Manoogian Collection.'' Through Feb. 25.
Philippe Staib Gallery: Bronze works by Mihail. Through Feb. 24.
American Craft Museum: ``Fragile Blossoms, Enduring Earth: The Japanese Influence on American Ceramics.'' Through March 25.
International Center of Photography: ``Henry Peach Robinson: Master of Photographic Art 1830-1901.'' Through Feb. 25. ``Douglas Kirkland's Light Years: Three Decades Photographing Among the Stars.'' Through Feb. 25.
Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum: Works of Jenny Holzer, including an electronic display signboard. Through Feb. 11.
Cooper-Hewitt Museum: ``The Intimate World of Alexander Calder.'' Through March 11.
Whitney Museum of American Art: Thomas Hart Benton retrospective. Through Jan. 31. ``Image World: Art and Media Culture.'' Through Feb. 18.
Spanierman Gallery: ``Views of the Cape Ann Shore: American Artists at Gloucester and Rockport, 1880-1940.'' Through March 3.
Washburn Gallery: ``Arco Fair, Madrid.'' Feb. 8-13.
Marisa del Re Gallery: Arman, ``Dirty Paintings.'' March 1-March 31.

Phoenix Art Museum: ``Napoleon the Great: Selections From the David Markham Collection.'' Through March 25. ``Frank Lloyd Wright Drawings: Masterworks From the Frank Lloyd Wright Archives.'' Through April 8. ``Fashion 1910-1920.'' Through April 15. Japanese art from the museum's permanent collection. Feb. 10-May 13.
Heard Museum: ``Fourth Biennial Native American Fine Arts Invitational,'' showcasing eight Indian artists from the United States and Canada. Through spring.
Dallas Museum of Art: ``American Art, 1700 to 1950.'' Through April 8.

Amon Carter Museum: ``American Prints: Recent Acquisitions.'' Through Feb. 18. ``Robert Adams: To Make It Home: Photographs of the American West.'' Through March 18.
Kimbell Art Museum: ``Imperial Taste: Chinese Ceramics From the Percival David Foundation.'' Through March 18. ``Expressionism and Modern German Painting From the Thyssen-Boirnemisza Collection,'' a collection of 34 modern German paintings from the collection formed by Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza, including works by 19 artists whose major paintings are rare in this country, including Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Emil Nolde, Paul Klee, Erich Heckel and Franz Marc. Through March 25.
Mesa Southwest Museum: ``The Train Show: 100 Years of Model Railroading.'' Through Feb. 25.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: ``Enemies, a Love Story'' _ a Victory for All Concerned
DOC.TEXT: If fate had taken a different turn, Ron Silver would now be teaching school or working for the State Department instead of starring in a leading contender for Academy Awards. In the much-acclaimed ``Enemies, a Love Story,'' the New York actor plays Herman Broder, a concentration camp refugee who finds himself with three wives: Margaret Sophie Stein, the peasant who saved him from the Nazis; Lena Olin, his tempestuous lover; and Anjelica Huston, who had been presumed killed in the war. Paul Mazursky based his film on the Isaac Bashevis Singer novel, and it's being treated gently by 20th Century Fox. The release pattern has been slow, the studio hoping that critical raves and favorable word-of-mouth will attract audiences to such a special kind of movie. Whether ``Enemies'' wins Oscars and box-office returns, Silver believes the film is a victory for all concerned, proving a quality film with literary elements can get made in Hollywood. Silver's roots are as deeply Jewish as Herman Broder's. His maternal grandparents came from Poland to New York's Lower East Side, where Silver grew up. Fascinated with foreign cultures, he gained a bachelor's degree in Chinese and Spanish at the State University of New York at Buffalo, and a master's at St. John's University in New York and at the Taiwan College of Culture. ``I dwindled into acting,'' he remarked. First came high school teaching: ``I thought I was a good teacher. I cared about what I was teaching. I wanted to reach the kids, and I wanted to make it entertaining. I wanted them to see what they were learning had application to their lives. I'm disappointed that when I left the school, they all didn't stand on their desks and say, `O, Captain, my Captain' (as in `Dead Poets Society').'' Silver quit to continue his travels abroad for his advanced degree. In 1968-69 he studied in Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Taiwan, India and Hong Kong. He was caught in the middle of the China-Soviet border conflict, crossed the Soviet Union on the trans-Siberian railroad, and was arrested in Leningrad. ``When I got back, I decided not to complete my Ph.D. and not to go into the government, which I was supposed to do,'' he said. ``I drifted for a while, took acting classes, was a social worker. I enjoyed the acting classes, and I received a lot of encouragement from my early teachers. I was involved in academia for the longest time, and this was kind of fun _ to go home with a blonde and rehearse a scene. ``I got lucky right away, found an agent and started getting jobs. I don't know how tenacious I would have been if I had to stick it through. (Acting) was not a life-long passion with me.'' Silver has led a busy career in films (``Garbo Talks,'' ``Silkwood''), theater (``Hurlyburly,'' ``Speed the Plow'') and television ``The Billionaire Boys Club,'' ``Wise Guy''). He admits he was not Mazursky's first choice for ``Enemies, a Love Story.'' ``Nor was I the second choice,'' he said with a laugh. ``It makes sense, artistically and businesswise to go with somebody who has a name. I don't know who was approached, but I can guess: Dustin Hoffman and Richard Dreyfuss. For one reason or another, it didn't work out.'' He responded immediately to Mazursky's proposal, not only because he believed in the material. ``Also it was a challenge for me,'' he said, ``because it was different from roles I had been doing, which were fairly exuberant, aggressive, articulate, expressive people. This guy was just the opposite.'' Silver sees one element favoring the movie's Oscar chances: ``It always seems to happen with pictures that take a long time to get made, where there is little compromising with the integrity of the picture. `Rain Man' had a tough time being made (also `Platoon' and `Ghandi'). It was a real labor of love for the director, and a lot of studios turned it down.'' ``Enemies'' was first developed by Mazursky at Touchstone Pictures, which had a winner with his ``Down and Out in Beverly Hills.'' The Disney people finally decided against proceeding, and the film ended up with the independent Morgan Creek. Fox is the releasing company. Silver admits he would love to see ``Enemies,'' and incidentally himself, receive Academy honors. The reason for the allure of Oscar? ``This country likes winners. They treat winners very specially,'' he said, laughing. ``The president refers to `the winning team.' He doesn't talk about `the losing team.' He doesn't say, `Hey, listen, you guys had a tremendous amount of character _ who cares who won?' This country is about winning.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Artists Struggle to Preserve Afghan Culture
DOC.TEXT: Ashraf Anjoorgar leans closer to his makeshift canvas to dab a more wishful shade of blue at the sky above the Minaret of Jam. His painting shows the 900-year-old monument in central Ghor province as it looked before the damage and neglect wrought by more than a decade of Afghanistan's civil war. Ashraf works by light that filters through sand-bagged windows at Kabul University's fine arts building. There is no heat or electricity. ``A lot of our most talented artists have left because of the war,'' he said with the help of an interpreter. ``There are many young artists who want to learn but there is a shortage of materials to teach them.'' He made his canvas by stretching a piece of bed linen over a wooden frame. There aren't enough brushes, paints or materials such as gypsum and marble for sculpture. Ashraf is an instructor and has joined about 3,000 Afghan painters, sculptors, musicians, dramatists, cinematographers and architects in trying to preserve their embattled country's ancient art and cultural traditions. Mohammad Haider Pardes, an architect and president of the Union of Artists' Associations of Afghanistan, says many of his members can earn a living only by lending their talents to the Moscow-backed government. The art gallery at Kabul University, alma mater of Afghanistan President Najib and his archrival, fundamentalist rebel leader Gulbaddin Hekmatyar, is a collage of pastoral landscapes, depictions of archeological treasures, portraits, sculptures and posters. Most have mundane motifs but the posters, especially, bear the hard lines of a political exhortation to defend the homeland against U.S.-backed Moslem rebels. They have fought for 11 years to topple the ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan and replace it with an all-Islamic government. ``Some of our artists work for the government some of the time, but otherwise they're free to (create) whatever they want,'' Pardes said. ``Very few of our artists have formal training. We've been sending them to the Soviet Union, India and East European countries,'' he said. ``We are interested in preserving our cultural heritage, but we are also trying to introduce our culture to others. This (training program) helps us do both.'' Pardes admitted, however, that the fall of several communist governments in Eastern Europe has disrupted the program. The army has, too. All Afghan men must serve at least once. The fine arts faculty at Kabul are required to put in two years. Their 300 students can look forward to four after graduation if the stalemated war lasts. Faculty members also must join the ruling party, Pardes said, but not the students, most of whom are the children of party members. He said that other talented Afghans either have been killed, pressed into government service or fled the country among more than 5 million refugees. One of the country's most renowned young painters works as a construction engineer. Pardes' union office is carpeted and plush. But as an architect, he designs public housing blocks, mosques and parks for which there is no money to build. Like many of Kabul's 2 million people, he hopes this year will bring some kind of peace to Afghanistan. ``We're trying to preserve our heritage. Many of our finest monuments have been destroyed. I think people don't have more patience with this bloody situation,'' he said. More than 1.5 million Afghans _ a tenth of the country's pre-war population _ are believed to have died since the 1978 Marxist coup that installed the ruling PDPA and touched off the insurgency. Soviet forces fought alongside the government for nine years but withdrew last February.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Don't Take Talent for Granted
DOC.TEXT: Phil Collins writes his album titles last, to reflect the the mood of the music on the album. His new album is ``... But Seriously.'' The first single, ``Another Day in Paradise,'' is about the homeless. There also are songs about famine and apartheid. In a recent interview, Collins recalled his last solo album, ``No Jacket Required'' in 1985. ``Apart from the little story of a Chicago hotel that wouldn't let me into the bar because I wasn't wearing a jacket, I thought the album was hotter, more danceable material than my previous two,'' he said. ``I wanted to do something now that had a little bit more depth to it, for a variety of reasons.'' One is that it follows Collins' acting and songs in the movie ``Buster,'' a film about the Great Train Robbery. ``Not a light subject, but the way the film treated that subject it was kind of a romantic comedy,'' he said. ``That was fine because it was an acting role. When I got involved with the music, I think the results to the casual person in the street were maybe a little light. ``I was working with Lamont Dozier, a hero of mine, and it was a film project. It didn't bother me `A Groovy Kind of Love' was a '60s song. I think a lot of people thought it was a Phil Collins solo project and felt I was getting very, very light. That wasn't where I was coming from. ``I thought, `Let me put that right with my next album.' That was one of the reasons the content of some songs was a little different for me.'' Most of the album reflects romantic and other individual concerns. ``I think they're my best collection of songs since `Face Value,''' he said. That was his first solo album, in 1981, followed a year later by ``Hello I Must Be Going!'' ``After all I've done, it is nice to know the best is still yet to come, really,'' Collins said. ``The album was great fun to write. Not having done it for five years, many of them came easily. There was a lot to come out.'' He'll tour until September. ``I'd like to do another film the end of 1990. We've got to do a Genesis album the beginning of 1991. I don't want to get involved with a big tour again so soon after the solo tour. ``By that time I'll be almost 40. I'd like to do another album, maybe; I'd like to concentrate on films. I think we'll tour with Genesis, because it's part of what we do. It won't be, if I can help it, anywhere near as long as Genesis' last tour, which was 10 months. ``The gigs become the most important part of the day; everything else tends to be very boring, one hotel after another, one plane after another. I never get bored with the gigs. They're always different. I can hea people say, `He's bored with first-class hotels?' It does get boring. I'd rather be at home doing the shopping.'' Speaking of boredom, Collins said, ``There is always a risk that people get bored with Phil Collins. That reached a peak in 1985-86 when we had five Top 5 singles with `No Jacket Required,' and Genesis' `Invisible Touch' had five Top 5. The voice was constantly on the radio. There was a severe danger of overkill, which is why I took a year away from music and did `Buster.' ``People still played the records on the radio,'' he said. ``The thing that sticks in my mind is a guitar player said Milwaukee had a guaranteed Phil Collins-free weekend. When radio stations guarantee not to play you, you know you're in trouble. ``I don't want to not work because people play the records too much.'' Some of ``... But Seriously'' was recorded in Los Angeles. David Crosby, who sings on ``Another Day in Paradise,'' and horn players Collins wanted to use live there. Jill Collins is from Los Angeles. Their daughter, Lily, 10 months, will go on the 1990 tour and his older children, a daughter 17 and son 13, will join them in Australia on their spring break. While recording, Collins said there are technical things that can thicken the voice, such as echoes. ``They're security blankets some singers use to mask inadequacies,'' he said. ``I was guilty of that. My voice became a bit of a sound rather than just the voice. I think my singing has gotten better over the last few years. I expose it more on this album; I use less effects.'' Since ``Buster,'' which came out in late 1988, Collins produced three songs on Stephen Bishop's album and played on ``Woman in Chains,'' Tears for Fears' current single. ``Eric Clapton, who is one of my best friends, was making his album around the same time I did my album. He played on mine; I played on his,'' Collins said. He didn't expect his success, and it has always surprised him. ``If you take things for granted, that's when the trouble starts. ``People say, `Why is it what you do appeals to other people?' I have no idea. If I knew, then I'd probably screw it up,'' he said. ``Maybe I write lyrics that are very direct. People understand them and relate to them. Maybe that's why what happens happens. Apart from that, you do it to please yourself first. If other people like it, that's great.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Psychedelic Pioneer Values Family Most
DOC.TEXT: Under the living room carpet in the converted barn author Ken Kesey calls home is a wrestling mat that has cushioned roughhousing with his four children and is a touchstone for the life he leads on his farm. ``I've always been very tight with my family,'' said Kesey, who saw both his sons follow in his footsteps as wrestlers for the University of Oregon. ``It's always been the most important thing in my life.'' Kesey has lived on this farm since 1965, after his novels, ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' and ``Sometimes a Great Notion,'' won him literary fame. His father and brother both owned it before him. ``When I was working on `Sometimes a Great Notion,' one of the reasons I could do it was because I was unknown,'' he said. ``I could get all those balls in the air and keep them up there and nothing would come along and distract me. Now there's a lot of stuff happens that happens because I'm famous. And famous isn't good for a writer. You don't observe well when you're being observed.'' Many of the outbuildings on the farm were built by the Merry Pranksters he led in the psychedelic bus trip across America chronicled by Tom Wolfe in ``The Electric Kool-aid Acid Test.'' The bus, called Further, is parked out back. ``Everybody in my family knows what I've done. I've smoked dope and would still be smoking dope if I could get some,'' Kesey said. ``I know enough about drugs ... to know that you can't really be a good family person and take certain types of drugs. They turn you into yourself. Cocaine and the opiates. Any of the barbiturates. Booze. Those harm your family. ``But the real psychedelics, they increase your awareness of the spiritual forces around you, which I think increases your love. I don't know anybody who ever had family problems because of smoking marijuana. They may have had financial problems because they're too lazy to get up and go to work, but they always like to hang around and play with the kids and the dogs, be in the kitchen.'' Kesey got his first taste of LSD in the early 1960s in government-run experiments in Menlo Park, Calif., where he also was studying writing under Wallace Stegner at Stanford University. His first novel, ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' was published in 1962. ``I felt like I was doing as American a thing as Neil Armstrong when he volunteered to go to the moon,'' Kesey said of the drug experiments. ``There was a new place to be explored and we were astronauts. ``That exploration of new territory is a very American thing. Say you're doing cocaine, that is not exploration of new territory. That's just a titillation.'' Most recently, Kesey has been giving performances of ``Tricker the Squirrel Meets Big Double the Bear,'' a story told by his grandmother and set to music by a neighbor, Art Maddox. He figures that videotapes of writers reading their works into the camera's eye, interspersed with actors presenting scenes, will take the place of books. His son, Zane, has done a ``Tricker'' piece that cuts between Kesey with the orchestra, and Kesey lip-syncing in the swamp behind his home. ``It will take over for about 50 or 70 years and then all that machinery will fall apart and we'll be back to the printed word,'' Kesey said. Kesey has taken a lot of heat for not producing another novel to put beside the first two, but he is halfway through one now and under contract to finish it this year. ``There's a saying from (William) Faulkner, who said every so often the dog has to go against the bear just to keep calling himself a dog. The novel is the real bear.'' Called ``Sailor's Song,'' the book is set in a fishing village on the coast of southeastern Alaska a little bit in the future, when things are bleaker and more hedonistic than they are now. ``I think it's about love at the end of the world,'' Kesey says. ``Can you love when you know things are coming to an end?'' The main characters are an Indian woman and a crop-duster who moves to town from Fresno, Calif., after the death of his child. Before leaving California, he loads his plane from a truck that pumps out portable toilets and sprays the state fair. When not working on the novel, Kesey is involved with his wife, Faye, who was his high school sweetheart, and their children, Shannon, Zane, Jed and Sunshine, who all grew up on the farm. Jed was buried here after his death in 1984, in the crash of a van carrying the University of Oregon wrestling team to Pullman, Wash. ``I learned something from Jed's death, which is how badly it hurts and that if I were to die, it would hurt other people, and I don't want to hurt other people,'' Kesey said. ``I button my seat belt and wear my life jacket. I used to think it's my life, I can do with it what I want. But it's not just my life.'' Recently, he and Zane planted some trees along the property line. At 54, Kesey doesn't expect to see the trees reach maturity, but feels they are part of the chain that is family. Kesey has a granddaughter, Katherine Grace, born to Shannon shortly after New Year's Day, and he is angered that many Americans doom their progeny by despoiling the environment. ``It used to be that old people, instead of spending their money at the end of their life, would be passing that money on to their children and grandchildren,'' Kesey said. ``But now, we've been taught to go ahead and waste it, fill the sky with poison _ we're not going to be here anyway. ``I have vowed not to do that. This piece of land won't move out of this family. Once you bury a kid on your land, it would take a bulldozer and a large government to move you.'' Kesey recalled how several years ago, a busload of people stopped by on their way from California to Kansas and asked Kesey to come along. ``They all had a vision that the whole West Coast was going to fall in the ocean and they were all moving to Kansas,'' Kesey said. ``They were the messiest bunch. When they finished with a can they just threw it. People's clothes were dirty. Their hair was uncut. They were angry with us for not joining them. ``They were sitting there and Faye got up and came back with a big knife and saw. I said, `Where are you going?' She said, `I'm going to go prune the fruit trees.' ``That's my feeling. Even if it is going to fall into the ocean, you still have got to prune the fruit trees and wash the dishes and take care of the daily chores of keeping the world running.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
A Glorious Trick
With BC-WKD--Kesey, b0843
DOC.TEXT: Ken Kesey took 12 writers from the University of Oregon master of fine arts program into his house, then showed them the tricks of writing a novel by having them produce one. Like many first efforts, this one started awkwardly, with Kesey knocking himself cold on a window frame trying to break into the house he uses in Eugene because he forgot the key. But the ending was a happy one. Viking Penguin bought the manuscript and in January released ``Caverns,'' by O.U. Levon, taken from UO Novel spelled backwards. ``Caverns'' is set in 1934, chosen by Kesey because it is the year before his own birth. The psychedelic pioneer of the 1960s is the author of ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' and ``Sometimes a Great Notion.'' The story for ``Caverns'' describes how carnival huckster Charles Oswald Loach is released from San Quentin, where he is serving 20 years for murder, to lead an expedition aboard an Army surplus field ambulance to a mysterious cave purported to contain a wild mix of prehistoric paintings that challenge the basic tenets of anthropology. ``We didn't set a high standard,'' Kesey said of the book, which was published in paperback on soft paper to give it a pulp fiction feel. ``If we had decided to write (Thomas Pynchon's) `Gravity's Rainbow,' we would be still writing, or we would have stopped writing.'' Kesey had everyone develop a character. They evolved into Loach, his desert rat brother, a girl who grew up in Loach's carnival act, a white supremacist brick maker, a sailor, an anthropologist, a priest, an alcoholic newspaperman, a would-be movie producer and two old-maid spiritualist sisters. Unlike the collaborative novels in which writers have taken a chapter to themselves, this one was written with everyone pulling a piece of each chapter out of a hat, then getting 30 minutes to write it. Afterward the book went through two revisions. ``If you've got a good point guard and two power forwards and keep moving the ball around, somebody's going to score,'' Kesey said. The method also minimized individual style and the shark attacks so common in writing workshops. ``You were in fine shape if you started out the chapter,'' said H. Highwater Powers. ``You could lay it out. If you were the last person you had to adjust. You had to think on your feet.'' Kesey said that was one of the great lessons of the class. ``In the hard and sticky and dry parts that you come to in your life or your work, all you have to do is put one foot in front of the other and pretty soon you find yourself in places you didn't expect to be,'' he said. ``There's no way you can teach that. You can only learn that.'' He recalled one discussion when someone complained that the plot had taken an unbelievable turn. ``I said, `That's the job of the writer,''' Kesey said. ``We've got to take the square peg and jam it into the round hole. ``The life of it comes from making people believe that these people are drawing breath and standing up, casting shadows, and living lives and feeling agonies. ``And that's a trick. It's a glorious trick. And it's a trick that you can be taught. It's not ... just a thing that comes from the muses.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: John Davidson Is Cooking Now
DOC.TEXT: TV entertainer John Davidson has given up lizards for pecan pie. Davidson, who confronted the giant reptile as host of ``That's Incredible,'' currently is whipping up tasty treats on cable TV's ``Holiday Gourmet,'' a cooking show on The Nashville Network. Davidson and his wife, Rhonda, make desserts on the 60-minute program, which is broadcast at various times the week before each Easter, Mother's Day, Father's Day, Thanksgiving, Christmas and Valentine's Day. He's no stranger to cooking, and calls himself ``a good assistant cook'' at home. ``There are three or four recipes I keep repeating. One is Polynesian peanut butter chicken, which I found in New Zealand. And I make a mean banana french toast. But really I do my best just as a chopper and cutter for Rhonda.'' TNN, which has broadened its scope and reached beyond Nashville for celebrities such as Davidson, says ``Holiday Gourmet'' has generated more than 13,000 letters a year from viewers seeking recipes or commenting about the show. ``Holiday Gourmet'' featured country music stars making their favorite recipes last year, but the Nashville performers were dropped this season to focus more on Davidson. He joins Dinah Shore and Florence Henderson as non-country music hosts of TNN programs, which are available in 48 million households throughout the country. On ``Holiday Gourmet,'' three chefs prepare dishes such as roast turkey, meat loaf and pasta. Davidson and his wife tackle less complicated recipes such as alpine white pecan pie, chocolate mincemeat squares and chocolate raspberry coconut squares. Cooking is the focus, though Davidson also sings. The 48-year-old Davidson, who's associated with such shows as ``Hollywood Squares'' and ``That's Incredible,'' says his wife may have upstaged him on the cable show. ``They (show executives and crew) were more impressed with Rhonda than me,'' he said cheerfully in a telephone interview from his Los Angeles-area houseboat. ``Everyone said, `Your wife was great.' No one said much about me.'' Rhonda, a former background singer with little TV experience, said she was surprised at the positive reception she received. ``I've always been more of a background person with no desire to be out front,'' she said. ``I expected to be nervous, but people put me at ease because they were so warm and kind. John was supportive, too. ``I just went on the show and did my John Davidson impression. I've watched him work and seen how he deals with the audience and how he conducted himself.'' For Davidson, who has sung some country songs during his career, the series is yet another outlet for showcasing his TV talents. He just finished three years as host of ``Hollywood Squares,'' which has gone out of production but is still seen in reruns. He was host of ``That's Incredible'' in 1981-86 and ``Incredible Sunday'' in 1988 and 1989. He had a syndicated talk-variety show, ``The John Davidson Show,'' from 1980 to 1982. He also had ``The John Davidson Show'' in 1966, 1969 and 1976 as part of ``The Kraft Summer Music Hall.'' He has been host on numerous TV specials such as ``The Golden Globe Awards,'' ``Miss World Competition,'' ``Miss Junior America'' and ``Mother and Daughter Pageant.'' He currently is also seen on ESPN's ``Boating World'' show. ``I always have three or four projects going at one time,'' Davidson said. ``I'm spread out.'' He believes the future of cable TV, the home of his programs on TNN and ESPN, is limitless. ``Producers have to find a place for their shows and they are turning to cable,'' Davidson said. ``In the next five years, I think the TV dial is going to be like a radio dial. You'll have trouble knowing which is a network station or a cable station or an independent. It'll be all one happy dial and you'll turn it just like on the radio.'' Davidson used to be a guest on ``Hollywood Squares'' when Peter Marshall was host, then ended up in Marshall's chair posing questions to the celebrities who would try to stump contestants. ``I liked to bluff and fool people and give an esoteric, impressive answer and try to seem erudite,'' he said. ``In fact, I didn't know the answer, but I got a lot of laughter that way.'' Davidson said his most memorable segment on ``That's Incredible'' was when he entered the cage of a giant lizard. ``They locked the cage on me, or pretended to, and I've never been more frightened in my life. It was scary.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Michael Moriarity, a Tony winner and two-time Emmy recipient, will star in a one-man play, ``A Special Providence,'' which he has written under the pen name Ernest Hart. Moriarity calls the work ``an automythography.'' It is based on a fictitious meeting between William Shakespeare and Ernest Hart, and Ernest Hart and God. In telling the story, Moriarity portrays more than one character. ``A Special Providence'' will run for four consecutive Monday night performances, beginning Feb. 5, at the John Houseman Theatre.

Everyone is invited to ``Tony N' Tina's Wedding,'' the comedy hit that starts its third year in New York City at St. John's Church on Feb. 6. Kelly Cinnante and David Dundara head the current New York cast, playing the bride and groom who invite the audience to their wedding ceremony and then to join their families at the reception for dinner, champagne, dancing and fussing at Vinnie Black's Coliseum. The original New York company of ``Tony N' Tina's Wedding'' opened in Los Angeles last October, where it also became a hit. A third company ushered in the fall theater season in Philadelphia, with equal success. Producers Joe and Daniel Corcoran are readying a Toronto opening of a fourth company in March, with late spring offerings in Boston, Chicago and San Francisco.

Country greats Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings, Johnny Cash and Kris Kristofferson are performing together for the first time on a national tour under the name ``Highwaymen.'' Their national tour begins March 3 at the Astrodome in Houston. Columbia Records will have the quartet's second album, ``Highwayman 2,'' in stores by Feb. 27. The first ``Highwayman'' project sold in excess of 1 million copies and was one of the biggest-selling albums of 1985, garnering a No. 1 single and album on the country charts. Columbia Records expects to release four singles from the album, the first of which will be ``Silver Stallion.'' ``Highwayman 2'' was produced by Chips Moman who has contributed to many Nashville successes including Willie Nelson's ``Always on My Mind'' and ``What a Wonderful World.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Retired Execs Teach Novices How to Succeed in Small Business
DOC.TEXT: In an age of multibillion-dollar buyouts and mergers, an unassuming army of 13,000 is teaching Americans to think small. Members of the volunteer Senior Corps of Retired Executives draw on decades of business experience as they offer free, one-on-one counseling to people who are just getting started in small business or who need help moving ahead. ``Since we have attained hard-won skills in our business lives, this is the best way we can volunteer,'' said Ann Oxley, a SCORE member from Fort Wayne, Ind., who volunteered for a year as the group's marketing director here. ``It's refreshing to see that you can use what you learned from all the bumps and slashes you got going through the business jungle.'' SCORE, sponsored by the Small Business Administration, has 13,000 active members, 80 percent retirees and 20 percent active businesspeople. Those still in business generally help put on workshops that SCORE offers its clients for a small fee. With more than 750 chapters and satellite groups nationwide, SCORE has served more than 3 million people over the past 25 years. Just recently, SCORE and the SBA sent out a notice seeking information on retirees with language skills that might be useful as Eastern European nations open to the West. Volunteers may be asked to help translate publications or speak to foreign delegations. John Daniels, executive director and one of only seven fulltime paid employees, said SCORE's impact is hard to measure in dollars and cents, but success stories abound. In Hostetter, Pa., SCORE counselor Lou Sabers helped the struggling volunteer fire department cut its loan payments in half by obtaining a special 2 percent emergency loan from the state. ``They told us they were on the brink of bankruptcy,'' Sabers said. In Independence, Mo., Norman Westheimer, a 78-year-old former vice president of the former GEM Corp., helped Brenda Louderback revamp her ad strategy for Diessl Jewelers and analyze her profit-and-loss statements. ``I only wish I had studied harder and followed more closely the advice and input that was so generously offered,'' Louderback said. In San Diego, 76-year-old David Gilbert _ with 30 years in the import-export business _ helped brothers Jim and Joseph Hadzicki turn their prototype giant kite into Revolution Kites, which racked up $500,000 in sales its first year. ``It was nice to have somebody who had been through this kind of stuff before who could recommend the proper steps,'' said Jim Hadzicki. Other less-evident successes are found in the ranks of people who decide not to go into business or to postpone it after SCORE members lay out the demands of running a small business and the potential pitfalls. A survey of SCORE clients in the Midwest found that 27 percent had canceled or delayed plans to go into business after contacting the organization, in some cases preserving savings that otherwise might have been lost to failure. ``We have people who think about taking their retirement money and opening up a pizza parlor right across the street from a Pizza Hut,'' Daniels said. ``We have prevented many, many casualties, which is good for the American economy as well as for the individual ego. It's crushing to fail,'' Oxley said. SCORE in many cases is able to match retired executives with novices who need advice in the same area of expertise, Daniels said. The organization keeps a special roster of those with international trade experience in order to help small business people expand their exports. ``There are many opportunities over there, but you have to know your way around,'' he said. SCORE counselors, who have an average of 35 years of business experience, say they benefit themselves even as they help others get started in business. Westheimer has been a SCORE counselor for 15 years and still puts in about 10 hours a week. ``It keeps an individual alert and it's an area where you can be of assistance to people who may be having problems,'' he said. Westheimer became Louderback's counselor in 1985 and she still calls him from time to time with questions about the jewelry store's operations. ``The thing I like about it is there's no `I told you-so' or anything like that. He'll suggest books to read or ways to find information. ``If we want to do it, it's up to us.'' While Revolution Kites is well on it way, Jim Hadzicki still calls Gilbert for occasional advice. For example, Hadzicki knew he should take gifts when he visited potential customers in Japan, but he didn't know what to take. He went with Gilbert's suggestions of Black Label scotch for the men and Estee Lauder products for the women. ``It was just nice to talk to somebody before going.'' The oldest active SCORE counselor has been 93-year-old W.P. Campbell of Searcy, Ark., who recently decided he'll move to inactive status after handling cases for 22 years. ``Whenever you do something for other people, you get a big kick out of it, especially when you do it without pay. ``It gives you a wonderful feeling.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Quilting Brings Together Pieces of Small-Town Life
DOC.TEXT: It is a quilt the women of St. Mary's Church are sewing, calloused fingers punching tiny needles through thick layers of cloth, but what they bind together is a community. The talk in the basement of the clapboard church is about babies and sewing patterns, husbands who spent the fall hunting and sons moving back to town. ``... They bought a house ... '' ``They move away to make money and then they come back. That keeps the town going...'' The chat is as pieced as the pink-and-blue, hearts-and-diamonds quilt top sewn together at home by Cheryl Rexroat Bunek, who's so busy with six children and her husband's plumbing business to run that she can't come to quiltings. No conversation goes deep at the biweekly winter meeting of the St. Mary's quilters, a dozen women around two large quilts stretched across lumber frames. The quilts, like the women who make them, generation after generation, stitch together life in this tiny northern Michigan town, population 368. ``We never gossip,'' insists Mildred Kirt, 81, a thin woman with a cap of short, charcoal gray curls. Her son, Mike, moved back 10 years ago. The cold air off Lake Michigan chases two more women down the stairwell. They add their coats to the pile on the table, their fingers to the sewing and their voices to the conversation. Talk and sew, talk and sew. The ladies of St. Mary's have been doing this to raise money for the church further back than anyone can recall, an endless succession of patterns that mirror their lives: courthouse steps, double wedding ring, Grandma's flower garden, seven sisters. It's a rich tradition of small-town life centered on an aging church and a country parish of 250 families. The farmers' co-op is closed and the train depot is gone, but St. Mary's endures. ``There wouldn't be much of a town if there wasn't the church,'' says Lynn Edwards, adding a swirling border to frame the calico heart Mildred is sewing. ``For these people, the church is still a center of life, their social life,'' says the Rev. Walt Derylo. ``Here, you take a step back in time.'' He is talking from St. Michael's Church, four miles away in Suttons Bay. St. Mary's has no resident pastor; there's a shortage of priests in the church. The women talk about that, too. ``The Pope should let priests marry,'' one says. These women's mothers in 1904 made a signature quilt to raise money for the church. A dime donation embroidered your place in devotion, your name stitched in red around the silhouette of St. Mary's. The spread was won at raffle by a priest, who gave it to a family that needed it for warmth against the Michigan night. The Leelanau peninsula was timbered bare by then. Poor potato farmers were all that were left. The rolling peninsula wasn't yet planted in the quaint cherry orchards that would attract tourists from Chicago and Detroit, antique shops and condominium builders. In summer now, tourists crowd the lanes with 10-speed bicycles, browse for antiques and take home smoked fish in paper bundles tied with string. But in winter, Lake Leelanau remains shut into itself and the old ways. The St. Mary's women meet Tuesdays and Thursdays. They raise about $10,000 a year for the church and its pride, a 101-year-old, 13-grade school. The old signature quilt hangs in the Leelanau Historical Museum, 600-some faded names on rough, unbleached muslin. ``Gauthier, Belanger ...,'' Curator Laura Quackenbush starts to read. ``You can see the French-Canadian influence. And the German: the Schaubs ... Emelia Schaub. Emelia is 96 now, living at the Omena House nursing home. ``She's the first woman prosecutor to practice in Michigan, elected in 1936 and re-elected five times.'' Actually, another woman was elected first, but was thrown out by the governor, who said it was an illegal occupation for women. Quilting was part of women's work, a way to keep warm at night, to tie a community together, to raise money for churches, schools, the needy. Mennonite women in Oscoda County sell quilts to benefit a world-wide hunger fund. A woman in eastern Michigan sells her quilts to pay her son's college tuition. ``They used to laugh at us,'' says Barb Merica, at 59 one of the youngest. ``They,'' are the men, but it's Barb who's laughing now, eyes twinkling over glasses perched on the end of her nose. The quilts go for hundreds of dollars each these days. Many never touch a bed, instead hanging from walls like giant paintings. Mildred Kirt doesn't understand. ``These quilts don't seem so fancy to me. ``When I was a girl, I thought my mother was so dumb to cut all those pieces and sew them back together. But I see now, it's an art.'' In 70 years of sewing, Mildred has made quilts for the beds of her four children and their 15 children and is starting on the great-grandkids. Suzanne Plamondon, 75, did the same for eight kids and 16 grandchildren. Jen LaCross made hers for nine children and 28 grandchildren. There's a splash of red on the fabric. Claire Routzahn has pricked herself, hard, and blood drips from her fingertip. She mops it with a little water. No one pays attention. There's a lot of blood spilt over a quilt, Barb says. And some pain. Mildred's mother, Josephine Hahnenberg, was a terror as a quilter, exacting and demanding of the talents of young brides who sought admission. Every careless stitch _ hundreds of them _ had to be ripped out. ``I came home crying every night,'' Suzanne says. ``My husband consoled me, told me not to give up, to stand up to this woman. He said, `She'll respect you.''' In the end, they became good friends and fishing buddies. Quilting is no longer the rite of womanhood in Lake Leelanau. Daughters have jobs and other demands. It's already been a struggle to keep the group from unraveling. Barb and Florence Scharnowski and Laura Couturier pitched in to take over the organizing work when Flo Lamie died of cancer. ``Flo's biggest worry was would the quilting fall apart,'' Barb says. Who is there to replace the replacements? Barb sighs. ``If we don't get young blood, like all things, it will die.'' The morning wears. The chatter slows. The women roll up the ends of the finished spread as they work, scooting their chairs forward and inward. It is godawful cold outside and getting worse as the day develops but in the warm basement, the women of St. Mary's keep sewing, knees to knees around an ever-shrinking quilt.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Divorced Over-40, Older Women Have More Financial Problems
DOC.TEXT: Like many middle-aged and older Americans, Carolyn Connor was raised to believe that nice people didn't get divorced. But at 49, she's been married, divorced, remarried and widowed. ``Society raised me to think it was an embarrassment to get a divorce. But he was an alcoholic... When I got a little money from my grandfather's estate, it gave me the guts to leave,'' said Connor, who was divorced at 33. ``It really makes me feel sorry for people who don't have the money.'' Sociologists say that while divorce rates have stabilized for younger women, they are increasing for older women. And newly divorced middle-aged and older women have a harder time financially than widows or those divorced early. ``Almost everyone recognized there was a tremendous increase in divorce rates since the 1960s,'' said Peter Uhlenberg, a University of North Carolina sociologist. ``Divorce is concentrated in younger women _ most occur before age 40. Women in later life, those who are old now, have not been affected by these changes. We're trying to anticipate what happens when women in their younger adult years hit their 60s and 70s.'' Uhlenberg and his associates, Teresa Cooney, now at the University of Delaware, and Robert Boyd, presently a graduate student at the University of South Carolina, used data from the U.S. Census, Vital Statistics and Current Population Survey for their study, published in the January edition of the Journal of Gerontology: Social Sciences. They found that one woman in eight will have her first marriage end in divorce after she reaches age 40. And the probability of remarriage is slim, decreasing rapidly with age. In 1985, for example, researchers found fewer than three out of 100 divorced women aged 45 to 64 remarried. ``There are competing explanations for why more older women are getting divorced and remaining unmarried. It's becoming more feasible for women to support themselves outside of marriage. There are more work opportunities. The age before marriage has gone up. The whole idea of being married is becoming less likeable after doing it once,'' Uhlenberg said. The economic status, family relationships, social support and emotional stability of recently divorced middle-aged and older women vary dramatically from those comparably married, widowed, or long-termed divorced women. ``Much more often, a widowed woman will have a house, which is a major asset going into old age,'' Uhlenberg said. Widowed women are also more likely to have their husband's pension as a source of income, but for divorced older women, the social implications are very different. ``A widowed woman is much more likely to be living independently and not working,'' he said. ``Divorced women are compensating economically by sharing their living expenses and working.'' ``It takes a while to recover financially from divorce,'' said Ms. Connor, who has worked as a secretary for three years to supplement her late husband's disabled veterans' benefits. ``And at the time I divorced, they didn't really enforce child support. I had my husband arrested twice for not paying and all they did was put him in jail overnight and then let him go.'' The picture becomes more bleak for older minority women, Uhlenberg said. ``Divorce rates are significantly higher for blacks. We know that. The economic implications are about what they are for white women. It's just that more black women will experience economic disadvantages.'' Another factor affecting divorce rates is the increased acceptability of single mothers and co-habitation before marriage, he said. And the more these types of families exist, the less likely children of such groups are to be socialized into the pattern of stable family relationships. ``What we're doing now is looking at one of the implications of divorce on older men,'' which will be published this month, he said. ``Specifically, the impact of divorce on older men and their relationship with their children. ``We've found that older divorced men are much less likely to have contact with their adult children. They report the relationship to be less satisfactory. ``For women, we find a greater impact on an economic level, while for men, the implication would be in terms of social support.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Women Fare Better Than Men After Spouse's Death
DOC.TEXT: Women who are suddenly widowed survive the trauma better than men whose spouses die unexpectedly, but when death follows lengthy illness, men seem to handle things better, a sociologist says. Studies have shown that women generally weather a spouse's death better than men, but women's traditional role as caregiver works against them when a death follows prolonged illness, said Ken Smith of the University of Utah. ``The idea here is that women, because they are taking on more caregiver burden, are likely to face a higher rate of mortality'' Smith said. Working with data from a multifaceted, nationwide study of 5,000 married couples that began in 1968, Smith studied data from 113 widowers and 383 widows over 14 years after a spouse died, and compared each with a control couple. Men who suddenly became widowed were 52 percent more likely to die within 14 years than men whose wives remained alive, while men whose wives died after a long illness were only 13 percent more likely to die than non-widowers. Women whose husbands died suddenly faced a marginal mortality risk _ 1 percent _ but those enduring a husband's prolonged illness and death were 49 percent more likely to die than non-widows, Smith said. He speculates that a woman, more used to caregiving, is better prepared for life after her husband's death. But she takes on a far greater than normal burden when nursing a husband through chronic illness. Men whose wives die suddenly run a higher risk of dying because they're unable to prepare for unexpected life alone, he said. ``Men tend not to possess the daily living skills that help to preserve one's health. When she dies suddenly, there's a source of support that's suddenly gone.'' However, men adopt caregiver abilities when forced to take responsibility for nursing a spouse through chronic illness, he said. Regardless of how sudden a wife's death, said University of Maryland psychologist Leon Levy, men have much greater difficulty with bereavement. They ``don't have the support system women do. Men are more isolated.'' Jean Buchin, an adjunct professor at City University of New York who conducts workshops for people whose spouses have died, said Smith's study does not consider age. ``The age factor of the widowed plays an important role. Older widows take the impact of widowhood _ sudden or anticipated _ in general harder, economically, emotionally and socially, than younger women.'' Paul Costa, head of the Laboratory of Personality and Cognition at the National Institute of Aging in Baltimore, said his own findings show the acute bereavement of the first six months has significant effects, while long-term grieving has virtually no impact on mortality or long-term well-being. Smith agrees, but puts the maximum impact later. ``You can see where the bereavement really kicks in. Things seem to peak at about one year.'' He presented his initial findings on widowhood last summer at a conference of the Society for Epidemiologic Research, and is revising the paper for publication by the American Journal of Epidemiology.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: 74 Average Is This League's Age, Not Scores
DOC.TEXT: Historians say bowling dates back to ancient Egypt, and while the members of the B'nai B'rith Sports Lodge have witnessed more than a few decades, they deny being among the original keglers. No sporadic bowlers, the 15 men _ averaging over 74 years old _ trek to the downtown Spencer Lanes every Tuesday night between Labor Day and Passover. ``We come through rain and shine, even a blizzard once,'' said Marvin Pechter, 67. And they have no plans to quit soon. ``I hope to keep at it for another 10 years,'' said Charlie Shayne, 85, a printing company manager who prefers bowling to almost anything else. ``I love it. I think you should do what you like. Summertime I play golf, Wintertime I bowl.'' Overnight he plays cards. ``Give Charlie a poker game he'll stay up all night long,'' said Pechter. ``He was late for a tournament once. And when he finally showed up, he said he'd been up all night playing poker.'' Setting up on the last four alleys at Spencer's, the Sports Lodgers bowl quickly, chatting and encouraging each other on. ``Charlie, you're up next,'' says Pechter. Shayne grabs his bowling ball, studies the spots on the alley, then spryly steps down the approach. The lefty's ball rolls less than halfway down the alley, then veers with a little hook into the pocket. Boom. Eight pins down. No. 6 and No. 10 left standing. Shayne gets his ball back from the machine, looks again at the spots, then smoothly moves toward the foul line. Again, that little hook. Bingo. A spare. ``Way to go, Charlie,'' several other call out. Charlie grins like a kid. ``Bowling definitely keeps you young. You got to keep active, not watch the boob tube. I see too many men vegetate. We have fun,'' said Pechter, who runs a hardware store. The chief funny man in the Sports Lodge is Ed Kallish, 65. ``The reason we bowl is to get away from our wives or girlfriends _ or both.'' The Sports Lodge is among nearly 4,000 senior leagues in the United States, all with bowlers over 55, said Mark Miller of the American Bowling Congress. Pechter, the league secretary, has all the stats: ``We got four teams, the oldest bowler is 85, our baby is 62, the mean age is 74 or 75.'' The league, formed a quarter century ago, has some pretty fair bowlers. Benny Lavin, 79, a retired musician who once managed a bowling alley, averages 174. ``I had a 716 series in 1968,'' said Kallish, a stationery supply salesman. Shayne, who started bowling at 46 in 1950, averages 145. Often Lavin and some of the others can be seen coaching in nearby alleys. ``You try to give them a helpful hint _ if they want it,'' Pechter said. ``We put a lot of years in. We're not pros _ far, far from it. But if we can notice a bowler making a mistake, we like to give tips.'' At the end of the season, the Sports Lodgers party. ``We take out our wives out,'' Pechter said, ``to thank them for letting us bowl.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Come on Over for a Bite of Supper
DOC.TEXT: Jane Weston Wilson is the author of the lifestyle cookbook ``Eating Well When You Just Can't Eat the Way You Used To,'' Workman Publishing.

``Come on over for a bite of supper.'' This is the kind of entertaining that is doable. Nothing fancy, mind you, but an easy, inexpensive casserole dinner, with fresh seasonal greens, a crusty bread and dessert. It can be a pot luck, where the host and@or hostess prepare the main dish and friends bring separate components that make up the rest of the meal, or, if you do it all, it can take as little as two hours. The casserole can go stove top to table top in 30 minutes and it's easy to wash fresh greens for salad, whisk together a light vinaigrette, spread whole wheat baguettes with herb butter and whip up a simple dessert. Yet, what I so often hear from friends in my travels around the country these days is, ``Now that the kids have grown up we don't entertain much any more,'' or, ``I seldom entertain now that I'm alone.'' This is the very time when entertaining should be at the top of our priority list. Whether we've moved to another area, from a house to an apartment, or stayed put, entertaining is a conduit through which we can share friendship and in opening ourselves up to each other we gain perspective, encouragement and succor. People love to go to each other's houses. And informality is often appreciated. There's no need to put on the ritz with a three-course dinner and rich dessert. Light, simple food is preferred, especially at this time of our lives when too many calories and too much fat can ruin our efforts to keep fit. The number of people: four or six, five or seven, singles and couples, mix and match in both ages and interests. The cost of this king of entertaining can be as little as $5 a person and it enriches our lives beyond measure. ``I like to entertain once aa month,'' my friend, Mary Rommer, says. ``But I don't want to go to that much bother, so I make it really easy on myself. ``Use pots, platters and ovenware that can come to table. Plates and glasses that can take the heat of the dishwasher. Runners and placemats that don't need ironing. Foods that don't need looking after. And casseroles that can sit around in the oven or on top of the stove, or a big kettle. ``I serve just the first time around and then guests can help themselves.'' Here's one of my favorite casserole dinners.
DOC.HEAD: Cassoulet on the Light Side (Serves 6)
Ingredients:
DOC.TEXT: 2 tablespoons butter 2 tablespoons olive oil 2 large onions, peeled and finely chopped 2 medium leeks, thoroughly rinsed and cut into 1-inch pieces 2 cloves garlic, peeled and finely chopped 3 whole chicken breasts (about 1 pound each), bones intact, rinsed, skinned and patted dry 3 medium carrots, peeled and cut into 1-inch slices 1 16-ounce can of small white beans 1 16-ounce can of pinto beans 1 10-ounce package frozen lima beans, defrosted 1 tablespoon chili sauce or 1 tablespoon tomato paste 1 tablespoon dried leaf thyme 3 cups canned beef or chicken broth 3 medium yellow squash, trimmed and cut into {-inch-thick slices salt and pepper to taste

1. Melt the 2 tablespoons of butter in a skillet over medium heat. Add the onions, leeks and garlic and saute until translucent, about 5-7 minutes. With a slotted spoon, remove the cooked vegetables and set aside. 2. Heat the 2 tablespoons of olive oil and saute the chicken breasts, about 5 minutes on each side, until browned. 3. In a 6-quart casserole, combine the sauteed chicken and onions, leeks, garlic, carrots, chili sauce, thyme and broth and simmer about 15 minutes. 4. Add the beans and yellow squash and cook 10 minutes longer. 5. With a slotted spoon, transfer the chicken to a cutting board and bone the chicken in strips, then return to casserole. 6. Serve hot at the table. Or cool (you may freeze at this point) and refrigerate, covered.
DOC.HEAD: Watercress-Arugula Salad (Serves 6)
Ingredients:
DOC.TEXT: 2 bunches of watercress, rinsed, stems removed, and patted dry 2 bunches of arugula, rinsed and patted dry 1@3 cup olive oil 1@3 cup red wine vinegar 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice 1{ teaspoons Dijon-style mustard freshly ground pepper to taste

1. In a medium salad bowl, combine the greens. 2. In a small bowl, whisk together the remaining ingredients. 3. Refrigerate the greens and dressing in separate covered bowls. 4. Just before serving, toss the greens with the dressing.
DOC.HEAD: Ice Cream Apricot Mousse (Serves 6)
Ingredients:
