DOC.TEXT: 1 envelope unflavored gelatin 2 cans, 1 pound each, whole peeled apricots, drained, juice reserved (Use enough apricots to make 1{ cups and } cups of juice and reserve the remainder for another use.) 1 quart vanilla ice cream, softened Garnish: strawberries or kumquats

1. In a medium saucepan over low heat, warm the apricot juice slightly. 2. Sprinkle the gelatin over the syrup and heat about 5 minutes, stirring constantly, until the gelatin dissolves 3. Place the apricots in a blender. Whirl until slightly pureed but still with some texture. 4. Fold into the ice cream. Spoon into individual stem glasses or into a serving bowl. 5. Refrigerate covered for about 3 hours to set. 6. Garnish each serving with one large, whole strawberry or a half kumquat.

DOC.HEAD: Many Gardeners Seem To Be Late Bloomers
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years that included coverage of World War II from Italy.

A farmer who hires teen-agers is quoted in a village weekly as saying ``they come here thinking tomatoes grow underground. Kids coming here to weed have plucked out my pepper plants and have planted onions upside down.'' Should kids know better, I wonder? I didn't start gardening until I was 35, and was so ignorant the first time out I emptied a whole packet of lettuce seed into a 6-foot row before my horrified father-in-law could grab my arm. But my goof didn't dampen my eagerness. Now, nearing 74, I make a lettuce packet last four and five years and I save wood ashes from the Franklin stove to fatten my beets. I've agonized over frost and drought and the raccoon has beaten me time and again to my best corn. But, learning all the time, I look with pride at my 20-year-old asparagus bed, my pencil-thin French beans and the gloriously red radicchio peeking through the mulch and snow on a winter day. The Barefoot Boy, as John Greenleaf Whittier pictured him 135 years ago, walked hand in hand with Nature and talked to her face to face. But was he a gardener? How many of our teen-age children garden of their own free will? And how about vegetables? I dusted off an old Whittier and found that the lad with cheeks of tan knew all about woodchucks, moles, turtles, robins, orioles, wasps, groundnuts, lilies, berries and apples. But no beans or onions in the 102 lines. Did Whittier forget the vegetables? Or, in America's pastoral age, was it quietly understood that vegetables were not a leisure activity for children? A farmer of our own day, reminiscing in The New York Times about his childhood, regrets he never played much baseball. ``I had to rush home from school to help my father with the planting.'' Aside from horticultural geniuses like Luther Burbank, many gardeners seem to be late bloomers. In my own family, I've seen my son, an artist, smitten in his mid-30s. He started because he wanted to paint flowers, like Claude Monet, but quickly he was deep into catalogs and manuals, potting soil, flats, tools, trips to nurseries, cold frames, mulches, hoses, trellises. Even botanical names. And it doesn't take forever to get pretty good. Unlike a heartless golf ball, plants help you. They want to live and ``make it'' as much as you do. A Gallup poll found gardening to be America's leading pastime, more popular than golf, jogging, biking, tennis and swimming. But working the soil abounds in irony and paradox. On city rooftops and backyards, amateurs multiply, while real farmers, once a multitude, dwindle in the greatest agricultural nation. Some seek loans and therapy even as a few giants achieve miracles of production. Astonishing machines, with cash the ultimate target, spew out spotless tomatoes as hard as baseballs, and as tasteless, while the greenest amateur, barely knowing enough to water his plants, exults over his first triumph, a juicy tomato with that old-time flavor. A thirtyish city friend came to see us at asparagus time. Asparagus is one of man's oldest companions, very little different in today's cultivated state from the wild spears harvested by our forebears. My friend's eyes widened when he saw the purplish spears poking up through the hay mulch, self-contained beauties all ready for the cooking pot. ``Is that how they grow!?'' he exclaimed. I thought I read the pleasure of discovery in his eyes. Another gardener down the road?

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Feb. 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Demographer: Florida's Elderly Population Will Keep Booming
DOC.TEXT: As the state with the oldest population, Florida offers lessons on dealing with the problems of a graying America, a demographer says. ``The way Florida deals with this aging population could be very instructive to the nation as a whole when it has to deal with it in the year 2020 or 2030,'' said Stanley K. Smith, director of population research with the University of Florida's Bureau of Economic and Business Research. Those 65 and older will comprise an estimated 18 percent of Florida's 13 million residents this year, and could hit 26 percent by the year 2020. ``An older population has a major impact on such things as health care, child care, education, the labor force and voter participation,'' Smith said. However, the growing elderly population is not predicted to be a drain on Florida's resources, as some officials fear. In fact, he said, recent studies have shown that the economic benefit of the elderly population far outweighs _ by four or five times _ its demand on the social system. ``Florida has a unique retiree ... healthier and considerably wealthier than the average for the United States,'' he said. ``And there also seems to be some evidence that when they start to become really old, when they begin placing more demands on the social system, they often move back to New York or Ohio or wherever they migrated from.''
DOC.HEAD: Pamphlet on Getting All Available Income Tax Deductions
DOC.TEXT: A new publication from the Senate Special Committee on Aging is designed to help older Americans hold down their income tax payments by claiming all the deductions to which they are entitled. The annual pamphlet, ``Protecting Older Americans Against the Overpayment of Income Taxes,'' contains information about the need for elderly and disabled taxpayers to ignore certain lines on their tax forms that don't apply now that the Medicare surtax for catastrophic coverage has been repealed. ``This information paper can help assure that senior citizens claim every legitimate income tax deduction, exemption and tax credit,'' said Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., chairman of the Senate committee. Write to: Senate Special Committee on Aging, Room G-31 Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, D.C. 20510-6400, Attention: Publications.
DOC.HEAD: Researcher: Working Daughter Increase Hurts Aging Parents
DOC.TEXT: An increase in the number working women has hurt aging parents who have traditionally depended on their daughters for care, says a University of Florida researcher and author of a new book. Daughters, as the caregivers in many families, have less time to cook and care for their elderly parents, said Jane Myers, professor of counselor education and author of ``Adult Children and Aging Parents.'' ``Many women begin or renew careers when their children leave home and look forward to a variety of new-found freedoms,'' Ms. Myers said. ``The last thing they want is to suddenly have an aging parent depending on them.'' More elderly people, as a result, are relying on social service programs and perhaps entering nursing homes sooner than they would otherwise. ``The whole phenomenon of dealing with aging parents is very new and it's a strain on family members that they aren't prepared for,'' Ms. Myers said. ``As the parent's health becomes fragile and they feel vulnerable, they want to know that the people they care most about are there for them. So they may reach out to their children more than they used to.'' Retirement can be especially stressful because they may want to get to know their grandchildren and be near their adult children, who may be busy with their own lives and resent the intrusion, Ms. Myers said. Another sore spot is the decision to place an aging parent in a nursing home. Between 20 and 30 percent of the elderly population can expect to spend some time in a nursing home, she said. ``The problem with many people who enter nursing homes is that most of the time they're OK and don't need to be there.'' Another major problem between elderly parents and their adult children is that both develop a lifetime of relationship patterns that often no longer work as the parents grow old, she said. ``Don't wait until your parents get old and problems arise to try to build a good relationship. It's much easier to deal with trouble spots when everyone is healthy.''

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,798,000 net tons during the week ending Feb. 3, 1990, down 0.1 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 80.3 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steelmakers produced 2,001,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 8,565,000 net tons, 9.7 percent below last year's pace, AISI said.

American workers' productivity rose just 0.9 percent last year _ the worst showing since the 1981-82 recession _ while hourly labor costs sped upward, the government said. The increase in non-farm productivity, defined as output per hour of work, was less than half the 2 percent gain recorded in 1988, the Labor Department said Monday. The report showed that while productivity was slumping, hourly labor costs _ a major inflation measure for businesses _ jumped by 5.5 percent, up from 4.7 percent in 1988 and the biggest increase since 1982.

Sales of North American-made cars and light trucks dropped 1.5 percent in late January from a year earlier as a strong rise in truck sales offset tumbling car sales, automakers reported. Domestic truck sales rose 8.1 percent, spurred by strong sales at Chrysler Corp., which offered incentives on its popular minivans, while domestic car sales fell by 6.6 percent during the during the Jan. 21-31 period, domestic automakers said Monday. Results in the year-earlier period were inflated somewhat by heavy fleet sales, a condition analysts said made this year's late January figures look relatively encouraging.

SCI Television Inc., the television station company controlled by investor George Gillett, says it had completed a debt exchange offer and avoided being forced into bankruptcy court proceedings. The Denver-based company, which had been unable to meet interest payments on its debt, has been trying for months to negotiate an exchange under which its bank and bond lenders would get an equity stake in the company. The deal Monday reduces Gillett's 55 percent stake in SCI to 41 percent, and cuts the share of the company owned by a group led by buyout specialist Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. to 15 percent from 45 percent.

Sears, Roebuck and Co. said fourth-quarter earnings rose sharply from a year earlier, when it undertook a costly restructuring, and said Hurricane Hugo and the Bay-area Quake made 1989 the costliest year ever for its Allstate insurance subsidiary. Sears on Monday reported net income of $602 million, or $1.76 per common share, for the three months ended Dec. 31 compared with $117 million, or 32 cents per share, for the same period a year earlier. Sales for the quarter rose 4.2 percent to $15.2 billion from $14.6 billion.

RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. reported losses for the fourth quarter and all of 1989, reflecting the cost of its record $24.5 billion buyout by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. a year ago. The consumer products giant, the former RJR Nabisco Inc. that was taken private in a deal finalized in February 1989, said Monday it lost $144 million during the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with a $411 million profit in the 1988 quarter. Sales were unchanged at $3.54 billion. For the year, RJR Nabisco lost $1.5 billion and had sales of $12.76 billion, compared with a $1.4 billion profit on $12.64 billion in sales in 1988.

General Electric Co.'s RCA division has pleaded guilty to illegally obtaining classified Pentagon planning documents and agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle charges in the continuing probe of contractors trading defense secrets. RCA Corp. pleaded guilty Monday in U.S. District Court to two felony counts of ``conveying without authority'' two secret editions of a Pentagon five-year spending program.

Texas billionaire Harold C. Simmons has revealed that the Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into his acquisitions of Lockheed Corp. and Georgia Gulf Corp. stock. In a filing Monday with the SEC, Simmons-controlled companies stated that the probe apparently centered on the timing of their filing of public disclosure documents regarding acquisition of the stock.

The government reportedly has offered Michael Milken the opportunity to plead guilty to six felonies and avoid a new indictment, lengthy trial and possible conviction on dozens more charges. But individuals close to the case said Monday there was no indication Milken would accept or even was considering a plea deal and noted that talks between opposing sides are common in complex federal cases. Milken was indicted last March on 98 counts of fraud and racketeering.

General Motors Corp. has boosted its Class E stock dividend by 17 percent and split the stock 2-for-1 because of growth in non-GM computer business at the automaker's Electronic Data Systems Corp. subsidiary. The company's board of directors also said Monday it was maintaining dividends on GM's regular common stock, keyed to the company's vehicle-making and marketing business, and on its Class H stock, which is related to the GM Hughes Electronics Corp. subsidiary.

The stock market gained more ground Monday, but its modest advance came in the slowest trading of the new year amid worries that interest rates are headed higher. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 16.44 points on Friday, added another 19.82 points to close at 2,622.52. The dollar finished lower against major currencies in quiet trading. Bond prices declined. Petroleum futures prices fell sharply; orange juice futures plunged; precious metals advanced; livestock and meat futures were higher; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: EDS Stock Dividend Raised 2-for-1 Stock Split Too
DOC.TEXT: A dividend increase on General Motors Corp.'s Class E common stock and a 2-for-1 split fulfills a promise the automaker made when it bought Electronic Data Systems Corp. six years ago. On Monday, the GM board of directors authorized the stock split and a 17 percent increase in the dividend to 28 cents a share. GM said the moves stemmed from growth in EDS's non-GM business. ``I think it is a good move on the part of GM's board,'' said analyst Terrance Quinn of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York. ``Even though General Motors is having its difficulties, it's living up to its word.'' The board also said it was maintaining dividends on GM's regular common stock, keyed to the company's vehicle-making and marketing business, and on its Class H stock, which is related to the GM Hughes Electronics Corp. subsidiary. GM's non-auto subsidiaries _ EDS, GM-Hughes and General Motors Acceptance Corp., the group's financing arm _ are expected to report fourth-quarter and year-end 1989 earnings next week. A day later, GM will report profits from its vehicle operations, which are expected to be down sharply from a year ago. ``The GM business has not gone anywhere,'' Quinn said. ``The non-GM component has grown in excess of 25 percent annually within the last two to three years.'' The moves on the Class E stock, based on EDS performance, indicate that while profits on GM's car and truck operations are falling, other GM businesses are booming. When GM bought EDS from Texas billionaire H. Ross Perot in 1984, it promised that the computer company's performance would not be dependent on the automaker's overall results. It created the class E stock to reflect EDS' performance. Quinn said the dividend increase and stock split are ``reflective of what EDS does outside of what GM does.'' Class E stock has not performed up to its potential because of a perception that it is ``another common class of GM stock,'' Quinn said. ``Because it's a wholly owned subsidiary, there's a feeling that there is no independence with it,'' he added. The increase in the Class E dividend, to 28 cents a share from 24 cents, also stemmed from an increased profit margin last year, the company said. It will be payable March 10 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 15. The board said the Class E stock split came as the company completed a 10 million, pre-split share repurchase plan. GM now will repurchase 5 million more shares of Class E stock. The board continued a 75 cent-a-share dividend on the company's regular common stock, called $1 2-3 par value, and an 18 cent-a-share dividend on Class H stock. A year ago, the board boosted the dividend and declared a 2-for-1 split on its regular common stock.

DOC.HEAD: Report Settlement Offer for Former Drexel Executive
DOC.TEXT: The government reportedly has offered Michael Milken the chance to plead guilty to six felonies to avoid a lengthy trial on new charges, but there was no indication the former junk bond king would accept a deal. Individuals close to the case said Monday they still expect the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive to defend his case at a trial tentatively scheduled to begin later this year. The individuals, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there was no indication Milken was considering a plea deal and noted that talks between opposing sides are common in complex federal cases. The case has been in a holding pattern, awaiting a new indictment superseding the one handed up last March that charged Milken with 98 counts of fraud and racketeering in connection with a series of securities transactions. Prosecutors originally planned to bring the new charges by last October. The government most recently said the indictment would be ready by mid-January, but the reported talks between prosecutors and Milken's lawyers purportedly caused the latest delay. Milken, through his lawyers, has proclaimed his innocence and pledged to fight the case in court. The report of a plea offer was published in Monday's editions of The Wall Street Journal. Prosecutors were said to have offered Milken the chance to plead guilty to six felony counts, each of which would carry a maximum five years in prison. The government would recommend to the judge that Milken serve the counts concurrently, for a maximum of five years _ or the equivalent of one felony charge. But a judge would not be bound by the recommendation. None of the six counts would involve racketeering, which carries a maximum 20-year prison term. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll did not return a call seeking comment on the report. A spokesman for Milken said: ``We've never commented and won't start now on the prejudicial and unfair leaks that have been printed about this case. Rather than printing the rumor of the day everyone would be better served by waiting for the facts.'' The newspaper report said the government offered the plea bargain after two weeks of negotiations with Milken's lawyers. A settlement would erase the need for a long and costly trial on wide-ranging securities charges, including insider trading, that could shed new light on one of Wall Street's most powerful figures of the 1980s. A trial is expected to include testimony by admitted felon Ivan Boesky, the former stock speculator. Reports of a settlement have circulated since Milken first was linked to the government's insider trading investigation about three years ago, particularly just before announcements of new developments. The Milken camp has maintained in the past that reports of developments, including a potential settlement or the contents of a new indictment, are designed to pressure Milken and others into cooperating. They have accused the government of deliberately leaking information and asked a judge to restrain such leaks. The latest report said a plea could be complicated because attorneys for Milken have told the government he is unwilling to cooperate with the continuing insider trading investigation. Such cooperation is customary in complicated cases. A deal also likely would have to be reached with Milken's brother, Lowell, who also was indicted, and there is no indication that one has been proposed or is likely. Michael Armstrong, Lowell Milken's attorney, did not immediately return a call seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Board Meeting Amid Financial Doldrums, Merger Speculation
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp., desperately seeking a merger partner for more than a year, has had its shares boosted by renewed speculation of an impending deal to help bail the airline out of its financial straits. Pan Am stock rose 75 cents to $3.75 a share _ a 25 percent surge _ in heavy trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange. Market watchers attributed the jump to weekend comments by William F. Genoese, director of the Teamsters' airline division. Genoese said Pan Am management had leaked word that a major announcement _ probably a deal with Northwest Airlines _ would come out of its board meeting today. Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon confirmed that the airline's board has a regularly scheduled meeting today, but she declined to comment on the speculation. Bob Gibbons, a spokesman for Northwest at its headquarters in Eagan, Minn., also declined to comment. A combination with a stronger carrier, or a sale of some routes, could pull Pan Am out of its financial difficulties, analysts said Monday. ``They need to do something,'' said Andrew Geller, an airline analyst at Provident National Bank in Philadelphia. Geller and other analysts cited rumors circulating in financial quarters that, short of merging with Northwest, Pan Am might strike a deal to sell some of its prized trans-Atlantic routes or other assets to the carrier. New York-based Pan Am, the nation's eighth-largest airline, has lost nearly $2 billion since 1981 and is saddled with $841 million in debt. Last February, Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett said the airline needed to merge with another carrier in order to survive. Pan Am offered about $3.3 billion last May for NWA Inc., Northwest's parent, but was outbid by a $3.65 billion offer from a group led by investor Alfred Checchi. Pan Am, with a small domestic route base, has an extensive network linking New York with major European cities. Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest carrier, serves more than 100 U.S. cities but also is strong in the Far East. A combination of the two would create the most extensive international route system of any U.S. carrier. ``Pan Am is unlikely to become profitable anytime soon given its current strategic direction,'' analyst Robert McAdoo of the investment firm Oppenheimer & Co. said in a recent report. He noted that in recent years Pan Am's New York-Europe routes have been challenged by competitors offering direct flights to Europe from newer hubs such as Dallas, Atlanta and Charlotte, N.C. Despite its problems, McAdoo said, ``Pan Am still has salable assets to enable it to survive this winter and probably again next winter.'' The airline's revenue was hit hard by the explosion of Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, which scared away many potential trans-Atlantic passengers. But the situation has improved in recent months, with passenger traffic up 15 percent last December from a year earlier. Pan Am's passenger load factors improved to an average 57.8 percent in November and 62.8 percent in December. But fare cuts and increased costs have raised the break-even level for each flight to around 73 percent of capacity, analysts estimate. Pan Am's cash balance was about $200 million at the end of last year, Ms. Hanlon said. The airline, which was founded in the 1920s by the legendary Juan Trippe, had become the object of a number of suitors in 1987, including investors Kirk Kerkorian, Sir James Goldsmith and real estate developer Donald Trump. A proposed takeover by Braniff Inc. collapsed in February 1988 when Braniff failed to win agreements for cost-cutting labor concessions from Pan Am's pilots union.

DOC.HEAD: Examiner: Eastern Can Fly in Spirit of Compromise
DOC.TEXT: The biggest obstacle to Eastern Airline's successful climb from bankruptcy is an atmosphere of confrontation rather than compromise, a court-appointed overseer says. ``There's got to be some give and take on both sides,'' David Shapiro, the carrier's bankruptcy examiner, said Monday. ``If the parties put the public interest first and their own selfish interests second, then Eastern is a viable airline.'' Shapiro said it is ``totally irresponsible'' to presume liquidation or sale are the only alternatives for the Miami-based airline, which he termed ``eminently reorganizable.'' Shapiro's comments were contained in a statement announcing court approval of a $105 million program to guarantee that any passengers and travel agents seeking refunds will be paid. Recently, rumors have circulated that Texas Air Corp. Chairman Frank Lorenzo, Eastern's owner, would opt for a Chapter 7 liquidation. Eastern set up the refund program to allay any fears of liquidation, The New York Times reported in today's editions. Ticket sales have fallen since the liquidation talk surfaced, the newspaper reported. The ticket refund program approved Monday would cover ticketholders and travel agents who made purchases after Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization last March 9. Those who bought tickets issued before the filing remain under bankruptcy court jurisdiction. Meanwhile, Eastern has agreed to hire back 215 union flight attendants by April 1 as part of an accord in which the union agreed to drop a lawsuit challenging the jobs of 215 recruits hired during the strike. ``Both sides had to compromise, but this was something we could live with,'' said Mary Jane Barry, president of Local 553 of the Transport Workers Union, which represents flight attendants at Eastern. The union walked out March 4 in sympathy with the Machinists union, which remains on strike. The flight attendants called off their strike on Nov. 23. Ms. Barry said terms of the agreement with Eastern were described in a letter sent Friday to the carrier's flight attendants. Also under the agreement: _Eastern agreed the union will continue to represent all Eastern flight attendants and that all future hiring will come from a seniority list. _Eastern will turn over to the union some $340,000 in dues collected from flight attendants working since the strike began. _The union will drop around $215,000 in claims from a longstanding dispute over pay to union representatives while on union business. Of the 3,600 flight attendants now working for Eastern, about half were hired after the strike began. The others are veterans who crossed the picket lines. The union and Eastern still must agree on a new contract to replace the previous one, which expired in 1988. Negotiations are continuing with the pilots union, which ended its sympathy walkout just before the flight attendants. Because of Eastern's downsizing as it strives to emerge from Chapter 11, the number of former strikers who will get their jobs back is in doubt. ``The company blackmailed the flight attendants,'' said Frank Ortis, president of the Machinists' local. ``There are still 3,000 of them out of work, and it looks like they are pretty well broke.''

DOC.HEAD: SCI Television Avoids Bankruptcy, Restructures Debt
DOC.TEXT: SCI Television Inc. has completed a debt exchange offer that will enable the TV station operator to avoid being forced into bankruptcy court proceedings. The Denver-based company, which had been unable to meet interest payments on its buyout-related debt, has been trying for months to negotiate an exchange under which its bank and bond lenders would get an equity stake in the company. ``I think the bondholders got a fair deal,'' said Wilbur Ross, a senior managing director at Rothschild Inc., which was financial advisor to a group of major SCI bondholders. He spoke Monday as the debt exchange was being completed. The deal reduces the stake held by controlling investor George Gillett to 41 percent from 55 percent. It also cuts the SCI stake held by a group led by buyout specialist Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., to 15 percent from 45 percent. A key reason why most bondholders accepted the plan was that Gillett and Kohlberg ``contributed more value to the resolution of the problem than anybody ever has in resuscitating a failed LBO,'' Ross said. In an effort to reduce its debt to manageable proportions, SCI wanted to get at least 85 percent of $100 million in 16{ percent senior subordinated debentures tendered under terms of an exchange offer. Those tendering debt would get new debt securities and stock in the company in return for their bonds. Although it failed to come up with the 85 percent goal by a Monday afternoon deadline, the company said a federal bankruptcy court judge in Delaware ruled that the difference between the target and the 83.9 percent the company actually received was ``not material.'' As a result, the company said the judge dismissed an involuntary bankruptcy petition against SCI that had been filed by a small group of bondholders. SCI Television was created in 1987 and consists of the six television stations once owned by Storer Communications. Kohlberg Kravis led a leveraged buyout of Storer in 1985 and sold the TV stations to the new company for $1.3 billion. But SCI has had trouble generating enough cash from station operations to pay the interest on its debt. It failed to make a $153 million principal payment on its $650 million in bank debt in October, and subsequently missed an interest payment on its $507 million in publicly-held bond debt. On Oct. 25, SCI announced a restructuring plan under which its bondholders would exchange their securities for more debt and stock in the company. In mid-November, a group of three SCI Television creditors unhappy with the plan filed a petition in federal bankrupcty court in Delaware to force the company into involuntary bankruptcy. The petition was filed on behalf of S.N. Phelps & Co. and two individuals who hold about $180,000 in SCI bonds and were owed about $15,000 in interest. In December, SCI proposed a revised debt restructuring plan under which Gillett's stake would fall to 41 percent and Kohlberg Kravis' stake would drop to 15 percent. Bondholders would get a 39 percent stake in the company and bank lenders would get 5 percent. In addition to giving up much of its equity in the company, Ross said Kohlberg Kravis cancelled a $160 million note it was owed. Kohlberg Kravis and Gillett chipped in another $20 million each by contributing their interest in a leasing company that owned the antenna and other equipment used by the SCI stations, Ross said. SCI Television operates stations WSBK in Boston, WJBK in Detroit, WJW in Cleveland, WAGA in Atlanta, KNSD in San Diego and WITI in Milwaukee.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Says SEC Probes Timing of His Lockheed, Georgia Gulf Filings
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire investor Harold C. Simmons says the Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into his acquisitions of Lockheed Corp. and Georgia Gulf Corp. stock, but he said the probe was routine and wouldn't interfere with his plans. Simmons announcement came as Lockheed reported a fourth-quarter loss of $109 million, and the board of the defense contractor affirmed the company's rejection of a request by Simmons for a seat on the board. In a filing with the SEC on Monday, Simmons-controlled companies stated that the probe apparently centered on the timing of their filing of public disclosure documents regarding acquisition of the stock. But Simmons pooh-poohed it all as a routine investigation with which he was cooperating. Simmons said he expected the government's questions to center on whether he intended to mount a takeover of Lockheed from the time he acquired a major interest in the company last April. On Monday, Simmons launched a $1.1 billion takeover bid for Georgia Gulf and said he planned to dump the Atlanta chemical concern's board. On Friday, he said he might seek control of Lockheed's board of directors after the Calabasas, Calif.-based defense contractor rebuffed his bid for representation on the board. In Monday's public filing, Simmons stated the SEC ``is conducting a private investigation regarding trading in certain securities'' of Lockheed and an undisclosed second company. Simmons' SEC filing said the agency had issued subpoenas requesting documents and testimony. SEC spokeswoman Mary McCue declined comment. In an interview with The Associated Press in Dallas, Simmons confirmed that the second company was Georgia Gulf. ``I'm primarily the one being investigated,'' Simmons said. ``We've always filed those (disclosure documents) promptly and told exactly what we knew at the time,'' he said. ``We think this is routine and we think nothing will come of it.'' According to the filing, the Simmons-controlled companies that have acquired Lockheed stock _ 18.9 percent as of Friday _ said the investigation focused primarily on ``the adequacy of disclosures in statements'' to the SEC and ``the timeliness of such filings.'' Those filings, SEC forms known as 13-Ds, require an individual or entity to publicly disclose their stockholdings in a company with 10 days after those holdings total 5 percent or more of the company's outstanding shares. ``There'll be depositions taken later this week and I think we'll be able to answer all those questions,'' said Simmons. Simmons said sworn statements are to be given by him, by Mike Snitzer, president of Valhi Inc., Simmons' major holding company, and by one of Simmons' stock traders.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Earnings Plummet; Board Discusses Simmons Stake
With PM-SEC-Simmons
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. reported a fourth-quarter loss of $109 million as directors of the hard-pressed defense contractor endorsed a decision rejecting billionaire Harold C. Simmons' attempt to get a seat on the board. The results announced Monday came as little surprise to analysts, who predicted a large loss back in November after Lockheed announced it would take a $300 million write-off because of unexpected design changes on a new Navy plane. Lockheed's common stock dropped 75 cents to $38.12{ a share in composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange Monday, meaning that Simmons' paper loss on his 18.9 percent stake in the company continued to grow. The Simmons-controlled investor group NL Industries has bought stock at prices ranging from about $39 to $48 a share. Analyst said they will be watching to see whether the drop in the stock price increases Simmons' resolve to get more control over the Calabasas-based military contractor. Simmons revealed in Securities and Exchange Commission filings that he wants representation on the board. Lockheed Chairman Daniel M. Tellep has opposed such a move, and the company issued a statement saying its board had endorsed the rebuff at a regularly scheduled meeting Monday. Simmons was not available for comment after business hours. ``On paper, this man has lost a great deal of money. I could understand why he would want more of a say in the company,'' Patricia Trent, an analyst with Seidler Amdec, said of Simmons. Lockheed, maker of the radar-evading stealth fighter, reported Monday that net income for 1989 fell to $2 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with $624 million, or $10.37 a share, in 1988. Sales fell to $9.89 billion from $10.43 billion. The 1988 results included a $202 million gain on the sale of Lockheed's DIALOG Information Services unit. Earnings for 1989 were pulled down by the fourth-quarter loss of $109 million, or $1.72 a share, compared with earnings of $104 million, or $1.75 a share, a year earlier. Sales in the latest quarter rose to $3.03 billion from $2.94 billion a year earlier. ``Basically, this is pretty much as telegraphed,'' said Wolfgang Demisch at UBS Securities in New York. Lockheed announced in November that it would take a $300 million pre-tax write-off because of design changes on the P-7A, a submarine-hunting airplane. Development costs on the plane rose because its design will be less like that of its predecessor, the P-3C Orion, than expected, Lockheed said. The company said it still expects to turn a profit once P-7A production begins.

DOC.HEAD: New Chief at Bank of America
DOC.TEXT: Richard M. Rosenberg, whose leadership in California banking helped steer Bank of America from record losses to record profits in three years, has been named successor to departing chairman and chief executive A.W. Clausen. Clausen, who elevated Rosenberg in 1987 after returning to the bank's helm to rescue it from financial crisis, announced Monday that he would retire May 24 as head of the parent company, BankAmerica Corp. ``The job I was called back to do, and which I came back to do, is done,'' Clausen said in a statement. ``The recovery has been accomplished. The turnaround has been completed.'' Reinforcing its turnaround message, BankAmerica also increased its dividend Monday to 25 cents a share from 15 cents on the strength of record 1989 earnings. The departure by Clausen marks the end of his second tour as bank boss. He ended a 32-year career at the bank by serving as president from 1970 to 1981. After a stint as head of the World Bank in Washington, D.C., he returned in 1986 when BankAmerica was mired in deep losses and said he would retire as soon as the bank was strong again. Rosenberg, 59, has served as vice chairman of the board of BankAmerica. The bank said Rosenberg's current postion as head of California banking would be eliminated. The statement described Rosenberg as the architect of the bank's profit resurgence in retail banking, real estate and commercial banking in California. BankAmerica Corp. last month reported 1989 net earnings of $1.1 billion, or $5.19 a share, the highest in its history. Fourth quarter 1989 earnings of $270 million represented the 10th consecutive quarter of higher operating income. In contrast, the bank posted losses totalling $1.8 billion from 1985 through 1987 as it struggled with bad loans to developing countries and troubled domestic real estate loans. ``Dick Rosenberg's record as a banker, a manager, and a leader speaks so strongly for itself that little else needs to be said,'' Clausen said. ``He gives BankAmerica the unique combination of strength, experience, innovation and inspiration that is critical to its success in the constantly changing and increasingly competitive marketplaces of the nineties.'' Clausen recruited Rosenberg in 1987 from a job as president of Seafirst Corp., Washington state's largest bank and a wholly owned subsidiary of BankAmerica. Clausen, 66, will remain a board member and serve as chairman of the executive committee of a new international advisory board.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Oppose Bush on Global Warming Issue
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate Governmental Affairs hearing begins 9:30 a.m. EST; will be led. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is moving too slowly on the global warming problem, say environmentalists who contend he worries too much about industry and not enough about possible environmental disaster in the next century. Bush's speech to an international conference on global warming Monday included ``more talk ... about economics than the environment,'' said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club, calling the president's remarks ``a gross disappointment.'' The administration was likely to get a better reception today when William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, appeared before a Senate committee to endorse the creation of a Cabinet-level Department of the Environment. While that decision is gaining Bush plaudits among environmentalists, his remarks on global warming prompted sharp criticism. Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., a frequent critic of the administration's environmental record, accused the president of ``moving as slow as molasses'' on concerns by many scientists that man-made pollution accumulating in the atmosphere threatens to significantly warm the earth by the middle of the next century. ``What we're hearing is talk of another year of waiting. I expected a lot more concern about the (global warming) problem,'' said Rafe Pomerance of the World Resources Institute. Bush, speaking to the 60-nation Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said, ``Our policies must be consistent with economic growth.'' He complained that in some areas of the debate over the greenhouse effect, ``politics and opinion have outpaced the science.'' ``Our goal continues to be matching policy commitments to emerging scientific knowledge _ and a reconciling of environmental protection to the continued benefits of economic development,'' the president said, promising to convene a White House conference on global warming in the spring. James Tripp, a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, said Bush failed to demonstrate ``the political will necessary to make the United States a leader in the effort to prevent global warming.'' But Tom Lambrix, head of the Global Climate Coalition, an industry group, called Bush's view of global warming ``an appropriate balance.'' ``We need a better understanding of the economic and social implications'' of dealing with global warming, said Lambrix, director of government relations for the Phillips Petroleum Co. The United Nations-sponsored conference of technical experts is meeting to work on a proposed treaty to deal with global warming. Reilly issued a statement saying the president's remarks ``made clear his determination to lead the world in addressing global climate change.'' Bush does not believe it is ``time for a call to arms'' on global warming, but instead favors continued research, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters after the president's remarks. But many environmentalists argue there is enough scientific evidence to warrant a commitment from the United States and other industrial nations to reduce global warming gases, especially carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels. Scientists fear such an accumulation of man-made pollutants will act like a greenhouse, trapping heat and reflecting it back to earth, causing a warming of the globe. Scientists disagree on how severe the warming will become or its effect, although some scientists predict droughts in some interior regions and coastal flooding because of higher ocean levels. Reducing greenhouse gases would require less reliance on coal, oil and natural gas and would require industry to develop more energy-efficient automobiles and industrial plants _ which industry fears could result in widespread economic disruption.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against other major currencies in nervous European trading today. Gold prices were also lower. Dealers said European markets were active following Monday's dollar sell-off in New York. The market sold dollars and bought West Germany marks in response to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal to end the Communists' monopoly on power in his country. The prospect of further democratization in the Soviet Union fueled expectations that last year's political changes in Eastern Europe are irreversible and will stimulate West German growth. Although the dollar remains highly sensitive to Soviet political developments, a Milan trader said the currency was close to bottoming out. ``U.S. interest rates are holding steady and I don't see great possibilities for the dollar to drop much further,'' he said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.70 yen to a closing 144.90 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 144.52 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.6591 West German marks, down from 1.6670; 1.4736 Swiss francs, down from 1.4780; 5.6380 French francs, down from 5.6573; 1.8750 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8880; 1,231.50 Italian lire, down from 1,236.00; and 1.1865 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1891. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.7040 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6980 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $421.20 a troy ounce, down from $423.25 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $421.40. In Zurich, the bid price was $421.25, down from $423.00 bid late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.61 to close at a bid $419.47. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.33 a troy ounce, down from Monday's $5.37.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drops, Stocks Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against the Japanese yen today after a five-day climb, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index inched up. The dollar opened and closed at 144.90 yen, down 0.70 yen from Monday's 145.60-yen finish. In between, it stayed in a narrow range of 144.80 yen to 145.03 yen. The dollar had climbed 2.38 yen in the previous five trading days. Today, ``the dollar-yen trading was very quiet as participants just made position adjustments around 144.90 yen,'' said a Mitsubishi Bank trader, speaking on condition of anonymity. Most Japanese investors were awaiting developments in the Soviet Communist Party meeting that began Monday, he said. Other traders said the dollar's weakness against the yen reflected concern among investors in New York that the Japanese might be less active in the U.S. Treasury Department's quarterly bond auction this week. Reduced Japanese purchases would mean lower demand for dollars to buy the bonds. Stock brokers in Tokyo, however, expected Japanese investors to pick up 30 to 35 percent of the U.S. government bonds, as they usually do. Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co., said expectations that Japanese investors might bid more than previously believed in the bond auction contributed to a rise in the key 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average. The index rose 35.42 points, or 0.09 percent, closing at 37,666.83. It had lost 18.74 points the previous day. After early gains, the index fell in the afternoon as market players sold issues for profit-taking, said Hitoshi Nagasawa, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. The yen's strength and overnight gains in overseas stock markets contributed to the index's early gains, dealers said. Buying also was encouraged by investors' belief that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev has been handling the Central Committee meeting well. Trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 530 million shares, up from Monday's 400 million.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Met to Sell Some Wimpy Restaurants
DOC.TEXT: Grand Metropolitan PLC, the food and liquor giant, said Tuesday it agreed to sell part of its Wimpy hamburger chain to a management team led by a former Wimpy managing director. The price was not announced, but a source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it was about $34 million. The sale includes 216 table-service restaurants in Britain and 140 overseas eateries. Barry Gibbons, chief executive of Grand Met's Burger King Corp. unit, said the Wimpy operations being sold don't ``fit our strategy for the development of the Burger King brand.'' Grand Met spokesman Bill Bullard described the deal as a ``tidy-up.'' He said the company had decided in September to sell the table-service Wimpy restaurants and convert the counter-service shops in Britain to the Burger King brand. Grand Met acquired 529 Wimpy restaurants last August from United Biscuits PLC as part of a $306 million purchase that also included several pizza restaurants.

DOC.HEAD: 3,850 U S West Managers Opt For Early Retirement
DOC.TEXT: An early retirement offer extended by U S West Inc. has been accepted by some 3,850 managers and the final tally is expected to hit 4,000, says Dick McCormick, company president. ``This action balances the company's need to reduce its costs with our commitment to treat these valued employees fairly,'' McCormick said Monday. U S West gave the managers a Jan. 31 deadline to apprise the company of their plans, but several hundred employees were given extensions for varying reasons. By noon Monday, the company had received about 5,700 responses, with slightly more than two-thirds opting for early retirement, said spokesman Dick MacKnight. As of Sept. 30, U S West and its subsidiaries had 23,651 managers, 21,735 of them in companies participating in the early retirement plan. Those who opted to stay face the possibility of a layoff. ``We're going to size this organization appropriately for the market demand,'' said Steve Lang, another U S West spokesman. ``That means we're constantly looking ... and making adjustments.'' Trimming management positions could be part of that adjustment. An in-house announcement of the early retirement program said there probably will be management layoffs in 1990 and that ``involuntary separations'' lay ahead. U S West Communications, U S West Inc.'s largest subsidiary, is conducting the study that will determine where a surplus of management exists. Since American Telephone & Telegraph's court ordered divestiture in 1984, U S West has increased its management staff by nearly 4,000, partly through the acquisition and creation of subsidiaries as well as a loose classification of management jobs. The early retirements should fuel cost savings in the company's telecommunications business, McCormick said in a news release. The company reported a 2.4 percent decline in earnings per share from 1988 to 1989. The early retirements are expected to help U S West achieve earning goals in 1990 and beyond, he said. ``We plan to invest a significant portion of the savings in long term projects that will allow us to serve our customers even better,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Late-January Truck Sales Rise, Car Sales Fall; Where From Here?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 1988 to 1989 in 4th and 14th grafs.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Automakers pared their new-car inventories sharply last month by cutting production and offering incentives, giving them room to boost manufacturing schedules somewhat to prepare for spring. The eight major U.S. automakers on Monday reported a 1.5 percent decline in car and truck sales during late January. A 6.6 percent drop in car sales during Jan. 21-31 was offset largely by an 8.1 percent increase in light truck sales. Analysts said the figures were better than they appeared because sales in the year-earlier period were inflated by a special factor. During all of January, when General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. shut down assembly and supplier plants for at least a week at a time, combined car and truck sales by the eight domestic makers were up 6.2 percent from January 1989. Sales of imported cars and trucks fell 6.1 percent in January. ``It looks like we just went from 97 days worth of supply on December 31 to about 65 at the end of January,'' said analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. of New York City. ``Sales have run 80 percent ahead of production. ``That's something I've never seen before in a January period,'' he added. Automakers usually let inventories build a little in February as they prepare for what usually is an increased buying pace in March and April. ``The key now is how you manage it,'' Brady said. ``You nudge up production and nudge back incentives and find a happy medium.'' Many of the Big Three plants that were shut down in January are returning to production this month. But in March, GM and Chrysler will make some permanent cuts by slowing line speeds, eliminating shifts or, in the case of GM's Atlanta assembly plant, shutting down an entire factory indefinitely. All told, the two companies have announced indefinite layoffs that will idle about 15,400 workers at 11 plants between January and September. Incentives last month appeared to be most effective in boosting truck sales, especially Chrysler minivans. The nation's No. 3 automaker on Dec. 15 offered cash rebates and low-interest financing for the first time on its Dodge Caravan, Plymouth Voyager and Chrysler Town and Country minivans. The incentives on the minivans ended last Wednesday, but Chrysler has continued the offers on other cars and trucks. Results in late January 1989 were inflated somewhat by heavy fleet sales, a condition analysts said made this year's late January figures look relatively encouraging. Typically, a large percentage of January and February car sales go to fleets, including auto rental companies and large corporations. But this year, because of severe cuts in production last month, fleet deliveries were put off. ``January a year ago was an especially strong fleet sales month for Ford,'' said Robert Rewey, vice president for Ford Motor Co.'s North American Automotive Operations. ``Due to downtime at a number of our plants in the early part of this January, assembly and shipment of many fleet units was delayed.'' Chrysler said its late-January truck sales rose 42.7 percent from sales during the same time last year. For all of January, Chrysler's truck sales were up 39.7 percent from January 1989. GM's truck sales rose 6.8 percent in late January and 11.8 percent for the whole month. Ford said its truck sales fell 8.2 percent during the period and 1 percent for the month.

The stock market pulled back today, following two consecutive advances. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose nearly 20 points on Monday, was down 9.23 at 2,613.29 after 30 minutes of trading. Declining issues outpaced gainers by a margin of 5 to 3 among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with 322 up, 543 down and 555 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 19.91 million shares at 10 a.m. on Wall Street compared with 17.6 million shares at the same point in Monday's session. Stock prices have risen in three of the past four sessions after sinking for most of the month of January. But the prospect of rising interest rates has limited the price gains, making yields on short-term Treasury securities more competitive with those available in the stock market. The financial community has been focused in recent days on the Treasury's impending auction of $30 billion in new securities. That auction begins later today with the sale of $10 billion in three-year notes. The three-year note sale will be followed by a $10 billion auction of 10-year notes on Wednesday and the sale of $10 billion in 30-year bonds on Thursday. Rates have risen over the past few days as many dealers feel that higher rates are needed to make sure that foreign investors, particularly the Japanese, buy a sizeable portion of the new issues. Rates have risen in Japan in recent weeks, making them more competitive with those available in the U.S. Among the early active issues on the NYSE, Pan Am was up [ at 3~, Bank of New England was up [ at 5~ and IBM was up { at 100[. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was off 0.54 at 182.81. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 0.24 at 354.46. On Monday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.82 points to 2,622.52. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed stocks, with 838 up, 646 down and 490 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 130.95 million shares, against 164.40 million in the previous session. That was the lowest since 128.03 million shares changed hands on Dec. 28, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Gulf Board Considering Simmons' Offer
DOC.TEXT: Georgia Gulf Corp., facing a $1.1 billion bid from Texas investor Harold Simmons, said today its board is considering the offer and will recommend by the end of the week whether shareholders should accept or reject the proposal. NL Industries Inc., a chemical supply company controlled by Simmons, began a $45 a share tender offer today for the 91 percent of Georgia Gulf it does not already own. NL said Monday it was also planning a proxy fight aimed at replacing the Atlanta chemical maker's board of directors with a slate of candidates more sympathetic to NL's position. Georgia Gulf Chairman James R. Kuse said in a letter to shareholders today the company's board and legal advisers were considering Simmons' bid. ``The board of directors encourages you to defer your decision whether to accept or reject NL Industries' offer until you have had the benefit of and reflected on the company's recommendation,'' Kuse said. Simmons has been eyeing Georgia Gulf since last summer, but the Atlanta company in January launched a recapitalization plan apparently designed to fend off Simmons. The value of that plan has been estimated by Georgia Gulf at about $55 a share. Houston-based NL, announcing its tender offer last week, said it was pursuing the acquisition because company officials believed the recapitalization, under current market conditions, would yield less than $45 a share.

DOC.HEAD: British Entrepreneur Maxwell to Set Up Investment Fund
DOC.TEXT: British entrepreneur Robert Maxwell said he would set up a $1 billion investment fund to finance joint ventures in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Maxwell told an international business conference late Monday the fund would be established by his London and Bishopsgate Investment Management PLC, according to a press release issued by the organizers of the annual World Economic Forum. Maxwell said the partnership will invest in East Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania, Poland and the Soviet Union. The release said a more detailed announcement giving names of the other partners in the fund would be made shortly.

Stock prices retreated broadly today, as investors waited to see what implications the first leg of a three-stage Treasury securities auction may have for the direction of interest rates. Trading was sluggish although activity picked up slightly from Monday, w| txowes| w to 4 among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with 416 up, 778 down and 513 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 43.96 million shares at 11 a.m. on Wall Street compared with 42.10 million shares at the same point Monday. But the prospect of rising interest rates has limited the price gains, making yields on short-term Treasury securities more competitive with those available on stocks and dimming chances for corporate earnings growth.
