DOC.HEAD: Administration Weighing in With Proposals for New Farm Law
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today sent Congress a package of recommendations for new farm legislation but did not spell out how commodity programs should be reduced in order to meet federal spending cutbacks next year. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter told a news conference the proposals dealt only with farm policy and did not address budget problems. He said if all the proposals were approved, they would have ``nominal impact'' on consumer food prices. One of the most controversial items facing the administration is how to cut fiscal 1991 commodity spending by $1.5 billion, a level included in the budget proposals President Bush sent to Congress last week. However the budget message said only that the White House ``is prepared to work closely'' with lawmakers on the $1.5 billion reduction in commodity programs. Yeutter said administration policy-makers ``do not intend to make specific recommendations'' on how to cut programs by $1.5 billion but will work that out with Congress when the time comes. He is scheduled to testify before the Senate Agriculture Committee on Wednesday. Between 60 and 70 specific recommendations were submitted to Congress, about 90 percent of which will require legislation, he said. Yeutter said the administration's plan calls for greater production flexibility and decision-making by farmers, allowing them greater choice on crops to grow under annual commodity programs. The package also included a recommendation for eliminating the department's Federal Crop Insurance Corp., which provides subsidized all-risk coverage to farmers, and replacing it with permanent disaster assistance. But Yeutter said the administration would listen to Congress in case there an alternate solution is sought. Another major question is what to do with the department's Federal Crop Insurance Corp., which provides subsidized all-risk coverage to farmers. The agency has been losing money for many years, with many farmers spurning the insurance and relying on Congress to bail them out with emergency legislation in case of drought, floods and other disasters. Yeutter says farmers can't have it both ways and that one or the other of the programs _ insurance or emergency aid _ has to go. The Bush budget recommended scrapping the insurance program in the 1991 fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1. The administration decided some time ago not to send a formally drafted farm bill to Capitol Hill to succeed the 1985 law that will expire at the end of the 1990 crop season. Instead, a series ``concept papers'' or guidelines has been prepared. Yeutter and others have lauded the Food Security Act of 1985, the current farm law, for helping make U.S. commodities more competitive in world trade, thus enhancing the nation's export position. The 1985 law has helped with its authority for lowering federal price supports and target-price benefits due farmers. The Bush budget said there could be substantial savings if these declines ``were continued or even accelerated'' by the 1990 farm bill. ``We must make certain that our commodity programs have enough flexibility to allow farmers to grow crops that consumers want, instead of crops that the government dictates,'' Yeutter said Monday. ``This, in concert with a stronger U.S. trading stance in world markets for agricultural commodities and products, will go a long way toward keeping the agrarian economy robust,'' he told the National Rural Electric Cooperative Assn. in Orlando, Fla. Most major farm organizations have already taken stands on some of the major issues involved in 1990 farm legislation. The American Farm Bureau Federation, for example, has been a strong supporter of the 1985 law's emphasis on greater market orientation by setting price supports in line with domestic and global competition. A federation position paper distributed Monday called for maintaining ``the general direction'' set by the 1985 farm law. It also urged greater acreage flexibility under federal commodity programs. The federation said price support loan rates, which act as a market floor for major crops such as wheat and feed grains, should continue to be tied to a percentage of the average price of the commodity over the past several years. But the federation said target prices used to compute ``deficiency payments'' to farmers when markets falter should be frozen at 1990 levels. ``Additional reductions would result in an unacceptable lowering of farm income,'' the federation said. The National Farmers Union says the 1990 farm bill should provide government muscle to ``sustain family-size farm operation; promote environmentally safe stewardship of the land; provide nutrition assistance for low-income citizens; and enhance the viability of rural communities.'' Generally, the NFU favors supply management concepts, not the looser ``market-oriented'' themes sought by the administration and the Farm Bureau. For example, the NFU's own farm bill would tie the target price of wheat to ``the full cost of production, plus a reasonable rate of return, on a commodity base which will sustain a family-sized unit.''

DOC.HEAD: Trial Opens in Lotus Suit Alleging Copyright Infringement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with trial started. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Paul Gupta ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp. went to federal court today to prove that two competitors copied its popular business spreadsheet program in a suit that could clarify copywrite laws for computer software. Lotus, which says its lawsuit aims to protect computer innovations, began the case by demonstrating its Lotus 1-2-3 program to the court. Using video screens, the company showed the basic steps for setting up financial statements, graphs and mortgage projections by inserting numbers into various columns and rows. Lotus filed suit in 1987 against Paperback Software International of Berkeley, Calif., and Mosaic Software of Cambridge, claiming a copyright infringement of the ``look and feel'' of Lotus' popular 1-2-3 program. The case centers on what protection should be given to images that appear on a computer screen and the commands associated with the program _ known as the ``user interface.'' ``A lot of people are looking at the case to make a decision on the issue,'' said Ned Saltzberg, a Boston lawyer and editor of the Computer Law Newsletter. Legal experts say the inner workings of the program are protected by copyright laws, but Lotus argues that the computer screen display constitutes an expression of an idea and thus falls under copyright protection. ``Lotus is alleging these companies copied keystroke for keystroke the spreadsheet modules for 1-2-3,'' said Bryan Simmons, a spokesman for the Cambridge-based company. The 1-2-3 menus provide users with options such as ``file,'' ``print,'' ``copy,'' and ``combine,'' and keyboard buttons are punched to activate those options. Paul Gupta, a lawyer representing Paperback Software, said ``what appears on a menu does not constitute expression. Where you've got a simple list of words on a screen, it's not enough to call it copyrightable.'' Gupta said Paperback Software, to some extent, had its hands tied in the development of its VP-Planner spreadsheet program. In order to make a product that is compatible with Lotus 1-2-3, the company had to use technologies that result in similar computer images and commands, he said. ``Where we had the opportunity to make changes, we did,'' he said. In fact, Paperback Software says by building on Lotus' system, the company was following a pattern in the computer industry, in which borrowed ideas have led to innovations. Adam Osborne, president of the company, noted that Lotus modeled 1-2-3 after a previous program, VisiCalc, and he said his firm has made further improvements. ``They had to hobble us with legal processes,'' he said. Officials at Mosaic Software were not available for comment Monday. But Simmons, at Lotus, said a ruling in his company's favor would not stifle innovation, but would do the opposite. Without the copyright protection, an entrepreneur might not experiment with new products for fear that a big company will swallow up the idea, he said. ``Lotus believes this will encourage innovators to take risks,'' Simmons said. Also, he said, companies can use the idea of a business spreadsheet, but do not need to copy each other's material in order to compete. Other spreadsheets, such as Microsoft Excel, are ``very different from our product,'' he said. ``It comes down to, `Are you building on an idea or building on an expression of an idea?''' he said. Lee Gesmer, a partner with the Boston law firm of Lucash, Gesmer & Updegrove, which publishes the Technology Law Bulletin, said he expects Lotus to win the case, based on recent similar decisions. But perhaps more importantly, Saltzberg said the case should give software designers a better idea of what is and isn't permissible. ``As long as the rules are clear, people can abide by them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures Open Mixed; New Demand Seen
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, with technical weakness offset by signs of strengthening foreign demand. Wheat futures were slightly lower, corn was a little higher and soybeans were narrowly mixed. The technical sell signals included Monday's lower close. Analysts said the markets could test recent lows today. But several weeks of falling prices have caught the attention of foreign buyers, and prospects for export business are improving, said William Biedermann, director of research for the futures brokerage Allendale Inc. The Agriculture Department on Monday approved a sale of 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat to China at subsidized prices, and a number of other countries _ including El Salvador, Pakistan, Zambia, Iraq and Taiwan _ are in the market for U.S. grains and soybean products, he said. In early trading, wheat futures prices were 1\ cents to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.81} a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $2.37 a bushel; oat futures were uncanged to { cent lower with March at $1.34} a bushel; soybean futures were { cent lower to { cent higher with March at $5.59 a bushel. Cattle futures advanced while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .08 cent to .25 cent higher with February at 79.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .40 cent higher with March at 83.35 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent lower to .02 cent higher with February at 48.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .43 cent higher with February at 50.95 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled higher across the board on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Grocer Reports Smaller Quarterly Net Loss But Bigger Annual Loss
DOC.TEXT: Kroger Co. on Tuesday said it lost $45.9 million in the fourth quarter due to an extraordinary loss of $51.3 million from writing off debt incurred in its 1988 restructuring. The fourth-quarter loss, which came to 56 cents a share, compared to a loss of $119 million, or $1.57 a share, in the final three months of 1988 when a $128.7 million after-tax restructuring charge was taken. The supermarket and convenience store company said that excluding the extraordinary loss it earned $5.3 million, or 7 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 30. Sales edged about 0.1 percent higher to $4.653 billion in the fourth quarter from $4.648 billion in 1988's fourth quarter. But not counting sales at stores divested since the fourth quarter of 1988, total sales were up 8.3 percent. Kroger in 1988 carried out a $4.6 billion restructuring to fight off takeover attempts. Joseph Pichler, Kroger's president and chief operating officer, said ``The continuing units of Kroger are managing expenses and cash flow with great dedication, and this is showing in our results,'' For all of last year, Kroger said it lost $72.7 million, or 92 cents a share, compared to $34.5 million, or 24 cents a share, in 1988. Before a$56.5 million extraordinary loss from early payment of debt and the write-off of deferred costs associated with 1988's restructuring, Kroger's 1989 loss was $16.25 million, or 23 cents a share. Sales for the year were $19.1 billion, compared with $19 billion in 1988. Kroger said its proceeds from divestitures and improved operating results were better than anticipated and allowed the company to reduce its outstanding debt and retire its preferred stock for a total of $372 million, including $125 million of scheduled payments. A new credit agreement negotiated during the last quarter gave Kroger more favorable credit terms and replaced portions of its debt with lower interest, longer term debt, the company said. ``Kroger maintained its strong market position and responded to the needs of our customers, and in doing so we were able to set the stage for continued growth in 1990 and beyond,'' said Lyle Everingham, Kroger's chairman and chief executive. The company owns and operates supermarkets, convenience stores and food processing plants in 32 states, mostly in the Midwest and South.

DOC.HEAD: Virgin Atlantic Starts Non-Smoking Flights Across Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Virgin Atlantic Airways announced Tuesday it is introducing completely non-smoking flights between New York and London starting May 18. Virgin, owned by British entrepreneur Richard Branson, said it is the first airline to offer such service between the two cities. The airline said increasing passenger demand for smoke-free flights prompted the move. Other trans-Atlantic carriers are also considering non-smoking flights. Congress passed a bill last November banning smoking on virtually all U.S. domestic flights effective Feb. 25. International flights, however, usually offer smoking sections. ``This is the first clear alternative to non-smoking sections, which are never completely satisfactory for today's health-conscious traveler,'' Virgin said in a statement. The airline said it will introduce a second flight between Newark, N.J., and Gatwick Airport outside London on Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays to accommodate the new non-smoking service. Virgin will continue to offer smoking and non-smoking sections on its other daily flights to London out of Newark and John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York. London-based Virgin said it hoped to extend the non-smoking service later to its flights to and from Tokyo, Los Angeles, Miami and Kennedy Airport if the idea is well received by passengers.

DOC.HEAD: R.P. Scherer Sells PACO Pharmaceutical Services of New Jersey
DOC.TEXT: R.P. Scherer Corp., the world's largest gelatin capsule maker, has signed a letter of intent to sell its PACO Pharmaceutical Services Inc. division to a management-led investor group, Scherer said Tuesday. The buyer is an investor group led by PACO President Russell Haines and Tullis Cook & Co. The price was about $39 million in cash and debt assumption, a news release said. The investors still must line up financial backing and win federal approval. Specific terms of the transaction, to be completed within four months, were withheld. The PACO sale is one of a series of Scherer divestitures the company undertook after it was bought by an investor group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. in May 1989. Three other Scherer subsidiaries, making up its Diversified Health Care Group, were sold earlier. PACO, based in Lakewood, N.J., packages and makes pharmaceutical and other consumer products.

DOC.HEAD: Yes, You Can Afford A House
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes you have to watch what you say, because people might take you too seriously. For several years the National Association of Realtors has promoted the idea _ particularly through its so-called affordability index _ that houses are unaffordable for a large percentage of potential buyers. The index is a product of five financial elements involved in owning a house, the most important of them being median household income, the median price of the ``typical'' single-family home and the level of interest rates. If prices and interest rates rise while income remains the same or falls, or even if income rises but not sufficiently to offset increases in other factors, affordability is said to fall. In December, for instance, the index measured 108.2, up from 105.5 in November, boosted to that level mainly by declines in mortgage rates. Since then, rates have risen. January's index seems destined to fall. It's the declines that create the problems, because they suggest that good, sound American families are being denied the right to live as good, average American families. The issue is almost a sacred one. Never mind that at 108.2, the December index meant a family earning the national median of $33,600 had 108.2 percent of income needed to qualify for a conventional mortgage of 80 percent on a home priced at $92,500. Many housing people find the measure useful as a trend indicator. But many buyers and sellers, even realtors, and sometimes the media make a different interpretation. They stress the UNaffordability aspect of the index. The index does suggest, for example, that while your family might be close to typical in income, you still might not be able to afford a typical house if local prices are higher than the national median. It also says that millions of other American households cannot qualify for the typically priced house, because 50 percent of them don't earn as much as the median income. When the index falls, that aspect is heavily stressed. In the past, in fact, it was stressed very heavily by the realtors, especially when issues affecting housing were discussed in Washington, and particularly when the index dropped below 100, as in 1983 and 1984. At times, the unaffordability of housing was promoted by various housing and real estate groups as a national disgrace, as something that demanded immediate correction, perhaps through the tax system. Other groups have since picked up the cry and the issue of ``affordable housing'' is a huge one now, and generally the stress is on the lack of affordable housing. It is a widespread perception, often accepted uncritically. Many Americans who otherwise feel typical now are convinced housing is beyond their financial reach. Some have become market dropouts, ignoring the fact that thousands of houses are available for under the typical price. In response, a grass roots campaign has begun in the Northeast, where prices are relatively high and the unaffordability attitude is entrenched. It's called, `Yes You Can,'' meaning, yes, you can buy a home. It seems destined to spread. It originated in Springfield, Mass. in 1982, when high interest rates undermined the market. Big inventories convinced The Greater Springfield Association of Realtors to resurrect the campaign in 1989. Iy has now been adopted in New Jersey, where the state association says it plans to spend $250,000 in the media and on billboards to promote its own campaign, ``Yes, You Can Buy a House in New Jersey.'' In the realtors' national trade paper, ``Realtor News,'' which carries the index, a member states that the industry has to change consumer perceptions about unaffordability. The member explained that ``many are not hearing from the press that affordable homes and financing are available.''

DOC.HEAD: United Telecom Says US Sprint Continues To Grow, But Profit Down
DOC.TEXT: United Telecommunications Inc. said Tuesday its profit declined sharply during 1988's fourth quarter, but that its revenue jumped 15 percent, thanks mostly to continued growth at its US Sprint long-distance phone company. Profit was hurt by the comparison with a strong 1988 fourth quarter, when United Telecom reported an after-tax gain of $369 million from the sale of its cellular phone and paging operations. But profit from continuing operations grew, the company said, to $101.4 million from $10.7 million during the fourth quarter of 1988. United Telecom had net profit of $101.4 million, or 48 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with $379.5 million, or $1.85 a share, during the same period of 1988. Revenue for the quarter jumped to $2 billion, compared with $1.7 billion during the same period a year earlier. For all of 1989, profit fell to $363 million, down from $509 million in 1988, also because of the sale of the cellular and paging units, the company said. For the year, overall revenue jumped to $7.5 billion, from $6.5 billion in 1988. U.S. Sprint Communications Co., the nation's third-largest long-distance company with about 8 percent of the domestic market, reported fourth-quarter revenue of $1.2 billion, 28 percent more than the $930 million reported in the fourth quarter of 1988. It was the company's third straight quarter of billion-dollar sales. Sprint's fourth-quarter operating income jumped to $81 million, compared with an operating loss of $176 million in 1988's fourth quarter. For the year, Sprint had operating income of $227 million, compared with a 1988 operating loss of $386 million. Operating revenue for 1989 totaled $4.3 billion, up 27 percent from 1988's $3.4 billion. ``We have every reason to believe the progress in our 1989 performance will continue into 1990,'' said William T. Esrey, president and chief executive officer of United Telecom. He noted that Sprint's fourth-quarter revenue reflected only minimal impact from a contract the company won last year to provide 40 percent of a new telephone system for the federal government. Esrey has said that the federal government soon will be Sprint's largest customer. In addition to its 80 percent ownership of Sprint, Kansas City-based United Telecom owns companies that provide local phone service in the South and Midwest. The rest of Sprint is owned by GTE Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Devalues Currency For Foreign Transactions
DOC.TEXT: The interim government on Tuesday announced a sharp devaluation of the lei and set a single exchange rate aimed at better reflecting the currency's real value and helping repair decades of chaotic monetary policies. The devaluation also was aimed at spurring exports by making Romanian products relatively cheaper in foreign markets. The ruling Executive Bureau of the National Salvation Front set new exchange rates against hard currencies, pegged to a dollar rate of 21 lei. The previous rates were 8.74 lei to the dollar for non-commercial transactions and 14.23 lei for commercial transactions. However, the official rate remains below black market dollar rates now averaging about 80 lei. The currency decree dated Feb. 1 was not published until Tuesday, when the new list of exchange rates appeared in the newspaper Romania Libera. The decree said it was aimed at rectifying an ``abnormal situation,'' and making the lei's value more realistic. The devaluation was announced less than 24 hours after the Executive Bureau, which has been running the country since dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was toppled Dec. 22, issued another decree legalizing free enterprise on a much larger scale than existed during 45 years of Communist rule. The decree, the most far-reaching consumer-oriented measure since December's revolution, will allow the existence of profit-making businesses with up to 20 employees. Under the old system, tradesmen could employ only up to three people and taxes were punitive. Under Ceausescu, the dollar-lei exchange rate was set artificially high in favor of the lei, in an apparent attempt to have it reflect what the dictator touted as Romania's economic strength. The single exchange rate that will replace the previous multiple lei rates will be set weekly by the National Bank of Romania to reflect the dollar's value on international markets. The lei rate for other hard currencies will be determined by their rate in relation to the dollar. For example, the West German mark's rate has increased from 5.17 lei at the end of January to 12.50 lei starting Feb. 1, as that currency has strengthened against the dollar. The new decree does not apply to Soviet rubles or other non-freely convertible currencies from countries that have established bilateral or multilateral agreements with fixed lei rates. The new rates are expected to stimulate exports, but imports will be more expensive in lei so the government has created a special fund to meet the increased cost, the newspaper said. ``What is important is that internal prices for consumer goods will not be changed. Tourism is thus stimulated,'' the paper said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished lower against most major currencies in European trading Tuesday, depressed by broad interest in the West German mark and worries about the U.S. Treasury's quarterly financing operation this week. Gold was lower. The dollar was quoted at 1.6570 Deutsche marks Tuesday afternoon, down from 1.6670 late Monday in London. Dealers said confidence in the dollar has been shaken by uncertainty over Japanese interest in sales of 10-year and 30-year Treasury securities on Wednesday and Thursday. However, they said the primary action in the market has been a broad return to marks after a bout of short-dollar covering against the West German currency. ``There was a bit of a short squeeze'' on the dollar, said John Wastell, a corporate dealer at Bank of America in London. ``But we expect the dollar to stay under pressure. The covering has cleared room for fresh selling'' against the mark. Wastell said interest in buying marks against the yen is underpinned to some degree by technical factors, including the mark's move through 87.15 yen early in the day. In late London dealings, the cross-rate was around 87.56 yen with some dealers predicting a move toward 87.80 yen before some profit taking might surface. While the dollar weakened against the yen, dealers anticipate the U.S. currency will remain firm in the run-up to Japanese national elections on Feb. 18. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.70 yen to close at 144.90 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 145.10 yen. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.4770 Swiss francs, down from 1.4780; 5.6405 French francs, down from 5.6573; 1.8680 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8880; 1,235.00 Italian lire, down from 1,236.00; and 1.1874 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1891. The British pound rose to $1.7015 from $1.6980 late Monday. Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $420.85 a troy ounce, down from $432.25 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold closed at $420.75, down from $423 bid late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.61 to close at a bid $419.47. Silver bullion traded at a late bid price of $5.31 a troy ounce Tuesday, down from $5.37 bid late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Fall Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stocks finished sharply lower in London Tuesday, as an early drop on Wall Street sent British shares spiraling downwards. Prices in New York fell broadly lower in the first hour of trading, as the market took its cues from weakness in the bond market ahead of Tuesday's first phase of the U.S. Treasury bond auctions. By the close of the European business day, the Dow Jones industrial average had slumped 26.57 points to 2,595.95. A round of futures-related sell programs contributed to New York's retreat, taking London equities with it, traders said. ``There have been too many downgradings, there's too much stock around and nobody wants to buy this market,'' said a dealer at a major U.S. brokerage firm in London. Dealers said selling spanned the entire spectrum of stocks. By the end of the session, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was 27.3 points, or 1.2 percent, lower at 2,321.1 after having reached 2,345.4 earlier in the day. Volume came to a light 406.9 million shares, compared with 378.9 million shares Monday.

Stock prices drifted at broadly lower levels this afternoon, weighed down by concerns about rising interest rates. Trading activity was moderate, picking up the pace from Monday which was the slowest trading day of the new year. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose 19.82 points on Monday and 36.26 over the past two sessions, was down 25.00 at 2,597.52 with two hours left in the session. Declining issues outpaced gainers by a margin of 2 to 1 among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with 446 up, 960 down and 504 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 96.50 million shares at 2 p.m. EST compared with 87.48 million shares at the same point Monday. Stock prices have risen in three of the past four sessions after sinking for most of the month of January. But the prospect of rising interest rates has limited the price gains, making yields on short-term Treasury securities more competitive with those available on stocks and dimming chances for corporate earnings growth. In the credit markets today, rates edged up on six-month Treasury bills while yields on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to the 8.56 percent level from 8.53 percent late Monday. The financial community has been focused in recent days on the Treasury's impending auction of $30 billion in new securities. The results of the first part of the auction are expected to be announced later today with the sale of $10 billion in three-year notes. That will be followed by a $10 billion auction of 10-year notes on Wednesday and the sale of $10 billion in 30-year bonds on Thursday. DOC.HEAD: OPEC Production Lower in January; Still Above Output Ceiling
DOC.TEXT: OPEC slashed oil production last month but not enough to meet its promised goal, according to estimates released Tuesday. The International Energy Agency said in its Monthly Oil Market Report that the 13 OPEC nations produced about 23.3 million barrels of crude oil a day in January. That was about 00,000 barrels below December's peak levels but still well above the 22-million-barrel limit OPEC pledged late last year. The bulk of the reduction occurred in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, the report said. The ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pledged last November to cut daily production to 22 million barrels for the first half of 1990. Although the ceiling was 20.5 million barrels a day in the final quarter of 1989, actual production had reached 24 million barrels a day in December boosted by excess flow from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Analysts had expected the producing nations to rein in production even more in January to try to meet the new production cap. Nonetheless, the continued brisk flow has not depressed prices as some had predicted. World oil prices, in fact, soared early in January although they have eased slightly since then. The average price of a basket of crudes monitored by OPEC was $19.56 a barrel in the last week of January, down from $20.46 in the first week of the month. OPEC's target price is $18 a barrel. On the futures market, West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, has been trading in the range of $22 to $23 a barrel, higher than the $20 to $21 range in December. ``Although OPEC's crude oil output in January has been well above the expectations based on the new production ceilings set by OPEC, the oil market has not yet shown any significant indications of oversupply,'' said the energy agency report. Analysts suggested OPEC production might even increase. Nick Antill, analyst at the London firm of County NatWest, said he had a ``strong suspicion'' that this month's output would show ``little change'' from January. He said there has been ``no serious effort to cut'' back on production. Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris-based newsletter Petrostrategies, predicted production would be higher in February. ``It is increasing ... That is undeniable,'' he said. Some analysts believe key producing countries want to keep prices around the $18 mark partly to discourage non-OPEC countries from muscling in on their share of the world oil market. Higher prices could attract more producers. Lower production would likely drive up prices, some argue, given the strong demand. Conversely, strong production would tend to weaken them. The energy agency estimated demand for OPEC oil would shrink from an estimated 22.7 million barrels a day in the first quarter of this year to 19.8 million barrels in the second three months. Total world demand was estimated at 53.9 million barrels a day in the January-March period and 51 million barrels in the April-June period. The report estimated production by Saudi Arabia, the world's largest crude oil exporter, at 5.3 million barrels a day last month, in line with its individual output quota for the first half of the year. Production by the United Arab Emirates was estimated at 2 million barrels a day in January, over its cap of 1.1 million barrels. Kuwait's output was recorded at 1.7 million barrels, above its limit of 1.5 million barrels. In December, output was put at 2.3 million barrels for the UAE and 2 million barrels for Kuwait. The agency set Iran's supply at 2.9 million barrels a day in January and Iraq's at 3.1 million barrels a day. Each has a quota of 3.1 million barrels. Other estimates for January production were: Qatar, 400,000 barrels a day; Nigeria, 1.8 million barrels; Libya, 1.2 million barrels; Algeria, 800,000 barrels; Gabon, 200,000 barrels; Venezuela, 1.9 million barrels; Ecuador, 300,000 barrels; and Indonesia, 1.3 million barrels. The International Energy Agency is an arm of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, made up of 24 Western nations.
