DOC.HEAD: Washington Post Co. Records Higher Profit for 4th Qtr, Decline for Year
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post Co. said Tuesday its fourth-quarter profit climbed 38.4 percent from a year ago, while its earnings for the year dropped 26.5 percent. For the three months ended Dec. 31, Washington Post said it earned $51.1 million, or $4.06 a share, compared with $36.9 million, or $2.87 a share, a year ago. The increase in the latest quarter would have been only 3 percent if restructuring charges at Newsweek magazine were excluded from the 1988 results. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 2.9 percent to $381.4 million from $370.8 million in 1988. For the year, the company said it earned $197.9 million, or $15.50 a share, compared with $269.1 million, or $20.91 a share, a year ago. Included in the 1988 earnings was a non-recurring gain of $103.1 million after taxes from the sale of the company's interests in cellular telephone operations, partially offset by restructuring charges at Newsweek magazine. Excluding the non-recurring items, net income increased by 19 percent and earnings per share jumped 20 per share in 1989. Revenue for 1989 totaled $1.44 billion, up 5.6 percent from $1.37 billion in 1988. Operating income from the newspaper division increased 25.5 percent to $176.6 million from 1988 levels, while the broadcast division was up 11.9 percent at $72.1 million and the cable division rose 27.6 percent to $26.1 million from the previous year. Operating income at Newsweek rose 40 percent to $28.2 million for the year from $20.1 million before restructuiring charges in 1988. Advertising volume at The Washington Post newspaper rose 1.1 percent for the year while ad revenue rose 7.4 percent. The Washington Post Co. also owns The Herald in Everett, Wash., four television stations and about 50 cable TV systems.

DOC.HEAD: Ben & Jerry's Homemade President Chico Lager Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS typos in 1st and 7th grafs.
DOC.TEXT: The president and chief executive officer of Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. will resign at the end of the year, company chairman Ben Cohen said. Fred ``Chico'' Lager said he will step down at the end of 1990. Chuck Lacey, the company's current general manager, is to replace Lager as president and become the company's chief operating officer. Cohen will remain as board chairman and assume the new title of chief executive officer. Lager started working for the socially conscious premium ice cream maker in 1982 as the company's first general manager after owning and operating Hunt's, a Burlington nightclub. ``I've been contemplating this move for some time,'' he said. ``I'm looking forward to taking some time off and working for a while at a more relaxed pace.'' Lager said he may pursue writing or teaching. ``I wouldn't rule out running another small business in the future, but I'm in no rush to get involved in another totally engrossing project.'' He'll also remain on the Ben & Jerry's board and work as a consultant to the company. Cohen praised Lager's ``managerial expertise and leadership that allowed us to grow successfully at an incredible rate.'' Sales have increased from less than $1 million in 1982, when Lager joined the company, to more than $50 million now, Cohen said. Lacey, a 1980 Amherst College graduate with a master's degree from the Cornell University business school, joined the company in 1989 after working for an upstate New York hospital chain.

DOC.HEAD: BAT To Open Bidding For Field's and Saks Retail Chains
DOC.TEXT: A proud and vital chunk of Chicago history goes on the auction block this week as BAT Industries PLC opens the bidding for the Marshall Field and Co. department store chain. At least half a dozen parties, including Field's management, are expected to join the bidding for the 135-year-old retailer, which has 24 stores in four states. The process begins Thursday when the investment firm Goldman Sachs & Co. hands out confidential prospectuses to potential bidders for both Field's and the larger Saks Fifth Avenue chain, according to a spokeswoman for Batus Inc., a subsidiary of BAT based in Louisville, Ky. London-based BAT hopes to announce the winning bids sometime in May, the spokeswoman said Tuesday. Observers have estimated Marshall Field will fetch $600 million to $1 billion, while some analysts have estimated that Saks could fetch upwards of $1.2 billion. BAT shareholders in October approved a plan to sell the company's U.S. retailing operations in a restructuring designed to thwart a $21.7 billion hostile takeover bid led by Anglo-French financier Sir James Goldsmith. BAT has owned Field's since 1982. Ironically, one of Goldsmith's backers is Frederick W. Field, a descendant of Field's founder. Field's Chairman Philip B. Miller and May Department Stores Co. have said publicly they want to buy Field's. Others reportedly interested in the chain include Dillard Department Stores Inc., Dayton Hudson Corp., JMB Realty Corp. and several U.S. investment firms representing foreign interests. The winner will get a thriving, determinedly upscale chain that commands 15 percent of the crowded Chicago retail market despite stiff competition from Bloomingdale's, Nieman-Marcus, Saks and others. Miller moved to Field's from the president's office of Nieman-Marcus in 1983. He engineered a financial turnaround at Field's, overseen an extensive remodeling of the company's flagship store on State Street and expanded its reach into Ohio and Texas. The company also has stores in Wisconsin. The prospective bid by Miller in conjunction with a yet-to-be identified partner or partners has fueled hopes that Field's will be returned to local ownership. Miller declined to comment on the bidding but in an October interview with the Chicago Tribune, he pledged to fight for control of Field's. ``The worst scenario would be to have someone come in here and treat it like any old department store and have it become just another store,'' Miller said. ``This is clearly not what Chicago wants or deserves.'' In the interview, Miller said that under his leadership, Field's annual sales have gone from about $650 million to more than $1.1 billion and annual profit has doubled to an estimated $90 million in 1989 from $45 million in 1983. He has concentrated on restoring class to the chain whose early motto, ``Give the lady what she wants,'' promised customer satisfaction. Miller's likeliest opponent, St. Louis-based May, could fill a hole in its national coverage with Marshall Field. May owns 14 department-store chains, including Lord & Taylor and Hecht's.

The stock market lost ground today but bounced back from its lowest levels of the day in late-afternoon trading. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 12.16 at 2,610.36. It had been down 25 points with two hours to go. Declining issues outpaced gainers by a margin of about 9 to 5 among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange with 540 up, 963 down and 473 unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: GTE Records 20 Percent Fourth-Quarter Earnings Rise
DOC.TEXT: GTE Corp. said Tuesday its 1989 fourth-quarter earnings rose 20 percent because of strong performances by its telephone and telecommunications units. The company said net income was $392 million, or $1.15 per share, for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1989, compared with $326 million, or 96 cents a share, in the same 1988 period. Quarterly revenue increased 7 percent to $4.6 billion from $4.3 billion a year earlier. For the year, GTE posted earnings of $1.4 billion, or $4.16 per share, up from $1.2 billion, or $3.58 a share, in 1988. Revenue totaled $17.4 billion, up 6 percent from $16.5 billion the year before. GTE said revenue from telephone operations was up 7 percent because of higher foreign revenue, more telephone use and more access lines in service. It said the improvements were offset by various rate reductions and other charges costing $300 million last year. ``Telephone operations performed exceptionally well in 1989,'' James L. Johnson, GTE chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. He said a reorganization and consolidation announced in 1988 is proceeding on schedule. Revenue from telecommunications products and services increased 9 percent last year, with higher sales of cellular-mobile phone services, satellite services, government communications systems and directory advertising. GTE said its cellular-mobile phone unit grew to 263,000 customers in 1989 from 50,000 customers. Sales of electrical products fell 2 percent, which the company attributed to lower prices, the sale of some marginal businesses and weaker currencies overseas. It also said fourth-quarter operating income was off due to a restructuring.

Stock prices finished broadly lower today, although a late-afternoon rally trimmed the losses for the session. Trading activity was moderate, picking up the pace from Monday which was the slowest trading day of the new year. Stock prices had risen in three of the past four sessions after sinking for most of the month of January. Some analysts said today's decline was an indication that the market's broader trend is still lower. The prospect of rising interest rates has inhibited recent price gains, making yields on short-term Treasury securities more competitive with those available on stocks and dimming chances for corporate earnings growth. Those worries grew more pronounced as the Treasury's auction of $30 billion in new securities approached this week. In the credit markets today, rates edged up on six-month Treasury bills while yields on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to the 8.56 percent level from 8.53 percent late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Air Posts $362.8 Million Fourth-Quarter Loss
With AM-TWA-Icahn, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Texas Air Corp., the nation's largest airline company, said Tuesday it lost $362.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1989 as subsidiaries Eastern Airlines and Continental Airlines both posted losses. Texas Air's deficit was widened from a net loss of $224.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. The latest quarterly loss, amounting to $9.17 a share, pushed Texas Air's loss for all of 1989 to $22.71 a share, or $885.6 million _ a record high for the U.S. airline industry. That compares with its 1988 loss of $718.6 million, or $18.88 a share. Fourth-quarter revenue fell to $1.7 billion from $2 billion. For the full year, Texas Air's revenue was $6.7 billion, down from $8.6 billion in 1988. The October-December figures include a $56.1 million net loss for Houston-based Continental, narrowed from a $99.2 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1988. Continental's fourth-quarter revenue was $1.2 billion, up from $1.1 billion. For the year, Continental turned a $3.1 million profit, reversing a $315.5 million loss for 1988. Full-year revenue was $5.1 billion, up from $4.7 billion in 1988. ``We are pleased with Continental's strong improvement in profitability in 1989,'' Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo said in a statement. ``In addition, given the significantly negative factors affecting all airlines in the fourth quarter, Continental stands out as the only major carrier showing marked improvement in year-over-year fourth-quarter results.'' Continental's figures included one-time net gains of $81.2 million from asset sales and $10.6 million in retired debt. Miami-based Eastern, which is reorganizing under federal bankruptcy court supervision, showed a fourth-quarter net loss of $282.6 million on revenue of $482.2 million. In the fourth quarter of 1988, Eastern lost $101.7 million on revenue of $844.4 million. For all of 1989, Eastern lost $852.3 million on revenue of $1.5 billion, compared with a 1988 loss of $335.4 million on revenue of $3.8 billion. ``Eastern's unique situation in 1989 obviously had a major impact on Texas Air's consolidated results,'' Lorenzo said. ``But as Eastern finalizes its reorganization plans, we are confident that a far more competitive airline will emerge.'' Eastern was hit by a crippling strike last March, forcing it into Chapter 11 reorganization. The unions representing pilots and flight attendants called off their sympathy walkouts in November, but the Machinists union remains on strike. The airline has hired mainly non-union workers to replace the strikers and is restructuring as a smaller carrier. ``Eastern's unique situation in 1989 obviously had a major impact on Texas Air's consolidated results,'' Lorenzo said. ``But as Eastern finalizes its reorganization plans, we are confident that a far more competitive airline will emerge.'' Eastern management recently proposed to pay unsecured creditors only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and another 70 percent over the following 10 years, without interest. In return for accepting partial repayment, Texas Air would give the unsecured creditors 40 percent of Eastern's equity. In addition, preferred shareholders would receive no more than 10 cents on the dollar in the form of new stock. A committee representing preferred shareholders attacked the plan. Eastern's fourth-quarter losses included a special charge of $153.7 million in back pay to some pilots, pension curtailment costs and legal expenses for the bankruptcy case.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Halts Distribution of Newsletter That Featured Ethnic Slurs
DOC.TEXT: First Union National Bank on Tuesday stopped distributing copies of a newsletter that referred to Germans as ``Huns'' and Japanese as ``Nips'' in an article satirizing fears of foreign investment. The bank also issued apologies about the article appearing in the Feb. 1 edition of the newsletter, which the bank said already had been mailed to some 600 of its customers, after it received media calls asking about the piece. William R. Hackney III, First Union's chief investment officer and the author of the article, referred questions to the bank's public relations staff. ``He was trying to satirize American economic weaknesses and he deeply regrets his choice of words,'' said First Union spokesman Jeep Bryant. In response to a request for a copy of the newsletter, Bryant said the bank was ``embarrassed by its content ... so we've stopped distributing it.'' The article, titled ``Racial Overtones'' refers twice to Germans as ``Huns'' and three times to the Japanese as ``Nips'' in what it characterizes as a ``tongue-in-cheek'' assault on foreign investment in the United States. The article begins: ``The Huns and the Nips are at it again! Fouling up our capital markets. The folks from the lands of Teuton and Nippon jacked up their interest rates sharply in recent months, dragging our rates along with them. ``(They) yanked the rug out from under our stock and bond markets. That's the thanks we get for protecting them from the Russians all these years.'' Hackney told The News and Observer of Raleigh on Monday that he intended to poke fun at U.S. fears of foreign investment in an obvious tongue-in-cheek style. ``Those terms, while they are slang, are like calling folks in the United States `Yanks','' he said. Charlotte-based First Union _ one of the largest banks in the Southeast _ issued an apology Monday in response to inquiries from the newspaper, and Bryant reiterated the apology Tuesday. ``It was not our intention to speak in a derogatory way about the German and Japanese people,'' he said. However, German and Japanese government representatives took exception to the article. Hans-Jochen Schmidt of the Consultate General of the Federal Republic of Germany said the term ``Hun'' suggested ``uncivilized barbarians.'' ``We wouldn't appreciate being called that,'' he said in a phone interview from Atlanta. Schmidt also disagreed with Hackney's characterization of the ethnic terms as slang. ``It's far more negative,'' he said. ``I can't imagine a bank would condone such a characterization. Banks like First Union are trying to reach out to the entire world.'' The Japanese Consultate General, which oversees cultural and business trade in the Southeast, issued a statement from its Atlanta office saying: ``While we find the choice of words used in the First Union newsletter very unfortunate, we trust and hope it is not representative of the attitude of this region. Bryant said the bank had received only a handful of phone calls about the newsletter _ mostly from the news media.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak Reports Only Third Quarterly Loss in its History
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. on Tuesday announced a loss of $60 million for the final quarter of 1989, due mainly to the costs of a restructuring the photographic company began earlier in the year. The loss marked only the third time in Kodak's history that it has reported red ink. Company officials and industry analysts cautiously predicted improved earnings in 1990 as Kodak begins to realize savings from the restructuring. The loss, which amounted to 19 cents per share, compared with earnings of $312 million, or 96 cents per share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. Sales for the fourth quarter totaled $4.89 billion, up 8 percent from $4.54 billion in the 1988 period. Fourth-quarter earnings were reduced by restructuring charges of $322 million, or $525 million before taxes, bringing total charges for 1989 to $549 million, or $875 million before taxes. As part of the restructuring, Kodak sold or consolidated about 20 businesses and eliminated 7,500 jobs during 1989 in United States and abroad, most through voluntary separation, attrition and transfers to other businesses. Kodak's earnings for all of 1989 declined 62 percent to $529 million, or $1.63 per share, compared with $1.40 billion, or $4.31 per share, in 1988. Sales for the year totaled $18.4 billion, up 8 percent from $17.93 billion in 1988. ``Clearly, 1989 was a difficult year for Kodak, with significant expenses related to our restructuring efforts as the most visible sign,'' Kodak Chairman Colby H. Chandler said in a statement. ``Earnings were further restrained by the impact of general inflation on operating costs, higher interest expense and the unfavorable impact of exchange-rate fluctuations,'' he said. All segments of the company reported increases in quarterly and annual sales. But information systems earnings dropped for both the quarter and the year even without the restructuring costs, and quarterly earnings from chemical sales also sagged. Quarterly earnings in the health segment, which includes Sterling Drug Inc., increased 15 percent without restructuring costs, but dropped 9 percent for the year. Without the restructuring costs, total Kodak quarterly earnings would have been $262 million, or 80 cents per share, down 16 percent from last year, while annual earnings for the year would have declined 23 percent to $1.08 billion, or $3.32 per share. Mark Obenzinger, an industry analyst with Trinity Trading Co. of New York, said Kodak expects to save $450 million to $500 million from the restructuring last year. Those savings should start to appear in mid-1990, he said, but the company will continue to face competitive and financial pressures. ``They'll have to do even better than that in 1990 and set up a momentum that continues into 1991,'' Obenzinger said. Analyst Brenda Landry of Morgan Stanley said she thought Kodak would only manage to save about $350 million. Landry said she was revising her estimate for Kodak's 1990 earnings downward from $4.20 per share to around $3.70 or $3.75. Health care profits will be lower than anticipated and ``the chemical business we know will be falling apart,'' she said. Chandler said he expects things to improve for Kodak in 1990. ``We look forward to higher sales, better earnings from operations, and improved cash flows, especially in later quarters when the benefits of initiatives put into place are more fully realized,'' he said. But Chandler warned that ``uncertainties in the U.S. economy, the down cycle in the chemical industry, and a softening in the domestic market for office equipment ... could restrain somewhat the gains which might otherwise have been achieved.'' The company has had a troubled decade, laying off thousands of workers in 1983, 1986 and 1989 in efforts to turn around sagging profits. The two previous losses recorded by Kodak also resulted from special charges _ in 1985 when the company gave up its instant photography business and in 1986 when more than 10,000 workers were laid off in an earlier restructuring.

DOC.HEAD: Hallmark to Buy Back Debt of Spanish TV Network
DOC.TEXT: Hallmark Cards Inc. on Tuesday began an offer to buy back at a discount some $270 million in debt securities used to finance Univision Holdings Inc., under a plan to ease the debt burden on the unprofitable Spanish-language broadcaster. The action by Hallmark, which owns a 63.5 percent stake in Univision, followed Univision's failure to make $10 million in interest payments due last week on some of the debt. Univision, the nation's largest Spanish-language communications company, said it missed the payments because of insufficient cash flow. Hallmark issued a statement saying it also was seeking concessions on some $315 million in bank loans, including a revised repayment schedule and increased availability of money. Hallmark, which is privately held, declined to comment further about the offer and referred all questions to Thomas M. Daly Jr. of Kekst and Co., a New York public relations firm. Daly would not say why Hallmark was making the offer. Univision owns eight full-power Spanish-language television stations and the Spanish-language network Univision, which has more than 500 affiliates. The company reported a net loss of $31.6 million for the year ended Dec. 31, 1988, the latest annual figures available. It had 1988 revenue of $132 million. Hallmark and a unit of the banking concern First Chicago Corp. began their interest in the Spanish-language communications network by acquiring five Spanish-language stations in 1987. First Chicago now owns 21.5 percent of Univision, while Hallmark owns a 63.5 percent stake. The rest, 15 percent, is owned by trusts of descendants of Univision's former owners. Hallmark said it planned to buy back two series of Univision debt securities, offering 30 cents on the dollar for one issue with a face value of $105 million and 45 cents on the dollar for a second issue with a face value of $165 million. The original proceeds of those securities, issued in July 1988, were used to repay two loans supplied by Hallmark for Univision acquisitions. Hallmark also said that if the debt restructuring was completed, it would defer for five years the interest payments due on both debt securities. Hallmark also is seeking unspecified concessions from First Chicago. The Wall Street Journal quoted people it said were close to the debt negotiations as saying that First Chicago's stake in Univision would be reduced in return for improved prospects that it would recoup its investment. Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corp., two New York rating services, lowered their credit ratings on both Univision debt securities last Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON BC
Dollar Mixed, Gold Off
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed against other major currencies Tuesday as buyers were preoccupied with the West German mark. Gold prices fell in domestic and overseas trading. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $421.30 a troy ounce, $1.10 lower than Monday's close. Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $420.70 as of 4 p.m. EST, down $2.05 from Monday's late bid. Currency dealers described dollar trading as uneventful because the mark has been the center of attention. The mark has been buoyed by developments in Eastern Europe that are expected to benefit West Germany economically. ``It's more of a mark-driven market right now rather than a dollar-driven market,'' said Thomas Palladino, a dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank's New York office. ``The sentiment still seems to be in favor of selling the dollar but more so of buying the mark.'' Traders also were awaiting the outcome of the Communist Party meeting in Moscow, which was unexpectedly lenghthened and will enter a third day Wednesday. News that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had called on the party to relinquish its monopoly on power spurred purchases of marks because it was taken as a sign that the pace of reform in the East bloc may quicken. The dollar ended the day in New York at 1.65605 West German marks, down from 1.6590 marks Monday. That was below the closing level in Europe of 1.6570 marks, which was down from 1.6670 in Europe late Monday. Dealers said confidence in the dollar was shaken by uncertainty ahead of the Treasury Department's quarterly financing operation this week. There has been speculation that Japanese investors might not be big buyers of the $30 billion of notes and bonds being sold in three auctions. In Tokyo, where the trading day begins, the dollar fell 0.70 yen to close at 144.90 yen. Later, it was quoted at 145.10 yen in London and at 145.245 yen in New York, up from 144.70 yen Monday. Dealers expect the dollar to remain firm against the yen before Japanese national elections Feb. 18. The British pound rose to $1.7015 from $1.6980 late Monday and to $1.7030 from $1.7000 in New York. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.4763 Swiss francs, up from 1.47275; 5.64 French francs, up from 5.6370; 1,233.50 Italian lire, up from 1,231.00; and 1.18755 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18735. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late levels Monday were: 1.4770 Swiss francs, down from 1.4780; 5.6405 French francs, down from 5.6573; 1,235.00 Italian lire, down from 1,236.00; and 1.1874 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1891. Gold and silver prices posted modest declines on world markets. Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $420.85 a troy ounce, down from $432.25 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold closed at $420.75, down from $423 bid late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.61 to close at a bid $419.47. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.306 a troy ounce, down from Monday's settlement of $5.329. Silver bullion traded at a late bid price of $5.31 a troy ounce Tuesday, down from $5.37 bid late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall Broadly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market slumped in sluggish trading Tuesday, weighed down by worries that this week's government borrowing binge will drive interest rates higher. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had risen 19.82 points on Monday, lost 16.21 points to close at 2,606.31. The market's best-known indicator had been down 25 points with about two hours left in the session. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 578 up, 909 down and 499 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 134.07 million shares, only slightly ahead of the 130.95 million shares traded on Monday in the slowest session to date in the new year. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 163.44 million shares. Stocks had made some gains in the four sessions leading up to Tuesday's trading after sinking for most of the month of January. But even as prices rose, the prospect of rising interest rates limited the advance, making yields on short-term Treasury securities more competitive with those available on stocks and dimming chances for corporate earnings growth. ``The market is back to its dominant short-term trend which is down,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, director of technical market analysis at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. Jack Baker, head of block trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said he sees no evidence that ``institutions feel any need to commit new capital to equities. They are happy to be where they are with equities.'' The financial community has been especially alert to the impact on interest rates of this week's $30 billion auction of new Treasury securities. That three-part auction got underway on Tuesday with the sale of $10 billion in three-year notes at an average yield of 8.43 percent, and some credit market analysts termed the sale a success. But two more auctions will follow in short order, with $10 billion in 10-year notes going on sale Wednesday and $10 billion in 30-year bonds on Thursday. In the credit markets Tuesday, 30-year Treasury bond prices lost as much as $5 for every $1,000 in face value and their yields rose to 8.58 percent from 8.53 percent late Monday. Pan Am led the list of most actively-traded stocks on the NYSE, falling [ to 3|. The Pam Am board met Tuesday but made no announcement. A union official said Sunday that Pan Am was considering a deal with the parent of Northwest Airlines. Also on the active list, IBM rose 1] to 101, Bank of New England rose 1 to 6}, Philip Morris lost | to 38\ and General Electric rose \ to 62. American Telephone & Telegraph fell { to 39{. Several of the former Bell System regional companies also fell. Southwestern Bell fell 1{ to 53|, U S West lost 1\ to 70[, Bell South fell | to 52} and Nynex lost | to 80}. Eastman Kodak tumbled 1{ to 37~. It reported a fourth-quarter loss of 19 cents a share compared with net income of 96 cents a share a year ago. It cited costs of a restructuring program begun earlier in the year. Precious metals stocks, which rose on Monday, reversed course. ASA lost 1\ to 71], Homestake Mining fell { to 23 and Newmont Gold fell ] to 56[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market fell $15.18 billion, or 0.47 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.02 to 182.33. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.20 to 380.09, and S&P's 500-stock composite index dropped 2.17 to 329.68. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 0.74 to 423.99. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 354.74, up 0.04.

DOC.HEAD: Profit-Taking Ends 3-Day Gold Rally
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices slipped Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid profit taking, ending a three-day rally that peaked when the contract for April delivery failed to find support above $430 an ounce. Silver futures also turned lower. On other commodity markets, oil futures were mostly lower; orange juice futures rebounded; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mostly lower. Gold futures settled $1.10 to $1.50 lower with the contract for delivery in February at $421.30 a troy ounce; silver finished 2.3 cents to 2.4 cents lower with March at $5.33 a troy ounce. Gold for February delivery had surged a total of $10 an ounce in the three previous sessions, mainly on supportive chart signals that defied the anti-inflationary rise in interest rates, a bearish fundamental factor. Analysts also noted that gold's strength had not been confirmed by similarly sharp increases in silver and platinum prices. The gold rally passed a milestone Monday when the heavily traded contract for April delivery moved above $430 an ounce, but confidence in the market then waned. Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with the investment firm PaineWebber Inc., said gold historically has performed poorly in February, which might account for traders' reluctance to keep betting on higher prices. ``If history serves as a guide, I would be on my guard here,'' he said. But another analyst, Peter Cardillo of Josephthal & Co., said uncertainty surrounding stock prices and the political upheaval in Eastern Europe could keep investors interested in gold. ``The market's looking at several things, so I don't think you can just look at the traditional history'' such as the February effect, he said. Petroleum futures turned in a mixed performance on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory report, which showed higher-than-expected supplies across the board. The API reported a 7.7-million-barrel increase in U.S. stocks of crude oil, a 4.7-million-barrel rise in gasoline stocks and a 4.5-million-barrel increase in supplies of petroleum distillates, which include home heating oil. Analysts said the report could prompt selling of futures across the board on Wednesday. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents lower to 12 cents higher with March at $22.51 a barrel; heating oil was .15 cent lower to .24 cent higher with March at 56.19 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.08 cents lower to 1.2 cents higher with March at 61.88 cents a gallon. Orange juice futures rose sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange, reclaiming most of the ground lost Monday in a technically inspired sell-off. Frozen concentrated orange juice settled 2.05 cents to 5 cents higher with May at $1.928 a pound. Soybean futures rose modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade amid bullish technical signals and signs of stronger foreign demand. Corn futures also advanced while wheat futures retreated. Wheat futures settled } cent to 3 cents lower with March at $3.82} a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2{ cents higher with March at $2.37} a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent higher with March at $1.35{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 4{ cents higher with March at $5.62} a bushel. Profit-taking kept most cattle futures under pressure on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures retreated in line with weakening cash markets. Live cattle futures settled .20 cent lower to .25 cent higher with February at 79.35 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .50 cent lower to .10 cent higher with March at 82.67 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .40 cent lower with February at 48.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .45 cent lower with February at 50.50 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices finished mixed in choppy trading Tuesday as the market awaited the latest inventory statistics from the American Petroleum Institute. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 12 cents to end at $22.51 a barrel. The contract traded in a 42-cent range during the session after falling 63 cents on Monday. Crude contracts for later delivery were fairly narrowly mixed. Among refined products traded on the exchange, the March contract for regular unleaded gasoline fell 0.52 cent to 61.88 cents a gallon, after a 1.82-cents loss on Monday. The contract had traded as high as 62.80 cents during the session. The April contract lost 1.08 cents to 62.62 cents a gallon and May was down 0.72 to 65.67 cents. No. 2 heating oil for March delivery, which tumbled 2.31 cents in the previous session, edged up 0.24 cent to 56.19 cents a gallon. Later contract months were down slightly. Analysts said prices fluctuated in a relatively wide range throughout the session, with crude oil breaking through the $22.37 technical level on the downside. The market later turned higher but stalled as investors turned cautious ahead of the weekly inventory report by the API, a trade association representing mainly large oil refiners. ``People are waiting for the statistics tonight to get a clearer picture of things,'' said Tom Bentz, director of futures trading at United Energy Inc. Analysts said the market generally anticipated an increase in product supplies but was mixed with regard to crude oil inventories. The report, released after the close of trading Tuesday, actually showed sharp increases in both crude oil and refined products. For the week ended Feb. 2, crude oil inventories rose 7.7 million barrels to 351.1 million; heating oil stocks rose 4.5 million barrels to 121 million barrels; and gasoline stocks rose 4.7 million barrels to 231.4 million barrels.

DOC.HEAD: Emerson First Qtr. Earnings Rise
DOC.TEXT: Emerson Electric Co., the world's leading maker of electric motors, said Tuesday first-quarter profits rose 3.8 percent while sales declined. It was the company's 129th straight quarter, dating back to 1957, in which profits have increased. For the three-month period ended Dec. 31, Emerson earned $141.9 million, or 64 cents a share, compared with $136.8 million, or 61 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue totaled $1.6 billion, down 4.3 percent from $1.7 billion. The company attributed the sales decline to the divestiture of several companies in the last half of the year including Day-Brite, an industrial lighting company, and five small electronics firms. The divestiture reduced sales in the quarter by $90 million. ``Our financial position remains strong,'' said Charles Knight, Emerson's chairman and chief executive officer. He noted that the company remained one of the few U.S.-based manufacturing firms with a triple-A credit rating. The rating was reaffirmed recently after Emerson spent $460 million to acquire Leroy Somer, a French electric motor maker, and $135 million for McGill Manufacturing, a maker of bearings and industrial electrical products. Knight said the company's capital goods divisions, which make industrial monitoring equipment and machines and components for assembly lines and other uses, had the best showing in the quarter. Sales were slow in computer support products, consumer tools and appliance components, he said. Emerson is the leading maker of garbage disposals, refrigerator compressors and uninterruptible power supplies for computers. It also makes Craftsman tools for Sears Roebuck & Co. ``Our capital goods related businesses have record level backlogs and expect good sales performances in the second quarter,'' Knight said in a news release. The results for the St. Louis-based company, which turns 100 years old this year, kick off what company officials hope will be Emerson's 33rd straight year of record profits.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Sues Louisiana Holding Company
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Security National Bancorp Inc. on Tuesday of filing false and misleading statements in the Louisiana holding company's annual report and other documents. A civil complaint filed at federal court in the District of Columbia accused the Shreveport, La.-based concern and its president and chairman, Wesley Godfrey Jr., of failing to disclose, among other things, that the company's primary asset, Security National Bank, had been declared insolvent. The SEC complaint alleged that an independent auditor's report prepared for inclusion in the company's 1988 annual report to the SEC was substantially altered and some parts were omitted entirely. ``Basically, it was a cut-and-paste job on the auditors' opinion on the annual report,'' said Bruce Hiler, an SEC attorney in Washington. There was no answer at Security National Bancorp on Tuesday evening and it could not otherwise be reached for comment. The SEC complaint further alleged that the company's 1988 filing failed to disclose that the independent auditors had resigned three weeks before the annual report was filed; failed to disclose in a timely manner that Godfrey obtained control of the company in Decemeber 1988; and failed to disclose that the Comptroller of the Currency declared the company's sole subsidiary and primary asset, Security National Bank of Shreveport, insolvent and put it under the control of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Hiler said the company's shares were not traded on any exchange or the National Association of Security Dealers quotation system for over-the-counter stocks. The lawsuit seeks a court order barring the company and Godfrey from any further alleged violations of securities law and requiring compliance with SEC disclosure rules. Hiler said that to his knowledge, no criminal charges have been filed.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Profit for 4th-Qtr, Year
DOC.TEXT: Polaroid Corp. on Tuesday reported it earned $46.5 million in the fourth quarter and $145 million for the year in contrast to losses for both periods in 1988 when the company fought off a takeover bid. For the fourth quarter, the photography company posted earnings per share of 72 cents in contrast to a loss of $7.5 million, or 10 cents per share, in 1988. Fourth-quarter sales rose to $538.1 million from $533.2 million in 1988. For the year ended Dec. 31, Polaroid had earnings of $145 million, or $1.96 a share, in contrast to a loss of $22.6 million, or 34 cents a share, in 1988. Annual sales rose to $1.9 billion from $1.86 billion the previous year. The losses stemmed from a restructuring plan the company undertook while thwarting a takeover attempt by Shamrock Holdings, which cost the company $151.9 million in 1988. ``Our results attest to the significant progress and fundamental changes made at Polaroid in 1989, all building and delivering value to our shareholders,'' I. MacAllister Booth, the company president, said. ``This past year, we increased productivity, controlled our overhead and developed new marketing perspectives for growth in the 1990s,'' he said. The company, known for its instant photography, has ``established a foothold for conventional film worldwide,'' Booth said. Also, he said, Polaroid this year will begin testing its electronic imaging system for the medical field. Booth added, however, ``we recognize we have much more to do, particularly in stimulating sales growth. To this end, we already have in place new marketing programs and new advertising approaches.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Plans to Cancel Two Financial Publications
DOC.TEXT: Media General Inc. said its financial services division would shut its two main publications at the end of the month and switch to providing data through electronic information systems. Media General Financial Services, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Richmond-based Media General, plans to shut The Financial Weekly and IndustriScope. The Financial Weekly contains statistical information and news reports about company stocks, while IndustriScope is a monthly tabloid containing investment analyses of various industries. The combined circulation of the publications is about 3,000. The decision, announced Monday, could affect up to five jobs, but Media General said it would try to place those employees elsewhere. ``Although visonary and unique when they were introduced in the early 1970s, such weekly or monthly publications have been rendered essentially obsolete by the overwhelming use of computers in the financial community,'' said Dennis H. Cartwright, president and chief executive officer of Media General Financial Services. ``Users of our financial data bases increasingly demand services that can only be provided electronically.'' Cartwright said the division has expanded its ability to provide financial data services electronically and is about to complete a three-year program to convert all data base management systems to new computers. Among Media General's other holdings are The Richmond News Leader and the Richmond Times-Dispatch.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Will Make Next's Software Available on Several Desktops
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. will make software developed by Next Inc. available on several of its desktop computers and workstations scheduled for introduction Feb. 15, the company said Monday. In an announcement that had been expected for some time, IBM said it plans to make Next's screen display software available on several of its PS@2 computers. The software, called NextStep, provides a graphic screen display that simplifies the Unix operating system. Unix has been gaining acceptance as an operating system for business computers lately because of programs like NextStep, which make it easier to use. Next, the Redwood City-based computer firm founded by Steve Jobs, hopes the IBM endorsement will provide additional credibility among corporate computer buyers. But IBM also will offer a competing screen display program called Motif, which is being developed by an alliance of firms including IBM, Hewlett-Packard Co. and Digital Equipment Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Once Again, Georgia-Pacific Extends Buyout Offer
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp., still battling to acquire Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., on Tuesday extended its $3.8 billion tender offer another two weeks. The $63-a-share bid for the Norwalk, Conn.-based paper products company now will expire at 5 p.m. EST Feb. 21. The previous extension of the offer, first made Oct. 31, expired at 5 p.m. Monday. Great Northern, which contends the offer violates antitrust laws, is fighting the bid in courts in Connecticut. A special meeting of Great Northern shareholders to consider the Atlanta company's buyout offer is scheduled March 2.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Strengthens, Stock Prices Edge Down in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen early Wednesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange edged lower. The dollar started trading at 145.18 yen, up 0.28 yen from Tuesday's close of 144.90 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 35.42 points Tuesday, shed 13.73 points shortly after the market opened to move to 37,653.10. Currency dealers said the dollar remained in a narrow range during early trading because the market was focused on cross-trading between the yen and the West German mark. ``As for dollar-yen trading, many market players are taking a wait-and-see position,'' said a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo who spoke anonymously. The dealer said the less active trading for the dollar was partly due to the one-day extension of the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee meeting, originally set to end Tuesday. At the meeting, Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev announced a dramatic proposal to terminate the Communist Party's monopoly on power. Some dealers said the mark was being bought on speculation that Gorbachev had gained support for his reform plan.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Captain Looked And Acted Sober Before Oil Spill, Pilot Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with radio officer's testimony, EDIT to conform; picks up 11th graf, `In a brief ...' Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: When Coast Guard officers boarded the oil-spewing Exxon Valdez and asked skipper Joseph Hazelwood to explain the problem, he replied: ``You're looking at it,'' the ship's radio officer testified Tuesday. James Roberson was asked by defense attorney Michael Chalos to interpret Hazelwood's remark. Chalos suggested Hazelwood was referring to the overall situation on the crippled tanker. But Roberson disagreed. ``I took it to mean that he meant himself,'' said the witness in Hazelwood's trial in the nation's worst oil spill. Minutes later, Roberson said, a U.S. Coast Guard commander came to his radio office to use a phone. ``I overheard the commander saying, `I smelled alcohol on his breath. I want a technician out here,''' Roberson recalled. Blood tests on Hazelwood taken 10{ hours after the tanker ran aground showed a blood-alcohol ratio of .061, lower than Alaska's limit for a driver to be considered legally intoxicated but above the federal limit for operating a commercial vessel. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone suggested out of the jury's presence that attorneys were failing to address a critical issue: whether there was liquor aboard the Exxon Valdez that night. If no liquor was found, he said, it would mean that Hazelwood's blood-alcohol level might have been much higher earlier in the evening. Roberson, however, was the third crewman to attest that Hazelwood was sober and clearly in control of the ship, and showed no signs of drunkeness. ``I would describe him as serious, calm,'' said Roberson who had seen Hazelwood drinking at a Valdez bar earlier in the day. Roberson was preceded on the stand by a marine pilot who testified that there was a telltale trace of liquor on Hazelwood's breath, but said the captain's judgment seemed unimpaired an hour before the tanker hit Bligh Reef and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in Prince William Sound. The two crew members' testimony challenged the prosecution's theory that Hazelwood had been drinking all day and was not in control when the tanker foundered on Bligh Reef. Under cross-examination by Hazelwood's attorney, pilot William E. Murphy told jurors he saw none of the usual signs of intoxication in the captain when Murphy left the ship shortly before it ran aground. ``Did you see anything that indicated the captain was impaired in any way?'' asked defense attorney Michael Chelos. ``Not at all,'' Murphy replied firmly. Murphy said Hazelwood's speech was not slurred. He also answered negatively when asked if Hazelwood's movements changed, if his eyes were watery and if he had a mood change from that afternoon when the men had a non-alcoholic lunch together. ``He seemed the same to me,'' Murphy said. He added that he observed Hazelwood giving orders to his crew which seemed clear, and seemed in command of his ship. When questioned Monday, Murphy said he smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath hours before the Exxon Valdez ran aground. Earlier in the day, Johnstone refused to let jurors hear about a grounding incident a couple months later involving Murphy. In a brief hearing outside the jury's presence, Murphy said the boat, which carried 13 schoolchildren, ended its journey safely because ``I drove it up on the beach.'' Murphy acknowledged that even the best mariners occasionally run aground. But Johnstone refused to let jurors hear that, saying: ``The fact that other mariners may have grounded vessels is not probative in this case.'' He also declined to let jurors consider the impact of the accident on Murphy's testimony. On Monday, Murphy recalled joining Hazelwood and two other crew members for lunch in Valdez, where their tanker had picked up its cargo of oil last March. After lunch, he said, he dropped off the captain across the street from a bar called the Pipeline Club, and when he next saw Hazelwood aboard the Exxon Valdez about eight hours later, there was the smell of alcohol about him. ``While on the bridge did you notice any signs that he had been drinking?'' Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole asked. ``No,'' replied Murphy. ``Except I smelled something I associated with alcohol on his breath.'' Within 30 minutes, he said, Hazelwood had gone below and remained there about an hour while Murphy checked the weather facing the ship in its tricky passage through the Valdez Narrows. ``It's not unusual for masters to leave the bridge,'' said Murphy, but added, ``It wasn't typical to be gone for that long in the narrows.'' Cole had maintained in his opening statement that Hazelwood was drunk and absent from his post when the tanker crashed onto the reef, and said Hazelwood spent the seven hours before the trip in a bar ordering vodka. Hazelwood is on trial on a felony charge of second-degree mischief, and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. To prove criminal mischief the state must show that Hazelwood recklessly created a risk of damage to the property of another in excess of $100,000. Under rules at the time of the Exxon Valdez accident, pilots were required to guide outbound ships to a point just short of Bligh Reef. The rules have been changed to require pilots, local boat handlers familiar with coastal waters, to remain aboard past Bligh Reef.
